headline: AT&T Agrees to Acquire USinternetworking to Expand Services
abstract: AT&T said Tuesday it has agreed to acquire USinternetworking, a privately held provider of specialized software for business customers, for about $300 million in cash and assumed debt.

headline: Open Text Casts Net for Hummingbird
abstract: Open Text has opened a bidding war for rival business software provider and fellow Canadian firm Hummingbird, presenting an offer worth about $536 million.

headline: In Battle for Scania, Volkswagon Tells MAN to Give It Up
abstract: Shares of Scania, Sweden’s second-largest truckmaker, fell the most in 6-1/2 years after Volkswagen, Scania’s largest shareholder, said its fellow German company, MAN, should abandon a hostile takeover bid and consider other options.

headline: Judge Reviews Two Major Telecom Mergers
abstract: U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan asked for full, unredacted versions of Federal Communications Commission orders that approved the mega-mergers of SBC Communications with AT&T and Verizon Communications with MCI last fall.

headline: Belk Carts Off Saks’s Parisian Store Chain
abstract: Saks said Wednesday it will sell its Parisian department store chain to Belk for $285 million in cash, leaving the high-end retailer with its namesake luxury business.

headline: In Contested Merger, Two French Utilities Offer Concessions
abstract: Suez and Gaz de France proferred a raft of proposals to the European Commission to win approval for their planned merger, including spinning off parts of their Belgian gas business.

headline: Troubled Mills Sells 3 Malls to Canadian Property Group
abstract: Mall developer Mills yesterday announced plans to sell its stakes in three foreign malls to a Canadian firm, as the struggling company tries to stay afloat.

headline: EMI Ends Talks With Warner Music
abstract: The EMI Group, the British music giant, has decided to call off, for now, its efforts to merge with a rival, the Warner Music Group.

headline: Troubled Brazilian Carrier Gets Greenlight for Auction
abstract: Brazil’s one-time flagship airline Viação Aérea Rio-Grandense, known as Varig, could get a new lease on life after a Brazilian bankruptcy judge set a new auction date for the ailing carrier.

headline: Reports Clash Over Potential NTL Buyout
abstract: Providence Equity, Blackstone, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Britain’s Cinven, are in talks to secure Britain’s largest cable company, NTL, in a record $20 billion deal, in what could be the biggest buyout in European history, according to BusinessWeek

headline: San Diego Accuses Law Firm of Negligence in Pension Inquiry
abstract: The city of San Diego in 2003 hired the law firm Vinson & Elkins to investigate problems with the city’s pension system. The firm failed to provide a “warts and all” assessment, the city now alleges in a lawsuit that seeks $10 million in damages.

headline: Merrill Lynch Will Acquire Turkey’s Tatbank
abstract: Merrill Lynch has agreed to buy Turkish bank Tat Yatirim Bankasi, including its brokerage unit Tat Menkul, the U.S.-based brokerage said on Thursday.

headline: ABN Amro Shares Rise on Takeover Talk
abstract: ABN Amro‘s American Depository Shares were 1.45 percent higher in late-morning trading Thursday amid speculation that the Dutch bank might be taken over by Bank of America.

headline: NGP Kicks Off Fundraising for Energy Fund
abstract: NGP Energy Capital Management kicked off a marketing campaign Thursday to raise a $1.5 billion private equity fund that will invest in energy infrastructure as well as the mining and minerals sector.

headline: Chief Operating Officer Leaves Sprint Nextel
abstract: Sprint Nextel said yesterday that its chief operating officer, Len J. Lauer, was leaving the company and that his responsibilities would be assumed by the chief executive, Gary D. Forsee.

headline: Merged Steel Concern Chooses Top Executives
abstract: The new Arcelor-Mittal steel group on Friday named a senior Arcelor manager, Roland Junck, to be its chief executive and Mittal Steel’s chief financial officer, Aditya Mittal, as the combined company’s C.F.O.

headline: For Chinese Underwriting, Morgan Stanley Wears the Crown
abstract: When Morgan Stanley‘s chief executive, John Mack, flew to Beijing on June 29, he met with the heads of China’s banking and securities regulatory commissions and with Zhou Xiaochuan, governor of the People’s Bank of China, the central bank. The visit was Mack’s third since he took over Morgan Stanley in June 2005.

headline: Levi’s Chief Executive to Retire at End of the Year
abstract: Philip A. Marineau, chief executive of Levi Strauss, will retire at the end of the year and John Anderson, president of the company’s Asia Pacific division, will be promoted to chief operating officer effective immediately, the company said yesterday.

headline: European Regulators Warn Spain and Germany Over Private Deal
abstract: The European Commission issued an unprecedented warning yesterday to Germany and Spain against reaching a private deal that would enable the German energy group E.ON to win its 27 billion euro takeover bid for a Spanish rival, Endesa, after months of political rows.

headline: Private Equity Pays a Call on the Valley Boys
abstract: There is a new siren song in Silicon Valley, and private equity is singing the tune. High-powered buyout firms are talking frustrated tech players into the idea of going private – and making billions.

headline: Are the 76ers on the Auction Block?
abstract: There are a couple of ways to establish yourself as a big-ticket baron. You can buy a newspaper, for example. Or you can own a major-league sports team. A number of individuals have tried the former lately; see McClatchy’s sale of the former Knight Ridder properties, aborted attempts at buying The Los Angeles Times and a successful bid for The New York Observer.

headline: Agents Arrest 3 in Plot to Sell Coca-Cola Secrets to PepsiCo
abstract: Federal agents have arrested and charged an employee of the Coca-Cola Company and two others with stealing trade secrets and wire fraud, saying they tried to sell “highly classified” information to that company’s competitor PepsiCo for $1.5 million.

headline: Lloyd’s Unit Cuts Offering
abstract: Heritage Underwriting, the specialist Lloyd’s of London insurer, has had to scale back plans to raise up to 50 million pounds ($92.5 million) when it lists on London’s Aim on August 1 and will now raise only 18 million pounds.

headline: Aviva Says AmerUs Is Not a Consolation Prize
abstract: Richard Harvey, Aviva‘s chief executive, claims that the 1.6 billion pound ($2.9 billion) takeover of AmerUs is not a substitute for failing to land Prudential earlier this year, the Telegraph said Monday.

headline: Online Dating Web Site Meets Its First Funding Rendezvous
abstract: Engage.com, an online dating Web site, raised $5 million in its first round of venture funding.

headline: Report Links Adviser to Charges of Client-List Theft
abstract: S3 Partners, a hedge fund advisory firm, is attracting some unwanted attention following last week’s arrest of a New York man on charges of pilfering confidential computer files about Morgan Stanley‘s clients, TheStreet.com wrote Wednesday.

headline: Tyco Buys Confluent Surgical
abstract: Tyco International on Tuesday announced its largest deal in more than four years, saying it would buy Confluent Surgical for $245 million in cash.

headline: Peltz Acquires 1.2 Percent Stake in Tribune
abstract: Is Nelson Peltz, the billionaire investor poised for a final proxy showdown with H.J. Heinz management, on the verge of taking up sword and shield, yet again?

headline: V.C.s Infuse Adam Aircraft With $93 Million
abstract: Jet manufacturer Adam Aircraft raised $93 million in its latest round of funding, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Buyout Firms Eye Netherlands’ TNT
abstract: Private-equity investors are the only bidders left in the race to buy the contract logistics business of Dutch mail group TNT. The business is estimated byanalysts to be worth 1.8 billion euro to 2.2 billion euro ($2.3 billion to $2.8 billion), The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

headline: Mass Exodus at Freshfields after a Rebuffed Merger, Report Says
abstract: Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, Britain’s second-biggest law firm, was hit by the departure of 30 partners yesterday, as it emerged that its senior partner had rebuffed a merger proposal from its smaller rival Allen & Overy.

headline: Why Barron’s Likes Lehman
abstract: Lehman Brothers “may be the best managed of the major securities firms,” declared Barron’s this week in its almost-totally-unabashedly-bullish cover article titled “Time to Buy.” Barron’s noted that Lehman shares have sold off along with those of other Wall Street firms, dropping to $60 from their April high of $78. The stock is priced at about nine times this year’s estimated profits — “a relatively low valuation,” according to Barron’s.

headline: Equity Office Plans Major Real Estate Sale
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest publicly traded office building owner in the United States, said on Thursday it plans to bring between $3 billion and $3.5 billion of its properties to market through 2007.

headline: Richard Li’s Dad Steps in to Acquire PCCW Assets
abstract: Li Ka-shing has put together a private bid for the core media and telecom assets of PCCW, the blue-chip fixed line and cellular services operator controlled by his son Richard Li, according reports.

headline: Bidding Heats Up for Australia’s Vision Systems
abstract: U.S. diagnostic test maker Cytyc launched a A$497 million ($374 million) bid for Australia’s Vision Systems, topping a rival offer by Ventana Medical Systems and driving up Vision’s shares.

headline: Time Warner’s Parsons Readies for Cable I.P.O.
abstract: Facing a frozen share price and another assault from Carl Icahn, Time Warner‘s chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, is readying to play one of his remaining cards: an initial public offering of part of the company’s cable unit.

headline: 2 Ex-Officers of Military Supplier Charged
abstract: Two former executives of DHB Industries, a maker of bulletproof vests for United States soldiers in Iraq, were arrested yesterday on federal securities fraud charges.

headline: Forced Viacom Stock Sales Should Stop, Analyst Says
abstract: In an open letter to the board of Viacom, a research analyst is calling for an end to a program that requires Sumner Redstone to whittle down his stake in the media conglomerate at regular intervals.

headline: Gabelli Will Pay $130 Million in F.C.C. Settlement
abstract: Mario Gabelli, one of Wall Street’s highest paid money managers, and affiliates agreed to pay $130 million to settle a civil-fraud lawsuit that alleged they used sham small-business affiliates to fraudulently buy parts of the U.S. cell-phone spectrum, the Department of Justice said Thursday.

headline: Parties and drugs
abstract: Formula One teams, media and many others met for a party at the exclusive Reina restaurant and bar on the edge of the Bosporus last night. The location is stunning, just below one of the bridges across the Bosporus, and the Reina itself is an interesting split-level with a stage set up for first class entertainment.

headline: Move to Try to Update Lease-Accounting Rules
abstract: Accounting rule makers agreed yesterday to try to develop a new rule on lease accounting to replace a 30-year-old standard that critics say has enabled companies to leave hundreds of billions in debt off their balance sheets.

headline: Solar Cell Maker Gets $22 Million in V.C. Investments
abstract: A solar photovoltaic company, Solaria, said Tuesday it had completed a second round of funding, collecting $22 million, and that it expects to bring solar concentrator products to market next year.

headline: Stranger Than Fiction: H.P.’s Dunn Receives Leadership Award
abstract: In a decidedly ironic turn of events, Hewlett-Packard‘s embattled chairman, Patricia Dunn, accepted a hall of fame leadership award at a gala dinner in San Francisco on Wednesday night, where she received a standing ovation from local executives.

headline: China Blue Looks Toward $400 Million Hong Kong Offering
abstract: China Blue Chemical, which starts pre-marketing today of its Hong Kong initial public offering, is banking on its modern production facilities and growth projections above the sector average to attract investors.

headline: Sun Valley Diary: Friday Photos
abstract: Attendees made their way, alone and in small groups, to the Allen & Company conference’s morning sessions on Friday. Michael Eisner and Barry Diller, pictured separately below, make up half of the four-person panel of media-industry power brokers scheduled for later that day; the others were Sony chief Howard Stringer and News Corporation chairman Rupert Murdoch. Mr. Eisner was down to play the role of interviewer.

headline: Japanese Retailer Is Window Shopping in the United States
abstract: The Fast Retailing Company, operator of the Uniqlo casual-wear chain of shops in Japan, said on Wednesday it plans to invest in a retailer in the United States in the next two to three years to expand its business in the country.

headline: Bârrx Medical Takes $27 Million in New Round
abstract: Esophageal treatment developer Bârrx Medical has completed a new $27.8 million third round of venture funding intended to support continued marketing of its medical device system.

headline: Brazil Says Mittal Must Bid for Arcelor Subsidiary
abstract: Brazil’s securities regulator upheld a decision requiring Mittal Steel to make an offer for the minority stakes in Arcelor Brasil as part of its $38.3 billion plan to join with Luxembourg’s Arcelor.

headline: WestLB Looks to Sell Stake in HSH Nordbank
abstract: WestLB, the German bank, is in advanced talks to sell its 27 percent stake in one of Germany’s biggest state-owned wholesale banks to private-sector investors.

headline: Judge in Grasso Pay Lawsuit Refuses to Remove Himself
abstract: A state judge on Thursday refused to remove himself from the civil action by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, to recover part of the compensation package of the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso.

headline: Legal Pressures Mount in H.P. Boardroom Scandal
abstract: The boardroom intrigue at Hewlett-Packard intensified Tuesday as the California attorney general, Bill Lockyer, said he had “enough information to indict people inside H.P. and outside” for snooping into confidential phone records.

headline: Merger Whispers, Suspicious Trades
abstract: The boom in corporate mergers is creating concern that illicit trading ahead of deal announcements is becoming a systemic problem.

headline: Corporations Could Face Lawsuits Over ‘Crackberries’
abstract: A management expert is warning corporations to gird themselves for a potentially costly wave of lawsuits from employees claiming they are addicted to “crackberries.”

headline: Acquicor to Acquire Jazz Semiconductor for $260 Million
abstract: Acquicor Technology said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Jazz Semiconductor for $260 million.

headline: Xstrata Nears Completion of Falconbridge Takeover
abstract: As the three-way battle for the copper miner Inco continues, Xstrata is poised to pocket the spoils of its battle for another Canadian mining company, Falconbridge.

headline: Blackstone Alliance to Buy Chip Maker for $17.6 Billion
abstract: In a rare buyout battle among the titans of private equity, the Blackstone Group has come away with a huge prize.

headline: Trade Volume Discrepancies Raise Questions of Misconduct
abstract: Discrepancies between what investment banks say they trade and what exchanges report has the NASD, the private industry regulator, wondering if the financial institutions are engaging in some serious misconduct.

headline: Ford Motor to Slash White-Collar Workforce, Report Says
abstract: Ford Motor, pressing ever harder to bring its auto business in line with harsh market realities, aims to slash its white-collar costs by nearly a third as part of a stepped up restructuring plan to be presented to its board on Wednesday, the Wall Street Journal.

headline: DCM Closes $500 Million Fund
abstract: DCM, a venture firm based in Menlo Park, Calif. and formerly called DCM-Doll Capital Management, has closed its fifth fund at $500 million.

headline: Rumors of Suitor for Condom Maker Said to Be Untrue
abstract: SSL International, the maker of Durex condoms, does not have a new partner, despite reports to the contrary, executives close to the company and its rumored buyer say.

headline: Out, or Not, in The City of London
abstract: Gay women working in the City of London’s financial services sector are three times more likely than male counterparts to keep quiet about their sexuality, according to a survey published on Tuesday.

headline: With Blu-Ray on Its Mind, Crystal IS Raises Fresh Cash
abstract: Crystal substrate developer Crystal IS has raised a $10.6 million Series A add-on round of funding to help the company tackle the growing demand for complex consumer electronics devices such as video game consoles.

headline: As Inco Bid Drags On, Teck Examines Its Options
abstract: Teck Cominco has started looking at alternatives in case its hostile takeover offer for Inco is unsuccessful, chief executive officer Don Lindsay said Tuesday.

headline: Rabobank Expanding In Indonesia
abstract: Netherlands-based Rabobank Group has signed an agreement to buy two Indonesian banks, Bank Haga and Bank Hagakita, from individual shareholders. However, it declined to say how much it would pay for the small banks.

headline: Adelphia Creditors Ask Bankruptcy Court to Liquidate Company
abstract: A group of Adelphia Communications creditors asked a judge to liquidate the company and its affiliates to speed payments to all creditors.

headline: Britain Hopes to Limit Changes at Exchange
abstract: Signaling the market’s increasing certitude that the Nasdaq will make another run at the London Stock Exchange, Britain’s treasury minister moved to assuage fears that the exchnage would be subject to stricter market regulations in place in the United States.

headline: Yukos Chief Resigns as Rivals Circle
abstract: Oil prices may be surging, but the prospects for Russia’s Yukos have never looked more grim. Yukos’ chief executive, Steven Theede, resigned on Thursday, saying he expects the company that was once Russia’s largest oil producer to be liquidated. His announcement came shortly before a meeting of Yukos’ creditors that Mr. Theede has labelled a “sham.” It also followed Yukos’ unsuccessful legal effort to stop Russia’s Rosneft, which took ownership of Yukos’ prized assets in a controversial transaction, from listing its new shares on the London Stock Exchange this week.

headline: Private Equity Firm Doughty Hanson Plans $1 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Doughty Hanson, a London-based buyout firm, plans to raise 1 billion euros ($1.27 billion) in an initial public offering of a private equity fund, following rivals Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Management.

headline: Will Foreign Firms Land Chicago’s Midway?
abstract: As Chicago prepares to sell its Midway airport, The Financial Times is taking note of the possibility — or, rather, the high probability — that firms outside the United States will be the strongest bidders in the precedent-setting auction. The privatization of Midway would be “by far the largest for a U.S. airport,” the newspaper notes. As such, it could inspire other cash-strapped cities to try similar moves.

headline: Silver Lake Connects With IPC in $800 Million Deal
abstract: Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire networking communications service company IPC Information Systems for $800 million in a secondary buyout from GS Capital Partners, the New York private equity arm of Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: AT&T Agrees to Acquire USinternetworking to Expand Services
abstract: AT&T said Tuesday it has agreed to acquire USinternetworking, a privately held provider of specialized software for business customers, for about $300 million in cash and assumed debt.

headline: Open Text Casts Net for Hummingbird
abstract: Open Text has opened a bidding war for rival business software provider and fellow Canadian firm Hummingbird, presenting an offer worth about $536 million.

headline: In Battle for Scania, Volkswagon Tells MAN to Give It Up
abstract: Shares of Scania, Sweden’s second-largest truckmaker, fell the most in 6-1/2 years after Volkswagen, Scania’s largest shareholder, said its fellow German company, MAN, should abandon a hostile takeover bid and consider other options.

headline: Judge Reviews Two Major Telecom Mergers
abstract: U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan asked for full, unredacted versions of Federal Communications Commission orders that approved the mega-mergers of SBC Communications with AT&T and Verizon Communications with MCI last fall.

headline: Belk Carts Off Saks’s Parisian Store Chain
abstract: Saks said Wednesday it will sell its Parisian department store chain to Belk for $285 million in cash, leaving the high-end retailer with its namesake luxury business.

headline: In Contested Merger, Two French Utilities Offer Concessions
abstract: Suez and Gaz de France proferred a raft of proposals to the European Commission to win approval for their planned merger, including spinning off parts of their Belgian gas business.

headline: Troubled Mills Sells 3 Malls to Canadian Property Group
abstract: Mall developer Mills yesterday announced plans to sell its stakes in three foreign malls to a Canadian firm, as the struggling company tries to stay afloat.

headline: EMI Ends Talks With Warner Music
abstract: The EMI Group, the British music giant, has decided to call off, for now, its efforts to merge with a rival, the Warner Music Group.

headline: Troubled Brazilian Carrier Gets Greenlight for Auction
abstract: Brazil’s one-time flagship airline Viação Aérea Rio-Grandense, known as Varig, could get a new lease on life after a Brazilian bankruptcy judge set a new auction date for the ailing carrier.

headline: Reports Clash Over Potential NTL Buyout
abstract: Providence Equity, Blackstone, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Britain’s Cinven, are in talks to secure Britain’s largest cable company, NTL, in a record $20 billion deal, in what could be the biggest buyout in European history, according to BusinessWeek

headline: Weekend Reading: Anti-Google Bloc As 19th Century Europe
abstract: Google, according to The Economist, is much like Napoleonic France. Google’s rivals – Yahoo, eBay, and Microsoft – are much like France’s enemies, Russia, Prussia and Austria. They should ally against their enemy to create a “balance of power.”

headline: Rivals May Challenge Vivendi-Bertelsmann Deal
abstract: The group that persuaded a European Union appeals court in July to annul the two- year-old merger that had created Sony BMG Music Entertainment, a joint venture formed by Bertelsmann and Sony, said Thursday that it would now go after Vivendi’s proposed $2.1 billion acquisition of Bertelsmann’s BMG Music Publishing.

headline: Rite Aid to Buy Drug Chains for $2.55 Billion
abstract: The drugstore chain Rite Aid agreed yesterday to acquire the Brooks and Eckerd drug chains for $2.55 billion in cash and stock, putting it within striking distance of its two largest rivals, Walgreen and CVS.

headline: Russian Banks Lure Talent With Bigger Bonuses
abstract: Western investment houses are finding it increasingly difficult to compete with Russian banks for leading investment bankers after a steady stream of senior dealmakers abandoned firms such as Dresdner and Merrill Lynch recently to work for Russian banks, lured by multimillion-dollar bonuses.

headline: If Heinz Wins Proxy Battle, Does It Really Matter?
abstract: H.J. Heinz is likely to fend off a proxy fight led by the billionaire Nelson Peltz at its annual meeting next month, but if history is any guide, the ketchup king may find itself with something of a Pyrrhic victory.

headline: In China, Will a Thousand Deals Bloom?
abstract: The value of Chinese mergers and acquisitions is still relatively small. But big things could be in store, according to Jim Hemerling, a Shanghai-based director for  Boston Consulting Group. Writing in BusinessWeek, he says that Chinese companies “have two things going for them that are necessary to move forward aggressively: encouragement from the government and plenty of available capital.”

headline: Dell Delays 3rd-Quarter Filing, Citing S.E.C. Inquiry
abstract: The computer maker Dell is delaying the filing of its latest quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said on Monday.

headline: Credit Suisse Goes Quietly into That Big Bank
abstract: An assessment of the performance of Credit Suisse‘s investment banking unit in the two years since Brady Dougan took the helm, particularly in light of the firm’s new “One Bank” strategy, leaves one marveling at the stark shift in culture. The former home of Frank Quattrone and John Mack now operates somewhat quietly within the scope of the Swiss parent’s unified front.

headline: Bank of China Managers Say They Were Set Up
abstract: Two former managers at Bank of China, jailed in Las Vegas on racketeering and money-laundering charges stemming from the alleged theft of $485 million, say they’re being framed to cover up corruption and incompetence at the state-owned lender.

headline: Apple Settles Patent Dispute With a Rival
abstract: Apple Computer said on Wednesday it will pay $100 million to rival Creative Technology to settle all patent litigation over Apple’s popular iPod music player.

headline: Cable Companies Still in the Wireless Game
abstract: While satellite heavies EchoStar and DirecTV dropped out of the government’s auction for wireless spectrum, the country’s major cable companies, in contrast, continue to be a force in the auction despite a partnership they forged last year with Sprint Nextel, the nation’s third-largest mobile phone company, that was widely expected to meet their wireless needs.

headline: Conflicts or Not, Merrill Plans More Private Equity Deals
abstract: In weighing the risks and rewards of putting its own capital on the line in the record-setting leveraged buyout of HCA, Merrill Lynch added investment banking and financing fees to the plus side of the calculus before jumping in.

headline: HealthSouth Considers Sale of Several Units
abstract: The HealthSouth Corporation said on Monday it would explore strategic options, including the spin-off, sale or other disposition of its surgery centers and outpatient rehabilitation divisions, in a move to focus on the post-acute care sector.

headline: Is NetBank on the Block?
abstract: With its stock down nearly 50 percent in the past year, NetBank may be looking for a buyer, an analyst suggested in a research note on Thursday. The comments, by Samuel Caldwell at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, were noted in Friday’s issue of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution.

headline: Gain Pulls Plug on Deal for Refco Unit
abstract: Bankrupt trading giant Refco has again scrapped a deal to sell its currency-trading business, leaving $103 million in customers’ cash frozen.

headline: Bertelsmann Closer to BMG Music Sale
abstract: Bertelsmann is getting closer to sealing a deal to sell its music publishing business, saying Thursday it expects to have a short list of potential suitors by month’s end.

headline: With Junk Bonds, Fat Fees Are Long Gone
abstract: The fees collected by sellers of junk bonds are at a record low, according to Bloomberg News, which compiled data showing that fees are just above one-quarter of the 4 percent charged during the 1980’s heyday of high-risk, high-reward debt. Still, as Bloomberg News notes, that is still more than double what investment banks charge for underwriting higher-grade bonds.

headline: Comcast and Time Warner Seal Adelphia Deal
abstract: Comcast and Time Warner, the two biggest U.S. cable-television operators, said yesterday that they had completed the $16.7 billion purchase of Adelphia Communications assets, adding systems in cities including Los Angeles and Miami.

headline: A real race…
abstract: The only weak part of the season’s new qualifying system is – as has often been pointed out – the first 12 minutes or so of the third and last 20-minute part when the final 10 cars go around in circles doing nothing at all but burn fuel.

headline: Judge Delivers a Dollop of Austerity to Lord Black’s Household
abstract: Two Fridays ago, Conrad Black celebrated his 62nd birthday with a small dinner at his grand house in Toronto, joined by family and friends. Before he could celebrate, however, he received news that there would be an uninvited chaperone: the courts.

headline: Value of Airbus Stake Down, BAE Has Less Money for Deals
abstract: BAE, Europe’s largest military contractor, came under severe pressure Monday to hold on to its 20 percent stake in Airbus after Rothschild valued it at a little more than half its expected worth.

headline: Three Beverage Giants Stake Their Claims on Tequila Maker
abstract: In what may turn out to be a bruising bar fight, French drinks group Pernod Ricard is one of three bidders for Tequila Herradura, a major Mexican tequila maker that could fetch up to $800 million in a sale, The Financial Times reported Monday.

headline: Yukos Says Western Banks Instrumental in its Demise
abstract: Though it says the Russian government hounded it to the point of death, Yukos accuses Western banks of delivering the coup de grace.

headline: Sears Fights Canadian Regulators Over Bid for Subsidiary
abstract: Sears Holdings argued on Monday that the Ontario Securities Commission should not have accused it of “abusive” treatment of shareholders of Sears Canada because its behavior breached no specific provisions of the Ontario Securities Act.

headline: Dunn Insists on Remaining H-P Chairwoman
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Chairwoman Patricia Dunn said Friday that several of her fellow board members want her to remain on the job despite a criminal investigation into her efforts to plug a media leak.

headline: PlayPhone Gets Real Cash from V.C.’s
abstract: PlayPhone said Monday it raised $9.1 million in second round financing. The San Jose, Calif.-based company, which provides direct-to-consumer mobile content distribution, said funding was led by Menlo Ventures.

headline: A Buyout Deal, Payable in Sofa-Cushion Change
abstract: So much talk these days focuses on the ever-larger sums that private equity investors are willing to pay for their takeover targets. So it was refreshing to hear about the deal MFI, Britain’s largest furniture retailer, struck for its 200-store retail arm with buyout shop Merchant Equity Partners.

headline: Ford Looks at Possibility of Alliances
abstract: The Ford Motor Company is evaluating the prospects for alliances with other automakers even as it moves ahead with its own revamping efforts, according to a report in The New York Times.

headline: In Two Bank Rankings, Goldman Shines
abstract: Goldman Sachs ranks first among investment banks in terms of “prestige,” according to a survey of bank employees by Vault.com. Vault, a career Web site that collects employees’ opinions on the companies they work for (or have worked for), said it surveyed more than 970 banking professionals, asking them to rate banking companies from 1 to 10, with 10 being “the most prestigious.”

headline: A Small I.P.O., But a Big Step for an Indonesian Firm
abstract: Indonesia’s leading construction company, Total Bangun Persada, has become the first Indonesian company this year to complete an initial public offering that was marketed to both international and domestic investors.

headline: Unsatisfactory Bids Prompt Pep Boys to Halt Auction
abstract: The auto-parts retailer and repair chain Pep Boys became the latest in a string of companies to take themselves off the auction block after failing to attract the right price from bidders.

headline: No Rush to Deregister Among Hedge Funds
abstract: Dozens of hedge funds have withdrawn their registrations with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the wake of a court decision that threw out a more-stringent oversight rule, Bloomberg News reported Friday. The figure is not exactly the mass exodus that some in the industry had anticipated, but it does suggest that the court’s ruling is having an effect.

headline: Software Start-Up Groxis Pulls $4 Million
abstract: Groxis said Monday it raised $4 million in its series B round of venture funding. The San Francisco company, founded in 2001, makes software used to search digital information.

headline: J.P. Morgan Botched Japanese Sell Order
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase said its Japanese brokerage unit mistakenly placed a sell order for a basket of securities linked to the Topix index instead of the Nikkei 225 Stock Average.

headline: Octagon Research Nabs Funding form Edison
abstract: Octagon Research Solutions, a provider of pharmaceutical research and development management technology, said it raised $10 million in third-round funding.Edison Venture Fund contributed a $2 million follow-on investment to the round. Edison, which led Octagon’s first round in 2002, has contributed $8.4 million to the company to date.

headline: Emdeon to Sell Stake in a Unit and Repurchase Shares
abstract: The Emdeon Corporation, which provides information, communications and plastic components used in the health-care industry, said on Tuesday that it plans to sell a stake in a unit and begin a tender offer to buy up to 100 million shares of its stock at $12.25 each.

headline: Instinet Backer Seeks Exit, One Way or Another
abstract: Hoping to seize the moment — or perhaps just impatient for a profit — Silver Lake Partners is already planning to cash out of its recent investment in Instinet‘s broker-dealer business. It expects to use one of two possible methods: a sale or an initial public offering.

headline: Record Companies Sue File-Sharing Software Distributor
abstract: A coalition of major recording companies sued the operators of the file-sharing program LimeWire on Friday, alleging that the company violates copyrights by encouraging users to trade music without permission.

headline: Germans Raise Bid for Spanish Utility
abstract: Despite winning new support from European regulators, the German power company E.On was forced on Tuesday to raise its offer for the Spanish utility Endesa, a deal seen as a crucial test for breaking down barriers to cross-border energy mergers in Europe.

headline: Defending the American I.P.O.
abstract: It has become almost a cliché by now: Selling shares on United States exchanges has become too hard for foreign companies, thanks to, among other things, the harsh legal environment and the complicated, onerous provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

headline: S.E.C. Investigating Amaranth
abstract: In the wake of its $6 billion meltdown, Amaranth Advisors is being scrutinized by regulators including the Securities and Exchange Commission. A top Securities and Exchange Commission official confirmed to Dow Jones that the agency is investigating Amaranth, and the inquiry is focused on whether the fund misled investors.

headline: Severstal Receives $177 Million Breakup Fee from Arcelor
abstract: Russian steelmaker Severstal confirmed on Friday that it was paid a 140 million euro ($177 million) breakup fee by Arcelor following the latter’s merger with Mittal Steel.

headline: A Done Deal for News Corp.’s Boston Property
abstract: Boston developer John B. Hynes III and financial services company Morgan Stanley on Friday bought 23 acres of South Boston Waterfront land from Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation for $203.7 million.

headline: Softbank May Miss Loan Deadline
abstract: Softbank may fail to refinance a 1.28 trillion yen ($11 billion) loan at its Japan mobile-phone unit by the end of this month, increasing interest costs, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: A Hedge Fund Wins The Day at Pep Boys
abstract: A group of hedge fund activists led by Barington Capital Group won a proxy battle against The Pep Boys on Thursday, gaining four director seats on the board of the auto-service chain.

headline: Bill Gates Moves into Newspapers — Sort of
abstract: When MediaNews sought to buy four newspapers from McClatchy, it found help from an unlikely source: Microsoft‘s Bill Gates.

headline: With HCA Deal, P.E. Firms Aren’t Joining the Club
abstract: While the $33 billion L.B.O. of hospital chain HCA is being done by a consortium, it nevertheless shows that general partners are moving to soothe the fears of limited partners by cutting back on club deals, L.B.O. Wire says.

headline: Brokers’ Quarterly Results to be Sifted for Deals, Not Profit
abstract: When the big Wall Street brokerage houses begin reporting third-quarter results next week, profit margins will not be the most important thing on investors’ minds.

headline: Judge’s Wide Disclosure Order Could Tie Up Litigation Firm
abstract: Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, an embattled class-action law firm that has been accused of paying people to serve as plaintiffs, may be required to turn over all its financial records since 1998 under an order released Thursday by an Indiana judge.

headline: Evraz to Buy Stake in South African Steel Company
abstract: Evraz Group, the Russian steelmaker partly owned by billionaire Roman Abramovich, agreed to buy Anglo American‘s 79 percent stake in Highveld Steel & Vanadium for 4.89 billion rand ($675 million).

headline: AIG Needs a Separate Fund as Private Equity Deals Balloon,
abstract: AIG Global Investment Group, an investment arm of insurance concern American International Group, has closed its first co-investment fund at $664.4 million, exceeding its $500 million target.

headline: British Property Group Buys Historic Covent Garden
abstract: Covent Garden Market and the surrounding piazza, one of the prime shopping locations in Britain, has been bought for 421 million pounds ($802 million) by Capital & Counties, a subsidiary of the FTSE 100 property group Liberty International.

headline: S.E.C. May Drop Charges Against Mack and Pequot — and Show Its Hand
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission may not only drop its charges against Pequot Capital Management and Morgan Stanley C.E.O. John J. Mack, but it may also take the unusual step of releasing all the evidence in its investigation, CNBC’s Charles Gasparino reported on the Squawk Box blog.

headline: In Midst of Scandal, H.P. Buys Gaming P.C. Maker
abstract: Hewlett-Packard said Thursday it has agreed to buy high-end gaming PC maker Voodoo Computers, giving the computer and printer company access to an elite group of hardcore hobbyists willing to shell out several thousand dollars for turbocharged customizable machines.

headline: Are Record Funds Over-Inflating Private Equity Bubble?
abstract: The 7.6 billion pound ($14 billion) fund just raised by private equity firm Permira may be a European record, but the real interest is in what it says about the state of the industry globally.

headline: KeyCorp Considers Selling Champion Mortgage
abstract: Midwestern bank KeyCorp said on Tuesday it may sell its Champion Mortgage subprime lending unit to focus on consumer and business banking.

headline: The Next Big Chip-Maker Buyout
abstract: Following Monday’s news that two groups of investment firms are vying to take Freescale Semiconductor private, which may result in the largest-ever leveraged buyout in the technology sector, Merrill Lynch analyst Joe Osha has published a report listing his top 10 candidates for leveraged buyouts in the chip industry.

headline: Wachovia Reports Record Second-Quarter Earnings
abstract: Strength in its investment banking, trading and mortgage businesses helped Wachovia post a 14 percent increase in profits in the second quarter, the company said early Thursday.

headline: Investment Banks Bow Before Private Equity Firms
abstract: Private-equity firms have become so powerful they have Wall Street’s biggest investment houses worshipping at their feet — and cutting their fees just to get in on these lucrative deals.

headline: Warily, Third Avenue Wades Into Private Equity
abstract: “Is Private Equity Investing Dead?”

headline: New Role for Rubin: Policy Guru
abstract: Does Robert E. Rubin still matter?

headline: Settlement Close on Enron Retirement Plan
abstract: The estate of the late Ken Lay is expected within days to reach a settlement in a lawsuit involving Enron‘s retirement fund that could bring thousands of former workers a step closer to receiving their share of a payout.

headline: NYBOT Said to Be Near $1 Billion Merger
abstract: The subject of intense speculation on the floor of the New York Board of Trade these days is likely to be the fate of the commodity exchange itself rather than the sugar and coffee futures that are traded there.

headline: Telefonica’s Risky Deals Pay Off
abstract: You have to grant César Alierta Izuel a bit of gloating. The low-key chairman and president of Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica suffered a lot of skepticism last fall when he shelled out an eye-popping $31.4 billion for British wireless company O2 – the biggest telecom acquisition in 2005 and one of the top M&A deals of the year.

headline: Heinz Unleashes Tangy Secret Weapon
abstract: In its increasingly acrimonious battle with activist shareholders led by Nelson Peltz, H.J. Heinz has fired off its latest salvo. And it goes quite nicely with a hamburger and fries.

headline: Cinram Rejects Amaranth’s Advice and Looks at Possible Acquisitions
abstract: Not only is Cinram International Income Fund not taking Amaranth Advisors‘ advice to sell itself, it’s gearing up to do some shopping of its own.

headline: Star Banker, With Future, Emerges Free
abstract: Now that Frank P. Quattrone reached a deal with prosecutors to dismiss their case against him and is going back to work, industry watchers can get back to the business of speculating about the former technology banker’s next move.

headline: Next for Nest Eggs: Hedge Fund Strategies?
abstract: Hedge-fund-like investments may soon be available to ordinary folks through — of all things — their retirement plans. So reports Alternative Investment News via DailyII.com, which tells us that some individual retirement accounts already allow investing in mutual funds that act like hedge funds, which are loosely regulated investment pools known for high returns, high risks and high fees. Some 401(k) plans may soon do the same.

headline: The Gambling Is Virtual; the Money Is Real
abstract: The arrest of David Carruthers, the British chief executive of online betting site BetOnSports, along with the recently approved congressional legislation that would clamp down on Internet casinos, appears to be the most concerted effort yet by the federal government to undermine Internet gambling in an era of well-organized, publicly owned offshore casinos.

headline: Fuzzy Laws Come Into Play in the Hewlett Pretexting Case
abstract: The California attorney general, Bill Lockyer, may decide as early as this week who to indict over Hewlett-Packard‘s improper investigation of board members and journalists.

headline: NYSE Group Quadruples Profit in Second Quarter
abstract: NYSE Group, owner of the world’s largest stock exchange, said second-quarter profit more than quadrupled after acquiring the Archipelago Holdings electronic market. Net income surged to $61.2 million, or 39 cents a share, from $13 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier, when it was still a not-for-profit organization..

headline: Baugur Keeps on Shopping in London
abstract: Baugur, an Icelandic investment group, is expected to launch its 350 million pound ($660 million) offer for the House of Fraser later this week.

headline: Buyout Firms Prepare for $19 Billion Cable Conquest
abstract: Private equity firms are preparing a fresh bid of 10 billion pounds ($18.9 billion) for the cable group NTL as disgruntled shareholders lodge a formal complaint against its rejection last year of a 9 billion pound offer, according to The Times of London.

headline: Russell Shareholders Approve Berkshire Merger
abstract: Russell shareholders on Tuesday approved the sporting goods maker’s $600 million takeover by Berkshire Hathaway, the insurance and investment company run by billionaire Warren Buffett.

headline: Diller Opens His Checkbook for Web Content
abstract: An executive at Barry Diller’s IAC/InteractiveCorp is offering some hints about what online acquisitions might be next for the company, which recently bought a controlling stake in the parent company of CollegeHumor.com.

headline: Left on the Shelf
abstract: In fashion or in finance, trends are notoriously hard to pin down.

headline: Newnham Technology Nabs Cash in Series B
abstract: Newnham Technology raised $13.25 million in a series B extension round that it will spend on making and selling its technology, which connects computers and displays.

headline: Citigroup Plans Emerging-Market Analyst Hiring Spree
abstract: Citigroup, the world’s largest financial services group, plans to hire about 35 research analysts this year as it expands into Brazil, Russia and other emerging markets, its global head of equity research said.

headline: Premier Foods Buys Campbell Soup’s British and Irish Unit
abstract: Premier Foods, a British company known for turning around flagging brands, agreed to buy Campbell Soup‘s British and Irish unit for about $845 million to add products including Homepride sauces and Batchelors soups.

headline: Eying a Hole in the Market, Apollo Plans European Mezzanine Fund
abstract: The private equity firm Apollo Advisors plans to beef up its investment activity in Europe, despite its relative late arrival overseas.

headline: The Case For Taking Viacom Private
abstract: If HCA can do it, why not Viacom? A thought-provoking report from Pali Research, flagged Tuesday by PaidContent.org, argues that media company Viacom could significantly boost its value by withdrawing from the public markets. Pali analyst Richard Greenfield runs the numbers for a hypothetical buyout at a 15 percent premium to Viacom’s current stock price and labels the results “compelling.”

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Profit Surged in 3rd Quarter
abstract: What summer slump?

headline: BSkyB Enters Race for AOL’s U.K. Internet Access Operations
abstract: British satellite TV operator BSkyB is among the suitors to buy Time Warner’s AOL UK Internet access business, Chief Executive James Murdoch said on Tuesday. Time Warner has said it is reviewing its Internet business in Europe with the help of financial advisers.

headline: Japan’s NTT Eyes Fuel Cell maker
abstract: Japan’s largest mobile phone company plans to buy a large stake in a fuel cell maker to develop handsets with longer-lasting hydrogen-powered batteries that are friendly to the environment.

headline: Circumspect Investor SAIC Takes a Chance on Integran
abstract: In its first new investment in two years, SAIC Venture Capital became the sole venture investor in Integran Defense Systems, a defense-focused nanotechnology company spun off from Integran Technologies.

headline: S.E.C. Names New Market Regulation Chief
abstract: Erik R. Sirri, an economist who specializes in the structure of securities markets, has been named the new director of market regulation at the Securities and Exchange Commission, the agency announced Monday.

headline: Newly Forged Arcelor-Mittal Plans Rich Dividend
abstract: Despite some slight wrinkles in the merger, the tie-up between Arcelor and Mittal Steel is apparently going so well that the company has announced a new and more generous dividend policy. There is certainly reason to celebrate at the Mittal family, which could reap $780 million under the new plan, according to The Times of London.

headline: Conrad Black Faces Additional Charges
abstract: Conrad M. Black, the former Hollinger International chairman charged with fraud and racketeering, caused his company to file false tax returns in 1999 and 2000, a federal indictment stated yesterday.

headline: Citigroup Names Head of Hedge Fund Unit
abstract: Citigroup named Dean Barr as the head of its Tribeca Global Management unit, succeeding Tanya Styblo Beder, in an effort to jump-start the hedge fund unit’s sagging returns.

headline: Joy in Job Cuts
abstract: Wall Street Loves It When (Other) People Lose Their Jobs

headline: Evergreen Wants to Help Nuprecon Tear Down the House
abstract: Some people enjoy building things. John Hennessey prefers knocking things down.

headline: Is There Too Much Money in Private Equity?
abstract: Ann Winblad, a founding partner of Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, criticized the amount of money flowing into private equity, of which venture capital is just a small portion.

headline: Akamai and M.I.T. Sue Limelight Networks
abstract: Akamai Technologies of Cambridge, Mass. and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have filed a patent infringement suit against Limelight Networks, an Arizona company that competes with Akamai in the Internet content-delivery business.

headline: Icahn Seeks Further Shake-Up at ImClone
abstract: Carl C. Icahn is one busy man these days. Shortly after he announced that he wants to buy up to $500 million in Federated stock, the billionaire investor said Thursday that he will seek to oust six directors from the board of drug maker ImClone.

headline: Candover May Want Mirror, Report Says
abstract: A private equity group, Candover, has emerged as a possible bidder for some or all of Trinity Mirror’s newspapers after the British group last week announced a review of its business that could lead to the sale of its flagship title, the Daily Mirror.

headline: Inco Extends Its Friendly Offer on Falconbridge
abstract: Inco and Phelps Dodge extended their friendly takeover bid for Falconbridge after failing to win enough shares, giving the miners more time to prepare a revised offer to fend off rival Xstrata, who sweetened its bid a few days ago.

headline: Premier Foods Considers a $3.2 Billion Bid for United Biscuits
abstract: Britain’s Premier Foods on Tuesday said it plans to make an offer for the U.K. and Irish biscuits and snacks business of private-equity owned United Biscuits in a 1.7 billion pound ($3.2 billion) auction.

headline: HSBC Is No Longer Afraid of Risks
abstract: HSBC, Britain’s biggest bank, is increasing the risks taken by its investment banking arm as it strives to raise profitability at the division, The Times of London said.

headline: H.P. Officials, Counsel Prepare for Congressional Hearings
abstract: Two Hewlett-Packard employees who directed the company’s spying operations have been subpoenaed by a House committee to appear at a hearing this week after refusing invitations to testify, the committee said Monday.

headline: Getting By on $240,000 a Year
abstract: A judge tampers with the divine right of proprietors.

headline: Intelleflex Closes Oversubscribed Round
abstract: Intelleflex said Thursday it closed a $15.5 round of equity funding. San Jose-based Intelleflex, an RFID platform company, said funding was over-subscribed and was led by Menlo Park-based Morgenthaler Ventures. Also participating were existing investors Woodside Fund, Alloy Ventures, and Selby Venture Partners.

headline: Murdoch Hops on Maker of the Crazy Frog Ringtone
abstract: Rupert Murdoch and Crazy Frog, a popular ringtone, may seem like unlikely partners, but the News Corporation was set to announce on Tuesday that it would buy a majority stake in Jamba, the maker of the ringtone, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: KKR Dials Up $4.2 Billion Bid for PagesJaunes
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the world’s biggest buyout firm, plans to purchase France Telecom’s remaining 54 percent stake in directories business PagesJaunes for about 3.3 billion euros ($4.2 billion).

headline: Halliburton Reconsiders KBR Offering
abstract: Halliburton on Friday backed away from a planned initial public offering of its KBR unit, as Dave Lesar, Halliburton’s chief executive, cited weak market conditions. Instead, Mr. Lesar said the company’s engineering and construction arm, which handles $10 billion in contracts in Iraq, may be separated through a tax-free spinoff to the unit’s shareholders.

headline: V.C.’s Take Another Look at Networking Investments
abstract: Rewind a few years, and venture capitalists wouldn’t go near networking equipment investments.

headline: Branson Pledges to Finance Clean Fuels
abstract: Sir Richard Branson, the British magnate and adventurer, said yesterday that his personal profits from airlines and a rail company that he controls – a sum he estimated at $3 billion over the next 10 years – would be invested in developing energy sources that do not contribute to global warming.

headline: Heavily Hyped Cellphone Won’t Make You a Chocoholic
abstract: The Chocolate music player/cellphone resembles a sticky mess more than a deeply satisfying treat.

headline: Enron’s Former Chief Kenneth Lay Dies
abstract: Enron founder Kenneth L. Lay died early Wednesday of a heart attack at his vacation home in Colorado. Mr. Lay, convicted in May of fraud and conspiracy related to Enron’s dramatic collapse into bankruptcy, was 64.

headline: Top Executives Return Offices to Manhattan
abstract: For the last half of the 20th century, New York City’s status as the national capital of business steadily eroded as companies fled to the suburbs and to other cities where costs were lower and the streets safer. But in the last several years, New York has regained its magnetic force and is re-establishing its claim as the city of big bosses. If decision-making were an industry, it would be one of the main engines driving New York’s economy.

headline: I’ll Trade You This Paper Clip for a House
abstract: About a year ago, Canadian blogger Kyle MacDonald began a quest: to trade one red paper clip for a house.

headline: Bidding Heats Up for Stake in German Lender Nordbank
abstract: Three private equity firms in the United States have made bids of about 1.2 billion euros ($1.55 billion) to buy a stake in government-backed ship financier HSH Nordbank of Germany from the German bank WestLB, a source close to the matter told Reuters.

headline: 76ers May Fetch Record Price
abstract: As many as eight potential buyers – including at least three with local ties – have come forward seeking to buy the Philadelphia 76ers, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: FTI to Buy Financial Public-Relations Firm
abstract: FTI Consulting, a Baltimore-based adviser in litigation and corporate restructurings, has jumped into the public relations business with Monday’s $260 milion acquisition of FD International of London. The deal for FD, known as Financial Dynamics, represents the highest price ever paid for a financial public-relations company, according to The Financial Times, which said it demonstrates the “increasing value that corporate clients place on issues such as reputation management.”

headline: Spanish Homebuilder Bids for Rival
abstract: Construcciones Reyal, the biggest homebuilder in Madrid, made a 3.3 billion euro ($4.2 billion) bid for Inmobiliaria Urbis to triple sales and add management of real estate in cities from Barcelona to Seville.

headline: Chinese Firms Spearhead Nasdaq Listings
abstract: Chinese companies are the biggest source of new share listings for Nasdaq Stock Market and do not appear to be discouraged by stricter regulatory requirements, the exchange’s international president said Wednesday.

headline: For V.C.s, Good Things Come in (Really) Small Packages
abstract: Venture capitalists, lured by potential breakthroughs in electronics, medicine and textiles, are heading to the labs in search of inventions based on nanotechnology. After decades of hype and false starts, the National Science Foundation forecasts that $1 trillion worth of nanotechnology-enabled products will be on the market by 2015.

headline: R.R. Donnelley & Sons Hold Talks With Buyout Firms, Report Says
abstract: Shares of R.R. Donnelley & Sons closed up nearly 5 percent Monday on speculation that the Chicago-based commercial printer has held talks with leveraged buyout firms.

headline: Goldman Sachs Wants To Get Rid of Goldmansex.com
abstract: Goldman Sachs wants a Dutch man to change the name of a sex-themed Web site called goldmansex.com. Goldman Sachs last week submitted a complaint to the National Arbitration Forum arguing the Internet domain name goldmansex.com would cause confusion and contained links to objectionable “adult” material.

headline: Vodafone C.E.O. May Face Shareholder Uprising
abstract: Arun Sarin could see an unprecedented vote against his re-election as the head of Vodafone on Tuesday after several important institutional investors joined a rebellion against his leadership of the mobile phone group.

headline: Sugar-Coating the Poison Pill
abstract: Poison pills, the corporate takeover defense strategy that came under assault earlier this decade from investor advocates, are grabbing headlines as Canadian mining companies Falconbridge and Inco have employed them to try to avoid unwanted deals.

headline: Yukos Executive Says Charges are Political
abstract: The key to deciphering last week’s announcement that Russian authorities are investigating former Yukos executives is all in the timing, said a former Yukos president and sometime Houstonian, Steven Theede.

headline: Candover Expands Its Optical Business With Linos
abstract: Candover Investments, a London- based buyout firm, plans to buy Linos of Germany in a transaction valued at about 80 million euros ($101 million) to integrate the maker of optical equipment with similar holdings.

headline: Battle of Wills in Fight for Croatian Drugmaker
abstract: Robert Wessman has led Icelandic generics drugmaker Actavis Group through 25 acquisitions in the past seven years, almost as many deals as years he has lived.

headline: Matchstick Marvels
abstract: Four words: Hogwart’s made of matchsticks. Unbelievable.

headline: With Banistmo Buy, HSBC Banks on Latin America
abstract: HSBC Holdings agreed to buy Grupo Banistmo, Panama’s largest bank, for $1.77 billion in cash, giving it access to five new countries in Latin America, its fastest-growing market.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Reports Jump in 3rd-Quarter Profits
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia joined other Canadian banks in reporting a big jump in profit for the third quarter.

headline: Cinven Hangs On in Belgian Cable Auction
abstract: U.K. buyout shop Cinven is one of three remaining bidders in a politically sensitive race for eight Belgian cable networks for a reported minimum price of 475 million euro ($608 million),The Deal.com reported.

headline: Time Warner to Sell AOL France’s Net Access Unit
abstract: The media conglomerate Time Warner said Thursday it would sell AOL France’s Internet access business for about $365 million, taking a step toward its goal of exiting the Internet access business in Europe. Time Warner is also in the process of changing AOL into a free, Web-based service.

headline: Milberg Weiss Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman pleaded not guilty to criminal charges before a district court judge Monday, the Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog noted. Two of its name partners, David Bershad and Steven Schulman, also pleaded not guilty.

headline: Patent Ruling Could Cost Pfizer Billions
abstract: Pfizer‘s basic patent on its top-selling drug Lipitor was upheld in federal court Wednesday, but a second, longer-running patent was ruled invalid, possibly eliminating billions of dollars in potential sales.

headline: Bertelsmann Might Trim Sony BMG Stake, Report Says
abstract: The German media group Bertelsmann is considering selling a part of its 50 percent stake in Sony BMG, the German music recording company it owns jointly with Sony. Sony’s chief executive, Howard Stringer, said last month the future ownership of Sony BMG would be determined by how Bertelsmann decides to repay the debts it took on to buy out a minority shareholder in the group.

headline: Mining Boom Stirs Wave of Mergers and Talk of a Slump
abstract: Digging up base metals like copper, nickel, zinc and iron ore is arguably the very definition of an old-economy effort. But the merger activity involving companies that pull those metals from the earth has the mark of a new-economy fervor.

headline: Bashing the Management Buyout
abstract: Management-led buyouts may be hugely popular these days, but they continue to draw skepticism in certain quarters.

headline: A MySpace Founder Reaches Out to China
abstract: A founder of MySpace who objected to the popular site’s $580 million sale to News Corporation has trained his sights on China.

headline: New Wine Fund Uncorked
abstract: Wine Asset Managers, based in Britain, has created the Fine Wine Fund, a scheme established as an association of members that will invest purely in fine wine, to allow prospective members to benefit from expected returns without having to do their own research and deal with the administrative headache of wine investment.

headline: Alcatel Seeks to Bolster Support for Lucent Merger
abstract: Alcatel began a series of meetings with top shareholders on Wednesday to secure their backing at its Sept. 7 annual meeting for its all-stock deal to acquire U.S. rival Lucent.

headline: Buyout Firms Said to Consider Verizon Unit Bid
abstract: Providence Equity Partners, Blackstone Group and Thomas H. Lee Partners may form a consortium to bid for the phone-book business of Verizon Communications, Bloomberg News said on Monday. If they do, the firms would become just the latest private equity funds to target a yellow pages business for a multibillion-dollar buyout deal.

headline: Former Chief of Brocade Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to 12 counts of securities fraud and other charges that he improperly backdated employee stock option grants.

headline: Comverse Executives to Be Charged in Options Scandal, Report Says
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn are preparing to bring charges against former Comverse Technology executives, including possibly its chief Jacob Alexander, in the next two weeks or so, The New York Times reported. Prosecutors are likely to build a case on whether the executives made misleading statements to the board and to its auditors, The Times said.

headline: Linux Networx Gets Another Hefty Cash Infusion
abstract: Linux Networx announced a $37 million Series D round of venture funding from new investors Lehman Brothers and Canaccord Adams, and existing backers Oak Investment Partners and Tudor Ventures, to expand its work force and advance its software for supercomputing systems.

headline: BA Chairman Avoids Scrutiny in Price-Fixing Inquiry
abstract: British Airways chairman Martin Broughton said yesterday he had not been questioned as part of the investigation into alleged price-fixing at the airline, and added that the first stage of the inquiry was due to end soon.

headline: Skilling Must Cover His Gains, and Lay’s Too, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Jeffrey K. Skilling is liable not only for his own ill-gotten gains but those of the late Kenneth L. Lay as well, The Houston Chronicle reported, citing a motion filed by prosecutors.

headline: Gateway Receives Bid After Hedge Fund Shines Spotlight
abstract: In just two days’ time, a hedge fund has managed to do for Gateway what its own earnings reports, pledges of growth in new markets and new C.E.O. haven’t been able to do for months: get investors to once again take notice of the nation’s No. 3 personal-computer company.

headline: Western Gas Shareholders Approve $21 Billion Deal
abstract: Western Gas Resources shareholders on Wednesday approved the sale of the company to Anadarko, paving the way for creation of an independent energy exploration and production giant in a $21.1 billion three-company deal.

headline: Addax Petroleum Sails Away With Pan-Ocean Energy
abstract: Addax Petroleum is buying the two main subsidiaries of Pan-Ocean Energy for $1.6 billion in cash, a move that expands the Calgary, Canada-based firm’s West African operations.

headline: Parlux Chief Pulls Buyout Offer
abstract: Despite heading a company that produces fragrances for Guess?, Perry Ellis and Paris Hilton, the one scent Ilia Lekach missed out on was the sweet smell of success.

headline: U.S. Bidding War for British Cooking Equipment Maker
abstract: Manitowoc, the biggest maker of ice machines in the U.S., raised its takeover approach for Enodis, fending off a rival with a bid that values the U.K. cooking equipment manufacturer at about 891 million pounds ($1.13 billion).

headline: U.K. Hedge Funds in Merger Talks
abstract: British hedge fund manager RAB Capital is in talks that are expected to result in its acquisition of Northwest Investment Management, the fund management group specializing in Asia that has $500 million under management.

headline: Did Milberg’s Meltdown Reduce Class Actions?
abstract: The troubles at Milberg Weiss might be a rich source of schadenfreude for the editorial board of The Wall Street Journal, which has long derided the law firm for its role in waging shareholder class action suits against corporations.

headline: Japan’s Mixi to Test Social Networking Waters
abstract: Sept. 14 could be a landmark date for social networking in Asia. That’s the day Mixi, Japan’s answer to MySpace, launches an initial public stock offering.

headline: End of the Road for the Town Car?
abstract: Much of Wall Street heaved a nostalgic sigh on Wednesday when they learned that the Lincoln Town Car, the unofficial taxi for tired investment bankers, was in danger of extinction.

headline: Apax Partners Buys Incisive Media of London for $375 Million
abstract: A private equity firm, Apax Partners said on Thursday it had agreed to acquire Incisive Media, a financial information provider, for about 199 million pounds ($375 million).

headline: DiVitas Connects With V.C.s
abstract: DiVitas Networks, a wireless network software company, said Tuesday it raised $15 million in its second round of venture funding.

headline: Pfizer Adds to Ranks of Lawyer-C.E.O.s
abstract: Many investors and analysts had considered Pfizer general counsel Jeffrey B. Kindler a long shot to follow Henry A. McKinnell as the pharmaceutical giant’s chief executive. Nevertheless, Mr. Kindler landed in the C.E.O. chair late last week, outmaneuvering the company’s finance chief and the head of its largest business unit, who had both been contenders for the post.

headline: Former Icahn Lawyer to Open Fund With Asian Approach
abstract: A former member of the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn’s inside circle is set to open a new hedge fund with an Eastern flavor.

headline: Aer Lingus I.P.O. to Go Ahead Despite Security Turmoil
abstract: Despite the current chaos at British airports, Irish flag carrier Aer Lingus is to press ahead with its 1 billion euro ($1.28 billion) flotation in London and Dublin next month.

headline: Bear Stearns Caps Third Buyout Fund
abstract: Bear Stearns Merchant Banking said Wednesday it has capped its third private equity fund at $2.7 billion amid a fundraising frenzy in which the buyout industry is raising record-breaking sums. Merchant Partners III raised about a billion more than the firm’s last investment vehicle, but Bear Stearns’ strategy of investing in midmarket companies in North America and Western Europe remains unchanged, C.E.O. John Howard said.

headline: SkyPilots Navigates $21 Million Venture Round
abstract: SkyPilot Networks of Santa Clara, Calif. raised $21 million in a round of venture funding led by August Capital. Current investors joining in the round include Mobius Venture Capital, Invesco Private Capital, Palo Alto Investors, Nexit Ventures and Selby Venture Partners. With this investment, SkyPilot’s funding since inception now totals $68 million.

headline: Valeant  Target of Federal Options Inquiry
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International disclosed Monday that federal regulators had begun an inquiry into stock trades that were made this spring when the company released results of a drug trial.

headline: Finalists Close in on AOL’s British Unit
abstract: Time Warner‘s plan to sell off AOL’s European assets continues apace, as two finalists have emerged for the Internet provider’s British arm.

headline: European Buyouts Surge, While U.K. Deals Decline
abstract: The European and British buyout markets have had two very different starts to the year, with deals in the first six months booming on the Continent while slowing in England.

headline: Mysterious Money Manager Charged in Prostitution Case
abstract: Jeffrey Epstein, a money manager with a secret list of billionaire clients and a strong penchant for privacy, suddenly finds himself at the center of a very public scandal. As reported earlier this week in The Palm Beach Post and several other publications, Mr. Epstein has been charged with soliciting prostitution after a long investigation by police in Palm Beach, Fla. In an affidavit describing their investigation, the police said that Mr. Epstein repeatedly paid young women, including some minors, for massages, and sometimes sex, at his Palm Beach home.

headline: In Asia, Young Entrepreneurs Are Pushing the Boundaries
abstract: It’s a good time to be a tech entrepreneur. After the dot-com bust, capital is flowing and venture capitalists are once again turning their attention (and opening their wallets) to a broad range of new technologies.

headline: Betting on the Weather and Taking an Ice-Cold Bath
abstract: There’s a lot of talk about lessons learned from the evaporation of $6 billion of capital at Amaranth Advisors in Greenwich, Conn. The most obvious one is: Don’t put all your eggs in one basket.

headline: Italian Telecom’s Strategy Puzzles Analysts
abstract: Telecom Italia, in a reversal of a recent and expensive consolidation, announced plans on Monday to spin off its fixed-line and mobile phone businesses into two companies. The chairman, Marco Tronchetti Provera, also said he would consider offers to buy the mobile phone business, Telecom Italia Mobile, which is estimated to be worth $53 billion.

headline: Mylan to Shell Out $736 Million for Indian Drugmaker
abstract: Targeting the emerging markets of India, China and Africa, pharmaceutical company Mylan Laboratories said Monday it would buy up to 71.5 percent of Matrix Laboratories, a maker of drug ingredients based in Hyderabad, India. Mylan said the purchase price could be as high as $736 million, depending on how many Matrix shareholders accept its “open offer” for Matrix’s publicly traded stock.

headline: Raytheon May Sell Aircraft Unit
abstract: Raytheon on Thursday reported second-quarter profit rose a better-than-expected 54 percent, helped by higher sales of military equipment, and it said it may sell or spin off its aircraft division, which makes Hawker business jets.

headline: Pinnacle Financial Completes $20 Million Offering
abstract: Pinnacle Financial Partners has completed the private placement of $20 million in trust preferred securities.

headline: For Real Estate Lawyers, Big Deals Are Big Business
abstract: Larger and increasingly complex deals involving real estate are creating “choice legal work” for attorneys, according to a report by The Recorder, a legal newspaper.

headline: Western Union Spin-Off Plan Receives Warm Welcome
abstract: Analysts issued bullish comments Monday on First Data as the transaction-processing giant moved ahead with plans to spin off its Western Union money-transfer business.

headline: Lawmakers Hear Concerns About Hedge-Fund Trading
abstract: Insider trading by hedge funds is a big worry to securities regulators, an official of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Senate panel Tuesday.

headline: Another English Soccer Club Is Now in American Hands
abstract: Randolph Lerner, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, agreed to buy the British soccer club Aston Villa for 62.6 million pounds ($119 million), becoming the second NFL owner in two years to buy a British soccer club.

headline: A Web Retrospective
abstract: An amusing, enlightening “Web museum” shows the Web sites of big companies like McDonald’s as they appeared in 1996.

headline: Big Video Game Producer Receives More Subpoenas
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, the embattled video game publisher, said yesterday that it had received additional grand jury subpoenas from the Manhattan district attorney’s office seeking information about its financial activities.

headline: Revolving Door: ABN Amro
abstract: ABN Amro has added to its Japan operations, announcing the appointment of Kim Rosenkilde in Tokyo. With immediate effect, the ABN veteran will take on the role of country executive in Japan and will report to Jeroen Drost, the firm’s chief executive of Asia in Hong Kong.

headline: Alticor Buys Beauty Brand
abstract: Gurwitch Products, the licensee of the Laura Mercier brand, has been sold to Alticor, the $6.4 billion personal products and water filtration company that is the parent of Amway.

headline: Parish Capital Advisors to Raise Nearly $1 Billion
abstract: Their firm’s background may be Carolina blue, but the three former Morehead Scholars who came together to create Parish Capital Advisors are looking at a future that is decidedly dollar bill green.

headline: Cambridge Industrial Trust Succeeds in Second I.P.O. Effort
abstract: Cambridge Industrial Trust has completed the initial public offering that it was forced to postpone in mid-June after the market turned sour and institutional investors snubbed the deal on the basis that the dividend yield wasn’t attractive enough compared with its already-listed Singapore peers.

headline: Federated’s Bridal Unit Said to Draw $1 Billion Bid
abstract: Federated Department Stores has been offered as much as $1 billion for its bridal and formal wear business, Bloomberg News reported Thursday, citing “people involved in the bidding.”

headline: Australian Exchange Merger Is a Surprise Winner
abstract: Against many odds, SFE shareholders have approved a A$4.56 billion ($3.38 billion) merger with the company’s larger local peer the Australian Stock Exchange following a friendly takeover bid launched in March. In a vote cast on Wednesday, 93 percent of shareholders backed the deal, though the board needed only 50 percent support to push it through.

headline: Former Kraft Chief Gets His Golden Parachute
abstract: Roger Deromedi, a former chief executive of Kraft Foods, will receive more than $8 million under terms of a severance agreement filed Wednesday with regulatory authorities.

headline: Skilling Request Denied
abstract: A federal judge on Tuesday rejected a request by a former chief executive of Enron, Jeffrey K. Skilling, to overturn his convictions for fraud and conspiracy related to lies told to investors and employees about the company’s financial health.

headline: Companies Are Primed For Deals, C.F.O.’s Say
abstract: Morgan Stanley‘s annual survey of chief financial officers suggests that companies are getting much more bullish about mergers and acquisitions going into 2007. However, they will face stiff — and maybe insurmountable — competition from financial investors as they seek out takeover targets, according to Henry McVey, Morgan Stanley’s chief U.S. investment strategist.

headline: Merrill Lynch Seeks Permission to Not Rehire Plaintiff
abstract: Merrill Lynch is asking an arbitration panel to excuse it from employing a former broker who successfully sued the company for $2.2 million.

headline: GATX to Sell Aircraft Business To Investors
abstract: GATX said Thursday it plans to sell most of its aircraft leasing business, worth about $1.5 billion, to a group of private investors that includes hedge fund giant Och Ziff Capital Management and Australia’s Macquarie Bank.

headline: 1990’s Reunion for Frank Quattrone?
abstract: Frank Quattrone may be trying revisit his glory days. Fortune magazine reports that Mr. Quattrone, the former technology banker from Credit Suisse whose years-long exile from the securities industry is coming to an end, will reunite with some of his old Morgan Stanley buddies from the early 1990’s to open a new firm in Silicon Valley.

headline: Deutsche Borse Touts Its Euronext Bid as Superior to NYSE’s
abstract: Deutsche Borse on Monday said its offer for Euronext, the pan-European stock exchange operator, is a better value after recent trading than the rival bid made by NYSE Group, the parent of the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Softbank and SBI to Launch India V.C. Fund
abstract: Softbank Investment and SBI Capital Markets are following the money into India, announcing plans yesterday to launch a $100 million India-focused venture capital fund.

headline: NYSE Acquires MatchPoint
abstract: NYSE Group said on Wednesday it bought MatchPoint Trading, a financial services technology company specializing in market trading and technologies.

headline: Athenagen Takes $50 Million
abstract: Drug developer Athenagen, which merged last month with biotechnology company Zapaq, has raised $50 million in Series B financing to advance its drug pipeline further in clinical trials.

headline: Kinder Morgan Prices Offering
abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners has priced the public offering of 5 million common units representing limited partner interests at $44.80 per common unit.

headline: Think Your Camera Has Enough Megapixels?
abstract: Then you don’t know jack. Or, rather, you don’t know Scott Howard, who’s posted a nighttime shot of Sydney Harbor that weighs in at a whopping 720 megapixels.

headline: Millennium Wins Bidding for AnorMed
abstract: Millennium Pharmaceuticals said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy AnorMed, a Canadian biotechnology company with an experimental treatment for patients with blood cancer, for $515 million, topping an earlier bid from Genzyme.

headline: University of Michigan Ranks First in M.B.A. Recruiter Poll
abstract: A survey of more than 4,000 recruiters found that the University of Michigan’s Ross School of Business is the most appealing place for companies to find their new crop of M.B.A.’s. In their sixth annual survey, Harris Interactive and The Wall Street Journal ranked Ross first among national business schools, followed by Dartmouth University’s Tuck School of Business, which took the No. 1 spot last year.

headline: Sun Valley Facebook
abstract: MONEY GUYS

headline: Proxy Firm Backs Hedge Fund in Topps Feud
abstract: Hedge funds trying to shake up the board at baseball card maker Topps got a boost on Tuesday when Institutional Shareholder Services, an influential proxy advisory firm, came out in support of the funds’ nominees for director. Despite Topps’ repeated assertions that the candidates are not qualified, the proxy firm has recommended that Topps’ shareholders vote for the rival slate at the company’s annual meeting later this month.

headline: French Politicians Back Utility Merger
