abstract: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of France, overcoming opposition within his ranks, said Thursday that the governing party was now united in backing a plan to merge the state-controlled Gaz de France with the private utility Suez.

headline: Judge Orders $1 Million Cash Added to Media Baron’s Bond
abstract: Reassessing his ability to flee, a federal judge raised the bond for the media baron Conrad M. Black by $1 million in cash on Thursday, saying he had lied about how much he was worth.

headline: Planar Systems Bets on the Big Screen
abstract: Shares of Planar Systems fell as much as 12 percent on Thursday on news that the flat-panel display maker will purchase large-format display maker Clarity Visual Systems.

headline: French Telecom Prepares $4.45 Billion Stock Float
abstract: Neuf Cegetel kicked off its flotation on Friday in a deal that could value France’s second largest fixed-line telecoms operator at more than 3.5 billion euros ($4.45 billion).

headline: Fee Hike at N.Y.S.E. Could Cause Bloodletting at Trading Firms
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange’s decision to raise fees will increase costs for some of the smallest trading firms by at least 25 percent and may force them to eliminate jobs.

headline: Slim Shops CompUSA, Report Says
abstract: CompUSA, owned by a Mexican conglomerate controlled by Carlos Slim Helú, is being shopped to potential investors, The Dallas Morning News reported.

headline: U.K. Espresso Bar Operator Receives Management Bid
abstract: The founder of Caffè Nero, the fast-growing espresso bar operator, surprised the market yesterday by confirming that he is looking at the possibility of taking the company private.

headline: Proxy Adviser Offers Split Decision on Heinz Fight
abstract: A second proxy advisory group said Tuesday that H.J. Heinz‘s performance has lagged its competitors and that a slate of director candidates advocated by shareholder activist Nelson Peltz collectively holds an “impressive” career record. But the firm also recommended rejecting the dissident proposal.

headline: M&A Activity Strong for Small-Caps — Especially Tech, Healthcare, Finance
abstract: Mergers involving small-cap companies are accelerating and are likely to continue, with the technology, finance and healthcare industries seeing the most activity, according to Merrill Lynch‘s SmallCap Strategy report.

headline: European Regulators Clear Mondadori Deal for Emap Unit
abstract: European Union regulators on Friday cleared Italy’s largest publishing house, Arnoldo Mondadori Editori, to buy Emap‘s struggling French consumer magazines division.

headline: Apollo Swoops In on TNT Unit
abstract: TNT, Europe’s second-biggest express-package delivery company, agreed to sell its freight division to Leon Black’s Apollo Management for 1.48 billion euros ($1.9 billion).

headline: Litigation Boutique Mergers with Larger Law Firm
abstract: After nearly 25 years of going it alone, 35-lawyer San Francisco litigation firm Morgenstein & Jubelirer will combine with Chicago’s Schiff Hardin. The merger, announced Thursday, will become effective in January.

headline: Bidding War Escalates for Canada Southern Petroleum
abstract: Petro-Canada has raised its bid for Canada Southern Petroleum to $13 a share in cash, double the amount of its first hostile offer two months ago.

headline: Diesel Owner in Talks With Viktor & Rolf
abstract: Diesel owner Renzo Rosso is said to have another quirky design house in his sights: Viktor & Rolf.

headline: Lehman Takes Pole Position in London’s Electronic Trading
abstract: Lehman Brothers set a record for monthly equity volumes traded electronically on the London stock market in June and July.

headline: Planitax Banks $5 Million from Investors
abstract: Planitax, which provides software to corporate tax departments, said Wednesday it received $5 million in third-round funding. Leading the round was Mobius Venture Capital. Also participating were existing investors, Redwood City, Calif.-based Draper Fisher Jurvetson and Denver-based Access Venture Partners.

headline: Investors Favor Large Banks over Securities Firms
abstract: U.S. bank stocks are beating Wall Street securities firms for the first time in more than a year as slumping equity and commodity markets lead investors to buy companies that can better withstand lower trading profits.

headline: Smith & Nephew Picks Up OsteoBiologics
abstract: The British orthopedics company Smith & Nephew said Tuesday its endoscopy unit is buying privately held, San Antonio-based OsteoBiologics, which sells bioabsorbable bone graft substitutes in Europe, for $72.3 million.

headline: Google Deal Will Give News Corp. Huge Payoff
abstract: It appears that News Corporation‘s bet on MySpace is paying off — and Google will be footing the bill.

headline: Arcelor Mittal to Announce Board Lineup
abstract: Arcelor Mittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, will announce the lineup of its six-strong management board tomorrow, the company said yesterday.

headline: Stealth Tech Start-Up Gets First Taste of Funding
abstract: Coming out of stealth mode, tech start-up iTaggit raised $1.04 million from some big-name backers in its Series A offering.

headline: Apollo Joins Chase for BMG, Report Says
abstract: U.S. private equity firm Apollo Management has emerged as a surprise contender for Bertelsmann‘s music publishing group BMG, which is valued at $1.5 billion to $2 billion.

headline: Buyout Chief Sees Private Equity Peak
abstract: As private equity firms continue to smash fund-raising records — the latest megafund came from Europe’s Permira Advisers — a leading executive in the industry is acknowledging that the long boom in buyouts may be about to crest, or may have crested already.

headline: Lower Earnings, Sinking Stocks  and Lucy Gao: Are the Good Times Over?
abstract: It’s been one slow summer on Wall Street, a reflection that has prompted MarketWatch’s David Weidner to gloomily wonder if the good times are over for the securities industry.

headline: KKR Group Ends Talks With Freescale, Report Says
abstract: An investor group that launched an unsuccessful, last-minute bid for Freescale Semiconductor has ended talks with the chip maker, Reuters reported on Tuesday. Shares of Freescale, which recently accepted a $17.6 billion takeover offer from another consortium, slipped more than 2 percent Tuesday as expectations of a bidding war between the two factions faded.

headline: Yukos Is Declared Bankrupt
abstract: It’s officially done. A Moscow judge declared Yukos bankrupt on Tuesday, paving the way for the liquidation of what was once Russia’s biggest oil producer.

headline: UCBH Holdings to Buy Summit Bank for $175.5 Million
abstract: UCBH Holdings, a California bank serving Asian-American communities, said on Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Summit Bank of Atlanta for $175.5 million in stock and cash.

headline: Freeman Spogli Spends $550 Million on Savers
abstract: Los Angeles buyout firm Freeman Spogli has agreed to buy thrift store chain Savers from Boston based private equity firm Berkshire Partners in a secondary buyout worth more than $550 million, said The Daily Deal.

headline: Venture Firm Rejects E-mail Destruction Claims
abstract: Attorneys for Hummer Winblad Venture Partners denied in a federal court filing last week that partner Ann Winblad destroyed company e-mails related to the lawsuit accusing Napster — the music-downloading company financed by Hummer Winblad — of copyright infringement. Citing court documents, The Red Herring reports that the prominent venture firm says it made “a good faith effort to preserve and produce relevant documents, including e-mails” in the case.

headline: Bittersweet End to Daily Candy Auction
abstract: Daily Candy, the shopping and culture e-mail newsletter and Web site put up for sale early this year, has yanked itself off the auction block, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing “people familiar with the matter.”

headline: Danaher May Join Bidders for Australia’s Vision Systems
abstract: The industrial conglomerate Danaher confirmed on Tuesday that it was in discussions to join the auction for Vision Systems, an Australian medical technology company already considering bids from two other suitors in the United States.

headline: Slaying of Banker Throws Spotlight on Russia’s Financial Community
abstract: No one doubts that the murder of Andrei Kozlov, the deputy chairman of the Russian Central Bank who was gunned down in Moscow, was a contract killing, linked to his key position at the Central Bank, BusinessWeek says.

headline: English Water Utility AWG in Play
abstract: AWG, a utility whose Anglian Water unit serves 6 million customers in eastern England, said it may be taken over. The shares jumped as much as 14 percent to a record, valuing the company at 2.2 billion pounds ($4.1 billion).

headline: Dell’s Bad News Has Silver Lining for V.C.s
abstract: Dell‘s recall of potentially explosive lithium-ion batteries could be good news for developers of next-generation portable power supplies – and their venture backers, The Daily Deal writes.

headline: Out of Boeing’s Cabin and Behind the Wheel at Ford
abstract: After 37 years at Boeing, Ford Motor Company’s new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, must quickly get up to speed during one of the company’s most severe financial crises. As soon as next week, Ford will unveil the next steps in its aggressive turnaround plan, called the Way Forward, that could include more job cuts, plant closings and revamping steps.

headline: Fox Rothschild to Merge With New Jersey Law Firm
abstract: Fox Rothschild of Philadelphia will merge with Grotta, Glassman & Hoffman, a 60-lawyer management-side labor firm in Roseland, N.J.

headline: Former Citigroup Banker Cleared in China Life Share Sale
abstract: A former banker at Citigroup, Margaret Ren, was cleared by federal regulators of any wrongdoing stemming from China Life Insurance‘s $3.5 billion initial share sale, the world’s biggest in 2003.

headline: Iced Tea Maker Changes Hands
abstract: Freestone Beverage Partners, an affiliate of a Houston-based private equity group, Freestone Partners, purchased the entire interest in the iced tea brewer Sweet Leaf Tea that was previously owned by another Houston private equity firm, Milestone Venture Group.

headline: Abromovich Bid Bodes Well for Rosneft I.P.O.
abstract: The Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich has placed a bid for a stake in Rosneft – possibly for several hundred million dollars – giving a lift to the Russian oil group’s planned initial public offering.

headline: J.P. Morgan Restates Results at Request of S.E.C.
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase said Thursday it restated its 2005 year-end financial statement at the request of securities regulators over the way it had classified three years’ worth of mortgage investments.

headline: Gresham Backs MBO at Giles
abstract: Private equity group Gresham has backed a 45 million pound ($87.9 million) management buyout at Giles Insurance Brokers.

headline: Deutsche Bank Is Sued in Dispute Over an I.P.O.
abstract: Ferris Baker Watts says the financial giant Deutsche Bank Securities swooped in and stole an underwriting deal from it, and Ferris wants Deutsche Bank to pay up.

headline: Warburg Pincus and Cinven Grab Dutch Cable Company
abstract: New York buyout shop Warburg Pincus and its London-based partner, Cinven, have won the auction for Dutch cable company Casema, agreeing to buy the Dutch cable company from its private equity owners for $2.77 billion, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Round Two of the Viacom Wars: Moonves Vs. Freston
abstract: Corporate squabbles seem to be following Viacom these days. After the highly-publicized break-up between Viacom‘s Paramount Pictures and Tom Cruise, The New York Post reports that a showdown is looming between former corporate cousins Les Moonves, who runs Viacom spinoff CBS, and Tom Freston, chief of Viacom, over a lucrative movie deal between pay-TV channel Showtime and Paramount.

headline: Rothschild Says Annual Profits Doubled
abstract: The Rothschild family will reap a dividend of more than £50 million ($94 million) from the London division of the family-controlled bank, which said yesterday that annual profits had doubled.NM Rothschild, one of the City’s oldest merchant banks, announced operating profit for the year to the end of March of 83.2 million pounds. The 200-year-old bank reaped the rewards from a buoyant market for mergers and acquisitions. Fees and commissions rose by 20 percent to 282.9 million pounds

headline: Venture Funding Steady in Second Quarter
abstract: U.S. venture capital firms raised $8.23 billion in the second quarter of 2006, relatively steady with the $8.27 billion in the same period last year, according to a report released late Wednesday.

headline: Iron Mountain To Issue Long Term Debt
abstract: Boston’s Iron Mountain plans a public offering of $200 million in aggregate principal amount of senior subordinated notes due 2018.

headline: Board Stiffs: Are Directors Obsolete?
abstract: The boardroom tumult at Hewlett-Packard has prompted Fortune columnist Justin Fox to wonder why companies should have boards of directors. He studied that matter, and was unable to find a convincing answer.

headline: Royal Philips Sells Unit for $4.4 Billion
abstract: Dutch electronics giant Philips Electronics said on Thursday it is selling an 80.1 percent stake in its microchip unit to several private equity firms for $4.35 billion.

headline: Canadian Regulator Delays Decision on a Mining Bid
abstract: Bids by two companies vying for control of the Canadian nickel mining company Falconbridge have met with differing announcements from regulators. Xstrata of Switzerland was told Monday that Investment Canada, a government agency that reviews foreign takeovers, would take at least another 30 days to deliver a decision.

headline: Freescale Considers Rival Bids, as Debt Risk Triples
abstract: As two private equity groups engage in a $16 billion duel over Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker that was spun off from Motorola two years ago, the amount of debt that the winner may need for the deal is generating alarm.

headline: Riviera Shareholders Reject Buyout Offer
abstract: Casino operator Riviera Holdings said on Tuesday its shareholders did not approve its proposed buyout by Riv Acquisition Holdings for $17 a share, or $211.5 million.

headline: V.C. Moves from Making Green to Investing in Clean
abstract: Vinod Khosla is a man on a mission. And this time, it is more than just making lots of money.

headline: Wonkette’s Ingredients for a Successful Blog
abstract: Ana Marie Cox, who wrote the gossipy blog Wonkette.com, talks about her rule of thumb: don’t blog anything that’s going to get anyone fired, indicted or divorced.

headline: Winners of Casema Auction Want to Go Dutch Again
abstract: The British and American buyout shops that won the 2.1 billion euros ($2.8 billion) auction of Dutch cable company Casema earlier this week are considered front-runners to triumph in a second Dutch cable auction now under way for Essent Kabelcom.

headline: Midwestern Utilities Confirm Deal Talks
abstract: WPS Resources and Peoples Energy said Thursday they were in discussions about a potential business combination between the two gas and electric utilities. Shares of Chicago-based Peoples Energy surged 8.8 percent following the announcement, which confirmed a report earlier Thursday that WPS was in talks to acquire it. At that price, Peoples Energy has a market capitalization of about $1.5 billion.

headline: Citigroup Spins Off Buyout Unit
abstract: Citigroup said on Tuesday it is shedding its Citigroup Venture Capital buyout unit amid renewed activity among banks in the buyout sector and, according to The Financial News, to avoid conflicts with clients and its own new private equity fund.

headline: He Said, She Said, and They Won’t Say
abstract: With its leaks about leaks and investigations of investigations, the Hewlett-Packard scandal was already hard enough to keep track of.

headline: Peltz Wins Another Round in Heinz Fight
abstract: Nelson Peltz, the activist investor battling management at H.J. Heinz, on Thursday won a partial, but crucial, victory when an influential shareholder advisory firm urged Heinz shareholders to vote for three of Trian Group‘s five dissident nominees.

headline: N.C. Banks Winner Merger Approval
abstract: The North Carolina Banking Commission has given final approval to the proposed merger of the Bank of North Carolina and SterlingSouth, clearing the way for the two financial institutions to complete their union Thursday night. The two banks announced their intention to merge in February in a deal worth about $36 million.

headline: NASD Fines Morgan Stanley $2.9 Million
abstract: The NASD on Tuesday said it fined Morgan Stanley $2.9 million for what it called “widespread” violations of the regulator’s rules.

headline: Critic: Parsons Keeps AOL to Satisfy His Ego
abstract: MarketWatch media critic Jon Friedman wants to know why Dick Parsons, the chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, keeps trying to reconfigure the AOL rather than unloading it. “Deep down,” Mr. Friedman wrote on Wednesday, “he must know, better than anyone, that it’s hopeless.”

headline: Time Confirms Plan to Sell 18 Magazines
abstract: Time Warner‘s magazine division Time Inc. confirmed Tuesday it would sell 18 of its titles, including Parenting, Field & Stream and Outdoor Life, as part of a move to focus on its biggest brands.

headline: Mets Owner Bogged Down in Bayou Suit
abstract: His team may be basking in the glow of the best record in the National League, but the New York Mets owner, Fred Wilpon, faces a dark cloud in his other life as a financier.

headline: With Mittal Lurking, Nippon Looks for Alliance
abstract: Nippon Steel, the world’s third-largest steelmaker, said it is studying expanding an alliance with South Korea’s Posco.

headline: Bank Of America, Almost Number One
abstract: There’s a legend on Wall Street that Hugh L. McColl Jr., Bank of America‘s storied former chairman, used to keep an “enemies list” tucked into his pocket — marching orders for who the bank must topple to become the biggest in the nation.

headline: New York Observer Deal Won’t Happen, 2 Sides Say
abstract: It appears that Robert De Niro will not be playing the real-life role of newspaper owner anytime soon. Talks are off between The New York Observer and Mr. De Niro’s partners, who had sought to become a major investor in the paper, both parties said Wednesday.

headline: Carlyle Backs Out of Guangdong Bank Bid, Report Says
abstract: The Carlyle Group is unlikely to participate further in a bid to take control of China’s Guangdong Development Bank, the latest twist in the battle for the bank which has now lasted for about a year, The Financial Times reported Tuesday.

headline: Of Youtube, MySpace, Eyeballs, Morons and Wildebeest
abstract: For Daniel Gross, who writes about business for Slate (and for The New York Times), the money and attention being lavished upon social-networking Web sites like MySpace, Facebook, and YouTube carries the stench of a previous era. “Big media types” are once again talking about “monetizing eyeballs,” he notes. And, he advises, “close those eyeballs for a moment, and it almost seems like 1999.”

headline: In M&A, More Deals, But Fewer Conditions
abstract: The number of mergers reviewed by federal antitrust agencies rose in 2005, but fewer deals ran into trouble with regulators than in previous years.

headline: Crow Holdings Sells Properties to G.E. Real Estate
abstract: Crow Holdings, the real estate investment firm headed by the Trammell Crow family of Dallas, said Tuesday that it would sell $2.2 billion of its properties to G.E. Real Estate.

headline: Hertz and Vanguard I.P.O.s Face Uncertain Outlook
abstract: Hertz and the Vanguard Car Rental Group, the operator of the National Car Rental and Alamo Rent A Car brands, are both planning public offerings at a time when the rental car industry faces a major business shift:

headline: U.K.’s Doughty Hanson Eyes TV Targets
abstract: British private equity group Doughty Hanson is plotting to assemble a 400 million pound ($755 million) TV empire that could include bids for Scottish Media Group and UTV, the quoted broadcasters that are considering a merger.

headline: Sun Valley Diary: Gabelli Speaks (a Little)
abstract: The real world intruded for a moment on the high-level networking here at Sun Valley, when news broke that the terms of money manager Mario Gabelli’s settlement with the Justice Department had been announced. Under the settlement, Mr. Gabelli and various companies affiliated with him agreed to pay $130 million to resolve charges that he helped arrange fraudulent bids in auctions for wireless spectrum licenses held by the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Barclay’s Held Buyout Talks With Torex, but That’s All Over Now
abstract: Some directors of Torex Retail have been in talks with Barclays Private Equity about taking the software company private. The private equity arm of Barclays Capital recently held discussions with Torex’s management team about a buyout of the business, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Australian Pipeline Outbids Rival for GasNet
abstract: In a move to secure a network that will allow it to boost gas volumes from Moomba in central Australia to Sydney, Australian Pipeline Trust, the nation’s biggest owner of natural gas pipelines, offered A$452 million ($344 million) for GasNet, outbidding a rival offer from Commonwealth Bank of Australia‘s money management unit.

headline: Investors Gobble Up Bank of China Shares
abstract: Bank of China‘s shares made a strong debut Wednesday in Shanghai, surging 23 percent in the mainland’s biggest initial public offering.

headline: Murdoch to Launch MySpace, Chinese-Style
abstract: Rupert Murdoch said on Tuesday that his wife, Wendy Deng, was working with senior News Corporation executives to help bring the company’s popular MySpace social networking site to China.

headline: U.K. Parliament Calls Emergency Debate on NatWest Three
abstract: The U.K. House of Commons will hold an emergency debate on the extradition of three bankers to the U.S. on Enron Corp.-related fraud charges.

headline: Amid Buyout Speculation, Weyerhaeuser Unveils Spinoff
abstract: Weyerhaeuser and Canada’s Domtar have agreed to bring together their fine-paper businesses to form what would be the biggest supplier of uncoated freesheet paper in North America, the companies said Wednesday.

headline: Air China Sets Price for I.P.O.
abstract: Air China set the price range for its domestic initial public offering, with the national flag carrier aiming to raise up to 8 billion yuan ($1 billion) from the share issue.

headline: With the Future Uncertain, CompassCare Shuts Down
abstract: CompassCare, a maker of health care software, said that it has ceased operations, VentureWire reported. Rick Valentine, chief executive of CompassCare, declined to discuss the details of the shutdown, but offered a hint about what will happen with the company’s I.P. “The developers have it in hand and will continue to work with the technology and customers,” he said.

headline: Intel Will Hold onto Its Memory Chips
abstract: Intel, the world’s top computer chip maker, denied speculation on Thursday it might spin off and list its memory chip business. “We are not currently thinking about those kind of things,” Chief Executive Paul Otellini said when asked if Intel might make an initial public offer of shares in the memory chip business.

headline: Big Names Pull Cash from V.C. Fund Over Political Contributions
abstract: A venture capital fund based in Century City, Calif., backed by the likes of Harvard, Boeing and other big-league investors, and consulting with such disparate advisers as the Columbia University business school dean and KISS singer Gene Simmons, has run into trouble over allegations that its founders solicited political contributions form their start-ups.

headline: Niveus Gets Cash Injection From Intel
abstract: Niveus Media, a maker of high-performance media products for home digital entertainment, said Thursday it received an undisclosed amount of funding from Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of Intel.

headline: Former N.Y.S.E. Trader Takes the Stand in Fraud Suit
abstract: A former New York Stock Exchange floor trader charged with securities fraud took the stand in his own defense on Wednesday, telling a jury that he had never intentionally ordered illegal trading that cheated investors.

headline: An Insider’s Look at Software Design
abstract: I found these notes from a panel that featured ex-Apple and ex-Microsoft software designers, discussing how Mac OS X and Vista came into existence.

headline: Ex-Paper Chief Gets 15-Year Term in Fraud
abstract: The former chief executive of American Tissue, Mehdi Gabayzadeh, was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison for organizing a fraud that cost banks and investors almost $300 million when the paper manufacturer collapsed.

headline: Swedish Investor Reportedly Has an Eye on Volvo
abstract: Shares in the truck maker Volvo rose Thursday after a newspaper reported that an investment fund was trying to drum up interest in a bid.

headline: Foster’s Pleads Ignorance to Takeover Proposals
abstract: Foster’s Group, Australia’s biggest beer and wine maker, said on Wednesday it was not aware of any takeover proposals, sending its shares down as much as 3 percent.

headline: Telmex Acquires 3.4 Percent Stake in Portugal Telecom
abstract: Mexican telecommunications giant Telmex has become Portugal Telecom‘s fifth-largest shareholder after buying a 3.4 percent stake, takeover target P.T. said on Friday.

headline: Uranium Player Goes Public in London
abstract: A Canadian mining business with operations in Kazakhstan plans to become Britain’s biggest listed pure uranium company when it joins the London Stock Exchange next week.

headline: Yahoo and Canaan Bring Cash to Bharat’s Altar
abstract: Venture capital firm Canaan Partners said Wednesday its new India office will invest in an online matrimonial service in India. Canaan Partners said the $8.6 million first round financing for the Bharat Matrimony Group is being joined by Yahoo.

headline: With Too Much Meat on the Market, Pork Producers Make a Deal
abstract: Smithfield Foods, the nation’s largest hog producer, said Monday it would acquire a smaller rival, Premium Standard Farms, in a cash and stock deal valued at about $810 million, including the assumption of about $117 million in debt.

headline: Finalists Emerge for Dubai Ports World’s U.S. Assets
abstract: Dubai Ports World will start a second round of bidding on Tuesday for its port assets in the United States, with Morgan Stanley, the Carlyle Group and SSA Marine among the finalists in the highly politicized sale, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Jones Apparel Auction Hits a Snag, Report Says
abstract: The auction for The Jones Apparel Group is near-death over price and concerns about the health of the company’s brands, which include Jones New York, Anne Klein and Nine West, The New York Post reported.

headline: A Safety Net for a High-Flying Buyout Market
abstract: Unlike the real estate world, the buyout business is a seller’s market these days. Private equity funds such as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone Group are awash in billions of dollars in cash and looking for public companies to acquire.

headline: GM’s Alliance Talks Put Ford in the Headlights
abstract: As the embattled auto maker General Motors considers what would be a historic alliance with Renault and Nissan, there was a growing sense that its archrival, Ford Motor, is feeling pressure to find a partner as well.

headline: Silicon Graphics Gets Approval to Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: Silicon Graphics, the once-high-flying computing business, released its reorganization plan Wednesday after approval by a United States bankruptcy court. With the ruling as well as exit financing from Morgan Stanley and General Electric Capital, the company plans to emerge from Chapter 11 next month.

headline: Former Enron Trader Expects to Raise $600 Million in First Day
abstract: Harry Arora, a former Enron trader and then a commodity portfolio manager at a leading hedge fund, is creating a new Greenwich, Conn.-based fund, Arcim Advisors.

headline: EchoStar in Settlement Talks With Networks
abstract: EchoStar Communications said Thursday hundreds of thousands of satellite TV subscribers will be affected if it is unable to resolve a long-standing dispute over the delivery of distant network programming.

headline: Party Crashers: Birthday E-Mail Lights Up London’s City
abstract: There is nothing inherently funny about being a Citigroup intern. Nor is there anything laughable, in itself, about throwing yourself a birthday party.

headline: HBOS and Reubens Win the Day in Battle for U.K. Homebuilder
abstract: HBOS and Simon and David Reuben have trumped Permira and Barclays Capital in the battle for McCarthy & Stone, offering 1.1 billion pounds ($2.1 billion) for the U.K.’s largest builder of retirement homes.

headline: Deutsche Bank Arm Shuts Down Philly Office
abstract: The investment arm of Deutsche Bank has closed its Philadelphia office and is transferring management of three high-yield-bond mutual funds to New York.

headline: Merrill’s Earnings Top Wall Street Estimates
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that its second-quarter profits climbed 42 percent as the giant brokerage firm managed a strong performance in its proprietary stock trading despite a downturn in the markets.

headline: Now Batting: Mets and Yankees at Municipal Bond Plate
abstract: The Yankees and Mets will take turns at bat in the municipal bond market this week as the two New York City baseball teams sell about $1.57 billion of bonds to finance the construction of new stadiums.

headline: Some V.C.’s Would Like You to Know You Stink
abstract: Humorous voice messages that inform friends of their bad breath or body odor may not seem like a big business opportunity.

headline: New Challenge Ahead of Rosneft I.P.O.
abstract: As the Russian oil company Rosneft prepares to roll out its $11.6 billion initial public offering, the company faces a legal assault that may complicate matters, The Financial Times reported.

headline: As Cruise Exits, Hedge Funds Step In
abstract: Who’s afraid of Tom Cruise? Not hedge funds, apparently.

headline: Top Homeland Security Privacy Official Jumps to Private Practice
abstract: The top privacy officer at the Department of Homeland Security will join the Washington, D.C., office of the law firm Hunton & Williams in September.

headline: Philip Morris Sues Tiny Rival for Imitation
abstract: Philip Morris, the nation’s biggest cigarette maker, is suing one of the smallest, a logging-company owner on the Yakama Indian Reservation, over a cigarette pack closely resembling that of Marlboro.

headline: Qimonda Shares Debut Slightly Higher after I.P.O. Price Cut
abstract: Shares in German memory chip maker Qimonda debuted at $13.50 on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, slightly above the issue price which the company had been forced to cut to $13 by weak demand.

headline: Mutual Funds Put Their Money on Private Equity
abstract: The unending search for higher returns has driven many mutual fund managers to place bets on private equity investments.

headline: Getting Hung Up on the Apple-Microsoft War
abstract: Two new operating systems from Apple and Windows are inspiring fierce arguments about which is better. But as far as I can tell, there is no real war.

headline: G.M. Cleared to Start Talks With Renault, Nissan
abstract: General Motors‘s board of directors has voted to start exploratory discussions with Renault and Nissan Motor on a potential alliance between the three automakers, GM announced Friday. The GM board authorized the company’s management to ”weigh the potential benefits of such an alliance in order to assist the board in its decision making,” George Fisher, a member of the board, said in a statement.

headline: Is Dealmaking Getting Harder in China?
abstract: A new set of rules governing mergers and acquisitions in China could make it even more difficult for foreign companies to take stakes in the world’s fastest-growing, and toughest, market, The Financial Times’s Lex column argues. But that’s not to say there might not be some good as well.

headline: Cruise Gets First Funds for Projects
abstract: Tom Cruise showed Hollywood the money yesterday, with his independent production company announcing that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.

headline: Coles Myer Receives $12.5 Billion Buyout Bid
abstract: Coles Myer, Australia’s second-largest retailer, said Tuesday it received a takeover offer from a group of buyout funds news reports have valued at about A$16 billion ($12.5 billion).

headline: Sun Valley Diary: Even Moguls Like Free Stuff
abstract: Kenneth Li of Reuters may have uncovered Meg Whitman’s secret agenda for attending this year’s Sun Valley conference: The eBay chief executive may hope to boost the subscriber base of Skype, the Internet phone services eBay bought for $2.6 billion last year, one mogul at a time.

headline: Countersuit by Hollinger Claims Fraud
abstract: Hollinger said yesterday that it was countersuing the newspaper publisher Hollinger International in Federal District Court in Chicago, contending there was fraud in the transfer of two newspapers to the publisher in the late 1990’s.

headline: 2 Rivals Authorize G.M. Talks
abstract: The boards of Nissan and Renault voted Monday to explore a historic three-way alliance with General Motors, putting pressure on the embattled automotive giant to decide whether it wants two foreign companies, and their charismatic chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, to play a role in its revamping.

headline: Ahead of Possible I.P.O., CoreOptics Scores $28 Million
abstract: CoreOptics, a German designer and manufacturer of optical networking chips and subsystems, closed a $28 million Series D financing as it contemplates going public in 2007 with the help of a new lead investor, GIMV.

headline: Xstrata Replaces Falconbridge Board as Its C.E.O. Resigns
abstract: Xstrata has taken over Falconbridge‘s board of directors and accepted the resignation of its chief executive, three days after acquiring a majority of the Canadian mining company’s stock, it said on Thursday.

headline: Lazard Banker Offered Chairmanship at Barclays, Report Says
abstract: Marcus Agius, the veteran investment banker and grandee of London’s City, is being lined up to take over from Matt Barrett as chairman of Barclays Bank, The Times of London reported.

headline: Bidder for Gateway Operations Has Been Selling Stake
abstract: Lap Shun Hui, the eMachines founder who made an unsolicited $450 million offer for Gateway‘s retail operations Wednesday, has been selling some of his holding in Gateway since March.

headline: EuroZinc and Lundin See a Bright Future Together
abstract: EuroZinc Mining and Lundin Mining on Monday agreed to merge in a stock deal that will create a copper and zinc producer with a market capitalization of about $3 billion.

headline: Hedge Funds Are Back (Were They Ever Gone?)
abstract: The hedge fund party seemed to be quieting down not so long ago. Returns were flagging. Blowout start-ups were fading from memory.

headline: ‘Big Brother’ Producer Is Watching Six Buyout Firms
abstract: Six private equity firms have been shortlisted to hold talks with Endemol executives about a 1.8 billion euro ($2.3 billion) management buyout of the “Big Brother” producer.

headline: 2 Japanese Banks Report Mixed Results
abstract: Japan’s two biggest banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and rival Mizuho Financial Group, reported mixed earnings results Monday, although both credited the revived economy for helping reduce bad loans.

headline: Santander Raises Stake in Sovereign Bancorp of Philadelphia
abstract: Santander Central Hispano, Spain’s biggest bank, raised its stake in Sovereign Bancorp of Philadelphia to about 24 percent, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Goldman Employees Hit Up for $10 Billion Fund
abstract: It’s not exactly like contributing to the birthday-party fund for Bob in accounting, but Goldman Sachs is asking employees to pony up for a new arrival. Of course, this one may end up being a lot more rewarding.

headline: Merrill’s HCA Hat Trick Showcases Its Private-Equity Push
abstract: Though Goldman Sachs has set the standard for triple plays over the years, Merrill Lynch‘s starring role in the titanic $33 billion HCA buyout caps the investment bank’s own efforts to score more hat tricks, according to TheStreet.com’s Lauren Rae Silva.

headline: After Takeover Talks Fail, Canada’s BCE May Opt for Telesat  I.P.O.
abstract: Canadian telecom BCE is pressing ahead with a C$1 billion ($904 million) initial public offering of its Telesat Canada unit this fall after talks broke down with potential buyers of the world’s fifth-largest commercial satellite operator.

headline: For Merrill Analysts, Euronext Question Weighs on NYSE
abstract: John Thain may say he is “comfortable” about the NYSE Group‘s plans to merge with Euronext, but analysts at Merrill Lynch have a few nagging doubts.

headline: Bain Buys Applied Systems
abstract: Bain Capital has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Applied Systems from Vista Equity Partners in a secondary buyout. The price was undisclosed, but The Deal said the transaction was worth about $675 million.

headline: Putting Philosophy to the Test
abstract: Philosophy Cosmetics, a maker of pricey lotions, hair-care and makeup products known for whimsical names such as Hope in a Jar and Grace, is on the block, according to The Daily Deal. The Phoenix-based company’s Ebitda is $45 million, and it is expected to be sold at a multiple of 10 times that, sources told The Deal.

headline: Mittal Must Buy Out Arcelor’s Brazil Unit, Regulator Rules
abstract: One of the biggest obstacles to the long, twisted $38 billion merger between the steelmaking giants Arcelor and Mittal has just gotten a little higher.

headline: P&G Sells Sure Deodorant Brand
abstract: Procter & Gamble has again turned to Innovative Brands to take an unwanted product off its hands.

headline: Is an ImClone Sale in the Works?
abstract: Some option players piled into the calls of ImClone Systems, hoping to profit from a share rally triggered by talk the biotechnology company is about to go on sale, option traders said on Thursday. One analyst told Reuters that the rumors about an imminent sale have heated up after the company’s board met earlier in the week.

headline: U.K. Businessmen Assail Blair over NatWest Three Extradition
abstract: Business leaders have been lining up to condemn a one-sided extradition treaty that has sent shock waves through Britain’s boardrooms. The heads of companies with even the slightest connection with America are looking at the so-called NatWest Three and thinking: there but for the grace of God go I, the Telegraph writes.

headline: Barclays and Permira Up Bid for U.K. Developer
abstract: Barclays Capital and Permira have raised their offer for retirement-home developer McCarthy & Stone to 1.06 billion pounds ($1.97 billion) to fend off a rival approach by U.K. billionaire investors Simon and David Reuben.

headline: Chicago Options Exchange to Launch Stock Market
abstract: As some the world’s major stock exchanges consider their merger options, the Chicago Board Options Exchange has announced plans to get into the business as well. The Chicago exchange, which is the largest venue for options trading in the United States, said Thursday it would start up a stock exchange through a partnership with four other companies. The partners are Interactive Brokers Group, LaBranche & Company, Susquehanna International Group and VDM Specialists. The Chicago firm hopes to launch the exchange in early 2007, provided the Securities and Exchange Commission approves.

headline: For Chicago Exchanges, Merger Talks Lead to Lawsuit
abstract: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said Thursday that it held discussions on a “business combination” with the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, but called them off Wednesday just “a few hours” before CBOT Holdings filed a lawsuit against the options exchange.

headline: At Amaranth, a Calm Facade (and a Security Guard)
abstract: How does it look when billions of dollars vanish in a puff of methane? That is what DealBook’s Michael de la Merced trekked to the outer reaches of Greenwich, Conn., to find out.

headline: Two More Companies Announce Further Backdating Troubles
abstract: Two companies implicated in the widening stock-options backdating morass said that they face further troubles over the controversial practice.

headline: Lost in Translation: Baidu’s Chinese I.P.O.
abstract: Baidu, often called “China’s Google,” will not be selling its shares in China, contrary to a report from Reuters, the company’s investor relations manager said.

headline: Longview Fibre Mulls Asset Sale
abstract: Longview Fibre, which had rejected an unsolicited takeover proposal from two private-equity firms, said it may put itself up for sale or shed some assets.

headline: Phelps May Partner Up for High Inco Bid, Report Says
abstract: The board of Phelps Dodge has directed its executives and advisers to review some new strategies for its attempted takeover of Inco, one of which calls for the addition of a bidding partner.

headline: Investors Reap Big Gains in Sale of Cramer Systems
abstract: Sprinkling $27 million into Cramer Systems Group, investors are arranging to sell the London-based network management software company to Amdocs for about $375 million in cash.Kennet Venture Partners Managing Director David Carratt said Kennet invested $6 million in Cramer, which will return a little over 10 times the investment, or $60 million. “This represents the kind of reward you can get if you’re a patient supportive investor,” Carratt said.

headline: Bear Stearns Names Heads of Global Equities
abstract: Bear Stearns, aiming to consolidate its equities business, named Bruce Lisman and Steven Meyer as co-heads of global equities on Wednesday.

headline: Citigroup and Societe General Prepare Revised Offers for Chinese Bank
abstract: Citigroup and Societe Generale were set to submit revised, rival bids for China’s Guangdong Development Bank on Thursday, with each seeking a stake of up to 20 percent, banking sources said.

headline: Prodi Jeered Over Telecom Italia
abstract: Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy defended himself Thursday at a noisy session of Parliament called to determine whether he had sought to meddle in the restructuring plan of Telecom Italia, one of the largest private companies in the country.

headline: Barrick Gold Goes Hostile on NovaGold
abstract: Barrick Gold has set in motion a $1.29 billion hostile takeover bid for NovaGold Resources – a move that would consolidate its mineral plays in Alaska and British Columbia.

headline: A Falling Out Between Wal-Mart Co-Defendants
abstract: So much for honor among, er, co-conspirators.

headline: 2 Firms Price I.P.O.s at Discount, While Alien Backs Out
abstract: Crystal River Capital and GeoMet priced their initial public offerings at a discount on Friday, and Alien Technology failed to price altogether as the summer heat continues to dry up the market for initial public offerings.

headline: Venali Files Suit Agains J2 Global and Catch Curve
abstract: Venali has filed suit against J2 Global Communications and Catch Curve, alleging violations of Federal antitrust, trademark competitiveness and patent laws.

headline: Onex Bets $575 Million on Aon Warranties Division
abstract: Onex said on Friday that it is making its first big push into the insurance business with a $575 million purchase of a division of Aon, which specializes in warranties. Onex is paying $575 million and assuming about $225 million in debt.

headline: Valassis Gets Direct with Advo
abstract: The marketing company Valassis Communications said on Thursday that it was buying Advo, the nation’s largest direct-mail marketer, for $1.2 billion.

headline: Justice Department Reviews Corporate Prosecution Rules
abstract: A Justice Department official on Tuesday defended the tactics used by federal prosecutors taking on corporations in the post-Enron era, but he also indicated that the agency might consider changes to the agency’s guidelines.

headline: Hong Kong Real Estate Firm Finally Completes Its Stock Offer
abstract: Shui On Land, owned by a Hong Kong billionaire, Vincent Lo, raised 6.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($797 million) in its delayed initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Apple Looks to Hearing As It Delays Its Latest Filing
abstract: Apple Computer will seek a hearing before the Nasdaq Stock Market after being told a delay in filing a quarterly report violates listing requirements.

headline: Who’s Afraid of China?
abstract: Is China really getting less competitive?

headline: After Failed Deal, Exelon Chief Looks for New Target
abstract: Just over a week after Exelon dropped its proposed merger with a New Jersey utility, John Rowe, Exelon’s chief executive, says he is eager to find another company to acquire.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Bubble Sitters Rent — and Wait
abstract: There are lots of new jobs in Silicon Valley, so how come home sales in this famously expensive real estate market are sagging? The Red Herring reports that in San Mateo County, the home of many venture-capital firms and the technology startups they invest in, the number of houses sold has fallen by 17 percent so far this year. Prices have even slipped, though they are hardly a bargain: The average home price declined from $759,000 to $754,000 on average.

headline: Biovail Asked for Punishment of Critical Analyst, Report Says
abstract: Executives at controversial drug company Biovail demanded the suspension of a critical Banc of America Securities analyst who soon after was fired by the financial giant, according to The New York Post.

headline: Buyout Boom Makes for Bondholder Minefield
abstract: Too much “event risk” is being created by too many events — leveraged buyouts, debt-financed acquisitions and share buybacks, according to Carol Levenson, a co-founder and director of research at Gimme Credit, an independent bond-research firm. The problem, she writes in the latest issue of Barron’s, is that corporate bondholders aren’t getting paid enough for the risk.

headline: Brocade and the ‘No Gain, No Pain’ Defense
abstract: While much of the debate over the growing investigations into stock-options backdating revolves around whether the practice is illegal, the White Collar Crime Prof Blog’s Peter J. Henning takes a look at the securities fraud charges leveled against former Brocade Communications officials from a different angle.

headline: Unit of Citigroup Fined $1.1 Million
abstract: Securities regulators ordered a division of Citigroup to pay $1.1 million in fines and restitution Thursday to settle charges that it allowed more than 100 brokers to submit false disability claims for customers so they would not have to pay certain mutual fund fees.

headline: Motorola Acquires Video-on-Demand Technology Firm
abstract: Motorola said on Tuesday it will acquire privately held Broadbus Technologies, a provider of technology for on-demand video for multiple devices.

headline: Gabelli Gets Back in the Game
abstract: Money manager Mario Gabelli, who earlier this month reached a settlement of charges that he had defrauded the government in an auction of wireless licenses, has won approval to participate in another auction this month, government records show.

headline: Reinsurer Plans I.P.O. for OneBeacon Unit
abstract: OneBeacon Insurance Group, a property and casualty insurance writer, hopes to sell as much as $500 million of stock in an initial public offering. The shares would be sold by OneBeacon’s parent company, Bermuda-based reinsurer White Mountains Insurance Group, which will keep control of OneBeacon after the I.P.O. through a special class of stock, according to a preliminary prospectus filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Yum Gobbles Up Whitbread’s Stake in Pizza Hut
abstract: Yum Brands, owner of restaurant chains including Taco Bell and KFC, said Monday it will buy out Whitbread‘s stake in their 50-50 U.K. Pizza Hut joint venture for $183 million plus the assumption of $25 million in debt and liabilities.

headline: A.M.D. to Buy ATI Technologies
abstract: In a transaction that will reshape the semiconductor industry, Advanced Micro Devices announced Monday that it would buy ATI Technologies for $5.4 billion in cash and stock.The deal will expand A.M.D.’s business into graphic chipsets used in high-end PC’s for playing video games and in workstations used in design work or to create video games and movie animation as well as chipsets for cellphones and handheld devices.

headline: Limelight Gets $130 Million, Mostly From Goldman
abstract: “Well-placed technology sources say that Limelight is in the process of raising a monster round of financing, which would value the company well in excess of $200 million,” wrote the blogger Om Malik back on July 11, in an item about the online content-delivery outfit’s legal battles with its chief rival, the much-larger Akamai.

headline: Music V.C. to Sing a Scottish Tune
abstract: Whimsical Scottish rockers Travis are to see their forthcoming album backed to the tune of 4 million pounds with a little help from Lord Lloyd-Webber’s ex-business partner.

headline: Emdeon Sells Healthcare Software Business
abstract: Emdeon late Tuesday said it has agreed to sell its practice services unit, a software and services vendor that caters to physicians and small health clinics, to Sage Software for $565 million in cash.

headline: Big Hedge Funds, Getting Bigger
abstract: Gauging the growth of the hedge fund industry is a notoriously tricky affair. This is partly because many of these investment pools are not required to give up financial information. It also does not help that the term “hedge fund” has no formal definition.

headline: A Boon, a Bane in New Rules for Mergers in China
abstract: Business forays into China could become both easier and harder under Commerce Ministry rules covering foreign investment and takeovers published on Wednesday.

headline: Texas Pacific to Buy Aluminum Maker Aleris for $1.7 Billion
abstract: An aluminum products maker and recycler, Aleris International, said on Tuesday it had agreed to be acquired by a buyout firm, the Texas Pacific Group, in a $1.7 billion deal.

headline: High Noon for 2 Former Merrill Brokers in Texas Court
abstract: The battle of the sexes at Merrill Lynchis moving to a Texas courtroom, with a former sales manager arguing that a female ex-broker and her lawyer schemed to get him fired so she could snatch his high-paying job.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Wins Antitrust Suit
abstract: Johnson & Johnson won an antitrust lawsuit yesterday that had accused the company of illegally using its sutures monopoly to increase sales of other surgical products.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Lose Top Female Banker
abstract: A highly ranked investment banker at Deutsche Bank who is one of the most senior women in London’s financial district is giving up her day-to-day management responsibilities, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

headline: More Defections at Goldman
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s head of European buyouts, Richard Sharp, plans to leave the securities firm in at least the second departure of a senior banker since Lloyd Blankfein took over as chief executive officer last month, Bloomberg News said .

headline: Lenovo Continues Its Raid on Dell’s Top Ranks, Hiring a Fourth Executive
abstract: Lenovo, the world’s third-largest computer maker, has hired its fourth Dell executive in little more than a week, continuing to poach top officers from its bigger rival.

headline: Skype Strikes Again
abstract: Skype is offering free calls from your Mac or PC to traditional landlines and cellphones in the U.K., Mexico or Japan.

headline: Guidant Settles Device Suit
abstract: Guidant, the maker of implanted heart devices, settled a fraud suit over its recalled defibrillator for an undisclosed amount, a plaintiffs’ lawyer said yesterday.

headline: Lehman Hires Internet Banking Heads
abstract: Six years after quitting the firm to become an executive at supply-chain software maker VerticalNet, David Kostman is back. Lehman said Monday that Mr. Kostman has rejoined the firm as a managing director and head of its global Internet investment banking group.

headline: Amvescap Completes PowerShares Buy
abstract: An asset manager, Amvescap, said it has completed its acquisition of the fast-growing PowerShares Capital Management in a move designed to bolster its presence in the mushrooming exchange-traded-fund business.

headline: MySpace Worth $20 Billion? It Could Happen, Analyst Says
abstract: MySpace, the online hangout that News Corporation acquired last year for about $600 million, has already “created billions of value for shareholders,” Jordon Rohan of RBC Capital Markets wrote in a research note on Wednesday.

headline: If Falconbridge Bid Fails, Phelps Willing to Work With Xstrata
abstract: Phelps Dodge chief executive officer Steven Whisler is not giving up the takeover quest for Falconbridge, but he conceded that if rival bidder Xstrata wins the day he would favor working jointly with the Swiss mining company in the Sudbury nickel basin.

headline: S.E.C. Investigates Pirate Capital Hedge Fund, Report Says
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether a hedge fund Pirate Capital, violated securities laws by failing to properly disclose it was selling stocks, The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday.

headline: S.E.C Accuses 3 Ex-Officers at Reinsurer of Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused three former executives of RenaissanceRe Holdings, a reinsurance company based in Bermuda, of using fraudulent accounting to improve earnings reports.

headline: NTL-Virgin Mobile Merger Complete
abstract: The combined NTL–Virgin Mobile TV, cable and telecoms business will be re-branded under the Virgin name from early next year at the latest, after the merger of the two companies was completed Tuesday.

headline: Coca-Cola Eyes Deal for Philippines Unit
abstract: Coca-Cola is in talks to take over management and control of the soft drinks arm of the Philippines company San Miguel, a Coke official said on Monday.

headline: First Reserve Raises $7.8 Billion Energy Fund
abstract: Private-equity firm First Reserve said on Wednesday it had launched a record $7.8 billion fund to invest in energy equipment, manufacturing and service companies.

headline: Universal Mulls Buying Bertelsmann Music Label
abstract: Universal Music Group, the world’s largest record business, is among the bidders preparing to submit offers for Bertelsmann‘s music publishing business by Monday’s first round deadline.

headline: Keyspan Shareholders OK Takeover
abstract: Keyspan shareholders gave their consent Thursday to an $11.8 billion takeover by Britain’s National Grid, the Brooklyn-based company said.

headline: TPG Playing for Field Container
abstract: The Texas Pacific Group is expected to announce later this month it is buying Field Container, a maker of folding cartons and specialty paper packaging based in Elk Grove, Ill. TPG will likely combine Field Container with its portfolio company, Altivity Packaging.

headline: Insider Trading Alleged in Petco Buyout
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it sued an investor or investors for allegedly making illegal insider trades ahead of the announcement of Petco Animal Supplies‘ $1.8 billion buyout deal.

headline: Seeing Wall Street Through the 9/11 Lens
abstract: It is easy to conclude that the wrenching events of Sept. 11, 2001, had few long-term effects on Wall Street or the financial-services industry, Michael Santoli writes in the latest issue of Barron’s. But he begs to differ –- and offers a long, convincing article detailing the ways in which everything changed.

headline: Oracle Sees Acquisition of Portal Software
abstract: The Oracle Corporation said on Monday it would complete its $220 million acquisition of Portal Software. Oracle offered $4.90 a share for Portal, which sells billing software to media and communications companies.

headline: G.M. Said to Be Wary of Alliance
abstract: General Motors has raised doubts in its talks with Renault of France and Nissan Motor of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result from such an agreement, a senior executive at Renault told The New York Times on Monday.

headline: Peltz Says He Wants Only a Say in Heinz’s Future
abstract: Nelson Peltz, the billionaire investor fighting a pitched battle to get on the board of H.J. Heinz, contends he has relatively modest goals in what has become one of the most vituperative proxy fights of the year.

headline: 3M to Buy Back $1 Billion in Shares
abstract: The diversified manufacturer 3M said on Tuesday its board of directors had approved the buyback of an additional $1 billion in stock.

headline: 2 Are Charged in Criminal Case on Stock Options
abstract: And so it begins.

headline: Alcatel to Critics: Allow Us to Rebut
abstract: With a week to go before a crucial vote on a deal that would redraw the landscape of the telecommunications equipment industry, Alcatel on Wednesday rebutted criticism from a French investment advisory group about its planned takeover of Lucent and insisted that the deal would be good for shareholders.

headline: Goldman Bulks Up Asia Leverage With New Hire
abstract: Goldman Sachs has signaled its intentions to build its Asian loan business, bringing in Nelson Lo to the firm in a newly created role in its financing group.

headline: NASD Warily Eyes Blank Check I.P.O.’s
abstract: A type of initial public offering that vanished in the 1990’s in a wave of scandals is making a comeback, and regulators say they are concerned investors may be defrauded again.

headline: Bids for Bayer Unit  Pass $1 Billion Mark, Report Says
abstract: German drugs and chemicals group Bayer has received bids for its H.C. Starck chemicals unit that are well above 1 billion euros ($1.3 billion), Reuters reported.

headline: Private Equity Giants to Meet with Coles Myer Board, Report Says
abstract: Buyout firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Carlyle Group and CVC Asia Pacific are meeting with the board of Coles Myer, Australia’s second-biggest retailer, with a view to tabling an offer for the company which could be worth as much as $13 billion.

headline: Janus Surprisingly Shutters Top-Flying Fund
abstract: Investment companies sometimes bury their mistakes, killing off their evil spawn, the funds that never produced good results, or that once attracted attention but have since fallen and can’t get up.

headline: Institutional Investors Lend Credibility to Rosneft Float
abstract: Although Rosneft is hearing complaints from institutional investors who say the share price is too high and while the Russian oil giant has interest from plenty of other sources, there are reasons to keep those grumbling institutions around. Chief among them is legitimacy, says Breakingviews.

headline: U.K. Gambling Site Chief Charged with Racketeering
abstract: The C.E.O. of BetOnSports, a prominent Internet gambling company that is publicly traded in Britain, was arrested in the United States and charged with racketeering conspiracy for participating in an illegal gambling enterprise. The move represents a sharp escalation of prosecutors’ crackdown on Internet gambling. Shares of several other online gaming businesses declined sharply on Monday.

headline: The $900 Million Facebook Dilemma
abstract: Is Facebook really worth $1 billion? Analysts easily agree the answer is yes. Whether it’s worth that much to Yahoo, however, is a more complicated question.

headline: Ralphs to Pay $70 Million in Identity Fraud Plea Bargain
abstract: Ralphs Grocery agreed to pay $70 million in restitution and fines as part of a plea agreement involving charges of illegally hiring hundreds of workers under fake names during a 2003 strike and lockout. As part of the deal with federal prosecutors, the chain plead guilty to conspiracy and identity fraud, and violating laws involving employee benefits and record-keeping for the Social Security Administration and Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Biodiesel Fuel Maker Gets $100 Million in Private Equity
abstract: As the price of crude oil hovers at more than $70 a barrel, alternative fuels are getting more attention from private equity investors, as DealBook highlighted last week. This week, more investors climbed aboard in Ralston, Iowa, and plunked down $100 million to do so.

headline: Indian IT Firm Takes I.P.O. on the Road
abstract: Tech Mahindra has started to market an initial public offering of up to $100 million, which it hopes will draw investor interest both because of its position as one of India’s leading providers of IT services to the telecom industry and because of its high-profile controlling shareholders.

headline: Bain, Apax Join Group Buying Philips Unit
abstract: Two more private equity firms have signed up to be part of the consortium acquiring the semiconductor business of Dutch electronics giant Royal Philips Electronics.

headline: Hopes Dim for Big Satellite TV Hook-Up
abstract: It was already a longshot, but the prospect of a merger between Echostar and DirecTV is growing more distant by the minute.

headline: S.E.C. Mulls Charges Against Mercury Directors
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission staff is considering civil charges against a former finance chief and three directors of Mercury Interactive, one of the earliest companies to become ensnared in the widening controversy over suspicious timing of stock option awards to top executives.

headline: Viacom Chairman Says Stock Sales Are Formality, Not a Valuation
abstract: When the major shareholder in a company sells shares as that company’s stock price declines, it can be a warning flag to investors. But that is not the case at Viacom – which owns media properties including MTV, Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks – says Sumner M. Redstone, the company’s billionaire chairman.

headline: Codexis gets $37 Million for Research Center
abstract: Codexis said Thursday it raised $37 million in its series D round of venture funding.

headline: Barclays Sets Up New Trading Desks in London and N.Y.C
abstract: Barclays Capital has boosted its proprietary trading activity by setting up new desks in London and New York, The Times of London reported.

headline: Investment Banks Look West
abstract: Silicon Valley’s investment banking business is continuing to show signs of growth with the entry of one well-known New York firm and the expansion of another Wall Street heavyweight.

headline: Emphasys Nabs $18 Million in Funding
abstract: Emphasys Medical, which makes breathing devices for patients with emphysema, raised $18.4 million in its series E round of venture funding.

headline: Inflation Sign? Don’t Bet on It.
abstract: The surge in unit labor costs does not mean inflation is raging.

headline: Cullen/Frost Bankers Acquires Summit
abstract: Independent bank holding company Cullen/Frost Bankers, which runs the nation’s largest Texas-based national bank, on Monday said it has agreed to acquire Summit Bancshares, the holding company for Summit Bank, for about $363.5 million.

headline: Glaxo to Pay $70 Million to Settle Suits on Drug Prices
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, the pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $70 million in a national settlement of civil lawsuits that accused the company of inflating costs of several medicines, including its blockbuster Zofran nausea drug.

headline: Phelps Seeks to Shore Up Support For Record Mining Deal
abstract: From the air, bringing it all together must have seemed so simple. On Saturday, Steven Whisler, the head of Phelps Dodge, took a helicopter tour over the Sudbury basin. From the cockpit, he could see mining operations belonging to both Inco and Falconbridge. With his company’s proposed merger, everything would come together under one owner.

headline: Al Gore Joins With Yahoo for a Video Venture
abstract: Al Gore wants his YouTube.

headline: Sarbanes-Oxley Takes Flight This Weekend
abstract: Come Saturday, foes of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 will be able to commiserate on an international scale. Starting July 15, the law’s corporate governance regulations will start applying to foreign firms, Forbes.com’s Hannah Clark notes.

headline: Cash America Acquires an Online Lender
abstract: Cash America International said on Monday it had agreed to buy an online lender, CashNetUSA, for around $35 million.

headline: Hilton Considering Sale of Scandic Hotels in Northern Europe
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said on Wednesday it might sell all or part of its Scandic brand of hotels.

headline: China Mobile Cancels Millicom Plans, Leaving Lots of Questions
abstract: With China Mobile Communications pulling its $5.5 billion bid for Millicom, jitters have spread from the I.P.O. market to mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Bay Area Continues to Attract V.C. Investment
abstract: The Bay Area continues to rebound from the depths of the dot-com bust, according to an analysis of venture financings in the region conducted by the law firm Fenwick & West.

headline: Air America Denies Bankruptcy Rumors
abstract: Air America is denying intense rumors that the ratings-challenged progressive radio network will declare bankruptcy this week and attempt to reorganize to stay on the air for the November elections.

headline: MAN May Pony Up $11 Billion for Scania, Report Says
abstract: MAN, a German maker of commercial vehicles, may offer 9.4 billion euros ($11.9 billion) for rival Scania to become the region’s biggest truckmaker, Bloomberg News said.

headline: Ascent Solar Completes I.P.O.
abstract: Ascent Solar Technologies on Tuesday said it completed its initial public offering of 3 million units at $5.50 per unit, raising approximately $16.5 million.

headline: Volvo Revving Up for Acquisitions
abstract: Volvo, the world’s second-largest truck maker after DaimlerChrysler, has outlined ambitious plans for a series of acquisitions to broaden its product range, according to a report published yesterday.

headline: Bank of America Is Big — Now What?
abstract: Bank of America is getting a lot of attention these days thanks to the narrowing gap between its market value and that of longtime rival Citigroup. The Economist reports in its latest issue that Bank of America has taken to calling itself the “most profitable financial institution in the world”; late last week, The Wall Street Journal observed that, in terms of market cap, Bank of America could “potentially seize the lead at any time.”

headline: Intersouth Partners Sticks With CallMiner
abstract: Intersouth Partners has continued its financial support of Florida software firm CallMiner by joining a handful of other investors in a $10 million series B venture capital round. The Durham, N.C.-based venture capital firm also took part in CallMiner’s $2.8 million series A round two years ago.

headline: Image Entertainment Gets Debt Financing
abstract: Image Entertainment has closed on a $17 million convertible debenture financing with an institutional investor, the company said Thursday.

headline: Hedge Funds to Bail Oneida Out of Bankruptcy
abstract: Oneida, a marketer of flatware, glasses and other tabletop items, said Friday it has tentatively agreed to be acquired by two hedge funds for “at least $222.5 million.” The deal appears to be a strategy for resolving a clash between Oneida, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March, and a group of shareholders who claimed they were being short-changed by its reorganization plan.

headline: U.K. Investment Group Mulls Buying Newcastle Soccer Team
abstract: British investment firm Belgravia Group said on Monday it was considering buying Newcastle United, sending shares in the English soccer club soaring.

headline: Venture Capitalists Pouring Money in Life Sciences
abstract: In the second quarter of 2006, venture capitalists invested more money into more companies than they had in four years.

headline: Australian Insurer Buys U.K. Rivals
abstract: Insurance Australia Group, the nation’s largest auto and home insurer, agreed to pay A$350 million ($262 million) for Hastings Insurance Services and Advantage Insurance, entering the U.K. market.

headline: Dreier Acquires Boutique Bankruptcy Firm
abstract: Dreier, a New York law firm, has acquired a well-known bankruptcy boutique, Traub, Bonacquist & Fox, a firm with eight lawyers that is led by Paul Traub and has participated in several of the largest bankruptcies of the past several years, especially in the retail sector.

headline: A Well-Heeled Ferragamo Looks to List
abstract: An initial public offering is on the horizon for the Salvatore Ferragamo Group, and the company is going outside the family to help get it done.

headline: Clorox Names Coke Official to Be Chief
abstract: In another sign of the difficulties facing the Coca-Cola Company as it tries to revive its core franchise, the president of Coke’s North American unit, Donald R. Knauss, resigned yesterday to become chairman and chief executive of Clorox.

headline: Questions of Succession at Fidelity Turn Boston Rumor Mill
abstract: Boston isn’t especially rich when it comes to matters of corporate intrigue, now that most of the city’s biggest companies have been turned into field offices and subsidiaries. But there’s no doubt what question still prompts impassioned downtown debate: Who will run Fidelity Investments?

headline: Alwaleed Calls for Drastic Measures at Citigroup
abstract: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, the largest shareholder in Citigroup, said shareholder patience is wearing thin over rising costs at the largest U.S. bank.

headline: Apple Gets French Support in Music Compatibility Case
abstract: The French constitutional council, the country’s highest judicial body, has declared major aspects of the so-called iPod law unconstitutional, undermining some controversial aspects of the legislation.

headline: Dubai Firm in Talks to Buy Crescent Real Estate
abstract: It has been snapping up New York skyscrapers at a rapid pace in the past year. Now, Dubai’s Istithmar  may be poised to buy an entire real estate investment trust. REIT Newshound, a real estate trade newsletter, reported that Istithmar was in talks to buy Crescent Real Estate Equities, which owns office buildings and resort properties.

headline: G.M. Will Air Arguments Against Proposed Alliance
abstract: General Motors‘s management plans to air arguments against a proposed three-way alliance with Nissan Motor and Renault at a meeting with its board on Friday, Reuters reported. Chairman and chief executive Rick Wagoner is expected not to dismiss the proposed alliance outright and is set to launch a due diligence review.

headline: Trial Is Set in Suit to Nullify Direct-Mail Deal
abstract: A lawsuit in which the coupon company Valassis Communications seeks to cancel its $1.3 billion merger agreement with the direct-mail marketer Advo will go to trial in December, a judge ruled on Wednesday.

headline: BAE Systems Orders New Airbus Audit
abstract: BAE Systems has ordered an audit of Airbus to determine why the value of its 20 percent stake in the jet builder has fallen to 2.75 billion euro ($3.50 billion), from earlier estimates of about 4 billion euro.

headline: For the Fourth Time, Back Yard Burgers Says No to Persistent Suitors
abstract: Restaurant chain Back Yard Burgers has rejected a fourth offer by a same group of investors to acquire the company.

headline: Woolworths Buys Stake in New Zealand’s Warehouse Group
abstract: Woolworths, Australia’s biggest retailer, bought 10 percent of the Warehouse Group, the biggest publicly traded reailer in New Zealand, threatening efforts by the company’s founder to take Warehouse private.

headline: Spain Approves Bid by E.On, but Imposes 19 Conditions
abstract: Efforts by Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero to create a national champion in the energy industry suffered a setback on Friday after regulators here approved a bid by a German company, E.On, to acquire the Spanish electricity company Endesa. Still, the approval came with conditions that critics portrayed as an indirect form of protectionism.

headline: Motorola to Buy Symbol Technologies for $3.9 Billion
abstract: The telecommunications giant Motorola said Tuesday it would buy Symbol Technologies, a maker of hand-held bar-code readers and other mobile devices, for $3.9 billion, or $15 a share.

headline: Excuse Me While I Bid on this Song
abstract: A copyright and an original reel-to-reel recording of a never-before-released Jimi Hendrix song will be made available in an intellectual property auction in New York City this fall, along with patents from 3Com, I.B.M., Cree and others.

headline: Is Merrill Getting a Raw Deal?
abstract: Despite market turmoil, Merrill Lynch managed to report robust results in equities and mergers and acquisitions, and record overall revenues. But while Merrill Lynch’s second-quarter earnings put Citigroup in the shade, the investment banks is still trading a lower premium than its larger rival. Breakingviews thinks that undeserved.

headline: Phelps Dodge Reaches a Crossroads
abstract: All eyes are back on Phelps Dodge in a complicated intercontinental bidding war over two Canadian nickel miners.

headline: VW C.E.O. Urges Sweden’s Scania to Partner Up
abstract: Scania shares hit an all-time high on Monday as Volkswagen, the largest shareholder in the Swedish truckmaker, joined German rival MAN in suggesting that a new round of consolidation in the industry was looming.

headline: After Amaranth Meltdown, Eyes Turn to ICE
abstract: Lighter regulatory oversight at the InterContinental Exchange, the Atlanta-based electronic futures exchange, may have contributed to last week’s $6 billion loss at hedge fund Amaranth, some industry analysts say. The debate about commodities-trading rules comes as energy traders have been increasingly taking their business to the ICE rather than the New York Mercantile Exchange, which has stricter reporting requirements.

headline: Cerberus-Backed Paper Maker Postpones I.P.O.
abstract: NewPage Holdings, a coated-paper manufacturer controlled by hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management, said Friday that it postponed its initial public offering of stock because of “market conditions.” In previous regulatory filings, the company had said it hoped to raise as much as $320 million through the stock offering, which was one of the few I.P.O.’s scheduled to take place this week.

headline: Goldman Is a Tough Act for Deutsche to Follow
abstract: Deutsche Bank is finding out just how hard it is to be more like Goldman Sachs Group.

headline: Former Goldman Bankers Aim for Hedge Fund I.P.O.
abstract: A hedge fund group formed by former Goldman Sachs investment bankers Emmanuel Boussard and Emmanuel Gavaudan intends to list one of its fund companies on the Euronext exchange, The Financial Times reported. If they succeed, it will be the latest initial public offering in London to raise money for a hedge fund.

headline: Lawyers Seek to Throw Out Lay Conviction
abstract: Lawyers for Kenneth L. Lay, who died of a heart attack last month, asked a federal judge yesterday to throw out his conviction for orchestrating the fraud that destroyed Enron, the energy trading company he founded.

headline: Schering-Plough Said to Consider Bristol-Myers Deal
abstract: Schering-Plough is considering a merger with Bristol-Myers Squibb in what would be a union of two pharmaceuticals giants, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported, citing “three people with direct knowledge of Schering-Plough’s deliberations.”

headline: Parlux Selling Perry Ellis Fragrance Rights for $140 Million
abstract: Parlux Fragrances, which licenses celebrity products such as Paris Hilton perfume, said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell its Perry Ellis fragrance rights to Victory International for as much as $140 million.

headline: Things Look Bad, or Good
abstract: Can Wall Street stumble while high end apartments do well?

headline: 8 Brokers Charged With Fraud
abstract: Eight Wall Street stockbrokers have been indicted for allegedly defrauding hundreds of customers of at least $13 million over five years, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: In Diversification Move, Times Company Buys Baseline
abstract: The New York Times Company announced today the acquisition of Baseline StudioSystems, a leading online supplier of data and information about the movie and television industries.

headline: McDonald’s President Quits Unexpectedly
abstract: In a stunning announcement of another shake-up at the top, McDonald’s said late Wednesday that Mike Roberts, its well-regarded president and chief operating officer, resigned after nearly three decades and was replaced by Ralph Alvarez, head of its North American operations.

headline: Nasdaq Mulls Hostile Bid for London Exchange, Report Says
abstract: Is the Nasdaq considering going hostile in its bid to hook up with the London Stock Exchange?

headline: Rent-A-Center to Buy Rent Way for $567 Million
abstract: Rent-A-Center, the largest rent-to-own chain in the nation, said Tuesday it plans to purchase a rival, Rent Way, for about $567 million.

headline: F.C.C. to Approve Adelphia Sale to Comcast and Time Warner
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is set to approve the sale of the bankrupt Adelphia Communications to rival cable operators Comcast and Time Warner despite objections from consumer advocates, Reuters reported.

headline: Venture-Backed Startups Try to Advance Mobile Phones
abstract: Big media companies, from CBS Broadcasting to MTV Networks, made it plain during the CTIA Wireless conference last week that mobile phones need to be ready soon for prime time as a way to consume songs, images, and other media.

headline: Reforms May Redraw Battle Lines in Proxy Fights
abstract: Even as baseball card maker Topps was squaring off with activist shareholders at its annual meeting on Friday, a prominent law firm was predicting a big shift in the landscape of such proxy contests. “The convergence of three strands of reform appears poised to change the mechanics — and perhaps eventually the results — of shareholder voting in director elections,” lawyers at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen and Katz, an adviser on many big Wall Street deals, wrote in a recent article that appeared in the New York Law Journal.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Tread Lightly on Private Equity Turf
abstract: Can Morgan Stanley avoid angering the private equity gods?

headline: Televisa Won’t Rule Out New Univision Bid
