abstract: Mexican media company Televisa said Tuesday that there was still a possibility that it would make a fresh takeover offer for Univision, the United States-based broadcaster that a rival group won at an auction last month. Televisa suffered a major blow to its U.S. plans when a group of investors, including media mogul Haim Saban, edged it out with a $12.3 billion bid for Univision, which Televisa supplies with much of its Spanish-language programming.

headline: Macquarie, King of Infrastructure
abstract: Riding a growing craze for infrastructure investment, the Macquarie Bank of Australia has staked its claim as the world leader in the high-stakes field. What was a small regional bank less than a decade ago now oversees more than $66.7 billion through its specialty funds business worldwide, more than five times its own market capitalization.

headline: KPMG Strikes Back at Former Employees in Tax Shelter Case
abstract: The accounting firm KPMG struck back yesterday against 16 former employees and the federal judge overseeing their coming tax shelter trial, filing court papers seeking compensation from certain defendants and saying that it would appeal a ruling ordering a related trial over their legal fees.

headline: 3 at Comverse Charged in Stock Options Case
abstract: Perhaps, in hindsight, naming a company account after “Phantom of the Opera” was not a good idea.

headline: Alonso’s penalty…
abstract: Fernando Alonso has been penalized for an incident with Robert Doornbos during qualifying. He will have two seconds added to each of his lap-times in qualifying tomorrow – Q1, Q2, Q3.

headline: Salesforce.com Buys Start-Up With Google Links
abstract: Software provider Salesforce.com said on Tuesday that it has acquired start-up Kieden, which helps customers track sales leads generated with online advertisements on Google.

headline: SL Green Realty Will Acquire Reckson
abstract: Update: SL Green Realty said on Thursday it will acquire Reckson Associates Realty for $6 billion in cash, stock and the assumption of $2 billion of Reckson’s debt. SL Green would pay $43.31 per Reckson share in cash and stock. The transaction is expected to close in January 2007.

headline: Wilbur Ross, Buyer of Assets, Is Selling Own Firm
abstract: Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the New York investor who has made a fortune buying troubled companies – including much of the American steel industry – is selling his own firm in an effort to make it bigger.

headline: Cinemark May Buy Century to Create Theater Giant, Report Says
abstract: Privately held theater operators Cinemark and Century Theatres may be looking to join forces, creating one of the largest players in the movie-exhibition industry, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: How to Lower the Value of Your Stock Options
abstract: As U.S. companies faced the prospect of having to deduct stock options expenses from their profits starting in 2005, they scrambled to cut their costs.

headline: Oldcastle Buys Ashland Paving Unit
abstract: Chemicals company Ashland on Monday said it has agreed to sell the stock of subsidiary Ashland Paving and Construction to Oldcastle Materials for $1.3 billion.

headline: Truckmaker Scania Rejects $12.2 Billion Takeover Bid
abstract: The truckmaker Scania rejected a 9.6 billion euro ($12.2 billion) takeover bid from a German rival, MAN, on Monday. The bid also got a chilly reception from Investor AB, which has a 29 percent voting stake in Scania. The investment group said the offer did ”not reflect the fair value and potential of Scania.”

headline: Sun to Shine On Real Mex
abstract: Sun Capital Partners is close to acquiring Real Mex Restaurants, a casual-dining chain that owns and operates restaurants under such names as Acapulco, El Torito and Chevy’s Fresh Mex names, from primary shareholder Bruckmann Rosser Sherrill, according to LBO Wire.

headline: Settlement Reached With Credit Card Issuers
abstract: Two class-action law firms announced Wednesday that they have reached a $336 million agreement with Visa USA, MasterCard and a number of other credit and debit card issuers over charges for foreign currency conversions.

headline: 3i’s Success Sparks Takeover Rumors
abstract: With the news that 3i‘s 4.3 billion euro ($5.5 billion) has beaten its fundraising targets, whispers of a buyout bid have begun floating about, The Financial Times (cited by the Controlled Greed blog) reported Wednesday.

headline: Trump to Kepcher: You’re Fired! No, Really
abstract: Donald Trump fired his prim sidekick Carolyn Kepcher according to news reports. In a brief phone interview Thursday with USA Today, Mr. Trump declined to confirm that he fired Kepcher for letting TV stardom from Apprentice appearances go to her head to the point that it interfered with her job of operating Trump-owned golf courses.

headline: Just How Popular Is That Baby Name?
abstract: Looking for a name for your baby? Worried about tagging the poor kid with some tired, unhip name that’s on its way out?

headline: InterNap to Return to Nasdaq
abstract: InterNap Network Services has gotten approval to move back to Nasdaq by the end of September.

headline: Baby Items Retailer Cleans Up Its Debt
abstract: BabyUniverse, an online retailer and content publisher in the pregnancy, baby and toddler marketplace, said Wednesday it had completed a $5 million debt financing transaction with Hercules Technology Growth Capital.

headline: Big Trouble for Giant Imax
abstract: Troubles deepened Tuesday for Imax as the giant-screen film company was hit with a U.S. class-action lawsuit by shareholders over allegedly “false and misleading” financial statements.

headline: United May Have Trouble Finding a Merger Partner
abstract: Its parent company has reportedly hired Goldman Sachs to play matchmaker, but it remains far from certain that United Airlines will find a merger partner soon, according to a report in The Daily Deal.

headline: InSpa Sitting Pretty With New Funding
abstract: Seattle beauty spa chain InSpa has scored a $5 million equity investment from the Bay Area Equity Fund I LP, a venture capital fund managed by financial services giant J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Will Suitors Pay Court to Schering?
abstract: The buzz about Schering-Plough on Wall Street is that the company is in play.

headline: UniCredit Buys $16 Billion Bank Austria Stake
abstract: UniCredit, Italy’s biggest bank, agreed to buy the HVB Group‘s 78 percent stake in Bank Austria Creditanstalt for 12.5 billion euros ($15.9 billion).

headline: Napster Hears Acquirers Calling
abstract: Facing a sagging stock price and a dip in its subscriber base, online music service Napster may listen if the right buyer comes along. The company has recently acknowledged that it has drawn interest from potential acquirers and would seriously entertain the right offer.

headline: Two Bidders Emerge for United Biscuits, Report Says
abstract: Premier Foods and buyout giant Blackstone were poised to bid for United Biscuits by a deadline later on Thursday, with Premier tipped by some as the front runner, sources close to the situation told Reuters.

headline: F.B.I. Casts Wide Net for Fugitive Ex-Chief of Comverse
abstract: Where in the world is Kobi?

headline: Apple May Restate Earnings After Options Inquiry
abstract: Shares of Apple Computer, maker of Macintosh computers and iPod music players, may fall as the company said it will probably restate earnings after an internal investigation into options backdating found more suspicious grants.

headline: Hollywood Studios Eyes Dubai Listing
abstract: The entertainment company Hollywood Studios International will consider listing on Dubai’s new stock exchange in the next two years, a United Arab Emirates newspaper reported.

headline: In De Vere Deal, Upping the Ante Pays Off For AHG Venice
abstract: After increasing its bid for the second time in a week, Richard Balfour-Lynn’s AHG Venice has won a takeover tussle for the hotel and leisure group De Vere. Private equity group Permira said that, in light of the new offer of about 767 million pounds ($1.42 billion), it had decided not to come up with a rival bid for the hotel chain.

headline: Brazilian Telecom Pulls the Plug on $1 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: In another blow to the limping I.P.O. market, Brazilian telecom company Telemar Participacoes pulled a U.S. initial public offering late Thursday, the biggest I.P.O. cancellation so far this year, according to Dealogic data.

headline: AdMob Gets First Round from Sequoia
abstract: Looking to expand its Web-based mobile advertising network, newly formed AdMob has raised an undisclosed amount in Series A financing.

headline: After Much Speculation, ITV C.E.O. Ousted
abstract: ITV bowed to shareholder pressure and removed Charles Allen as chief executive yesterday, as the British broadcaster’s chairman said he might rename the company to distance it from the travails of ITV1.

headline: Court Upholds Halting of Sears’ Takeover of Canadian Unit
abstract: An Ontario court dismissed an appeal by Sears Holdings on Tuesday of the decision by Canadian securities regulators to halt its takeover offer for its Canadian unit, Sears Canada, Reuters reported.

headline: Hewlett Review Is Said to Detail Deeper Spying
abstract: A secret investigation of news leaks at Hewlett-Packard was more elaborate than previously reported, and almost from the start involved the illicit gathering of private phone records and direct surveillance of board members and journalists, according to The New York Times.

headline: Ciena Goes In for Stock Split
abstract: Fiber-optics equipment maker Ciena, whose stock has almost doubled in the last year, is boosting its per share stock price even more, with a reverse stock split.

headline: More TED Talks Online
abstract: TED has released 12 more of its astonishing free videos online.

headline: Open-Source Software Firm Zend Rakes in $20 Million
abstract: Zend, which commercializes the widely used open-source PHP software that lets computers create customized Web pages, has received a $20 million boost through a fourth round of funding.

headline: 110-Building Site in New York City Goes on Market
abstract: Metropolitan Life is putting Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village – a stretch of 110 apartment buildings along the East River – on the auction block.

headline: Dismissal Recommended for Bristol Chief
abstract: A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to press reports.

headline: Tabcorp Won’t Battle Regulators’ Decision
abstract: As expected, Tabcorp Holdings, Australia’s biggest gaming company, withdrew its hostile bid of 1.9 billion Australian dollars ($1.5 billion) for Unitab after antitrust regulators opposed the deal, leaving Tattersall’s as the only bidder for the sports betting chain.

headline: “It’s All Geek to Me”
abstract: A help-wanted ad for Pogue’s new TV show on Discovery.

headline: A Modest Proposal: Shorting Hedge Funds
abstract: Plenty of people have speculated recently that the hedge fund craze will come to a bad end. However, few have gone on to ask the next logical question: If it does, how can I profit from it?

headline: Ashton Mining Rejects Stornoway Diamond
abstract: Diamond exploration company Ashton Mining of Canada rebuffed a $118-million takeover bid by Stornoway Diamond on Tuesday and looked to challenge a lockup agreement with Ashton’s majority shareholder, Rio Tinto.

headline: Plains Exploration Sells Properties to Occidental
abstract: Plains Exploration & Production said on Monday it has agreed to sell oil and gas properties that it no longer considers strategic to Occidental Petroleum for $865 million.

headline: Former Citigroup Chief Named Chairman of American International
abstract: Robert Willumstad once led the world’s largest bank. Now he’ll lead the world’s largest insurer.

headline: UBS Buys Asset Management Unit from KeyCorp
abstract: UBS, the Swiss investment bank, is to acquire the branch network of McDonald Investments, a unit of KeyCorp, for up to $280 million, UBS said on Wednesday.

headline: Ghosn Reassures Detroit About His Intentions
abstract: Trying to blunt opposition to a potential alliance that would link automakers on three continents, the chief executive of Nissan and Renault said Friday that he would not discuss buying a stake in General Motors as part of initial talks to weigh the benefits of a partnership.

headline: British Building Supplies Concern Wolseley Slips on Share Issue
abstract: Wolseley, the world’s biggest distributor of plumbing and heating equipment, said on Monday it plans to sell 59.5 million new shares to institutional investors to help fund purchases and to cut debt.

headline: U.S. Closes Lucrative Airwaves Auction
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission declared the latest and most lucrative auction of the public airwaves closed on Monday, with bids totaling nearly $13.9 billion.

headline: Connections Help RingCube Net Funding
abstract: Connections made during Silicon Valley’s late 1990’s halcyon days have helped launch RingCube Technologies, a start-up developing technology for transferring data between computers.

headline: Revolving Door: Bank of America, Credit Suisse
abstract: Bank of America has appointed Richard L. Prager as its global head of commodities, a platform that incorporates energy products like oil and gas, base and precious metals. He will report to Tom Connor, global head of liquid products, the bank said Thursday.

headline: Australia’s Woodside Bids for Energy Partners
abstract: Woodside Petroleum, Australia’s biggest independent oil and gas company, on Monday made an unsolicited offer to buy Energy Partners for $23 a share in cash, or about $883 million, driving the U.S. company’s stock up more than 30 percent.

headline: Japan’s Nomura Looks to Branch Out
abstract: Nomura Asset Management is the big fish in a medium-sized pond. With around $200 billion of assets under management, it is the biggest fund house in Japan.

headline: Cablevision Says Stock Options Are Being Investigated
abstract: Cablevision Systems said yesterday that federal prosecutors and regulators were investigating its stock options grants, a week after the company disclosed some discrepancies in the dating of the grants.

headline: Is eBay the New Testing Ground for Star Entrepreneurs?.
abstract: Every couple of years, a new company in Silicon Valley becomes a wellspring of a new generation of entrepreneurs and executives. Back in the ’70s and ’80s, Intel sales guys like Bill Davidow and John Doerr went onto V.C. firms Mohr Davidow Ventures and Kleiner Perkins. In the ’90s, Sun execs popped up as C.E.O. of Autodesk (Carol Bartz) and Motorola (Ed Zander).

headline: Regulators Kick Off Probe of Stock-Loan Pricing
abstract: Federal prosecutors have launched a broad probe into price-gouging in the market for borrowed stock, targeting Wall Street firms that allegedly attach gratuitous finder’s fees for arranging stock loans, TheStreet.com’s Matthew Goldstein reported Monday.

headline: Canadian Oil Sands Lowers Bar for Canada Southern Bid
abstract: Canadian Oil Sands Trust said on Monday it had lowered the threshold for shareholder acceptance of its takeover offer for Canada Southern Petroleum, and was close to meeting that revised condition.

headline: Rothschild Scion Plans Property I.P.O.
abstract: One of the scions of the Rothschild banking dynasty is planning to float a commercial property company in London with a 2 billion euro to 3 billion euro ($2.6 billion to $3.8 billion) price tag.

headline: Bain Capital Nears Deal to Buy a Maker of Insurance Software
abstract: Bain Capital was near a deal last night to acquire Applied Systems for about $675 million, according to The New York Times, in a move that would end a month-long battle for the insurance software company.

headline: Chicago Exchange Plans to Go Public, Despite Legal Tussle
abstract: The Chicago Board Options Exchange is moving toward becoming another publicly traded financial marketplace. Its chairman and chief executive, William Brodsky, said Friday that the bourse plans to move ahead despite a lawsuit from its rival, the Chicago Board of Trade.

headline: Swedish Prime Minister Denounces Private Equity Firms
abstract: Sweden’s prime minister assailed two activist funds on Thursday for demanding a restructuring of Volvo, marking the latest attack by a European government on private equity, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Texas Buyout Firm Snaps Up Lone Star Steakhouse
abstract: Steakhouse chain operator Lone Star Steakhouse & Saloon on Friday said it will be bought by a Dallas-based private equity firm for more than $600 million, sending its shares up sharply.

headline: Ziff Davis to Seek Buyers
abstract: Long rumored to be on the block, technology-themed media company Ziff Davis Holdings made it official on Monday. In a press release to announce its latest quarterly results, the privately held magazine publisher said it had brought in Evercore Partners and Lehman Brothers to explore its strategic options, “including the possible sale of some or all of the company’s groups.”

headline: S.E.C. Charges 3 in Fraudulent I.P.O. Scheme
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday filed a civil suit in an effort to freeze the assets of a group of New Yorkers accused of selling at least $1.6 million of fraudulent investments to at least 64 unsuspecting investors, many of them elderly.

headline: L.S.E. Forecasts Stellar Year
abstract: The London Stock Exchange forecast an “excellent” performance for the year as its former suitor Icap gave warning that its profits could be hit by the decline in the U.S. dollar.

headline: E.U. Examines New Microsoft Documents
abstract: Microsoft has given the European Union more documents in response to a 2004 antitrust order, but regulators said they do not know yet whether the company will avoid additional fines.

headline: 2 Buyout Firms Team Up Again for Restaurant Deal
abstract: Catterton Partners and Oak Investment Partners, doing their fifth restaurant deal together, have purchased casual-dining chain Cheddar’s Holding from Brazos Private Equity Partners.

headline: Alltel’s Wireless Purchase Gets OK from Regulators
abstract: U.S. antitrust authorities on Thursday approved rural telephone operator Alltel‘s $1.075 billion deal to buy Midwest Wireless Holdings.

headline: How to Become a Venture Capitalist
abstract: Six masters of business administration students from all over the country have come to New Mexico to find out if they will sink or swim in the high-risk world of venture capital. They are the inaugural class of a new internship program at Flywheel Ventures, an Albuquerque/Santa Fe venture capital firm with $31 million under management.

headline: SunGuard Shines Light on Possible Misys Takeover
abstract: The financial data firm SunGard Data Systems has registered its interest in taking over the British software group Misys.

headline: Riviera Receives Competing Takeover Bid of $248.6 Million
abstract: The casino operator Riviera Holdings Corporation said on Tuesday that International Gaming & Entertainment had offered to buy it for about $248.6 million, or $20 a share, competing with an earlier offer from Riv Acquisition Holdings.

headline: Hewlett-Packard’s General Counsel Resigns
abstract: Hewlett-Packard‘s general counsel has resigned, the embattled computer maker said Thursday as current and former executives prepared to testify before a Congressional subcommittee about its controversial leak investigation.

headline: Total Raises Stake in Cepsa of Spain After Resolving Ownership Issues
abstract: French oil major Total said on Wednesday it had raised its direct stake in Spanish oil firm Cepsa to 44.5 percent after an agreement with bank Santander ended a long-running ownership dispute.

headline: M&A Bankers Take Strength from Energy Industry
abstract: Anyone who wants to know the hottest bankers in mergers and acquisitions should look at the energy industry, where Lehman Brothers Holdings and J.P. Morgan Chase are doing more business than anyone, including traditional leaders Morgan Stanley and Citigroup.

headline: For Insiders, West Corp. Buyout Would Bring Windfall
abstract: The proposed $4.1 billion buyout of West Corporation has triggered litigation and some sharp criticism from a few institutional shareholders who claim the offer price is too low. But directors and officers are probably not complaining. A recent filed proxy statement highlighted by Footnoted.org notes that, as a group, West’s directors and officers stand to receive more than $98 million in payments for options that have vested or will vest as a result of the merger.

headline: Murder of Russian Central Banker Linked to His Job
abstract: A Russian central banker, Andrei Kozlov, was assassinated in Moscow, victim of a shooting that the prosecutor general linked to his job regulating the nation’s banks.

headline: Incuity gets Cash to Bring Products to Market
abstract: After laboring as a reseller of other company’s software for eight years, Incuity Software has raised $7.3 million in its first institutional round to bring its own products to market.

headline: The Reality of Selling Endemol
abstract: Telefónica has been fielding prospective offers for Endemol, but as the Spanish company begins an auction process expected to culminate in a sale by year’s end, buyers are looking for any clue to determine what has so far stymied a sale.

headline: Business Objects Vulnerable to Takeover, Report Says
abstract: Business Objects is starting to look a lot like a takeover target, Reuters reported. The business-intelligence software company’s stock fell 22 percent on Friday, ending at $21.03 a share, after it said second-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts’ expectations.

headline: Barnes & Noble Gets Options Subpoena
abstract: The inquiry into stock-option practices at Barnes & Noble turned more serious on Tuesday as the bookstore chain revealed that it had received a subpoena from the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

headline: Virgo Raises $50 Million Fund
abstract: Private investment firm Virgo Capital has set up shop in Austin with a $50 million fund.

headline: Predictions, anyone?
abstract: I was taken in – twice.

headline: Envisioning the Merger of Three European Exchanges
abstract: Borsa Italiana‘s chief executive Massimo Capuano has announced his 21.5 billion euro ($27.2 billion) plan to merge three of the continent’s largest stock exchanges. At a meeting in Rome on Monday with Euronext‘s chief executive, Jean-Francois Theodore, Mr. Capuano set out a proposal to unite the two exchanges with Deutsche Borse to form a European super-exchange, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Bear Stearns’s Profits and Revenue Rise
abstract: Bear Stearns, extending a string of better-than-expected results from major Wall Street companies, reported a 16 percent rise in profit for the fiscal third quarter. The securities firm said Thursday that net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 was $438 million, up from $378 million a year ago. Net revenue jumped 17 percent to $2.1 billion.

headline: Tobacco Ruling Rekindles Spinoff Concerns
abstract: It has nothing to do with sales of cookies and processed cheese, but Thursday’s legal victory for Big Tobacco still weighed on shares of food giant Kraft. The reason: The Florida Supreme Court’s decision, which upholds a ruling that voided a $145 billion judgment against major tobacco companies, is expected to speed up Kraft’s separation from its parent, cigarette maker Altria Group.

headline: If Not G.M., Says Ghosn, Maybe Ford
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance – raising the prospect of eventual talks with Ford.

headline: Buy, Hold or Sail
abstract: Whether it was a venture capitalist on a yacht or hedge fund professionals on sailboats, last week was a chance for the investment community to flaunt its sea legs.

headline: Proxy Adviser ISS Backs Lucent-Alcatel Merger
abstract: Institutional Shareholder Services, the influential U.S. shareholder advisory firm, has recommended shareholders approve the $10.4 billion acquisition of Lucent Technologies by Alcatel, the French telecoms equipment maker.

headline: Shutterfly Frames I.P.O
abstract: Online photo-sharing pioneer Shutterfly said Thursday it would float 5.8 million shares at an estimated price range of $13 to $15 for its initial public offering.

headline: Tech Ties That Bind: Google Chief Joins Apple Board
abstract: Apple Computer said yesterday that the chief executive of Google, Eric Schmidt, was joining its board, linking two of Silicon Valley’s most iconic – and maverick – companies.

headline: Sale of U.K. Soccer Club to Polygon Hit Snag
abstract: Talks between Sir John Hall, the life president of Newcastle United, and the secretive Chelsea, U.K.-based hedge fund Polygon have stalled over the blocking stake held by group chairman Freddy Shepherd.

headline: Televisa Abandons Quest for Univision
abstract: Grupo Televisa said Monday that it will not make another offer to buy Univision Communications, the Spanish-language broadcaster that it unsuccessfully pursued in an auction earlier this year.

headline: Shares of Vespa Maker Race Higher
abstract: The road to the public markets in Milan has been littered with casualties lately, with Pirelli Tyre recently becoming the latest Italian company to withdraw its planned initial public offering. No such fate befell Piaggio, however. Shares of Italian company, which makes the Vespa scooter, staged strong gains on Tuesday after it raised about $400 million in an I.P.O.

headline: Plan for Vista Draws Warning to Microsoft From Europe
abstract: The competition regulator for the European Union clashed with Microsoft again on Tuesday, this time over security upgrades in the company’s new Windows Vista operating system.

headline: Tribune Factions May Unwind Partnership, Report Says
abstract: Tribune and California’s Chandler family are close to unwinding two controversial partnerships at the heart of the boardroom battle that has roiled the company since early June, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Naked Shorts? Immodest Traders Sought in Britain
abstract: Traders who work for investment banks in London are apparently being invited to get naked for a 2007 calendar being produced by the KatCanDo charity. The casting call is being reported by financial-news Web site Here is the City, which suggests that full frontal nudity will not be required. “It will all be done very tastefully,” it writes.

headline: Macquarie Delays Anticipated Toll Roads Sale
abstract: Macquarie Infrastructure Group has delayed the A$1.1 billion ($827 million) spinoff of three Sydney toll road assets just one day before the offer to retail and institutional investors was due to close.

headline: 2 Healthcare Companies Mull Merging Pharmacy Units, Report Says
abstract: AmerisourceBergen and Kindred Healthcare are near a deal to combine their institutional-pharmacy businesses into a separate, publicly traded company that would become the nation’s second-largest pharmacy distributing and preparing patient medications for nursing homes, hospitals and hospices, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Inter-Tel Founder Submits Another Takeover Bid
abstract: Inter-Tel founder and former chairman Steven Mihaylo and Vector Capital resubmitted their offer to acquire Inter-Tel for $22.50 a share in cash, Vector Capital said on Friday. Mr. Mihaylo previously made an offer of the same price in June.

headline: HSBC Buys Westpac Custody Business
abstract: After 60 years in the custody business, Westpac has sold its domestic book to HSBC for A$150 million ($113 million), making HSBC the second largest sub-custodian in the market behind National Australia Bank.

headline: Loeb Pens a Second Bitter Missive to Nabi
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb hasn’t been shy about expressing his feelings to Nabi Biopharmaceuticals before. In June, the voluble manager of Third Point, one of Nabi’s largest shareholders, wrote to the company’s board of managers, urging it to dump adviser Lehman Brothers and explore a sale of all or part of the company.

headline: Merrill Penalized Over Analyst’s Work
abstract: Merrill Lynch must pay at least $495,000 to a Pennsylvania couple who said they lost part of their retirement savings because an analyst at the firm issued a flawed “buy” rating on Tyco International stock.

headline: Wireless Auction Brings Together Players from Across the Spectrum
abstract: Starting on Aug. 9, more than 160 telecommunications and media players, large and small, will be pitted against one another in an auction by the Federal Communications Commission for the largest chunk of wireless spectrum ever put out to bid in the United States.

headline: Ex-S.E.C. Chairman Hired for Cable Case
abstract: The United States attorney’s office in Manhattan said Wednesday that Richard C. Breeden, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had been hired to oversee the payment of hundreds of millions of dollars to investors defrauded by Adelphia Communications, the cable company that is in bankruptcy.

headline: Bristol-Myers C.E.O. Resigns
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb‘s chief executive, Peter Dolan, and the drugmaker’s general counsel will resign after federal regulators called for their departures as part of a criminal investigation.

headline: Buyout Speculation Surrounds Lumber Giant
abstract: Shares of Weyerhaeuser surged 5.2 percent Tuesday, the most in 15 months, on speculation that the world’s largest lumber company may be the target of an unsolicited bid, possibly by a buyout firm.

headline: Goldman’s Management Revamp Continues
abstract: Goldman Sachs has rearranged the top management at its overseas operations, marking the latest executive changes under the investment bank’s newly installed chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein.

headline: Wachovia Shareholders Approve Golden West Deal
abstract: Following Golden West Financial shareholders’ lead, shareholders of Wachovia have approved the company’s proposed acquisition of the California-based lender by a wide margin.

headline: Embattled Milberg Gets a Gig
abstract: A New York judge has given a boost to Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman by appointing the embattled law firm co-lead counsel in a consolidated suit over stock option backdating.

headline: Haliburton Stays the Course with K.B.R. Offering
abstract: Halliburton is pressing ahead with plans to spin off Kellogg Brown & Root in an initial public offering, a move that comes as the Army subcontractor scales back its work in Iraq.

headline: Verizon Favors Hybrid Strategy for Yellow Pages Unit, Report Says
abstract: After months of internal debate, Verizon Communications is leaning toward a two-step plan to spin out its yellow pages unit, tapping private equity firms for capital while handing over the bulk of the stock in the business to Verizon shareholders, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Christopher Bearg joined Hunt Adkins, Minneapolis, as strategic planning director, a new post. He had most recently been a partner at Egg, Seattle.

headline: Creditors Push Yukos Close to Liquidation
abstract: The Yukos oil company’s fight for existence neared its end on Tuesday when creditors rejected its plans for recovery and recommended that Yukos, once Russia’s largest and most successful oil concern, be declared bankrupt.

headline: Judge Delays KPMG Tax Shelter Trial
abstract: The judge overseeing the tax fraud trial involving shelters designed or marketed by 16 former partners at the accounting firm KPMG and two others has delayed the trial by four months.

headline: Mellon’s Progress in China Is Halted
abstract: Mellon Financial‘s plan to expand into China’s $64 billion mutual fund market has suffered a setback after the U.S. group failed to acquire a stake in a small local fund house.

headline: Inco Opens Talks with Teck Cominco
abstract: Canadian nickel miner Inco, which plans to be acquired by Phelps Dodge, said on Monday it would open negotiations with unsolicited suitor Teck Cominco.

headline: Higher Rates May Dim the New Dawn of LBOs
abstract: For Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and their partners, the cost of acquiring hospital operator HCA will be nearly $100 million higher for than it would have been just three months ago, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Rock Me, Corporate Titans
abstract: Meet the new boss: He’s playing Led Zeppelin covers until closing time at the neighborhood bar and recording CDs in the basement. From the president of buyout firm Wasserstein & Company to the president and chief executive of Cablevision Systems, baby boomers at the top of their professions are refusing to give up their youthful rock-star fantasies.

headline: DirecTV and EchoStar Pull Plug on Pricey Wireless Bids
abstract: It appears that, ultimately, those juicy wireless licenses were just too rich for Rupert Murdoch’s blood. The satellite TV providers DirecTV Group, which is owned by Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation, and EchoStar Communications on Wednesday pulled out of the Federal Communications Commission auction for licenses to deliver advanced wireless services.

headline: National City Buys SSG Capital
abstract: National City, the nation’s ninth-largest bank, has extended its push into Philadelphia business banking with the purchase of SSG Capital Advisors, of West Conshohocken, Penn.

headline: Tech to Try Out I.P.O. Market Next Week
abstract: Three tech companies, DivX, Riverbed Technology and CommVault Systems, will attempt to go public next week, hoping for standout performances in a choppy year for newly issues technology shares.

headline: Northwest Wants Approval for $1 Billion Facility
abstract: Northwest Airlines is asking a U.S. bankruptcy court to approve a new $1.125 billion refinancing facility to help the company emerge from bankruptcy, company officials said Tuesday evening. If the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York approves the bankrupt carrier’s request, Northwest will be closer to securing part of the debt financing needed to emerge from its Chapter 11 reorganization

headline: For Pequot Accountant, Next Stop Is Vegas
abstract: By day, Brian Fidler is an accountant with Pequot Capital Management, the giant hedge fund that made headlines in recent weeks because it was being investigated for potential insider trading. By night, Mr. Fidler has a different claim to fame: He is a rising star in the competitive poker-playing scene. As noted by the Wall Street Folly blog, he won an online tournament in April that put him in the World Series of Poker, taking place this week in Las Vegas.

headline: Citigroup May Take Control of Amaranth, Reports Say
abstract: As Amaranth Advisors, the hedge-fund company that imploded after making wrong-way bets on natural gas, said Wednesday that its losses had swelled to $6 billion, reports began to surface that Citigroup might buy a stake in the firm.

headline: Venture Investors Bet $70 Million on MobiTV
abstract: A company that brings television shows to mobile phones and other portable gadgets said Wednesday that it has scored a $70 million investment from venture firms led Oak Investment Partners. PaidContent calls MobiTV‘s third-round financing “possibly the biggest mobile content funding to date” and quoted MobiTV’s interim chief financial officer as saying the money was for expansion.

headline: E.U. Confirms U.S. Rules Don’t Apply to European Firms
abstract: Quelling the fears of some European investors, concerned that a proposed merger between Euronext and the New York Stock Exchange could require European companies to comply with Sarbanes-Oxley corporate governance rules in force in the United States, the European Union has said that companies listed in Europe would remain subject to European regulations in the event of a trans-Atlantic stock exchange merger.

headline: Canadian Telecom Files Telesat I.P.O.
abstract: The Canadian telecommunications giant BCE filed on Tuesday to sell a stake worth as much as $400 million in its Telesat Canada satellite arm in an initial public offering, the latest corporate revamp in a transforming telecom sector.

headline: Wall Street’s Women Face a Fork in the Road
abstract: Wall Street, long known as a clubby man’s world, has long sought to shed its reputation as a land of Gordon Gekko wannabes. For more than a decade, firms like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers have not just opened their doors to women but actively seek them out.

headline: Deutsche Borse’s 2nd-Quarter Profits Rise 70 Percent
abstract: Deutsche Borse, who has thus far been left out in the cold in the rapidly consolidating exchange market, reported a 70 percent jump in second-quarter net income on Wednesday as the German exchange operator benefited from surging trading on Eurex, its majority-owned derivatives exchange.

headline: Brickmaker Bulks Up in Deal for Rival
abstract: Wienerberger, the world’s largest maker of bricks, is to buy Baggeridge Brick, its British rival, for 89.2 million pounds ($167.9 million) in cash.

headline: Rosneft Shares Flat in London Debut
abstract: Shares in Russian oil company Rosneft held close to their offer price Wednesday as the company made its official debut on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: 3M Acquires Security and Printing Systems
abstract: 3M has agreed to acquire a passports and secure cards producer from German holding company authentos to augment its security businesses, 3M said on Tuesday.

headline: Court Freezes the Assets of Ex-Media Baron
abstract: A Canadian court has frozen the assets of the former media tycoon Conrad M. Black and his wife, Barbara Amiel Black, putting the couple on an allowance of about $20,000 a month, according to press reports.

headline: BP Chief Will Retire (No Demurrers)
abstract: Ending rampant speculation in U.K. business circles, Lord Browne, chief executive of BP, the giant energy group, said unequivocally Tuesday that he would leave the company at the end of 2008, after reaching BP’s mandatory retirement age of 60.

headline: Esmark Kicks Off Proxy Fight to Wrest Control of Wheeling-Pittsburgh
abstract: Steel supplier Esmark on Monday said it has nominated a slate of candidates to Wheeling-Pittsburgh‘s board, in an effort to gain control of the troubled steelmaker through a proxy fight.

headline: Hedge Fund Amaranth Said to Report Big Loss
abstract: September may turn out to be the cruelest month for Amaranth, a large hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn. Bloomberg News and CNBC reported Monday that the fund, which was up more than 30 percent at the end of August, has warned its investors that its year-to-date losses could exceed 35 percent as the price of natural gas has dropped sharply.

headline: In a Quick Flip, Firms Put Greek Telecom Up for Sale
abstract: Only a year after buying TIM Hellas for 1.1 billion euros ($1.4 billion), the Texas Pacific Group and Apax Partners are planning on flipping the company for up to 4 billion euros, The Times of London reported Monday.

headline: Trial Begins for an Icon in Japan
abstract: Takafumi Horie, the brash, 33-year-old Internet entrepreneur whose rise and fall has captivated Japan the last two years, pleaded not guilty to charges of violating securities law at the opening of his trial in Tokyo on Monday.

headline: Mortgage Gamblers
abstract: More Risk Is Being Taken By Mortage Borrowers and Lenders

headline: Defending the C.E.O. Paycheck and the Banker Bonus
abstract: Executive pay is an explosive issue these days, and a recent interview published on SmartMoney.com is apt to spark more debate.

headline: OneSteel Expects Smorgon Shareholders to Back Contentious Deal
abstract: OneSteel, the second-largest producer of the metal in Australia, expects Smorgon Steel Group shareholders to approve a $1.2 billion takeover bid that’s opposed by its biggest rival and the competition regulator.

headline: Sharp’s Exit Could Spell New Private Equity Fund at Goldman
abstract: Speculation is increasing that Goldman Sachs is moving closer to raising a new giant private equity fund after it confirmed that Richard Sharp, the current head of its European principal investment division, is resigning at the end of the year.

headline: G.O.P. Attracts More of Wall Street Firms’ Donations
abstract: On Monday, Goldman Sachs‘s Hank Paulson, a longtime Republican, is expected to be sworn in as the next Treasury Secretary of the United States. His successor, Lloyd Blankfein, has already taken over as Goldman’s chief executive, putting a Democrat in charge of the world’s largest securities firm. Given the strong and shifting ties between Wall Street and Washington — not to mention the upcoming midterm elections in Congress — it seems a good time to ask: What are the political leanings of the major financial firms?

headline: 7-Eleven Parent Company Buys White Hen Pantry
abstract: Japan’s Seven & I Holdings, operator of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, said on Friday it has bought out White Hen Pantry for $35 million to strengthen its U.S. operations.

headline: Kozlowski’s Yacht Finds New Skipper
abstract: Former Tyco International chief Dennis Kozlowski has reportedly located a buyer for his historic yacht, the Endeavour. Bloomberg News reported on Thursday that an entity called Sempervirens — about which little is known — agreed to pay $13.1 million for the 130-foot vessel. That is well below the $17 million price he originally sought, and also less than the $15 million that Mr. Kozlowski paid for the boat in 2000.

headline: Wall Street Banks to Launch Trading Service, Report Says
abstract: Six big Wall Street firms plan an electronic trading service for big “block” stock trades, adding competition for the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq Stock Market, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Judge Approves Winn-Dixie Reorganization Plan
abstract: A federal judge approved the reorganization plan of Winn-Dixie Stores on Friday, setting the stage for the supermarket chain to emerge from bankruptcy if its creditors also accept the proposal.

headline: What to Pack for a Geek Cruise
abstract: Ten days in the Mediterranean with my wife and kids? These are the gadgets up to the task of documenting such an adventure.

headline: Trial of NatWest Three Delayed
abstract: A U.S. judge last night delayed setting a trial date for the NatWest Three after two of the bankers, Giles Darby and Gary Mulgrew, said they needed more time to hire lawyers. The trial had been due to start on September 11, but U.S. magistrate Stephen Smith agreed to wait to set the trial date.

headline: Shareholders File Suit Against EADS
abstract: A French shareholder association has filed a lawsuit over the recent share price collapse of EADS. The suit, filed in the Netherlands, where the Airbus parent group is registered, seeks class-action status.

headline: Ahead of Merger, Mittal and Arcelor Report Lower Profits
abstract: Mittal Steel and Arcelor, whose $38.3 billion combination will control a tenth of the world’s steel, said second-quarter profit dropped on rising raw-material costs and lower prices.

headline: Langone Readies Attack on Spitzer Suit
abstract: Kenneth Langone has made barbed comments about New York attorney general Eliot Spitzer to the press and supported a rival’s bid for the governor’s mansion. This week, Mr. Langone will take his struggle against Mr. Spitzer to the place it really counts: the courtroom. CNBC’s SquawkBlog on Monday gave a preview of the arguments that Mr. Langone, a co-founder of Home Depot, is expected to make on Wednesday as he seeks to persuade a judge to throw out Mr. Spitzer’s lawsuit against him, which concerns the compensation awarded to former NYSE chief Dick Grasso while Mr. Langone was head of NYSE’s compensation committee.

headline: Pensions and the Kravis Crowd: The Odd Couple
abstract: When a Pennsylvania state bureaucrat can keep Henry Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts waiting, it is safe to say that public pension funds have become increasingly important for private equity firms. The Financial Times reported Tuesday that these huge publicly managed pools, which deploy tens of billions of dollars, have sought to cash in on the private equity boom of recent years.

headline: A Revolution, or Just a Mouse?
abstract: Logitech is advertising its MX Revolution mouse as a revolution in personal computing.

headline: For Investors, eMinor Hit the Right Note
abstract: EMinor, a Durham, N.C.-based software firm with a focus on music, has reeled in $2 million in series A funding.

headline: Chief Who Led Turnaround Will Retire From Peugeot
abstract: Jean-Martin Folz, who has presided as chief executive of Peugeot Citroën during a three-year decline in profitability, will retire in January, the company said on Friday.

headline: EchoStar Reaches $100 Million Settlement With Networks
abstract: Satellite TV provider EchoStar Communications said Monday it has reached a $100 million settlement with affiliate associations of three major networks over distant programming service but has been unable to resolve differences with Fox Network.

headline: This Week, a Full I.P.O. Dance Card
abstract: A drugmaker, Warner Chilcott, leads a busy calendar of initial public offerings with a rare $1 billion stock offering this week, as the I.P.O. market attempts to quicken the pace for the fourth quarter.

headline: Man Group’s C.E.O. Will Step Down Next Year
abstract: Stanley Fink, the man who has built Man Group into the world’s largest listed hedge fund, will step down as chief executive next year, the firm said Thursday.

headline: Employee Says Investment Bank Is a ‘Scam’
abstract: A former employee of N.C.-based Madison Keats has sued the investment-banking firm and its founder, describing the operation as a “financial scam” that collects thousands of dollars in fees from cash-starved life-science companies but fails to deliver deal-making services in return.

headline: H-P to Acquire Mercury Interactive
abstract: Hewlett-Packard late Tuesday announced a $4.5 billion deal to buy Mercury Interactive, a software company that has been struggling with an investigation into its stock option grants. Hewlett, a giant maker of personal computers, has agreed to pay $52 per share in cash for Mercury, or about 33 percent above the closing price of Mercury’s shares on Tuesday.

headline: Why Does Icahn’s White Whale Keep Sinking?
abstract: With his enduring fixation on Time Warner, billionaire investor Carl Icahn has done little more than show his ability to pick one of the media sector’s worst-performing stocks. That is the general assessment of both the Financial Times’ Lex column and the Breakingviews blog, each of which commented Friday on Mr. Icahn’s latest tactic, reported Thursday in The New York Times: the creation of a “special purpose vehicle” to acquire yet more Time Warner shares.

headline: Televisa Stake Will Not Affect Univision Sale
abstract: Univision Communications said Thursday that Grupo Televisa‘s decision to sell its stake in the Spanish-language broadcaster will not affect its sale to a group of private equity firms.

headline: Former Staples Executive Indicted on Embezzlement Charges
abstract: Federal prosecutors yesterday alleged that a vice president at Staples stole more than $580,000 over two years and used a company credit card for shopping and adult entertainment before the company discovered the scheme and fired him in November.

headline: Shareholders Sue Apple Over Stock Options

headline: Sri Lanka:  Fierce Fighting Rages; Sweden Pulls Out
abstract: Government jets pounded Tamil Tiger positions in the east after the rebels fired shells at a ship ferrying more than 800 troops, as a fight over an irrigation canal dragged the country closer to full-fledged war. The fighting began last week when the military sought to gain control of a waterway in rebel-held territory. The government accuses the rebels of blocking irrigation water to thousands of farmers, mostly from the Sinhalese majority. Sweden, meanwhile, said it would pull its monitors out of the country. The Tigers want the withdrawal of all monitors called for in a 2002 truce who come from countries in the European Union, which added the group to its list of banned terrorist organizations in May. Sweden’s move would bring the Nordic-supervised monitoring mission to a third of its original 57-member size. Last week, Finland and Denmark said they were withdrawing. Only Norway and Iceland, neither in the European Union, remain.

headline: Phelps Dodge Offer for Inco Advances in Canada
abstract: A judge in Ontario approved Inco’s plan to be bought by the Phelps Dodge Corporation and allow shareholders to vote on the proposal on Sept. 7, even as Inco considers a rival offer from Teck Cominco. Judge Colin Campbell of Ontario Superior Court issued an interim order approving the company’s plan after a hearing in Toronto, Inco’s chief legal officer, Simon Fish, said. The sale to Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, can be scuttled if enough stockholders tender their shares to Teck by Aug. 16. Teck, which already owns about 4.5 percent of Inco, needs two-thirds of the shares to move ahead with the takeover. Inco, which is based in Toronto, supports Phelps’s bid, although the company said it would be willing to consider Teck’s proposal if it were improved. Teck’s chief executive, Donald Lindsay, said Tuesday that a higher bid was “unlikely.”.

As motorists’ tempers flared, he apologized for the jams. “We are not rebels without a cause,” he told reporters at the biggest camp, in Constitution Plaza. “It is not that we like being here. We don’t like being here. It is out of necessity.”.

headline: Sri Lanka: Peace Monitors Quit
abstract: Finland and Denmark said they would withdraw their citizens from the five-country team that monitors a cease-fire between the government and the rebel Tamil Tigers. The pullout of the Finns and Danes reduces the size of the 57-member monitoring mission by about a third. Sweden, a European Union member, is keeping its nationals in the monitoring mission. Citizens of Norway and Iceland, neither of which belong to the Union, make up the rest of the mission, which investigates suspected violations of the 2002 truce, now all but shattered.

headline: Tough Immigration Bill Passes a Hurdle
abstract: Parliament’s lower house, controlled by the governing Liberal Party, passed a tough immigration bill that would send asylum seekers who arrive in Australian waters by boat to remote islands while they await action on their claims for asylum. Nauru, a tiny and desolate island with only basic facilities even for residents, is the most likely place for future asylum seekers. In a rare move in a government with strong party discipline, three members of the Liberal Party joined the opposition Labor Party to vote against the bill. The measure, proposed by Prime Minister John Howard, above, who has taken a tough stance on asylum seekers, is widely seen as a concession to Indonesia, which reacted strongly earlier this year when Australia granted asylum to 43 refugees from Papua Province. The bill must still be approved by the Senate, where the Liberals have a slim majority.

Overall seat capacity increased 3.9 percent. The average load factor  the percentage of seats filled  was 88.9 percent, up from 87.9 percent last June. United States carriers accounted for nearly all the added seat capacity on trans-Atlantic routes, the company said.

headline: Jobless Rate in Brazil at 15-Month High
abstract: Brazil’s unemployment rate jumped to a 15-month high in July as an appreciation in the currency eroded profits on exports and led companies including Volkswagen to cut payrolls. The jobless rate in Brazil’s six largest metropolitan areas rose to 10.7 percent, from 10.4 percent in June and 9.4 percent in July 2005, the government said. Economists had predicted a decline in the rate to 10.2 percent, according to the median of 14 forecasts in a Bloomberg survey.

headline: South Africa: Jump in Robberies
abstract: Robbers struck South Africa’s 800 or so armored cars at the rate of more than one a day over the last 12 months, the largest number of cash-in-transit robberies recorded since current recordkeeping began in 1996, the Police Service reported. The 383 armored-car robberies marked an increase of nearly 75 percent from the previous 12-month period. Business robberies and car and truck hijackings also rose; with armored-car robberies, those crimes are often the work of large organized gangs.

headline: Plan to Ban Free Plastic Shopping Bags

The state government hopes that supermarkets and other outlets will voluntarily stop giving plastic bags to customers, but they will be required to charge a customer the equivalent of seven cents a bag under the proposed legislation, which is expected to pass. “Non-biodegradable plastic bags kill substantial numbers of whales, seals, turtles and other marine wildlife and can take up to 1,000 years to break down in the environment,” said John Thwaites, Victoria’s environment minister. He said about 10 million plastic bags were now being used and disposed of each year.

Santander will also pay as much as $175 million to some of Drive Financial’s management if the company meets goals in the next two years. Drive Financial offers financial services through 10,000 car dealers and had $2.4 billion of loans in August.

abstract: A judge filed human rights charges against Ollanta Humala, the runner-up in the presidential election this year, in relation to his role in the early 1990’s as part of a counterinsurgency unit that sought to weaken the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla movement. The charges, filed late Thursday by Judge Miluska Cano, connect Mr. Humala to allegations of an abduction and murder of a married couple and the torture of a man, actions reported to have taken place in 1992 around a jungle military base in the north. Mr. Humala, who retired from the army as a lieutenant colonel before his presidential bid, acknowledges that he was based out of the area at that time. His lawyer called the charges “an abuse of the law against my client.” Judge Cano ordered Mr. Humala to remain in Peru.

headline: Indonesia: Aceh Bill Aims for More Autonomy
abstract: Parliament passed a law that is intended to give Aceh Province greater autonomy under the terms of a peace accord with former separatists there. But the Free Aceh Movement, which fought for independence for nearly three decades and signed the peace accord last year, said the new law fell short of its demands, and of the provisions in the accord. “The authority for the government in Aceh is not clear — it says in the bill that the law in Aceh has to follow Indonesian law,” said Bakhtiar Abdullah, above, a spokesman for the movement. “If everything has to be in with the Indonesian standard, where’s the new law?” A key to the settlement, negotiated between the sides by Martti Ahtisaari, a former president of Finland, was an understanding by the rebels that a new provincial government in Aceh would have far wider authority than in the past. The passage of the law, four months later than stipulated in the peace accord, paves the way for elections later in the year.

headline: France: Donkeys Disrupt Rail Links

The accident will disrupt rail travel on the major route between Bordeaux and Nice on the Mediterranean coast, as well as high-speed services from Paris to Montpellier.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: U.S. FEE SET FOR REGISTERED TRAVELER The Transportation Security Administration will charge vendors who operate Registered Traveler programs $30 a year for each member. The announcement was seen as a green light for wider introduction of the program, which aims to speed frequent travelers through airport security lines. “T.S.A. said all along that they wanted to hear from the industry about actual costs and to pin down their own anticipated costs before deciding on the fee, and their word was good,” said Steve Brill, whose company, Verified Identity Pass, operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear in Orlando, Fla., and has agreements to expand to four other airports. A competitor, Unisys, said it hoped to open programs soon at airports in Denver and Reno, Nev. Clear costs $79.95 a year; the T.S.A. fee will be added to that. Larry Zmuda, who leads the Unisys Registered Traveler initiative, said he expected Unisys charges to be in the same range.

headline: Britain: Lifting Secrecy on Terror Risk

In the United States, the five levels of terror risk go from green (low) to red (severe). Last year Britain lowered its secret threat-level assessment only weeks before the London bombings.

It is charged with maintaining order as the country prepares for its first elections in 2007.

headline: Russia: School Massacre Remembered
abstract: Bereaved families observed the second anniversary of the start of a hostage siege at a public school in Beslan, tolling a bell slowly in the remains of the gym where more than 1,100 hostages were held by a Chechen terrorist group. A total of 332 people were killed in the siege. Families and survivors demanded, as they have since the siege ended in gunfire and flame, an honest government accounting of the bungled government response. Many questions remain unanswered. A Russian opposition politician recently advanced his own theory, claiming the final battle began when troops fired two rockets at the school. The official version holds that the terrorists’ own bombs exploded in error or by chance. The evidence for each theory is unclear and in dispute.

headline: South Korean and Indian Lead Poll for Next Leader
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, left, South Korea’s foreign minister, won a straw poll of the 15 Security Council members on which of the four announced candidates to succeed Kofi Annan as secretary general enjoyed the most support, according to diplomats who confirmed the results of the secret ballot. They said that Shashi Tharoor of India, the under secretary general for communications and public information, finished a close second, while Surakiart Sathirathai, Thailand’s deputy prime minister, and Jayantha Dhanapala of Sri Lanka, a former under secretary general for disarmament, trailed by wide margins. The informal poll, in which the Council members had the choice of marking ballots with “encourage,’’ “discourage’’ or “no opinion,’’ was held to guide the candidates’ decisions on whether to stay in the race. More candidates are expected to enter the contest, which will be decided in October when the Security Council is to recommend one name to the General Assembly for ratification.

headline: Cablevision to Restate Its Earnings

Cablevision, based in Bethpage, N.Y., is controlled by the Dolan family, which also owns Madison Square Garden. The company said yesterday that a voluntary review of stock option grants and stock appreciation rights had revealed that a number of grants from 1997 to 2002 carried dates that did not match the actual dates they were granted. The company said it expected financial results for those years would have to be restated.

headline: A Professional Vacationer Goes on Safari
abstract: Ocean Adventures sales and marketing vice president Francesco Galli Zugaro comments on vacations to far-flung destinations that he has taken as part of his work; photo (M)

headline: Pressure on Blair Mounts as 8 Aides Resign
abstract: In a mood of gathering crisis, Prime Minister Tony Blair sought Wednesday to face down a revolt within his Labor Party as an extraordinary procession of eight junior aides resigned to protest his refusal to set a date to leave office soon.     The spectacle of Mr. Blair fighting off such challenges, in sharp contrast to the euphoria of his rise to power nine years ago, recalled Margaret Thatcher's final days as her authority seeped away in 1990. Even as the chorus of dissent mounted, however, Mr. Blair was still scheduling Middle East diplomacy, with a planned visit to Lebanon on Monday.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 3 Hezbollah Members Charged
abstract: Hezbollah members Hussein Suleiman, Muhammad Sarour and Maher Qurani are charged in Israel with murder and other crimes in connection with recent fighting in Lebanon; Suleiman is accused of involvement in July 12 raid in which two Israeli soldiers were seized; Hezbollah is demanding prisoner exchange for seized Israelis and may demand return of three defendants (S)

headline: Sprint Will Build an Intel-Backed Network
abstract: Sprint Nextel says it will use WiMax, technology promoted by Intel, in building high-speed wireless data network with connection speeds about five times faster than those currently available; network will allow users to gain access to Internet while in motion (M)

headline: Semtech to Restate Earnings Over Stock Option Grants
abstract: Semtech Corp says it will restate five years of results to correct errors related to stock option grants; Verint Systems Inc says Securities and Exchange Commission has asked that it supply information on its stock option grants; says request was related to grants issued by Comverse Technology, which owns 57 percent of Verint (S)

headline: Market Maker Settles
abstract: Van der Moolen Holding will pay $8 million to settle accusations of improper trading made in lawsuit filed by holders of its American depository receipts traded on New York Stock Exchange (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telstra's Earnings Show 26% Decrease
abstract: Telstra reports its net profit in year that ended June 30 fell 26 percent, to 3.18 billion Australian dollars ($2.44 billion), as customers drop fixed-line service for competitors' cellular phones; revenue rose 2.7 percent, to 22.75 billion Australian dollars (S)

headline: Foreign Automakers See India as Exporter
abstract: Recent announcements by BMW, Suzuki, Nissan, Volkswagen, Honda and Toyota of plans to assemble cars for domestic sale and export in India reflects allure of growing number of people with disposable income; Indian government has forecast that auto sales will soar to $145 billion in 2016 from $34 billion this year; producers are designing smaller cars for emerging value-conscious consumers and hope to export made-for-India cars around world; photo (M)

headline: Sudan Releases an American Journalist From Jail in Darfur
abstract: New Mexico Gov Bill Richardson secures release of American journalist Paul Salopek, who was held on spying charges in Sudan with his Chadian driver and interpreter; men crossed into Sudan from Chad without visa on assignment for National Geographic, and were seized by rebel group aligned with Sudanese government; arrest of Salopek is one of series of recent actions against journalists in Sudan (M)

headline: Europe Envoy to Meet Iranian Negotiator
abstract: The European Union's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, will meet Saturday with Iran's top nuclear negotiator, he said Thursday, a day after their meeting in Vienna was postponed.      Mr. Solana, who was in Denmark, would not confirm the location of the meeting. Iranian state television said Wednesday that the Iranian negotiator, Ali Larijani, was heading to Spain, but neither side confirmed whether the two would meet there.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Production Slows
abstract: Indian government reports industrial production slowed to 10 percent in May from 10.8 percent in May 2005; growth in mining fell to 3 percent from 5.2 percent while electricity slid to 4.7 percent from 10.5 percent; manufacturing, however, grew 11.3 percent, compared with 10.9 percent last year (S)

headline: Consumer Reports to Add Shopping Magazine
abstract: Consumer Reports, the not-for-profit magazine that provides information on cars, computers and household appliances, is taking a step toward the publishing mainstream in a category that has vexed other publishers: women's shopping magazines.     Consumers Union, which publishes Consumer Reports, will introduce ShopSmart, a shopping magazine intended for women over 30, on Aug. 1. The magazine will be published quarterly and will have an initial newsstand-only circulation of 800,000.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Expanding Role For Nuclear Power
abstract: Foreshadowing a major environmental debate, the British government said nuclear power would make a ''significant contribution'' to future energy needs. Nuclear power currently accounts for one-fifth of Britain's energy, scheduled to fall by 6 percent by 2020. Alistair Darling, the trade and industry minister, told Parliament that a new generation of nuclear power stations could help reduce carbon emissions and dependence on imported energy.   ALAN COWELL (NYT)

headline: Croatia: Bid Rises for Drug Maker
abstract: Barr Pharmaceuticals raises bid for generic drug maker Pliva to $2.5 billion, topping rival bid from Actavis Group (S)

headline: Judge Sets Aside Airbus Request to Disqualify Boeing Lawyers
abstract: A District of Columbia Superior Court judge has shelved efforts by Airbus to disqualify lawyers for the Boeing Company from working on a contentious trade dispute.     Airbus had filed a complaint against Boeing's use of the law firm of Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale & Dorr for work related to a dispute with the World Trade Organization. The complaint said Boeing would have an unfair advantage because Wilmer Hale employed a former United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and a former internal lawyer for Airbus, Marco C. E. J. Bronckers, who is now a partner in Wilmer Hale's office in Brussels.

headline: A Portable (and Squeezable) Way to Recharge
abstract: Anne Eisenberg column on new portable fuel cell from More Energy, subsidiary of Medis Technologies, that uses chemical reaction to recharge variety of hand-held electronic devices; photo (M)

headline: Dow Climbs 93 Points and Posts Its Second-Highest Close
abstract: dow Jones industrial average climbs 93.58 points, to 11,722.98; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 9.97 points, to 1,336.34; Nasdaq composite index rises 12.27 points, to 2,261.34; price and yield of 10-year Treasury note noted; graph (M)

headline: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale  $8.95 million    426 West Broadway (between Prince and Spring Streets)  Manhattan    An investor has bought a five-unit 8,220-square-foot commercial condo, with shops including Max Studio and M Missoni, on the first two floors of this six-story 1900 building.    Buyer: Marvin Shulsky, Shulsky Properties  Buyer's Broker: Martin Ezratty, Eastern Consolidated  Seller: Todd Aaron, Resolution Capital  Seller's Broker: Stuart Gross, Eastern Consolidated    Recent Lease  $30/sq. ft.  approximate annual rent $40,500    Goelet Building  900 Broadway at 20th Street  Manhattan    A skin care company took a three-year lease for 1,350 square feet on the fifth floor of this 1887 building.    Tenant: Prescribed Solutions  Tenant brokers: Daniel Wolpert and Jeffrey Schwartz, Adams & Co. Real Estate  Landlord: W&M Properties  Landlord brokers: Samuel Stein, Justin Management    For Sale  $2.7 million    191 Hanse Avenue  Freeport, N.Y.    This one-story 40,000-square-foot vacant industrial site, includes 4,000 square feet of office space and two loading docks.    Owner: Mark Briter Realty  Broker: Ralph Perna, Newmark Knight Frank

headline: Biggest Bank in China Planning an I.P.O.
abstract: Hong Kong stock exchange reportedly gives Industrial and Commercial Bank of China permission to proceed with sale of shares as part of initial public offering on Hong Kong and Shanghai exchanges that could raise record $19 billion if fully subscribed; shares in China Merchants Bank jumped 25 percent on first day of trading, raising $2.4 billion in heavily oversubscribed initial public offering; photo (M)

headline: Refugees Cut Off From News of Village in Middle of Fight
abstract: Few towns have paid a higher price for the Israeli onslaught than Aitaroun, in the southernmost corner of Lebanon, about a mile away from where Israeli soldiers have crossed the border into the country.      So far, at least 30 residents have died, said the town's deputy mayor, a tall and reserved man named Najib Kawsan. Many residents have left.

headline: Retail Sales Slow Their Rise; Wall St. Awaits Price Report
abstract: Commerce Department reports retail sales rose 0.2 percent in August after surge of 1.4 percent in July; also reports that business inventories rose in July, matching increase in sales and suggesting that companies are stocking up on goods in anticipation of strong demand; Labor Department reports number of first-time unemployment claims dropped by 5,000 last week, to 308,000; says prices of imported goods rose higher-than-expected 0.8 percent in August; graph (M)

headline: Rights Groups Say Military Is Behind Killings in Philippines
abstract: Amnesty International says politically motivated pattern of killings of members of legal leftist groups is spreading in Philippines, resulting in deaths of 51 people in first six months of 2006, compared with 66 in all of 2005, and that government is implicated in killings; Beatriz Perido, leader of human rights group in Lupao region, says she has been forced into hiding by death threats; her organization, Karapatan, says more than 700 civilians, including more than 300 left-wing activists, have been killed around the country by 'suspected security forces' in past five years (M)

headline: Rising Production Costs Join the List of What China Exports
abstract: Signs are multiplying that China, as its economy races forward, is raising prices of goods it exports as result of cost increases for raw materials and labor; China's role in global disinflation is not going to disappear, but recent numbers and anecdotal evidence suggest that its contribution to low prices globally may be ebbing; data in US shows that Chinese import prices are leveling off; photo (M)

headline: Talk of Liberty Deal Leaves Some Puzzled
abstract: Possibility of swap of Liberty Media Corp's stake in News Corp for News Corp's holding in DirecTV is greeted with enthusiasm by News Corp investors and skepticisy by Liberty shareholders; future of DirecTV seems even more precarious after Federal Communications Commission Chairman Kevin Martin says FCC will not look favorably on merger of DirecTV and EchoStar Communications; photo (M)

headline: Car Parts Maker Fires Officers After Inquiry
abstract: CSK Auto Corporation dismisses president and chief operating officer Martin Fraser and chief administrative officer Don Watson after accounting investigation identifies errors; chief executive Maynard Jenkins will resign after successor is named; auto parts maker will restate financial results from fiscal year 2001 through first three quarters of 2005 (M)

headline: Lawyers Seek to Throw Out Lay Conviction
abstract: Lawyers for former Enron executive Kenneth Lay, who died last month, ask federal judge to throw out his fraud conviction; Jaclyn Lesch, spokeswoman for government's Enron Task Froce, says Justice Department remains committed to pursuing all available legal remedies for victims; US District Judge Sim Lake says Lay's estate could take his place as defendant in criminal proceedings (M)

headline: In a Graying Japan, Lower Shelves and Wider Aisles
abstract: Convenience stores in Japan, which for decades have largely served youthful clientele, hope to lift sales by catering to country's growing elderly population; are widening aisles to accommodate wheelchairs, lowering shelves for easier reach, enlarging price tags and adding tables where people can linger and socialize; Lawson, Japan's second-largest convenience store chain, plans to transform 20 percent of 8,400 stores into elderly-oriented stores, focusing on rural areas with large concentrations of the elderly; photos; map (M)

headline: Own a PSP, but Tired of Squinting?
abstract: Nyko's Play on TV Adaptor for Sony's PlayStation Portable clamps onto game console, scans image and sends signal through standard cables to user's television set; costs $80; photo (M)

headline: Farms’ Output Grows Closer to Matching Fishing Harvests
abstract: Food and Agriculture Organization of United Nations reports that fish farms are close to matching fishing fleets in supplying seafood to expanding global markets; credits explosive growth of acquaculture in China for more than decade; warns that both sources of supply taken together are unlikely to keep up with demand fueled by rising populations and incomes; says main impediments to aquaculture are lack of sufficient capital in poorer countries, limited land and fresh water and concern about environmental impact; says there is not much chance of increasing ocean fishing because most wild fish stocks are already either overexploited or at peak harvest; graph (M)

headline: I.R.S. Wins Its Appeal Over Abusive Tax Shelter
abstract: Three-judge US Court of Appeals, overturning lower court decision, rules Goodrich Corp subsidiary Coltec Industries is not entitled to $83 million refund from IRS stemming from tax shelter it bought through Arthur Andersen; shelter, known as continent liability shelter, is intended to generate losses and was barred by IRS in 2001 (M)

headline: Ford and G.M. Talk of Quality as They Try to Court Buyers
abstract: After years of trying to court customers with ever-larger discounts, General Motors and the Ford Motor Company are now vying to prove that each is more willing to stand behind the vehicles it builds.     They also hope to persuade consumers who started buying Toyotas and Hondas out of frustration that the quality problems that have plagued American vehicles have been fixed.

headline: Turkey, a Touchy Critic, Plans to Put a Novel on Trial
abstract: ''If there is a thief in a novel,'' said Elif Shafak recently, ''it doesn't make the novelist a thief.''      Yet, Ms. Shafak is due in court here on Sept. 21 to defend herself against charges that she insulted ''Turkishness'' because a character in her latest novel, ''The Bastard of Istanbul,'' refers to the deaths of Armenians in 1915 as genocide.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS: AUDIT AT ACCOUNTING FIRM
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm, is being audited by the Internal Revenue Service for potential violations in reporting its own taxes, according to I.R.S. and company documents. The review may be completed later this month and the I.R.S. is expected to reach its conclusions by the end of the year, a PricewaterhouseCoopers tax partner, Samuel Starr, said in a June 15 letter to the firm's 2,000 United States partners, who could be liable for any back taxes. ''PricewaterhouseCoopers is a large organization and like any large entity is under constant review by various taxing jurisdictions,'' said Steven Silber, a spokesman for the firm, which is based in New York.

headline: Drug Makers Pay for Lunch as They Pitch
abstract: Anyone who thinks there is no such thing as a free lunch has never visited 3003 New Hyde Park Road, a four-story medical building on Long Island, where they are delivered almost every day.     On a recent Tuesday, they began arriving around noon. Steaming containers of Chinese food were destined for the 20 or so doctors and employees of Nassau Queens Pulmonary Associates. The drug maker Merck paid the $258 bill.

headline: Israel Says Blockade of Lebanon Will Continue
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Olmert of Israel rebuffs request from United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan for even partial lifting of seven-week-old blockade of Lebanon; recalls Annan's previous insistence that all parties to UN-brokered cease-fire on Aug 14 abide by all of its provisions; two men appear at joint news conference in Jerusalem; Olmert's domestic popularity has suffered from widespread dissatisfaction with his handling of war, which failed to achieve his broad goal of dismantling or at least disarming Hezbollah; Annan travels to Ramallah on West Bank to meet with Palestinian Pres Mahmoud Abbas; Annan notes continuing conflict in Palestinian areas has been overshadowed by fighting between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon; photo (M)

headline: In Russian City, a Rampage of Ethnic Violence
abstract: Ethnic animosity that runs close to surface of Russian society erupts in quiet mill town of Kondopoga, on shore of Lake Onego 600 miles north of Moscow; photo; map; deaths of two ethnic Russians in bar fight with men from Azerbaijan and Chechnya provoke angry protests and rampage through town, followed by sporadic acts of vandalism in last week; mobs of young men fueled by anger and alcohol burn Azerbaijani-owned bar and then properties of Caucasus migrants; tensions are fueled by latent racism common among many Russians, who freely use perjorative 'blacks' to describe migrants; police have arrested more than 100 people, including three accused murderers, but Karelia Gov Sergei Katanandov blames behavior of migrants, not mobs (M)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES
abstract: BEING BRITISH AND MUSLIM -- British policies in Afghanistan, Iraq and Lebanon have led to resentment among some Muslims in Britain. For a few, that has led to violence. For many others, it has meant struggling with competing identities.   PAGE 6    QAEDA-PAKISTAN ROLE? -- A Pakistani official says a report that bombers in the 2005 London attacks met in Pakistan with senior Qaeda leaders suggests that they may be coordinating or inspiring militants.   PAGE 6    RALLYING REPUBLICANS -- A week ago, the Republican Party seemed splintered over White House policies. But news on terror has given the administration a chance to unite the party for the midterm elections.   PAGE 21    NAVIGATING NEW RULES -- Flying from New York to London, passengers encounter another post-9/11 transitional moment, with old fears and new procedures.   WEEK IN REVIEW

headline: Trying to Figure Out How Much Tease Is Too Much
abstract: Julie Bosman Advertising column explores question of whether teaser ad campaigns that dupe consumers with fake videos and covert viral marketing efforts go too far; focuses on current teaser campaign for new ABC show Six Degrees; photo (M)

headline: China Gives Times Researcher 3 Years
abstract: A Beijing court on Friday morning unexpectedly dismissed a state secrets charge against a researcher for The New York Times but sentenced him to three years in prison on a lesser, unrelated charge of fraud.     The verdict against the researcher, Zhao Yan, 44, spared him a prison sentence of 10 years or longer and also served as a blunt rebuke to the investigation by state security agents. Agents began detaining Mr. Zhao almost two years ago and accused him of leaking state secrets to The Times. He has consistently stated that he is innocent of both charges.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,675 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:    DAVIS, David J., 32, Sgt., Army; Mount Airy, Md.; Fourth Squadron, 14th Cavalry, 172nd Stryker Brigade Combat Team.
