KNOX, Adam L., 21, Sgt., Army Reserve; Columbus, Ohio; 346th Psychological Operations Company.  MAKOWSKI, Russell M., 23, Specialist, Army; Union, Mo.; Fourth Infantry Division.  SHAFFER, Jeffrey P., 21, Pfc., Army; Harrison, Ark.; First Armored Division.  WORSTER, James R., 24, Sgt., Army; Broadview Heights, Ohio; 10th Combat Support Hospital, 43rd Area Support Group.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Eight Months Still To Go
abstract: Segolene Royal, front-runner to be Socialist Party's candidate to succeed Pres Jacques Chirac, says she returned from vacation with her partner Francois Hollande to find that their Parisian apartment had been rifled; claims it was not burglary, but search of her home (S)

headline: Iran Fires Practice Missiles and Affirms Nuclear Stance
abstract: As Iran fired 10 short-range missiles on the second day of a large-scale military maneuver, officials on Sunday reiterated Iran's stance that it did not intend to halt its uranium enrichment program.     The statement comes two days before Iran's self-imposed deadline of Aug. 22 for responding to a package of incentives offered by six Western nations in return for halting the program. The United Nations Security Council has set a deadline of Aug. 31 for Ian to suspend the program or face the possibility of economic sanctions. Statements by officials so far suggest that Iran will neither agree to the incentives deal nor yield to the Security Council.

headline: Back of the Envelope
abstract: Chart of leading US technology private equity mergers and acquisitions (S)

headline: Former Aide Says Pinochet and a Son Dealt in Drugs
abstract: Gen. Augusto Pinochet's former intelligence chief, now one of his bitterest enemies, has implicated the disgraced dictator and one of his sons in a cocaine manufacturing and smuggling scheme and contends that it was one of the sources of General Pinochet's illicit $28 million fortune.     Gen. Manuel Contreras, who ran the Directorate of National Intelligence, the Chilean secret police, during the 1970's, made the charges in a document submitted last week to an investigating magistrate here. He also accused General Pinochet of embezzling money from secret government accounts that the dictator controlled during his 17 years in power, which ended in 1990.

headline: British Police Arrest 3 Over Taps on Phones at Royal Residence
abstract: British police arrest three men on suspicion of intercepting telephone calls, reportedly on cellphones, after complaints by staff at Clarence House, Prince Charles's residence in London; tabloid News of the World acknowledges arrest of reporter Clive Goodman; police statement says other public figures may also have had calls intercepted (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Troops Take Area Of Defiant Militia
abstract: Georgia said its special police forces had taken control of the remote Kodori Gorge, but were searching for a militia leader who had eluded capture. Government troops had intermittently clashed for two days with a paramilitary militia, known as the Hunter Battalion, whose leader, Emzar Kvitsiani, had said he would not recognize federal rule. The fighting, in the mountains along the Russian border and beside the breakaway region of Abkhazia, raised concerns of a wider conflict. A full accounting of the casualties has not been released, but at least one civilian, a woman, died in the clashes. The government put a bounty on information leading to Mr. Kvitsiani's capture.   C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

headline: Job Growth Slackened Last Month
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports US economy gained only seasonally adjusted 113,000 jobs in July, well below first-quarter pace of 176,000; unemployment rate jumped 0.2 percent, to 4.8 percent, highest level in five months, with nearly all of increase among African-Americans; some economists, citing job numbers and slowdowns in housing and retail sales and business investment, express concern that Federal Reserve will push nation toward recession if it lifts interest rates much higher; photo; graph (M)

headline: ‘Survivor’ to Divide Teams Along Racial Lines
abstract: CBS' Survivor reality show will divide its teams along racial lines for its new season; four teams of five members each will be made up of blacks, Asian-Americans, Hispanics and whites; series producer Mark Burnett says decision is effort to make program more diverse, not to create racial diviseness; photo (M)

headline: In British Inquiry, a Family Caught in 2 Worlds
abstract: Abdul Rauf and his sons British-born Rashid and Tayib and Crescent Relief charity Abdul helped found are at heart of British investigation into alleged terrorist plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airliners; central question concerns connection between younger Raufs and world of sophisticated terrorism based in Pakistan and Afghanistan; authorities see Tayib as leader of plot in Britain and Rashid as connection to Pakistan; Tayib has been arrested by British authorities and Rashid has been arrested by Pakistanis, but whereabouts of Abdul are unknown; photos (L)

headline: U.S. Transportation Security Agency Prohibits Carrying Liquids and Gels on Flights
abstract: Travelers still having nightmares over the delays caused by passengers who forgot to remove tweezers and matches from their carry-on luggage should prepare for the Transportation Security Administration's new target: all nonsolid forms of matter.     Effective yesterday, the Department of Homeland Security banned all liquids and gels from carry-on luggage aboard airplanes. That means everything from bottled water to coffee to common toiletries like contact-lens solution, nail polish and toothpaste now must be checked. If you forget, prepare to surrender offending items at the security checkpoint.

headline: Airbus Jet Faces Further Delivery Delays
abstract: The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent company of Airbus, confirmed Thursday that the troubled A380 would face still more delivery delays while it tackles wiring ''challenges.''     This prompted hints by some important customers of the twin-deck A380 that they may scale back their orders of the plane. The news also raised fresh questions about the depths of the troubles facing Airbus and the credibility of its management at a time when the company is struggling to regain customer and shareholder confidence.

headline: Conflict Leads Smirnoff To Drop Bartle Bogle
abstract: An agency that gained attention for a humorous commercial appearing on YouTube, promoting a new Smirnoff beverage, is losing its Smirnoff account.     The agency, the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, has created campaigns for Smirnoff malt beverages like Smirnoff Ice since early last year. The Smirnoff parent, Diageo, is returning the account to its previous agency, JWT in New York, part of the WPP Group. JWT, the worldwide agency for Smirnoff vodka, handled the Smirnoff malt beverages from 2000 to 2004.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: In A Compromise, Fox Stays Away
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox will avoid confrontation with leftist protesters in Mexico City on Independece Day and celebrate in Dolores Hidalgo (S)

headline: More Iraqis Fleeing Strife and Segregating by Sect
abstract: Relentless sectarian violence is forcing Iraqi families to flee their homes in ever larger numbers, according to figures released Thursday by the Iraqi government.      Sattar Nowruz, a spokesman for the Ministry of Displacement and Migration, said 1,117 families abandoned mixed areas for Shiite or Sunni strongholds in the last week alone, an increase since March that analysts described as a conservative snapshot of internal migration.

headline: Borrowing Rises as Credit Card Use Jumps
abstract: Federal Reserve reports rise in consumer credit in May for seventh consecutive month; consumer credit rises to $4.4 billion, or 2.5 percent at annual rate, to $2.174 trillion (M)

headline: Thousands Flee as Hurricane John Batters Mexican Coast
abstract: Hurricane John churns up western coast of Mexico, raking coastal towns and tourist resorts with high winds and heavy rains but staying far enough offshore to prevent major damage; photo; map (S)

headline: My Life B.W., Before Wi-Fi
abstract: David Pogue column describes difference between 1995 and present day in terms of ease of communicating via Internet; cites dearth of available connections while traveling in 1995 and one particularly difficult episode that occurred while trying to transmit data; drawings (M)

headline: Sick, and Far From Home
abstract: Article on increasing popularity of stand-alone international medical insurance, which offers coverage for self-employed executives and businesses whose staff travel abroad; some companies that offer such coverage and types of medical conditions and expenses they cover described; photo (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: THE TIME EVOLUTION -- For most of the 20th century, under the influence of its founder, Henry R. Luce, Time magazine spoke in a single authoritative voice that reflected the world back to its readers. Now Richard Stengel, the new managing editor of Time, wants to change the metaphor. His plan is to fill the pages of Time with more essays and news analysis, give the magazine a sharper point of view and draw more brand-name journalists into the fold. If this sounds familiar, it may be that Mr. Stengel wants Time to be a little more like its chief rival, Newsweek. [Page C1.]    A WIKI WAVE -- Although Wikipedia is operated by a nonprofit foundation, ideas for advertising-based wiki sites are beginning to take their place alongside blogs and social networking sites as a staple of Silicon Valley business plans. [C1.]    GIRLS AS GAMERS -- The Frag Dolls, a group of stylish, fresh-faced girls, are one of the latest weapons in the gaming industry's effort to smash the stereotypical image of the gamer as a geeky teenage boy battling aliens. The French computer game giant Ubisoft is backing teams of girl game players while the girls help Ubisoft promote computer play. Other companies are also intensifying efforts to tap the feminine side of computers in a $29 billion industry that is trying to cope with declining sales as consumers await the arrival of a new generation of consoles. [C2.]    A REVIVAL OF SORTS -- Vonage went public in May at $17 and bottomed out at $6.30 in July, but since then the stock has stabilized and climbed slightly. It closed on Friday at $8.90. Today, the company plans to announce that it has attained 2 million subscribers, up from 1.6 million at the end of the first quarter. [C1.]    A MESSAGE IN LEBANON -- A billboard for Johnnie Walker whiskey stretches across the side of a multistory building north of Beruit and shows a drawing of a bridge with a chunk missing. In an allusion to the Israeli air strikes, the Johnnie Walker character, cane in hand, strides away from the gap and across the bridge on the poster, which urges the Lebanese to ''keep walking.'' The ad is notable because multinational companies usually go out of their way to insulate their marketing from any reference to sensitive international disputes. [C4.]    ASSESSING A PRODUCT -- Scores of Internet merchants have begun following Amazon's lead by posting customer reviews -- both flattering and flaming -- of products they sell, and directing shoppers to sources of the most highly rated items. At Petco, for example, the Web division has tested the service of a new technology that essentially polls retail customers. According to John Lazarchic, Petco's vice president for e-commerce, left, 30 days after the company placed links near products asking visitors to write reviews, more than 1,000 products attracted comments. Bob Tedeschi, E-Commerce Report [C5.]    BLOG SITE SHUTDOWN -- Lee Siegel, a senior editor for The New Republic and the author of the Lee Siegel on Culture blog, was suspended indefinitely from the magazine after a reader accused him of using a ''sock puppet,'' or Internet alias, to attack his critics in the comments section of his own blog. An editor's apology replaced the blog on the Web site. [C4.]    TAKING ON ITUNES -- So far, none of the companies that sell music online have emerged as serious competitors to Apple iTunes. But not one has an audience like MySpace, which announced plans to begin selling songs. For the industry, which worries about Apple's online dominance, a MySpace music store could present a difficult decision. News Analysis. [C3.]    THE LIFE OF CONRAD BLACK -- According to a Canadian newspaper report, a recent court order stipulates that Conrad M. Black and his wife, Barbara Amiel, can each spend up to $25,000 a month on ''reasonable'' expenses, which must be approved by the court. For Lord Black, that is budget living. In a financial disclosure, Lord Black said his monthly expenses ran more in the range of $200,000, and that was after selling his homes in London and New York. The asset freeze is yet another major obstacle for the former press tycoon, who is at the center of a web of corporate scandal and is preparing to defend himself against criminal fraud and racketeering charges. [C1.]    MARKETS CLOSED TODAY -- Financial markets and banks in the United States are closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day. They will reopen Tuesday.

headline: Days Before Brazil Votes, New Scandal for Leader
abstract: Just when President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva thought he was past the worst of the scandals that have plagued his government for the past 18 months, a new, especially damaging one has surfaced. And the timing could not be worse for him: barely a week before Brazil's 126 million voters cast their ballots in a presidential election.     The focus of the new scandal is a dossier that officials in Mr. da Silva's party and campaign had hoped would incriminate his opponent in the 2002 election, former Minister of Health José Serra, in an overbilling scheme involving the sale of ambulances. Mr. Serra is now a candidate for governor of São Paulo, the country's most populous state, and is running far ahead of one of Mr. da Silva's allies.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Petrobras Protests Bolivian Measures
abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro cancels meeting with Bolivian government officials after Brazil takes steps to take over company's oil operations in country (S)

headline: 7 Face Srebrenica Tribunal in Largest Group Trial at The Hague
abstract: Seven former officers in Bosnian Serb forces are on trial for their role in massacre of 8,000 men and boys in Srebrenica in 1995; it is largest group trial in history of war crimes tribunal in Hague; five of accused are facing charges of genocide; they are Ljubisa Beara, Ljubomir Borovcanin, Vinko Pandurevic, Drago Nikolic and Vujadin Popovic; Radivoj Miletic and Milan Gvero are accused of war crimes and crimes against humanity (M)

headline: Root, Root, Root for the Start-Up
abstract: Article on Golden Baseball League, formed two years ago by Silicon Valley venture capitalists Kevin Outcalt, David Kaval and Amit Patel; three men expect six-team league to expand to at least 40 teams, or even 80, in upcoming years and hope to have rich payout through public stock offering or sale to large entertainment conglomerate; have already sold league's naming rights and have taken aggressive advertising stance, even allowing ads to be placed on player uniforms; recruit players rejected by major-league farm teams; photos (L)

headline: Foes Say Tehran Builds Fast Uranium Centrifuges
abstract: National Council of Resistance in Iran, political wing of People's Mujahedeen of Iran, which seeks to overthrow Islamic Republic by force, says in Paris that Iran has built at least 15 advanced uranium enrichment machines that could speed production of nuclear fuel; says Iran will have a hundred more by next year (M)

headline: Official Union Set Up in China at Wal-Mart
abstract: Workers at Wal-Mart Stores have formed their first trade union in China, after demands from the government that the company allow organized labor in its stores, according to reports in the official news media over the weekend.     Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, has long sought to bar unions from its stores, particularly in the United States. But the government-controlled All-China Federation of Trade Unions has campaigned to set up branches in China, where Wal-Mart employs 30,000 people at 60 outlets.

headline: It’s a Good Time to Be a Landlord
abstract: Article on current boom times for rental housing landlords; apartment vacancy rate is at five-year low, averaging 5.6 percent nationwide and only 2.9 percent in New York metropolitan area, while rents have risen average of nearly 4 percent over last year; photos; graph (M)

headline: In a Slow Period, Lehman Posts Strong Profit
abstract: On Tuesday, shares of Lehman Brothers surged after Goldman Sachs, one of its main rivals, reported earnings that were better than expected. Yesterday, Lehman turned the same trick, reporting strong third-quarter results amid weak markets, lackluster deal flow and higher global interest rates.      Lehman shares rose $2.10, or 3 percent, to $70.12.

headline: When the Résumé Is Not to Be Believed
abstract: Article offers advice to small businesses on how to detect whether resumes are accurate; 2005 survey by Society for Human Resource Management said that almost half of human-resource specialists had significantly increased time they spent checking resumes and that 52 percent had started contracting background checking; drawing (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Scuffles in China as Trial of Peasants’ Rights Advocate Is Postponed
abstract: Chinese officials postponed the criminal trial of a peasants' rights advocate on Thursday as his supporters gathered in large numbers to protest what they say is a politically motivated prosecution.     Some 200 people gathered outside a courthouse in Yinan County, Shandong Province, where Chen Guangcheng, who is blind and taught himself law, had been scheduled to go on trial on charges of destroying property and blocking traffic.

headline: Canadian Regulator Delays Decision on a Mining Bid
abstract: Investment Canada expands by at least 30 days review of takeover by Xstrata of Switzerland of Canadian nickel mining company Falconbridge (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Fire And Blasts At Arms Warehouse
abstract: Two days of fire and explosions at Novobohdanivka arms depot in Ukraine disrupt rail service; began as brush fire that spread to vast stores of weapons abandoned after fall of Soviet Union (S)

headline: White-Water Rafting With Everything but the Guide
abstract: Article on Professional River Outfitters (PRO), river-rafting service in Flagstaff, Ariz, that offers unguided raft expeditions down Colorado River to private boaters who have obtained coveted non-commercial river permits that Grand Canyon National Park issues each year; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Toll Rises in Middle East; Bunker Is Hit
abstract: The deadliest day yet in the deepening two-front Middle East crisis claimed more than 70 lives on Wednesday in Lebanon, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and northern Israel, with no immediate cease-fire in sight.      ''The country has been torn to shreds,'' a desperate Lebanese prime minister, Fouad Siniora, said at a meeting he had called of foreign diplomats, including the American ambassador.

headline: For Flight Attendants, No Liquids and No Glamour
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on adverse impact that no liquids/no gels airline security rules are having on flight attendants; Janice Gorham, flight attendant for 33 years, comments; drawing (M)

headline: Mixed Ruling in France on Suit Against Morgan Stanley
abstract: Both sides claim victory when Paris Court of Appeals upholds ruling that Morgan Stanley harmed LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton while trying to take over rival Gucci Group when analyst Claire Kent wrote negative report in 2002; appeals court finds Morgan Stanley incorrectly stated LVMH's debt level but rejects contention that Kent's work was intentionally biased; LVMH says it is now seeking more than 100 million euros ($128 million) in material damages; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: MTV Acquires Its Partner
abstract: Viacom unit MTV Networks agrees to buy out H&Q Asia Pacific, partner in MTV Japan, to consolidate businesses in country and increase growth (S)

headline: Executive Buys Control of CMS
abstract: Daisy Expósito-Ulla, a longtime executive at agencies specializing in the Hispanic market, is returning to advertising by buying a majority stake in an agency, CMS/Partners in New York, that was started last year by former colleagues. Financial terms were not disclosed.     Ms. Expósito-Ulla will become chairwoman at the agency, renamed D Expósito & Partners. Her former colleagues, Fernando Fernández and Gloria Constanza, who were partners at CMS/Partners, will be partners at the renamed agency. Ms. Expósito-Ulla had most recently been chairwoman and chief executive at the Bravo Group in New York, part of the Young & Rubicam Brands division of the WPP Group.

headline: When Couric Broadcasts the News, Some Radio and Web Sites Will Too
abstract: When a network evening newscast passes the anchor's baton, viewers have come to expect an overhauled set, music and graphics. But for Sept. 5, when Katie Couric takes over on ''The CBS Evening News,'' the network is planning more widespread changes, including fanning the newscast out across different media, including radio and the Web, to capture a wider audience.     Taking questions from more than 200 television critics gathered here on Sunday for their semiannual meeting, Ms. Couric and Sean McManus, president of CBS News and Sports, outlined some of what Mr. McManus calls ''expansive and in many ways unprecedented'' changes that will come when Ms. Couric takes over from Bob Schieffer and becomes the first female sole anchor of a major network newscast.

headline: Microsoft to Provide and Sell Ads on Facebook, the Web Site
abstract: Microsoft Corporation will be exclusive provider of advertising for social networking site Facebook over next three years; deal follows Google Inc's announcement that it agreed to pay at least $900 million to News Corporation to provide search functions and advertising to MySpace.com (M)

headline: For One Publisher, the Life of Every Comic Book Starts on the Web
abstract: For generations of Americans, comic books were the first real page-turners. But the audience for their digital counterpart, called Webcomics, has for the most part been limited to a niche group of comic book creators and their most ardent followers.      Scott Mitchell Rosenberg, the chairman of Platinum Studios, a privately held California entertainment company that develops and adapts comics for other media, wants to change that.

headline: Venezuela’s Passion: Twisting the Tail of an Angry Beast
abstract: Venezuelan sport of coleo features four men on horseback chasing bull within corridor length of football field for five minutes, competing to see who can tip animal over most times by pulling its tail; bull is encouraged to get to its feet again by twisting or biting tail, or by electric prod; many bruised and worn out bulls are hauled to slaughterhouse afterward; supporters want Pres Hugo Chavez to declare coleo national sport; photo; map (M)

headline: At Some Publishers, Nonbusiness Is Going Strong
abstract: Richard Siklos column on continued success of AARP The Magazine and Consumer Reports despite their not-for-profit status; notes AARP increased its advertising revenue by 37 percent in 2005, magazine plays central role in promoting AARP and affiliated products and receives tens of millions in federal and other grants and contributions each year; Consumer Reports has increased print sales, added new magazine ShopSmart and continues to eschew ads; drawing (M)

headline: Palestinian Prime Minister Calls for a Truce With Israel and New Talks
abstract: Palestinian Prime Min Ismail Haniya of Hamas calls for mutual cease-fire with Israel after Israeli forces pull out of most of northern Gaza Strip; move may be response to Israeli hints that package deal might be possible to end military and political crisis caused by kidnapping of Israeli Cpl Gilad Shalit and militant rocket-fire into Israel; Israeli official says there will be no cease-fire until release of Shalit; photo (M)

headline: Europe Union and Iran Report Progress in Nuclear Talks
abstract: Representatives of Iran and the European Union said Sunday that they had made progress in the search for a compromise to avert possible United Nations sanctions over Iran's nuclear program, and they said they would meet again soon.      ''The meeting, the hours of work, have been productive,'' said Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign policy chief, after two rounds of talks in Vienna with Ali Larijani, Iran's top nuclear negotiator. ''We have clarified some of the misunderstandings that existed before.''

headline: Living at the Crossroads, Working There, Too
abstract: Tens of thousands of businesspeople now fly in and out of Willow Run Airport in Ypsilanti, Mich, on shuttles operated by Johnson Controls and Pfizer; Detroit Metro Airport seven miles east is also enjoying surge in passenger traffic; Wayne County leaders see two airports as anchors of Airport City, new regional development strategy to attract high-tech manufacturers, research campuses, housing and jobs; photo (M)

headline: Inco, Not Getting Raised Bid, Returns to Phelps Dodge Offer
abstract: Inco, failing to persuade Companhia Vale do Rio Doce to increase hostile takeover bid, confirms its support for friendly offer from Phelps Dodge; photo (M)

headline: Court Upholds Case Dismissal in Ford Harassment Lawsuit
abstract: Michigan Supreme Court, in 4-to-3 ruling, upholds lower court decision to dismiss sexual harassment suit filed against Ford Motor Co on grounds that plaintiff Justine Maldonado and her lawyers discussed with reporters evidence that court deemed inadmissible (M)

headline: BetOnSports, After Indictment, Folds Its Hand and Shifts Focus to Asia
abstract: Online gambling site BetOnSports plans to shut down most of its operations after being indicted by United States prosecutors for taking bets from hundreds of thousands of Americans; tells 800 employees in Costa Rica and Antigua of layoffs; will refocus business in Asia and other countries; 70 to 80 percent of site's bets come from United States gamblers; photo (M)

headline: British School, Searched in Inquiry, Was Used to Train Police
abstract: In a strange twist to Britain's newest terrorism scare, a regional police force admitted Monday that it had sent officers for ''diversity training'' to an Islamic school that the police searched Sunday as part of a crackdown on jihadist recruiters and trainers.      In a statement, the Sussex police said the Jameah Islameah school south of London ''has been used by officers and staff undergoing advanced training for their role as diversity trainers to the rest of the work force.''

headline: Thousands of Residents Are Moved From Northern Israeli Towns as Rockets Keep Falling
abstract: Israeli government, unable to stop Hezbollah from firing hundreds of deadly Katyusha rockets into north every day, will temporarily relocate thousands of residents who are unable to leave on their own; most of Kiryat Shmona's 25,000 people have already left and those remaining have been driven underground or behind reinforced concrete; about 500 leave for respite after four weeks in shelters; photo; military is frustrated by inability to stop barrages as it fights pieched battles with Hezbollahwithin few miles of Lebanese border (M)

headline: Prescreening Draws Interest as Lines Grow at Terminals
abstract: The security lines at Orlando International Airport in Florida on Friday provided an unusual glimpse of the future in these increasingly terrorism-conscious times.     As a member of the nation's only express security program, Carolyn Adams, a frequent flier, whisked through a special lane at the checkpoint. Ms. Adams, a prosecutor traveling to Atlanta, had only to approach a kiosk akin to an A.T.M., insert a small plastic card, place her fingers on a touchpad and wait for her identity to be verified before passing through the metal detector.

headline: Auction Schedule for Treasury Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.07 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.23 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.84 percent.

headline: Department Stores Staged a Comeback in June
abstract: Sales at department stores beat specialty apparel chains for second consecutive month according to June data; retail sales generally missed analysts forecasts; sales at stores open at least one year rose 2.8 percent last month compared with year earlier period; graph of sales results for major retailers; photo (M)

headline: Israel Pushes On Despite Agreeing to Airstrike Lull
abstract: As Israel poured soldiers and artillery shells into southern Lebanon, it vowed Monday to press ahead with its war on Hezbollah and made a number of airstrikes after promising a 48-hour pause in its air campaign.     ''The fighting continues,'' Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said. ''There is no cease-fire, and there will not be any cease-fire in the coming days.''

headline: Accounts
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, Bentonville, Ark., hired agencies for two assignments. The New York office of StrawberryFrog will handle the creative part of the Sam's Club account, which had been at GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. Also, Saatchi & Saatchi X, Springdale, Ark., part of the Saatchi & Saatchi unit of the Publicis Groupe, was named the first agency of record for communications aimed at Wal-Mart and Sam's Club employees and shoppers. Spending for the assignments has not been determined.     Sara Lee Corporation, Downers Grove, Ill., expanded its relationship with the office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of Omnicom, in the Playa del Rey section of Los Angeles, awarding the agency the Hillshire Farm brand, which had been at Element 79, Chicago, also part of Omnicom. Billings were estimated at $25 million. TBWA/Chiat/Day also handles Sara Lee brands like Ball Park.

headline: Arrest Made in Crackdown on Internet Betting
abstract: In a sharp escalation of their crackdown on Internet gambling, United States prosecutors said yesterday that they were pressing charges against the chief executive of BetOnSports, a prominent Internet gambling company that is publicly traded in Britain, and against several other current and former company officers.     Federal authorities arrested the chief executive, David Carruthers, late Sunday as he was on layover at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport on his way from Britain to Costa Rica. In a hearing yesterday in Federal District Court in Fort Worth, he was charged with racketeering conspiracy for participating in an illegal gambling enterprise.

headline: New Premier Seeks a Japan With Muscle and a Voice
abstract: In his first act after being installed as prime minister, Shinzo Abe, a popular nationalist who has vowed to make Japan more assertive globally, appointed a cabinet on Tuesday packed with social conservatives and foreign-policy hawks.     Mr. Abe, 52, bowed deeply in front of lawmakers after winning 339 votes in the 476-member lower house, which selects the prime minister.

headline: Amnesty Says Hezbollah Committed War Crimes
abstract: Amnesty International accuses Hezbollah forces of war crimes and 'serious violations of international humanitarian law' during Lebanon war; cites 'firsthand information' in visits to Israel and Lebanon; report specifically rules out any assessment of Israeli accusations that Hezbollah used civilian population as cover for its military activities and should bear responsibility for harm to civilians from Israel's attacks; Hezbollah officials deny endangering civilians or launching attacks on Israel from populated areas (M)

headline: Johnson & Johnson Told to Pay Damages in Pain-Patch Death
abstract: Johnson & Johnson must pay $772,500 in damages to family of Texas woman who died after Duragesic pain patch leaked; claims that patches were safe; Food and Drug Administration is investigating 120 deaths related to patches (M)

headline: In the Exporting Horse Race, It’s China by a Nose Over the U.S.
abstract: Floyd Norris column on switch in which China now exports more goods--$80.337 billion in July--than US, whose figure was $80.313 billion; notes that if figures were seasonally adjusted, which China does not do, US would likely still be ahead, perhaps for a few more months; graphs (M)

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 16 in Kabul Near Embassy
abstract: Suicide bomber smashes his car into US military vehicle near US Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing as many as 16 people and wounding 29; bombing is one of most powerful to shake capital since US forces drove Taliban from power in 2001; US military confirms deaths of two soldiers and says two others were wounded; Afghan police put death toll at 11 civilians and 5 US soldiers; bombing comes amid sharp escalation of violence in Afghanistan, where NATO and US forces are waging offensive to crush Taliban insurgency that has revived with unexpected strength; Gen James L Jones, NATO's top commander of operations, asks for 2,000 to 2,500 people on top of roughly 18,500 soldiers NATO has already deployed in Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Officials Vow to Press Political Shake-Up, Saying Corruption Is Focus
abstract: Chinese authorities vow to press forward with corruption crackdown that has already ensnared Shanghai Communist party chief Chen Liangyu and other ranking officials in major cities; most were considered linked to Jiang Zemin, Pres Hu Jintao's predecessor; political jockeying often precedes party congress, set for Oct; Chen's swift removal could open floodgates for information on power-brokering and deal-making in Shanghai, country's most prosperous market-oriented enclave (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: CHARGES IN OPTIONS INQUIRY -- Federal prosecutors filed the first criminal charges against executives in a mushrooming investigation into the possible manipulation of stock options. Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, and Stephanie Jensen, its former vice president of human resources, were each charged with one count of securities fraud. Their lawyers said they denied the charges and vowed to defend themselves. [Page A1.]    FORD PUSHES THE PEDAL -- Just seven months into its turnaround plan, the Ford Motor Company said it would speed up and expand the plan after it reported a second-quarter loss and falling market share. The company's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said Ford had not abandoned its goal of becoming profitable again in North America by 2008, a promise that some analysts have begun to question. [C1.]    CROSSING THE BORDER -- During the last dozen years, many foreign auto manufacturers rushed to build factories in states like Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee, inspiring the sobriquet Detroit South. Now Mexico is eyeing that nickname as General Motors and others build more factories there. [C1.]    GOOGLE'S PROFIT SOARS -- Google's profit more than doubled in the second quarter as it continued to increase its share of the lucrative search advertising market. [C1.]    SUCCESSOR AT BMW -- The luxury automaker BMW chose its head of production, Norbert Reithofer, to succeed Helmut Panke, the chief executive who had directed the company's successful expansion into the United States while pushing it to ever-higher profits. [C7.]    COSTLY MEDICAL MISTAKES -- Medication errors harm 1.5 million people and kill several thousand each year in the United States, costing the nation at least $3.5 billion annually, a report by the Institute of Medicine concluded. [A12.]    MAD COW TESTING SCALED BACK -- The Agriculture Department said it would scale back testing for mad cow disease by about 90 percent, saying the number of infected animals was far too low to justify the current level of surveillance. [A13.]    THE NEW MA BELL -- If AT&T's pending purchase of BellSouth is approved, as expected, by the end of the year, it plans to rename that company as well as Cingular, which they jointly own. The rebranding campaign is an attempt to capitalize on the most recognizable name in the phone business as AT&T tries to sell bundles of services under a single banner. Advertising. [C7.]    TOYOTA WEIGHS IN -- The president of Toyota, Katsuaki Watanabe, below, said his company was not considering an alliance with General Motors, denying reports that Toyota might make an offer to compete with one from Renault-Nissan. He also apologized for a recall scandal that has added to mounting quality woes at Toyota. [C4.]    LAW FIRMS UNDER PRESSURE -- The nation's largest law firms, long dominated by white men, now have a powerful incentive to add minority and women lawyers to their ranks: Some of their biggest corporate clients are demanding it. [C6.]    YUKOS HEAD STEPS DOWN -- The American president of the Yukos oil company, Steven M. Theede, announced his resignation, ending two years in charge of Yukos, Russia's embattled private energy company. [C7.]    ONLINE    SQUARE FEET -- As Midtown rents go up, small companies in modest Class B office buildings could be out of their quarters entirely. A report is at nytimes.com/realestate.    SLIDE SHOW: PERSONAL SHOPPER -- Twenty-four decorators dress up 18,000 square feet in Bridgehampton, on Long Island at nytimes.com/style.    ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    THE LEAR CORPORATION and the billionaire investor Wilbur Ross said that Mr. Ross's International Automotive Components Group had agreed to buy nearly all of Lear's European auto interiors business. (REUTERS)    THE OIL SERVICES conglomerate Halliburton Company said second-quarter net income rose 51 percent, mostly on strong demand and higher prices for energy services. (REUTERS)    CONTINENTAL AIRLINES said its second-quarter net income nearly doubled because of higher fares and packed planes. (AP)    A FEDERAL JUDGE in Alabama ruled that a former chief financial officer of HealthSouth, Weston L. Smith, must pay $6.92 million for his part in an accounting fraud at the chain of rehabilitation and surgery centers. (BLOOOMBERG NEWS)    THE HERSHEY COMPANY said second-quarter profit grew 6 percent, helped in part by seasonal shipments and the popularity of its Kissables candy-coated chocolates. (AP)    HONEYWELL INTERNATIONAL said second-quarter profit surged 73 percent on strong sales, and that full-year earnings would be better than expected. (AP)    IMCLONE SYSTEMS said its second-quarter profit rose 43 percent, surpassing Wall Street estimates, as strong sales of the cancer drug Erbitux increased revenue. (AP)

headline: Europe Drawing Up Plans to Deal With Cheap Shoe Imports From Asia
abstract: European Union, seeking to avoid another surge of imports of leather shoes from China and Vietnam, is drafting plan to impose five-year combination of tariffs and quotas; new measures would cover only about 20 percent of market for leather footwear in Europe; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Revenues From Oil Rise Only Slightly
abstract: Government Accountability Office, following nearly six-month investigation, reports federal revenues from oil and gas produced on publicly owned land, barely increased in recent years despite soaring energy prices; agrees with Interior Department assessment that apparent shortfall in revenue stemmed primarily from statistical confusion about production (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,557 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    CASTNER, Stephen W., 27, Specialist, Army National Guard; Cedarburg, Wis.; First Battalion, 121st Field Artillery.    FARGO, Adam J., 22, Cpl., Army; Ruckersville, Va.; 101st Airborne Division.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 3 More Airline Incidents
abstract: Three Russian passenger planes made emergency landings after suffering malfunctions one day after a jet burst into flames in Siberia after crashing during a landing. No one died in the new incidents, but three people were injured when their Tu-134, carrying the navy chief of staff, Vladimir Masorin, caught fire after it overran the runway at a military base in the Crimea region of Ukraine. An Airbus A-310 operated by S7 Airlines made an emergency landing in Ukraine after an engine malfunctioned, and a Urals Airlines Tu-154 flight from Yekaterinburg landed in Irkutsk after one of its engines broke down. On Sunday, an S7 A-310 crashed in Irkutsk; 124 people died and 4 were missing.   C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

headline: World Bank Reaches Pact With Chad Over Use of Oil Profits
abstract: World Bank reaches agreement with Chad over how to spend profits of nation's booming oil industry, with Chad promising to earmark 70 percent of money to fight poverty; agreement ends dispute that threatened to kill experimental arrangement in which World Bank agreed to invest in Chad's oil industry if bulk of proceeds went toward alleviating poverty (M)

headline: F.B.I. Calls Ex-Comverse Chief a Fugitive, and Casts a Wide Net
abstract: FBI declares former Comverse chief executive Jacob Alexander fugitive after he fails to show up for arraignment on charges that he and two others conspired to commit securities fraud in connection with suspected stock options scheme; Alexander has roots in Israel and he wired about $57 million from accounts in US to Israel in July; photo (M)

headline: World Powers Fail to Agree on Plan to End Fighting, Underscoring U.S. Influence on Israel
abstract: World powers failed to agree Wednesday on a plan to end the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah, underscoring the power of the United States to prevail when it comes to dealing with Israel.      In their formal statement, the United States, the Europeans, and Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia expressed a vague ''determination to work immediately to reach with the utmost urgency a cease-fire that puts an end to the current violence and hostilities.''

headline: Smart Is as Smart Does
abstract: Syms Corp chief executive Marcy Syms The Boss column on her early business experiences and influence that her father Sy Syms had on her work ethic and attitude toward job; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: The Churn column on some recent executive appointments (S)

headline: Focus Moves to One Shelter in Tax Inquiry
abstract: Federal prosecutors investigating Deutsche Bank over its role in questionable tax shelters are focusing on Cards shelter sold through investment firm known as MyCFO.com, created by Netscape Communications founder James H Clark; investigation aims to determine whether loans involved in shelter were legitimate (M)

headline: For Cuban Exiles, a Day Filled With Celebrations, Rumors and the Wait for News
abstract: Anticipation is palpable in South Florida, as Cubans await updates from island they fled, mostly to escape authoritarian rule and harsh economic conditions under Pres Fidel Castro, who has ceded power to his brother Raul because of illness; Miami's emergency operations center opens in case developments in Cuba foment chaos; photo (M)

headline: With Little Authority, African Union Force Struggles With Its Mission in Darfur
abstract: African Union peacekeeping force in Darfur is struggling to keep fragile peace in war-wracked region; force, with its poor equipment and tiny contingent of 7,000 troops, had hoped to turn over command to larger, better-equipped UN-led force, but government has refused, as it continues to press offensive against some rebel factions; it has proposed keeping African Union force in place; map; photo (M)

headline: Cut Off, Gazan Economy Nears Collapse
abstract: For the last week, Zidan Abu Reziq has been sleeping outside, next to his plantings on a small square of sand he expropriated.     The Abu Reziqs, like many of the large, destitute refugee families in this shrapneled, tumbledown slum, need to plant to eat. They took the land and planted it with vegetables, an investment of about $50, most of the money that the United Nations Relief and Works Agency gave them to buy school uniforms for the children.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: More Security Urged For Envoys In Region
abstract: Chinese officials urge Central and South Asian countries to increase security for Chinese diplomats after deportations of Uighurs to China from neighboring countries (S)

headline: Got a Secret? Share It With Us, Marketers Say
abstract: Growing number of national advertising campaigns are inviting public to reveal secrets to be disclosed publicly or, in some cases, marketers are sharing corporate 'secrets' themselves; trend is inspired by popular culture and obsession with celebrity gossip; companies like Nestle, Procter & Gamble and 3M take advantage of Internet to allow consumers to share secrets; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Peter Daboll joined Yahoo, Sunnyvale, Calif., in a new post, chief of insights and head of global market research. He had been president and chief executive at comScore Media Metrix, Reston, Va.     Rob Feakins joined Publicis USA, part of the Publicis Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe, in the new posts of president and chief creative officer for the New York office. Mr. Feakins, who also becomes chief creative officer for the New York office of Publicis Dialog, had been vice chairman and executive creative director at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, part of MDC Partners.

headline: The Footrace to Rebuild Lebanon
abstract: The militant Islamic group Hezbollah has seized an opportunity to show how much power it still wields by assuming a key role in the Lebanese reconstruction effort. With its generous assistance programs, the organization is shoring up its influence among the country's Shiites.     Mohammed al-Safadi is sitting in a rubble-filled wasteland wiping the dust from his forehead. The Lebanese minister of public works and transport is visiting Haret Hreik, one of Beirut's southern suburbs. He seems out of place in his elegant suit and his smooth-shaven, aristocratic face. Behind his back, huge chunks of concrete crash to the ground about every five minutes. Bulldozers and cranes maneuver among the ruins of bombed-out high-rise buildings as workers wearing facemasks scurry through the rubble. The effort to rebuild Haret Hreik, a Hezbollah stronghold, is clearly in full swing.

headline: Survivor Gently Adds Voices to Cambodia’s Dark Tale
abstract: Youk Chhang heads Documentation Center of Cambodia, private organization that over past decade has collected trove of documents, photographs and documentary films recording Khmer Rouge rule; special prosecutor's office in July opened formal investigation into Khmer Rouge crimes, first step in process financed by UN to bring top leaders to trial; Youk Chhang has handed over hundreds of thousands of documents and other materials that will form core of evidence to be presented in court; photo (M)

headline: A.D.M. BUYS CHOCOLATE PRODUCER
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland, which has cocoa processing plants on five continents, said it acquired Classic Couverture, a British chocolate producer, from Edward Billington & Sons, to expand its capacity to produce chocolate in Europe.     The price of the acquisition was not disclosed. Shares of Archer Daniels, based in Decatur, Ill., fell 34 cents, or 0.9 percent, to $39.59. The stock has climbed 71 percent in the last year.

headline: After Smooth Sales Talk, Stores Take Macy’s Name
abstract: Federated Department Stores on Sept 9 will rename over 400 stores in 11 regional chains as Macy's; brands, acquired in 2005 as part of $11 billion merger with May Department Stores, include number of venerable names like Marshall Field's and Filene's; focus groups signaled that renaming of stores could be public relations disaster; Federated chief executive Terry J Lundgren crisscrossed country and met with company officials as part of campaign to neutralize opposition before it gathered strength; photos of Lundgren and Gerry Frank, whose family started Meier & Frank, 149-year-old Oregon department store that Federated inherited (M)

headline: In Hawkish Tones, Europeans Again Lift Rates
abstract: European Central Bank board, meeting in Frankfurt, raises benchmark short-term interest rates by 0.25 percent, to 3 percent, and warns of further increases; bank president Jean-Claude Trichet, striking more hawkish tone, says it will monitor inflation 'very closely' and continue to tighten monetary policy; photo (M)

headline: This Player Doesnt Mind a Childs Persistent Request
abstract: Shaped like a hockey puck and just about as indestructible, the Kid-Tough FP3 Player from Fisher-Price puts music and stories at children's fingertips. Because preschoolers can't read song titles, the player's backlighted display can show an associated picture icon, one per selection.     After loading the two AAA batteries, you install the FP3 Player Software onto a Windows computer. Six songs and two stories are included, and additional titles can be downloaded for 99 cents each from a Fisher-Price online store. It is also easy to import files from just about any existing format -- music CD's, for example -- and transfer them to the player.

headline: A Hedge Fund’s Loss Rattles Nerves
abstract: Enormous losses at one of the nation's largest hedge funds resurrected worries yesterday that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions.     The hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, based in Greenwich, Conn., made an estimated $1 billion on rising energy prices last year. Yesterday, the fund told its investors that it had lost more than $3 billion in the recent downturn in natural gas and that it was working with its lenders and selling its holdings ''to protect our investors.''

headline: Protest Keeps Fox From Giving State of the Union Speech
abstract: Leftist lawmakers who have charged that fraud marred Mexico's presidential election stage protest that prevents Pres Vicente Fox from making his final state of union speech; Fox had vowed he would give speech, despite threats from leftist candidate Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador and his followers to stop him; photo (M)

headline: Hedge Funds Place Big Bets on Hurricane Season
abstract: Jenny Anderson column on current focus by hedge funds on property catastrophe reinsurance, specifically for Florida and Gulf of Mexico coastal region, as hurricane season heats up; hedge funds and private equity firms have led way in $7.3 billion that has been pumped into Bermuda start-up companies and $3.6 billion in special-purpose entities through which hedge funds capitalize existing reinsurers; photo (M)

headline: Apple Plans to Inhabit Living Room
abstract: Steven P. Jobs, Apple Computer's chief executive, concluded a much-anticipated company event on Tuesday with his usual tease, noting that he had ''one last thing'' to introduce.      Then, in an unusual departure from Apple's practice of announcing new products when they are ready to ship, he talked about a product due out early next year that will be the company's first step into the living room. The device, which Apple is calling iTV for now, will plug into a television and wirelessly pull in video and music from a Macintosh computer in the den or from the Internet. The box, which will cost $299, is about the size of a slim paperback novel.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Court Charges 4 Russians With Spying
abstract: Georgia court orders four Russian intelligence officers accused of espionage to be held for two months (S)

headline: Hezbollah Leads Work to Rebuild, Gaining Stature
abstract: As stunned Lebanese returned Tuesday over broken roads to shattered apartments in the south, it increasingly seemed that the beneficiary of the destruction was most likely to be Hezbollah.     A major reason -- in addition to its hard-won reputation as the only Arab force that fought Israel to a standstill -- is that it is already dominating the efforts to rebuild with a torrent of money from oil-rich Iran.

headline: Israel Weighs Foreign Troops on Border
abstract: As Israel again pounded southern Lebanon from the air and ground on Sunday and the Hezbollah militia rained dozens more rockets on Israel's north, diplomatic efforts increased with growing discussion of a multinational armed force being placed in the area.      Defense Minister Amir Peretz said Israel was interested in a NATO-led force, and the prime minister, Ehud Olmert, spoke of one consisting of European Union members with combat experience and the authority to take control of Lebanon's border and crossing points.

headline: The Science of Zzzzz’s
abstract: Travel and medical experts as well as frequent travelers offer advice on how to combat jet lag; some, like Dr Charmane Eastman, director of Biological Rhythms Reserach Lab at Rush University Medical Center, favor resetting body clock with small doses of hormone melatonin before flights, while others favor combination of naps and caffeine; photo (M)

headline: GONE, NOT FORGOTTEN
abstract: Former ITXC manager Yaw Osei Amoako pleads guilty to violating Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by bribing African government officials to win telecommunications contracts; Securities and Exchange Commission also implicates former vice president Steven Ott and former managing director Roger Young in scheme (S)

headline: Slower Growth With Low Inflation Spurs Stocks
abstract: Roundup of last week's stock market performance; graphs (M)

headline: Boston Scientific Fills Post
abstract: Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had hired William E. Young as a vice president to oversee quality at its newly acquired heart rhythm unit, which last year recalled 109,000 defibrillators.      The position had been vacant since Allan Gorsett left the job at the time of Boston Scientific's acquisition of Guidant in April.

headline: Follow Your Bliss, Yes, but Maybe Not Into a Stock Fund
abstract: Article on pros and cons of investing in quirky, themed mutual funds; some examples cited; photo; graph (M)

headline: Microsoft Fixing Hole in Media Software
abstract: A solitary computer hacker has entangled Microsoft in a high-stakes battle of wits by repeatedly releasing a free program that strips away the software lock that the company created to protect digital movies and songs from being freely copied by Internet users.     While Microsoft has publicly sought to portray the David vs. Goliath contest as a nuisance, the affair escalated to become a genuine challenge to one of the company's significant businesses this week after the BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster, suspended its film download service amid fears of illegal copying.

headline: The Wi-Fi in Your Handset
abstract: New phone technology takes advantage of wireless networks that allow Internet access to offer free or cheap calls to users; Wi-Fi devices are potential problem for cellphone companies who have spent billions in nationwide cell tower networks and for traditional phone companies as Internet-based calling will reduce need for standard phone lines in homes; companies may need to find ways to integrate technology into existing services in order to compete; photos (M)

headline: A Woman to Be Chief at PepsiCo
abstract: PepsiCo said yesterday that its president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi, would succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chief executive on Oct. 1, a move that makes the company one of the largest led by a woman.     ''I've been talking to the board about retirement for a year,'' Mr. Reinemund, 58, said yesterday in a conference call, ''but the seeds of this were really sown five years ago, when Indra was named president.'' Mr. Reinemund will stay as executive chairman until he retires in May.

headline: U.S. Firm Has Korea Up in Arms
abstract: South Korean authorities are continuing a high-profile investigation into Lone Star, the Dallas-based private-equity fund, fueling a public backlash against excessive profits made by foreign investment funds.      Just eight years ago, Lone Star was hailed as a savior, pouring money into companies crippled by South Korea's financial crisis. Today, it appears to be in danger of being run out of town in a flap that could threaten Seoul's attractiveness to foreign investors.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,681 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:    NEEDHAM, Robb G., 51, Master Sgt., Army Reserve; Vancouver, Wash.; First Battalion, 356th Regiment (Logistical Support).

headline: The Rise of Baidu (That’s Chinese for Google)
abstract: Article profiles Baidu, Chinese search company founded in 1999 by former Infoseek staff engineer Robin Li with market value of $3 billion and which operates fourth-most trafficked Web site in world; while Baidu continues to gain market share in China, some analysts question whether it can withstand competition from Google and Yahoo, which posess superior technology and global work forces; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Panel Plans to Make Cities Reveal More on Pensions
abstract: Governmental Accounting Standards Board begins project to improve disclosure of cities' pension fund information; New York City's pension fund appears to be fully funded due to unusual calculation that does not comply with accepted accounting rules; current rules have made it difficult to compare pension funds of different cities' and states (M)

headline: The Lonelygirl That Really Wasn’t
abstract: A nearly four-month-old Internet drama in which the cryptic video musings of a fresh-faced teenager became the obsession of millions of devotees -- themselves divided over the very authenticity of the videos, or who was behind them or why -- appears to be in its final act.     The woman who plays Lonelygirl15 on the video-sharing site YouTube.com has been identified as Jessica Rose, a 20-ish resident of New Zealand and Los Angeles and a graduate of the New York Film Academy. And the whole project appears to be the early serialized version of what eventually will become a movie.

headline: Royal Ahold Will Avoid Prosecution
abstract: Royal Ahold Will Avoid Prosecution***Justice Department says Royal Ahold will not be prosecuted in connection with criminal fraud investigation; company agrees to cooperate with federal investigations after former US Foodservice chief financial officer Michael J Resnick pleaded guilty to conspiracy related to $800 million fraud; former marketing chief Mark P Kaiser will be tried next month (M)

headline: Fed’s Notes About Rate Policy Send Shares Higher
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.5

headline: A Search Engine That's Becoming an Inventor
abstract: When Google was a graduate-school project being run from a Silicon Valley garage, its founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, built their own computers out of cheap parts meant for personal computers. They wanted to save money, and they felt that they could design a network of computers that would search the Web more efficiently than those available from traditional manufacturers.     Google no longer needs to pinch pennies. It is a solid member of the Fortune 500 with $9 billion in cash. Still, it is stubbornly sticking to its do-it-yourself approach to technology. Even as it spends more than $1.5 billion this year on operations centers and technology, most of the hundreds of thousands of servers it will deploy are being custom-made based on Google's own eccentric designs.

headline: Judge Raises New Concerns About Tactics in Shelter Case
abstract: Federal District Judge Lewis Kaplan, overseeing criminal trial of former tax professionals accused of defrauding government through abusive tax shelters sold by KPMG, raises new concerns about how and when prosecutors turned over evidence to defendants and pressure they exerted on KPMG to cut off payment of legal fees for defendants; suggests he may postpone trial or dismiss case (M)

headline: Lenovo Aims to Calm Fears Over Security
abstract: Lenovo president and chief executive William J Amelio, in Saturday Interview column, discusses company's branding and strategy, and future of computer security; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Protest Over Award For Leader
abstract: Human rights organizations score Unesco after it awards Borobudur gold medal to Uzbekistan's Pres Islam Karimov for contribution to international cooperation, dialogue and social diversity; Uzbekistan government killed several hundred people in suppressing uprising in city of Andijon in 2005; photo (S)

headline: Italy Is Roiled by Murder of a Pakistani Woman and Other Violence Involving Immigrants
abstract: Series of unrelated killings in Brescia, Italy, has pushed city to center of national debate on challenges of immigration and cultural integration; trigger was killing of Hina Saleem, Pakistani woman who was found buried, with her throat slit, in garden of her family home; tragedy ballooned into cause celebre after media reports alleged that Saleem had been killed because her traditionalist Muslim father objected to her Western lifestyle; map; photo (M)

headline: Top Blair Fund-Raiser Arrested in British Labor Party Scandal
abstract: Lord Levy, Prime Minister Tony Blair's chief fund-raiser, as well as his tennis partner and Middle East emissary, was arrested on Wednesday in connection with allegations that Labor Party backers were offered peerages in return for loans and donations.     The development, which surprised many politicians, brought the long-simmering scandal closer to Mr. Blair and raised new questions about the future of his increasingly beleaguered government.

headline: Smoke if You’ve Got ’Em on This Airline Next Year
abstract: Alexander Schoppmann plans Smokers International Airways airline to cater to smokers who want to light up on long flights; service will begin on routes between Germany and Japan; will be priced comparable with business class offerings from other carriers (M)

headline: Selling Shares by the Billions to Racing Fans
abstract: Was this stock being traded by crooks? Should the brokers have noticed? How about the regulators, who now charge that the brokers missed ''red flags'' but may have missed a few themselves.     The story of a tiny Nevada company that claimed to be in the diamond mining business but spent the little money it had on sponsoring a race car, sheds light on the market for small stocks that can fly below the radar for years.

headline: Palestinians Look Ahead Even as Israel Besieges Gaza
abstract: Israel's siege of this slender stretch of Mediterranean seacoast took seven more lives Thursday even as Palestinian political factions met to plan for when the crisis ends.     The Israeli Defense Forces continued their assault on the cluster of cinderblock homes that make up the Mughazi refugee camp near the border with Israel. By day's end, 4 Palestinians had been killed by tank fire and 3 had died of wounds sustained Wednesday, bringing the death toll from two days of fighting to 16. Two were under age 18, said Assad Rayan, an administrator at Al Aksa Hospital in Deir al Balah.

headline: Advanced Micro Is Updating Its Key Chips
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices plans to introduce faster versions of Opteron server chips with built-in support for so-called virtualization technology (S)

headline: Downloading Service to Allow Film Watching on TV Screens
abstract: CinemaNow, with participation of Sony, Disney, Universal, MGM and Lions Gate movie studios, is offering new download-to-DVD service that allows customers to create DVD's of movies that can be viewed on television sets; previously downloaded movies were restricted to computer viewing and downloads included only film; new offering also includes bonus material, like filmmakers' commentary and extra scenes; photo (M)

headline: Brazilian Mining Company Joins Bidding for Canadian Nickel Producer
abstract: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the Brazilian mining company, joined the bidding for Inco, the Canadian nickel producer, on Friday with an offer of 19.9 billion Canadian dollars ($17.7 billion) in cash.     Seeking to trump two bids already made by suitors in the United States and Canada, the Brazilian company, known as CVRD, said the acquisition of Inco, the world's second-largest nickel producer, would enable it to expand its geographic reach in major mineral sources and broaden the mix of minerals it sells on the global market.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Aceh Bill Aims For More Autonomy
abstract: Parliament passed a law that is intended to give Aceh Province greater autonomy under the terms of a peace accord with former separatists there. But the Free Aceh Movement, which fought for independence for nearly three decades and signed the peace accord last year, said the new law fell short of its demands, and of the provisions in the accord. ''The authority for the government in Aceh is not clear -- it says in the bill that the law in Aceh has to follow Indonesian law,'' said Bakhtiar Abdullah, above, a spokesman for the movement. ''If everything has to be in with the Indonesian standard, where's the new law?'' A key to the settlement, negotiated between the sides by Martti Ahtisaari, a former president of Finland, was an understanding by the rebels that a new provincial government in Aceh would have far wider authority than in the past. The passage of the law, four months later than stipulated in the peace accord, paves the way for elections later in the year.   JANE PERLEZ (NYT)

headline: Under Couric, Ratings Race Is Once Again, Well, a Race
abstract: Katie Couric, two weeks after taking over as evening news anchor on CBS, becomes apparent, but close, victor in ratings races with NBC and ABC; preliminary Nielsen figures show Couric drew average of 7.9 million viewers each night last week, beating out NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams by about 70,000 viewers and ABC's World News with Charles Gibson by about 370,000 each night (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Security Council To Take Up Myanmar
abstract: Security Council puts Myanmar on its agenda in what US Amb John R Bolton calls major step forward in calling international attention to military dictatorship that has imprisoned hundreds of political opponents (S)

headline: Profit Lags as Microsoft Spends to Meet Competitors
abstract: Microsoft, in midst of product transition, says quarterly sales rose 16 percent, to $11.8 billion, compared with nearly $10.2 billion year earlier; net income for quarter was $2.83 billion; quarterly revenue slightly surpassed Wall Street consensus of $11.6 billion; photo (M)

headline: What Does Organic Really Mean?
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 119.27 points, or 1.07 percent, to 11,219.70; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 15.35 points, or 1.22 percent, to 1,278.55; Nasdaq composite index gains 39.67 points, or 1.93 percent, to 2,094.14; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note; graph (M)

headline: Israeli Premier and Saudi Said to Hold Secret Meeting
abstract: An Israeli newspaper reported Monday that Prime Minister Ehud Olmert held a secret meeting about 10 days ago with a senior Saudi Arabian official to discuss issues that included Iran's nuclear program and prospects for Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.     In response to the reports, Mr. Olmert and his aides said he did not meet with King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia. However, they declined to answer directly when asked if he met with any other senior Saudi leader.

headline: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale    $5.8 million    143 East 60th Street  Manhattan    A Manhattan developer has bought this five-story mixed-use building, which has six apartments and the Subway Inn on the ground floor.    Buyer: David Lowenfeld  Sellers: William T. Shepard, guardian for Charles Ackerman; and Ruth Schultz  Brokers: Robert Burton and Clint Olsen, Massey Knakal Realty Services    Recent Lease    $73/sq. ft.  approximate annual rent $1.19 million    Chrysler Building  405 Lexington Avenue, at 42nd St.  Manhattan    A law firm has a 10-year lease for 16,315 square feet on the 11th floor of this 77-story 1930 skyscraper.    Tenant: Clyde & Company  Tenant broker: Mike Burlant, Cushman & Wakefield  Landlord: Tishman Speyer Properties  Landlord broker: Greg Conen, Tishman Speyer Properties    For Sale    $6.7 million    71, 73 and 75 Pineapple Street  Brooklyn Heights, Brooklyn    These three properties in the local historic district are a five-story mixed-use building, a vacant lot and a five-story multifamily building with 23 vacant apartments and a vacant retail space.    Owner: Manmark Realty Corp.  Brokers: Brian T. Leary, Massey Knakal Realty Services

headline: Earnings at Philips Exceed Expectations
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics says second-quarter net income more than doubled, to 367 million euros ($460 million); says sales rose 10 percent, to 7.6 billion euros; announces 1.5 billion euro ($1.87 billion) stock buyback (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,548 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    BAUGHMAN, Nathaniel S., 23, Cpl., Army; Monticello, Ind.; 101st Airborne Division.    DICKINSON, Michael A. II, 26, Staff Sgt., Army; Battle Creek, Mich.; Ninth Psychological Operations Battalion, Fourth Psychological Operations Group, Special Operations Command.    HOLGUIN, Manuel J., 21, Specialist, Army; Woodlake, Calif.; First Armored Division.    PUGH, Kenneth I., 39, Cpl., Army; Houston; Fourth Infantry Division.    SMITH, Scott R., 34, Sgt. First Class, Army; Punxsutawney, Pa.; 737th Explosive Ordnance Detachment, 52nd Ordnance Group.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Advertising was up 5.6 percent across all media in the first quarter, according to Nielsen Media Research. On TV, where the 30-second spot is losing impact, advertisers are turning to sponsorships and product placement.      Placement is a natural for reality shows like ''Extreme Makeover Home Edition,'' and was a staple on the sitcom ''King of Queens'' (above, with Kevin James and Leah Remini). And those thirsty contestants on ''American Idol''? About 2,500 placements were for Coca-Cola.   SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: U.S.-Bound Plane Turned Back Over Security
abstract: An American Airlines flight to Boston returned to London after United States authorities said the name of one of the 240 passengers matched a name on a security watch list. The British police interviewed four passengers when the Boeing 777 returned but made no arrests. There had been no threat to the airplane, the airline said. American law requires airlines to provide information about passengers flying to the United States.

headline: A Brief Recovery and Now This
abstract: This was to be the summer the airlines were going to put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them.      And it seemed to be working: fares were up, planes were full -- albeit to passengers' discomfort -- and the airlines were making money again. The industry just reported surprisingly strong second-quarter profit of $1.6 billion, its best showing in six years, after losing $40 billion since the 2001 terrorist attacks.

headline: Build a Robot of Your Own, Lickety-Split
abstract: Lego Mindstorms NXT kit, priced at about $250, comes with hardware and software to build working robot in half hour; photo (S)

headline: Detroits Answer to $3-$4 Gas: New Muscle Cars
abstract: American auto makers, despite surge in gas prices, are highlighting muscle cars; Ford plans to build 325-horsepower version of Ford Shelby GT and luxury car Lincoln MKS; General Motors expects to confirm it will resurrect Chevrolet Camaro; neither Ford nor Chrysler sell subcompacts in US; photo (M)

headline: Home for Sale, by Anxious Owner
abstract: Home sales are falling rapidly, and the number of houses on the market is surging. Yet each new economic report offering evidence of a housing slowdown also shows that the national median home price has continued to rise over the last year.      To understand how this could be happening, consider a three-bedroom house surrounded by oak and redwood trees, not far from the Golden Gate Bridge, in San Rafael, Calif. Reluctant to cut the price from its current listing of $1.54 million, its owners are instead offering a weeklong vacation time-share, every year for life, worth about $10,000, or an equal amount toward lease of a car.

headline: Court Backs I.B.M. on Pensions
abstract: A three-judge panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999. Page C1.

headline: Marketers Trace Paths Users Leave on Internet
abstract: If you use Yahoo's Web search engine to learn about hybrid cars, the site will quietly note that you fit into a group of users it calls ''Consciously Cruising.''      If you click on ads for moving van companies, you will join the ''Home Hopping'' group. Shop for wedding cakes and reception halls and you might be tagged as a future bride or groom.

headline: Creditors Push Yukos Close to Liquidation
abstract: Creditors for Russian oil company Yukos reject recovery plan and recommend company be declared bankrupt; founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky was arrested three years ago for tax evasion and fraud and is serving eight years in labor camp; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Plan to Ring Baghdad With Trenches
abstract: Iraqi government plans to seal off Baghdad by ringing it with series of trenches and setting up dozens of traffic checkpoints to control movement in and out of violent city; Brig Gen Abdul Karim Khalaf says effort is one of most ambitious security projects in 2006; US military has approved plan; there has been surge in number of Iraqis killed execution-style; Baghdad morgue reports that at least 1,535 Iraqi civilians died violently in capital in August; US military disputes morgue's numbers, but has made securing Baghdad its top priority; photo (M)

headline: Western News Operations Expand Into Arabic Market
abstract: Competition heats up as Western news organizations prepare to expand into Arabic market; daily news programming and Web sites are under development by Deutsche Welle, Russia Today and in France, Denmark and Spain; CNN, whose Arabic Web site attracts more than 300,000 visitors monthly, may consider television presence; debate is beginning over whether foreign broadcasts will create understanding or lead to more conflict (M)

headline: In Africa, a More Business-Friendly Approach
abstract: World Bank report finds that Africa has made substantial changes that make it easier to start and run business; Tanzania and Ghana jump into ranks of top 10 reformers; Rwanda and Nigeria make it into top 20; 26 other African countries take modest steps to ease business regulations; economists say rankings are useful to countries seeking to improve their foreign investment, aid and grant opportunities (M)

headline: Paulson Says China Hurts Itself With Economic Policies
abstract: In the administration's toughest warning yet to China on economic issues, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said on Wednesday that Chinese leaders were imperiling their nation's future by engaging in policies that Americans and others see as unfair.      Speaking as he prepared for his first trip to Beijing since taking office this summer, and one day after China's monthly trade surplus set another record, Mr. Paulson said that the United States had ''a huge stake in a prosperous, stable China'' and that ''we are not afraid of Chinese competition.''

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: INSURER DISCUSSES BID FOR AMERUS -- Aviva, the largest insurance company in Britain, said it was in talks to buy the AmerUs Group, an insurance company based in Iowa, in a deal that would increase its presence in the American market.     AmerUs, of Des Moines, confirmed the talks but said there was no assurance a transaction would result. The company provides life insurance and annuity products and has a market capitalization of $2.4 billion.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Pharmaceutical Company Is Acquired
abstract: UCB agrees to purchase Schwarz Pharma for 4.4 billion euros ($5.6 billion); will acquire new drugs that may provide more than 2 billion euros in annual revenue; graph (S)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: EXPECTING A BLOCKBUSTER -- A heart drug still in the testing phase at Pfizer will be offered as a stand-alone pill, rather than only in combination with Lipitor, as Pfizer had first planned. Doctors had criticized the company over the combination approach to sales. [Page C1.]    JAUNTING BY JET -- Entrepreneurs are betting on air taxis as a way to entice business travelers who are frustrated by jam-packed planes, endless delays and long security lines. [C1.]    HONDA TAKES TO THE AIR -- Honda known for its small cars, plans to offer what could become the Honda Civic of the skies. The car maker said the HondaJet would be fuel-efficient, with twin engines and room for six passengers. [C4.]    HOUSING CATCHES ITS BREATH -- The torrid pace of the housing market is slackening as prices level off and properties stay on the market longer. Experts say the housing industry appears to be evolving into a buyer's market. [C1.]    TWO SIDES OF GOLDMAN -- A new focus at Goldman Sachs has exposed fault lines between the investment bankers who advise blue-chip corporate clients and the private-equity bankers who manage multibillion-dollar funds. [C1.]    NEW UNION FRONT -- The Service Employees International Union has undertaken a drive to unionize more than 100,000 security guards nationwide -- a group of workers that in many cities is more than 50 percent African-American. The average pay for guards, says the union, is $8.50 an hour or $17,000 a year. [A13.]    REGIONAL HANDSHAKES -- As global trade talks falter, regional deals are moving to the forefront. India, for example, is planning to sign an agreement with Japan and is talking with the European Union. The United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, above, said that America would also seek regional agreements and singled out Asia as a prime target. Countries like China and India, with fast-growing economies and a large middle class, are attractive markets for Western companies that manufacture goods or provide banking and insurance services.
