[C3.]    TROUBLESOME BLIPS -- The Federal Aviation Administration has scheduled air-traffic controllers at seven of its busiest radar offices so that at least 70 percent of the controllers on a shift are always at their radar scopes, in effort to cut costs and errors. But controllers say they are working without breaks longer than rules allow, and their union has complained. [A14.]    STRONG PHONE RESULTS -- AT&T and BellSouth, heading toward a merger, are continuing to add high-speed Internet customers, and AT&T's wireless group, Cingular, is still on top and getting stronger. Those bright spots, as well as the substantial savings they are wringing from the integration of SBC Communications and AT&T along with Cingular and AT&T Wireless, were behind the companies' better-than expected profit growth in the second quarter. [C6.]    AMAZON PROFIT DROPS -- The online retailer Amazon.com reported a steep drop in its quarterly profit, while its sales continued to rise. The results showed the effects of higher expenses as Amazon offered free shipping and lower prices in response to more competition. [C7.]    SLUMP AT NISSAN -- Nissan Motor reported a slight quarterly profit, but said operating income dropped steeply amid a slump in vehicle sales that the company called temporary. Analysts said the performance raised questions about the management of its chief executive, Carlos Ghosn. [C6.]    YUKOS LIQUIDATION APPEARS NEAR -- The Yukos company's fight for existence neared its end on Tuesday when creditors rejected its plans for recovery and recommended that Yukos, once Russia's largest and most successful oil concern, be declared bankrupt. [C6.]    JOBS SITE GETS A LIFT -- The new owner of the two major daily newspapers in Philadelphia said that it had formed an alliance with Monster Worldwide, the parent of the online jobs Web site. The resulting cobranded jobs site will be the first such venture between a big city newspaper publisher and Monster.com. [C5.]    TEEN PEOPLE TO SHUT DOWN -- Time Inc. announced that it was shutting down Teen People, the monthly magazine that was a pioneer in the teenage category when it was founded in 1998. [C5.]    ONLINE    TRAVELING WITH CHILDREN -- Most people traveling with children know the drill and maintain order in the ranks. Still, tensions sometimes ensue. A report is at nytimes.com/business.    POWER PLAYS IN FLIGHT -- At the Farnborough Air Show outside of London, the world's leaders in aviation gather to make both monetary and political deals. A audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Shares of United Parcel Service, the world's largest shipping carrier, fell sharply after the company reported an increase in second-quarter profit that missed Wall Street expectations. (AP)    The DuPont Company reported a 4 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. Net income was $975 million, down from $1.02 billion a year ago. (AP)    3M's second-quarter profit jumped 17 percent and fell within the lowered guidance it gave about three weeks ago. (AP)

headline: Back of the Envelope
abstract: Chart of leading advisers for mergers of $500 million or less (S)

headline: For the Osprey Hybrid Aircraft, Zigzags to Cap 20 Years of Zigzags
abstract: Bell Helicopter and Boeing Co debut V-22 Osprey helicopter-airplane hybrid, made specifically for US Marine Corps, at International Air Show in Farnborough, Eng; first squadron of V-22's is slated to be deployed next fall; Marines have been promised 360 planes--at cost of about $70 million each--in program costing $49 billion; have about 40 such aircraft flying today at various American bases, but none overseas or in combat; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bharti Posts Profit Rise
abstract: Bharti Airtel, India's biggest mobile phone services provider, announced a 48 percent growth in quarterly profit, exceeding expectations. The earnings were helped by strong growth in its subscriber base. New Delhi-based Bharti, which is one-third owned by Singapore Telecom and about 10 percent owned by Vodafone Group, said its profits in the quarter ended in June grew to 7.55 billion rupees ($165 million) from 5.1 billion rupees a year ago. Sales rose 53 percent, to 38.6 billion rupees ($838 million) as Bharti added 3.65 million customers in the quarter. The company has nearly 25 million subscribers in more than 4,000 cities and towns.    SARITHA RAI (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Opposition Leader Detained
abstract: The authorities detained Aleksandr Milinkevich, the leading public figure in Belarus's opposition movement and the principal challenger to President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko in the widely criticized election in March, regional news agencies reported. Another candidate in the election, Aleksandr V. Kazulin, was arrested while leading an anti-government march in the spring and was sentenced this month to five and a half years in prison. Both men lost by overwhelming margins to Mr. Lukashenko after a campaign season and vote that the West denounced as rigged. The reasons for Mr. Milinkevich's detention were not immediately clear.    C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

headline: To Stay Alive, Iraqis Change Their Names
abstract: There was nothing out of the ordinary about the young man clutching a sheaf of papers at the birth certificate office, except for his name: Saddam Hussein al-Majid.     ''All three of your names match his,'' the clerk at the desk said with a laugh, referring to Iraq's deposed leader. ''That's unbelievable!''

headline: Lucent Cites U.S. for Sales Slide
abstract: Lucent Technologies says United States sales slide will cause third-quarter sales and profit to miss analysts estimates; chief executive Patricia Russo comments; Lucent agreed to be bought this year by Alcatel; combined company will lay off 9,000 workers, up from previously stated 8,800 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: $8 Million En Route To U.S. Stolen At Airport
abstract: Armed robbers take $8 million from truck parked in secure area of Guatemala City airport, part of $22 million cache to be shipped to United States Federal Reserve (S)

headline: Big Oil Find Is Reported Deep in Gulf
abstract: Chevron, Devon Energy and Statoil ASA announce that they have found 3 billion to 15 billion barrels in several oil fields 30,000 feet below surface of Gulf of Mexico; experts see finding as ushering in new era in ultra-deepwater offshore drilling; map (M)

headline: British Security Says Terrorist Attack on Nation Is ‘Highly Likely’
abstract: The security services here made public their assessment of the probability of a terrorist attack for the first time on Tuesday, telling Britons they faced a ''severe'' threat, meaning that an attack was ''highly likely.''     British authorities also suffered what they took as a significant setback in their counterterrorism strategy when three appeal judges upheld a previous ruling that so-called control orders -- a form of house arrest -- that were used to detain six Iraqi suspects constituted a breach of their human rights and should be ended.

headline: Banks Sprout Around a Town Green
abstract: Scene in Morristown, NJ, described as more and more banks open branches along and around town green; four of ten businesses on North Park Place are banks and downtown area has 17 banks; local officials worry that banks, willing to pay significantly higher rents, have snapped up much of area's prime retail space, and are driving away other types of retailers; photo (M)

headline: A Comcast-CBS Venture
abstract: Comcast will make eight CBS prime-time series, including CSI: Miami and Survivor, available to customers through on-demand service at no extra cost (S)

headline: Whiffs of Combat Waft Over Natural Cosmetics
abstract: L'Oreal's 652 million pound ($1.2 billion) acquisition of Body Shop International threatens to change natural cosmetics business as large companies recognize potential of market; French cosmetics company L'Occitane will be most affected; photos (M)

headline: Blair Delays Vacation for Mideast Diplomacy, but His Specific Goal Remains Unclear
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair, after series of pronouncements about struggle with radical Islam, delays Caribbean vacation, saying coming days will be crucial in diplomatic effort to secure cease-fire in Lebanon (M)

headline: Web Casinos Becoming a Riskier Bet for Investors
abstract: How much more of a gamble has it become to own a piece of an Internet casino? Is it a sucker's bet, or the chance to buy low and score a big payday?     The questions have intensified since BetOnSports, an online sports betting company traded on the London Stock Exchange, stopped taking bets from the United States after the Justice Department charged the company and current and former executives with operating an illegal gambling operation.

headline: POLICE BLOTTER
abstract: University of San Diego places its business school dean Mohsen Anvari on administrative leave after he is arrested and charged with felony drug possesion; Anvari is chairman of Developers Diversified Realty Corporation (S)

headline: Trying to Avoid the Perils of Peacekeeping
abstract: Diplomats involved in negotiating cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah acknowledge that efforts are lagging in part because of reluctance of governments to introduce troops into troubled region of southern Lebanon; leaders question whether rules of engagement defined by United Nations will allow them to accomplish mission in support of Lebanese Army efforts to establish buffer area, to secure borders and police ports to prevent entry of illicit arms (M)

headline: Karelian Conflict Divides Chechen Leaders
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Tuesday.     TOP STORIES

headline: Another Prominent Lawyer Departs From Milberg Weiss
abstract: Patricia Hynes, prominent trial lawyer at enbattled securities class-action law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, resigns to join Allen & Overy as senior counsel; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. to Expand Use of Chips From Advanced Micro Devices
abstract: IBM, in strong endorsement of Advanced Micro Devices, says it will offer five models of computers powered by Opteron microprocessor intended for use in corporate data centers for mainstream business tasks; AMD stock slide illustrates daunting competitive challenge it faces against Intel, whose chip sales are more than six times as large; photo (M)

headline: Lebanon Throng Hails Hezbollah Chief, Who Calls Militia Stronger
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people stood Friday and chanted ''God, God, protect Nasrallah.'' It was the moment they had waited for: Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in person, declaring that his militia was stronger than ever and that no army in the world could force it to disarm.     This was Sheik Nasrallah's first public appearance since the war with Israel started in July, and it was steeped in defiance: at Israel, the United States, Arab heads of state and those political forces in Lebanon aiming to clip Hezbollah's political and military power.

headline: Germans Raise Bid for Spanish Utility
abstract: Despite winning new support from European regulators, the German power company E.On was forced on Tuesday to raise its offer for the Spanish utility Endesa, a deal seen as a crucial test for breaking down barriers to cross-border energy mergers in Europe.     The European Commission, administrative arm of the European Union, rebuked Spain for blocking cross-border mergers and ordered it to stop trying to thwart E.On's bid for Endesa. But the disclosure on Monday that a Spanish industrial holding company, Acciona, had bought 10 percent of Endesa stirred speculation that the Spanish government was behind the new challenge and that E.On would have to sweeten its offer.

headline: If Bigger Is Better, NBC Is Moving Up
abstract: NBC Universal will move its video screen promoting its television programs to new location in Times Square; chief marketing officer John Miller says previous sign became less special as other companies put up their own nearby; new screen and billboards will measure almost 3,500 square feet, compared to 1,400 square feet of old advertising; photo (M)

headline: In Britain, Sports Betting Can Look a Lot Like Investing
abstract: In the last seconds of extra time, Francesco Totti bangs a penalty kick into the Australian goal, driving Italy into the World Cup soccer quarterfinals in Germany and sending Australia home. In a room full of television monitors and computers in London, Dean Shaddick swivels in his chair, puts down his pencil and sighs.      ''Someone, somewhere, just made a lot of money,'' he said last week as Italy advanced.

headline: Debating the Course of Chile’s Rivers
abstract: Chilean government has embraced Spanish company Endesa's plan to build series of dams in rugged, pristine Aisen region of Patagonia that would flood thousands of acres to generate electricty; project has provoked intense opposition in region, where local people feel it would bring few benefits and host of problems; opponents suggest that other renewable resources are cheaper, less intrusive and not subject to foreign control; photos; map (M)

headline: Ford Brings in Outsider to Help Run the Company
abstract: William Clay Ford Jr., great-grandson of the founder of the Ford Motor Company, brought in an outsider Tuesday to help run the company, in a tacit acknowledgment that he needs a new approach in his efforts to turn around the struggling automaker.     Mr. Ford took the highly unusual step, for Detroit, of turning to an executive with no experience in the auto industry. He gave up the titles of chief executive and president to Alan R. Mulally, a top executive of Boeing; Mr. Ford remains chairman.

headline: In a U-Turn Quarter, a Retreat From Risk
abstract: Paul J Lim column on sharp u-turn investment bandwagons made in second quarter, in which domestic stock mutual funds tumbled average of 2.9 percent; investors, bullish on markets in fourth quarter last year, poured money into speculative stocks in first quarter but shied away from risks in second quarter; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Hedge Funds Flirt With Heresy: Going Public
abstract: Hedge funds -- fast-growing private investment pools of capital -- are known for their secrecy.      That is partly because federal regulations prohibit them from advertising or talking to anyone but their investors. But being private and secretive also enables them to develop investment strategies and manage their business, big fees included, without the Corporate Library criticizing their outsize pay.

headline: Recovering a Fumble at the Flip Chart
abstract: Matt Villano column offers advice on what to do if you botch presentation in front of your boss and important clients; drawing (M)0

headline: Siberia Crash Inquiry Studies Brakes
abstract: Investigators are looking into whether the crew of an Airbus jet that went off a runway in Siberia on July 9, killing 124 people, improperly used a braking system that was partly disabled before takeoff, people involved in the inquiry said.     The model involved in the crash, the Airbus A310, has a thrust reverser on each of its two engines, and normal procedure is that after touchdown the crew deploys the reversers, which direct jet blast toward the front of the plane, to help the wheel brakes slow the plane. After the reversers are deployed the crew applies the throttles on the engines.

headline: Medicare Gains Lift Humanas Profit 9.9%
abstract: Humana, citing larger than expected growth in its Medicare Advantage program, reports second-quarter net income rose to $89.5 million, from $81.4 million year earlier; says revenue climbed 52 percent, to $5.41 billion (S)

headline: Europeans Favor Admitting Romania and Bulgaria, Then Retooling
abstract: Romania and Bulgaria will receive a qualified endorsement on Tuesday to join the European Union on Jan. 1, but the bloc will warn that expansion must then halt until the organization makes needed structural changes, the European Commission president said Monday.     José Manuel Barroso, the commission president, said the admission of the two countries was the last phase of integration in a European Union that has been stretched beyond capacity for now.

headline: Mobile ESPN to End Service Aimed at Sports Customers
abstract: Unable to attract enough customers, Mobile ESPN said yesterday that it would shut its mobile phone service aimed at sports fans at the end of the year. The company said it would focus instead on selling its real-time scores and video to existing cellular providers.     The shift in strategy is a sign of the difficulty in attracting new cellular customers at a time when more than 70 percent of consumers already have an existing plan. Despite carrying exclusive material, Mobile ESPN was unable to compete with Cingular Wireless and other national carriers that offer customers the option of paying as little as $10 a month to join family plans.

headline: Failure of Global Trade Talks Is Traced to the Power of Farmers
abstract: For months, the Bush administration had tirelessly warned farmers to prepare for the possibility of a global trade deal. At the Indiana State Fair last year, Charles F. Conner, the deputy agriculture secretary, told listeners not to expect ''anything close'' to the subsidies they had been used to for decades.     But the collapse of world trade talks this week has again proved that a small number of farmers in the United States -- as well as Europe, Japan, India and other trading partners -- have the power to resist lower agricultural tariffs and subsidies, even though a global trade deal might ultimately benefit most of them.

headline: Missing Chechen Was Secret Bride of Terror Leader
abstract: Disappearance of Elina Ersenoyeva offers glimpses into Chechen netherworld; Ersenoyeva was journalist and social worker, but also secret wife of late Chechen terrorist Shamil Basayev; Ersenoyeva's mother says her daughter was forced into marriage by threats to family; much of Chechen life is centered around male-dominated rituals and kidnapping of brides is persistent tradition; Ersenoyeva seemed relieved at news of her husband's death, but there are indications she was kidnapped by pro-Russian Chechens; photos (L)

headline: Holding Liev Schreibers Tony Award? Priceless
abstract: Visa Signature, American Express Platinum and MasterCard Premium offer access to special events as way to lure consumers to sign up for premium credit cards; perks are increasingly taking form of unique experiences rather than products and services that no longer entice shoppers; customers often pay high prices for events, but access is limited to members; photos (M)

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: Memo Pad column; Donald N Martin & Co reports overall trans-Atlantic air traffic increased 5.1 percent in June and average load factor was 88.9 percent; British Airways says premium-seat traffic rose 11 percent in July; Bureau of Transportation Statistics reports percentage of late departures on domestic flights through June rose to 19.39 percent, highest in more than decade; most major carriers report load factors rose to record levels in July; US Airways and Delta, reacting to aggressive competition from JetBlue, cut fares on Boston-New York La Guardia route; Continental Airlines orders 12 new Boeing 737-900ER aircraft for delivery in 2008; US Airways orders 25 Embraer E190 jets; Smith Research reports overall daily hotel room rate in US rose 6.7 percent during last week in July (M)

headline: The Internet Knows What You'll Do Next
abstract: A FEW years back, a technology writer named John Battelle began talking about how the Internet had made it possible to predict the future. When people went to the home page of Google or Yahoo and entered a few words into a search engine, what they were really doing, he realized, was announcing their intentions.      They typed in ''Alaskan cruise'' because they were thinking about taking one or ''baby names'' because they were planning on needing one. If somebody were to add up all this information, it would produce a pretty good notion of where the world was headed, of what was about to get hot and what was going out of style.

headline: Apple Earnings Bolstered by iPod and Notebook Sales
abstract: Apple Computer, reporting strong growth in iPod music player and MacBook portable computer businesses, says fiscal third quarter net income rose 48 percent, to $472 million, from $320 million year earlier; reports revenue climbed 24 percent, to $4.37 billion, from $3.52 billion year earlier (M)

headline: Bodies Yield Evidence of Hussein-Era Killings
abstract: Beneath the clinical glare of fluorescent lights in a collection of makeshift laboratories here, the victims of mass murder under Saddam Hussein are slowly brought back to life.      For two years, a team of forensic scientists from around the world has sifted through bones, clothes, identity papers and spent bullet casings exhumed from mass graves to build criminal cases against Mr. Hussein and to reconstruct the victims' final moments.

headline: India: Loan Demand Helps Lift Big Bank's Profit
abstract: Hewlett-Packard will install Internet search software from Baidu.com on desktop and laptop computers sold in China; one-year deal may help Baidu.com secure lead against Google and Yahoo (S)

headline: AIDS Cited in the Climb in South Africa’s Death Rate
abstract: With South Africa's anti-AIDS efforts under increasingly bitter assault by global experts and local activists, government statisticians reported Thursday that death rates for adults of virtually all ages and both sexes rose sharply from 1997 to 2004, in some groups by a factor of four or more.     AIDS is not reported as a cause of death in South Africa. But the age patterns of the increased deaths and their reported causes -- in many cases parasitic infections, immune disorders and maternal conditions -- made it likely that AIDS and ailments related to H.I.V. were behind much of the trend, they stated.

headline: Largely Empty, Stronghold of Militia Is Still Perilous
abstract: Not long ago, this town was known as ''the capital of the resistance,'' the most important Hezbollah stronghold in the southern reaches of Lebanon.      Now Bint Jbail appears largely deserted. Most of the homes are damaged, some pockmarked by bullets or shrapnel and others reduced to piles of stone and concrete by Israeli artillery that continues to pound the village.

headline: Microsoft Increases Buyback of Shares
abstract: Microsoft nearly doubles stock buyback, to $36 billion; investors tendered only $3.8 billion in initial 'Dutch auction', missing goal of $20 billion (S)

headline: A Column on (Your Product Here) Placement
abstract: Stuart Elliott column on report to be released by PQ Media that predicts marketers will remain enamored with product placements in wide variety of entertainment media as technology continues to enable consumers to avoid or skip over ads by using devices like digital video recorders or iPods; report predicts worldwide paid placements will total almost $7.6 billion by 2010 and there could represent triple-digit percentage increases in ad spending by marketers if Eurpean Union approves changes in rules that limit or prohibit inclusion of products and brands in government-run TV networks; photo (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: BEHIND ABC'S 9/11 SERIES -- It is little wonder that ABC's mini-series ''The Path to 9/11'' drew stinging criticism for its invented scenes, made-up dialogue and unsubstantiated accounts. A more puzzling question is why ABC spent $30 million on what amounted to a five-hour public service announcement. [Page C1.]    FROM HUNTER TO HUNTED -- Duane Chapman, the star of A&E's ''Dog the Bounty Hunter,'' found himself on the other side of the handcuffs last week because of a three-year-old charge stemming from one of his captures. The latest turn in the story probably won't hurt ratings. A&E plans a special on him tomorrow night, and the stories about his travails are likely to add to his legend. [E1.]    THE FUTURE OF SATELLITE TV -- The idea that Rupert Murdoch, who controls the News Corporation, would be willing to surrender his stake in DirecTV, the largest American satellite broadcaster, says a lot about the competitive pressures on the satellite business. [C5.]    NEW LASER-GENERATING CHIP -- Researchers plan to announce that they have created a silicon-based chip that can produce laser beams. The advance will make it possible to remove the most significant bottleneck in computer design. [C1.]    WANTING MORE FROM FORD -- Analysts were not satisfied last week as Ford called for 44,000 job cuts and other drastic changes. For all of the stunning admissions Ford made, Wall Street wanted more answers. [C1.]    MTV'S VIRTUAL WORLD -- MTV aims to push the boundaries of fake reality one step further with Virtual Laguna Beach, an online service in which fans of the show can immerse themselves -- or, at least, digitized, three-dimensional characters called avatars -- in virtual versions of the show's seaside hangouts. [C1.]    NICKELODEON FOCUSES ON PARENTS -- Nickelodeon, the children's cable channel, is seeking to move into a new demographic. Its first step is ParentsConnect.com, a social networking Web site. [C6.]    BLACKBERRY'S NEW PUSH -- BlackBerry, whose service is irresistible to many businesspeople, is trying to spread its wireless e-mail addiction to mainstream consumers. [C5.]    AWARDS FOR THE AUDIENCE -- As the latest example of Broadway's embrace of modern marketing techniques, the Nederlander Organization has created an awards program for theatergoers. [E1.]

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: More Charges In Bombing Plot
abstract: Donald Douglas Stewart Whyte and Mohammed Usman Saddique are charged in Great Britain in connection with terrorist plot to blow up trans-Atlantic passenger planes; brings to 17 number of people charged in plot (S)

headline: Watching the Fireworks (but Keeping Them Outside)
abstract: Article offers advice on type

headline: Germany: Airline Settles Price Suit
abstract: Deutsche Lufthansa says it will pay $85 million to settle 80 class-action suits in US in price-fixing inquiry involving its air cargo unit; payment reportedly would release airline and Swiss International Air Lines, which it is taking over, from pending suits in US (S)

headline: Conrad Black Faces Additional Charges
abstract: Former Hollinger International chairman Conrad Black, in revised indictment, is charged with causing his company to file false tax returns in 1999 and 2000; indictment requests that Lord Black forfeit 26-carat diamond ring said to be worth $2.6 million (S)

headline: New Dangers to Add To the Old Ones
abstract: Israeli troops moved back into Gaza on Saturday night, setting up tank positions on the outskirts of Beit Hanun, a crowded town of 35,000 people in the small territory's northeastern corner. Children gathered on the street corners on Sunday, peering around corners for a glimpse of gun-toting militants who darted from building to building as Israeli snipers tried to pick them off.     The rattle of automatic weapons fire echoed through the otherwise empty streets, sometimes sharp and close, sometimes muffled and far away. All over northern Gaza, there was the steady thump and thunder of artillery fire as Israel shelled the fields of Beit Hanun from the southeast, raising great clouds of dust. Ambulances patrolled slowly, picking up occasional casualties.

headline: For eBay, Departures Underscore a Risky Time
abstract: Even as many of the other hot Internet companies were faltering in recent years, eBay remained a Wall Street darling. It made two big acquisitions -- PayPal and the Internet phone service Skype -- and continued to post heady sales and earnings growth as it expanded overseas.     But after a trying week in which one of the company's top executives resigned, eBay is facing new concerns over executive turnover and management succession, adding to what may be an even bigger challenge: an invasion of its turf by Google.

headline: Iraqi Oil Official Abducted by Gunmen in Baghdad
abstract: Gunmen in vehicles resembling those used by Iraqi security forces kidnapped the president of one of Iraq's state-owned oil companies in Baghdad on Sunday afternoon, an Oil Ministry spokesman said.      The abduction, the second of a high-profile Iraqi official in two days, underscored the danger that high-level Iraqi officials face and the power of criminal groups who strike at them seemingly at will.

headline: How Many Fund Choices Are Too Many?
abstract: Article offers warnings and advice on investing in too many exchange-traded funds; drawing (M)

headline: How to Use Google Trends
abstract: On its home page, Google Trends offers a number of sample searches. Some of them can be interesting like the recent one showing that "blogs" is now searched more often than "magazines" but I found most of them to be too general. It's much more fun to do your own.     To look at the search history of a single term, simply enter it into the window Google provides and hit return. The data goes back to the beginning of 2004.

headline: One Game for a Small Screen, Another for Fans of Ed Wood
abstract: Charles Herold reviews Tekken: Dark Resurrection, developed and published by Namco Bandai for PlayStation Portable, and Night Watch, developed by Nival Interactive and published by CDV Software Entertainment; photos (M)

headline: Real Estate Deals to Flip Over
abstract: Article on Broadway Partners of New York and its chief executive Scott Lawlor, who purchased Manhattan office building at 522 Fifth Avenue last spring for $420 million and hopes to sell it for $468 million or more; practice of flipping, or quickly buying and selling office towers, is gaining prominence as prices and rents rise; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Suicide Bombing Kills 5, Including A British Soldier
abstract: Suicide bomber drives car into British convoy in Kabul, killing British soldier and four civilians; in southern Afghanistan, NATO plane accidently strafes NATO forces, killing Canadian soldier (S)

headline: Finland: Nokia to Buy Music Distributor
abstract: Nokia agrees to buy digital music distributor Loudeye for $60 million to compete in market for mobile music downloads (S)

headline: I.M.F. Votes to Enhance Power of China and Others
abstract: International Monetary Fund member states, yielding to demands from China and leading Western countries, vote to adopt disputed plan to modify fund's power structure and take steps to expand voice of China and other rapidly developing countries; US Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr hails change; committee of finance ministers that oversees World Bank endorses in principle plan by president Paul Wolfowitz to crack down on corruption in bank's lending; adds proviso that board of executive directors be able to override way Wolfowitz carries out plan; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Central Bank Raises Interest Rate
abstract: South Korea raises benchmark interest rate quarter percentage point to 4.5 percent; Bank of Korea governor Lee Seong Tae comments (S)

headline: Iran Says It Will Ignore U.N. Deadline on Uranium Program
abstract: Iran's chief national security official said Sunday that Iran would defy the United Nations Security Council by refusing to halt enrichment of uranium by the end of the month.     During a news conference in Iran, Ali Larijani, the country's security chief and top nuclear negotiator, condemned the West. He said it had engaged in double-dealing, by first offering a package of incentives in exchange for suspension of its nuclear-enrichment program, and then by issuing a threat.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Supports Artificial Disks for Upper Spine
abstract: An independent panel of reviewers voted unanimously Tuesday to recommend that federal medical regulators approve the first artificial replacement for failing disks in the upper spine.     The panel told the Food and Drug Administration that the stainless steel device, made by Medtronic, performed at least as well in its clinical trials as spinal fusion -- a common surgical procedure. But the group attached several conditions to its approval, including a requirement that Medtronic perform additional safety studies if the product goes on the market.

headline: A Windfall From Shifts to Medicare
abstract: The pharmaceutical industry is beginning to reap a windfall from a surprisingly lucrative niche market: drugs for poor people.     And analysts expect the benefits to show up in many of the quarterly financial results that drug makers will begin posting this week.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Possible Sale of Assets
abstract: The prime minister of Italy, Romano Prodi, left, said his government was studying the sale of state-owned property and stakes in companies to reduce the European Union's biggest debt. ''We have nothing against privatizations and we are studying asset sales,'' Mr. Prodi said. ''We will do it in a way that is well thought-out and intelligent, both with real estate assets and other assets.'' Standard & Poor's has threatened to cut Italy's credit rating for a second time since the start of the euro if the government does not reduce debt and contain its budget deficit, which it forecasts at about 4 percent of gross domestic product this year. Italy's debt will rise for a second year in 2006, at a time when higher interest rates are increasing the cost of financing the shortfall.

headline: 2 Arrested in Thefts at Hermitage, Reports Say
abstract: Investigation into theft of 221 pieces of art from State Hermitage Museum in St Petersburg, Russia, leads to arrest of two suspects; fate of about 70 works that have been sold is unknown; suspects are believed to have stolen works with aid of curator who was responsible for storeroom where majority of missing items were kept; death of curator last year prompted audit of collection that uncovered scheme (M)

headline: Deal Is Seen for Creating Urban Films
abstract: The Weinstein Company, the film studio started by the founders of Miramax, is near a deal to form a joint venture with Robert L. Johnson, founder of Black Entertainment Television, to create an urban entertainment company, according to people involved in the negotiations.     The joint venture could be announced as early as Thursday, these people said, though they cautioned that the deal could be delayed.

headline: Strong Earnings and a Big Buyout Turn Investors Bullish
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and Dow Jones industrial average gain 1.7 percent; Dow gains 183 points, to close at 11,051; Nasdaq rises 2 percent, to 2,062; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; chart; graphs (M)/

headline: At Work in Real Time
abstract: Thomas S Rogers, TiVo president and chief executive, in The Boss column, discusses his childhood, career and state of television industry today; photo (M)

headline: Big Promoter of Concerts to Acquire House of Blues
abstract: Concert promoter Live Nation reaches deal to buy HOB Entertainment, operator of House of Blues clubs, for $350 million; deal, subject to approval by regulators, would reshape concert industry landscape by reducing number of promoters with national presence from three to two and expand Live Nation's network of concert sites by 18 to 150; photo (M)

headline: A Swastika, 60 Years Submerged, Still Inflames Debate
abstract: Private syndicate that has recovered fragments of Graf Spee, Nazi battleship scuttled off Montevideo in December 1939, wants to put pieces up for auction, with money to be divided evenly with Uruguayan government; government officials, however, threaten to suspend syndicate's permit and take control of salvaging operations themselves, fearing that auction might let neo-Nazi groups acquire artifacts; photos; map (M)

headline: Respect and Anger Voiced at Lay Service
abstract: More than 1,000 people, including politial and business leaders, gather at First United Methodist Church in Houston for memorial service for former Enron chairman Kenneth Lay; some laud his dedication to his family, city and community while others express anger at treatment of Lay; photos (M)

headline: French Newspaper of the Far Left Faces Financial Ruin
abstract: The end could be near for Libération, the newspaper founded by the philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre and members of the extreme political left.      After years of falling readership and advertising, the paper's largest shareholder, Edouard de Rothschild, has stopped paying operating costs and, according to Pierre Haski, deputy editor of the newspaper, salaries have been frozen for October. ''On Sept. 28, we hit the wall,'' Mr. Haski said. ''This seems too sad, but it is the reality.''

headline: Accounts
abstract: Bally Total Fitness, Chicago, named the Eastwest Marketing Group, New York, to handle its creative and promotional advertising and marketing account, which had been handled internally at Bally and by various outside agencies. Spending was estimated at $75 million.

headline: A Platoons Mission: Seeking and Destroying Explosives in Disguise
abstract: When American soldiers take to the road they pray they avoid the roadside bombs that seem to explode every day in Iraq. Sgt. First Class Timothy Faust has a very different goal: he hopes to find them.     Sergeant Faust's Demon Platoon has the ''route clearing'' mission for Company A, Task Force 1-36. That is the somewhat understated description of an operation that involves driving into a veritable no man's land in hostile Anbar Province to uncover mines, buried artillery shells and all manner of explosive devices, often under sniper fire.

headline: Conocos Profit Rises by Two-Thirds on Soaring Oil Prices
abstract: ConocoPhillips reports profits rose nearly two-thirds due to soaring oil prices; earned $5.19 billion in second quarter, compared with $3.14 billion in period year earlier (M)

headline: Leftist Starts Legal Battle Over Mexico Vote
abstract: Andres Manual Lopez Obrador, losing Mexican presidential candidate, begins legal battle to try to overturn results of vote; act is largely symbolic, but aides say other challenges will be submitted to local election boards and to Federal Election Tribunal; lawyers contend that initial count of ballots was careless; photo (M)

headline: Reporter's Notebook; Two Leaders Whose Friendship Has an Edge
abstract: United States and Russian officials say that despite some appearances, President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin got along famously at the Group of 8 summit meeting this week, and that their relationship is at one of its highest points in its five-year history.     Still, though the officials said there were great areas of agreement, they did not work quite as hard to deny analyses that competitive friction between the nations was as high as it had been in years. And while the cold war may be over, its icy residue could have frozen even the strongest vodka during the summit meetings between leaders of the economic powers gathered at the Konstantinovsky Palace near here.

headline: TO THE RESCUE
abstract: Apple Computer's chief executive Steven P Jobs was asked by Reporters Without Borders, journalism advocacy group, to intercede on behalf of Chinese reporters Wang You and Weng Bao who are facing $3.8 million lawsuit by Taiwanese contract electronic manufacturer Foxconn, which assembles iPods for Apple; company accused reporters of 'smearing its reputation' in article criticizing working conditions; Apple says report of labor abuses is false and that it is working behind scenes to resolve dispute between Foxconn and journalists; Foxconn has dropped its request for damages; photo (M)

headline: Back to School, With Cellphone and Laptop
abstract: Jeffrey Selingo Basics column describes latest back-to-school electronic devices for all age levels; photos(M)

headline: Text of the Fed’s Statement on Interest Rates
abstract: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.       The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to keep its target for the federal funds rate at 5.25 percent.

headline: Beating of Lawyer Threatens Hong Kong’s Allure
abstract: The anonymous letter arrived Thursday evening with a box-cutter blade.     It was addressed to one of the city's best-known lawmakers and litigators. And it held a chilling reminder of his beating at a McDonald's restaurant on Sunday.

headline: Lavishing Attention on the College-Bound
abstract: FOR years, older teenagers have been the darlings of online marketers, who see these tech-savvy, free-spending legions as potential lifelong customers.     So why has it taken them this long to discover college students?

headline: As Summit Opens, Russia Counts Its Gains and Slights
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.    TODAYS TOP STORIES       Moscow will empty this weekend as politicians, bureaucrats and journalists head for St. Petersburg and the Group of Eight summit. The major Russian newspapers today glance over the already-well-known substance of the proceedings, choosing to highlight Russias unique place in the summit and speculate on potential intrigue.

headline: A Producer’s Hit Broadway Memorial
abstract: Joel Grey sang ''Willkommen,'' Donna McKechnie sang ''I Love Paris'' and Neil Simon delivered a few one-liners; that's how a showman is mourned, if mourned is the right word.      It was more of a memorial cabaret yesterday as hundreds gathered at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Broadway to pay tribute to Cy Feuer: trumpet player, Oscar-nominated composer, director and, most notably, producer of musicals like ''Guys and Dolls'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' and the film version of ''Cabaret.''

headline: A New Blast at a Horrific Memory Salts a Fathers Wounds
abstract: The explosion that awakened Muhammad Khaitan at dawn on Wednesday seemed sadly routine. The dust rising skyward a few blocks from his home suggested yet another attack on a police checkpoint.      But for Mr. Khaitan, the target proved far more personal and depraved. Two bombs, witnesses said, shredded a memorial commemorating the death of his 14-year-old son and two dozen other children who were killed last summer when a car bomber sped into a crowd receiving candy from American troops.

headline: AOL Adds Another $584 Million to Restatements of Ad Sales
abstract: Time Warner restates another $584 million related to revenue booked by its AOL division shortly after 2000 merger; change brings to more than $1.26 billion total sales that AOL booked improperly over several years (M)

headline: Leaders of Two Parties for Left-Wing Alliance
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.     TODAYS TOP STORIES

headline: One Route Seems Closed, So Lawyers Try Different Lawsuit in Stock-Option Scandal
abstract: As the number of companies caught up in the options-backdating scandal continues to grow, many plaintiffs' law firms are looking to see if the latest round of corporate greed and malfeasance offers them an arena for possible payoffs.     But so far, law firms that represent shareholders are struggling to find a foothold-- and a payday for the investors and for themselves.

headline: Portable Navigation Systems Going in More Directions
abstract: Sure, portable navigation systems, the kind that can be taken from car to car and plugged into a lighter socket, are a godsend for driving directions, but they are becoming quite handy in other ways as well -- and not just for drivers.     With more than a dozen brands of portable global positioning system devices now sold in the United States for $300 to $1,500, manufacturers are competing by adding features like audio, video, photography and language guides rather than becoming tangled up in price wars.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Four Years In Prison For Brutal Army Hazing
abstract: Russian military court sentences Army Sergeant Aleksandr V Sivyakov to four years in prison for physical abuse of draftee Andrei S Sychev, whose injuries were so severe that his legs and genitals were amputated; beating took place at Chelyabinsk Tank Academy during military hazing ritual known as dedovshchina, which is acknowledged to be widespread (S)

headline: At Least 41 Die as Train Derails in Spanish Subway
abstract: At least 41 people are killed when subway train derails in Valencia, Spain; no indication of terrorism is uncovered; Spanish government declares three-day mourning period; photo (M)

headline: Millennium Wins Bidding for AnorMed
abstract: Millennium Pharmaceuticals, topping earlier bid from Genzyme, reportedly agrees to buy AnorMed, Canadian biotechnology company with experimental treatment for patients with blood cancer, for $515 million in cash (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of Aug 13 article about Defense Department's cancellation of contract with MZM Inc, which misstated amount of campaign contributions of former MZM Inc executive pleaded guilty to illegally funneling to Rep Virgil H Good; it was $8,000 not $90,000; larger figure represents all contributions Goode received from MZM's political action committee and company's employees and their spouses

headline: A Pot of Tax-Free Bonds for Post-9/11 Projects Is Empty
abstract: Federal Liberty Bonds program, created to help Lower Manhattan and New York economy recover from September 11 terrorist attacks, ends; $50 million in bonds remaining from $8 billion designated has been tentatively approved for 220-room luxury hotel, which will be developed by Moinian Group on site south of ground zero adjacent to Deutsche Bank Building, which is slated to be demolished; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Heavily Hyped Cellphone Won't Make You a Chocoholic
abstract: Chocolate, under the proper circumstances, can be a deeply satisfying treat for the senses.     It can also be a sticky mess.

headline: Enron Founder, Awaiting Prison, Dies in Colorado
abstract: Kenneth L. Lay, who as founder of the Enron Corporation rose to peaks of influence in business and politics, only to fall into disgrace amid scandal, died early yesterday morning in Aspen, Colo., while awaiting a judge's sentencing this fall that could have sent him to prison for decades.      Mr. Lay, who was 64 years old, died of coronary artery disease, according to Scott Thompson, the chief deputy coroner for Pitkin County, Colo. The finding was based on an autopsy completed late yesterday.

headline: Hot German July Doesnt Faze Farmer Who Reaps the Sun
abstract: Surely Heiner Gärtner is one of the only farmers in Germany, if not most of Europe, who greets the dawn of yet another cloudless day with anticipation rather than angst.     As Germany sizzles through what is expected to be its hottest July on record, crops are shriveling and farmers are growing desperate. Some have petitioned the European Union to allow sheep and cattle to graze on land normally off limits, because their own fields are scorched.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Progressive Corp awards creative ad account for Progressive Direct insurance to Arnold Worldwide, Boston (S)

headline: Wal-Mart Finds That Its Formula Doesnt Fit Every Culture
abstract: Three days after Wal-Mart Stores announced that it would pull out of Germany, Roland Kögel was wandering through the aisles of a somewhat threadbare Wal-Mart in a strip mall in this western German city.     ''Why are they giving up now?'' he asked. ''They have good prices and a good variety of products.''

headline: Polygamy Fosters Culture Clashes (and Regrets) in Turkey
abstract: Polygamy remains widespread in Turkey even though it was banned by first president Mustafa Kemal Ataturk as part of modernization effort; creates cultural clashes in country struggling to reconcile secularism of republic with Muslim traditions; because polygamous marriages are not recognized by state, imams who conduct them are subject to punishment and wives have no legal status; photo; map (M)

headline: Serbs Criticize U.N. Mediator, Further Bogging Down Kosovo Talks
abstract: Talks on future of Kosovo, mostly Albanian-inhabited province of Serbia, appear further complicated as their main mediator, Finnish politician Martti Ahtisaari, is accused by Serbs of bias against them (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Justice Minister To Quit Over Kiss Charges
abstract: Justice Min Haim Ramon says he will resign and face charges of sexual harassment lodged by female Israeli soldier who said Ramon forcibly kissed her (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Power Company Plans Sale
abstract: The AES Corporation, the American power producer with businesses in 26 countries, plans to sell a 33 percent holding in Brazil's biggest electricity distributor to help complete a $1 billion rescheduling of debt owed to the state development bank. The stake in the distributor, Eletropaulo Metropolitana Eletricidade de São Paulo, is worth 1.29 billion reais ($603 million), based on the Sept. 1 closing price. AES Transgas Empreendimentos, a unit based in São Paulo, will sell 13.76 billion preferred B shares of Eletropaulo this month, through a public offering, according to a statement filed with Brazil's securities regulator. The share sale will enable AES to cover payments on $582 million of bonds the bank holds.

headline: G.M., Renault and Nissan Agree to Study Alliance
abstract: General Motors, Renault and Nissan agreed Friday night to begin studying whether they want to form a three-way, global alliance that could change the shape of the automobile industry.      The companies, in a joint statement, said the review would take approximately 90 days.

headline: Court Backs Nonresidents Right to Obtain Delaware Documents
abstract: US Court of Appeals affirms earlier Federal District Court decision declaring it unconstitutional for Delaware to deny public documents to nonresidents under state's Freedom of Information Act; case involved Matthew Lee, consumer advocate and lawyer who lives in New York and sued Delaware for denying him access to documents related to nationwide settlement with consumer lender Household International (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: PIPELINE LEAK SENDS OIL HIGHER -- BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel. BP said it could not estimate how long the system would be down. [Page A1.]    STOCKS FALL ON OIL WORRIES -- Stocks declined as crude oil surged after BP began shutting down its field in Alaska for emergency repairs. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.59 points, to 1275.77. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 20.97 points, to 11,219.38. The Nasdaq lost 12.55 points, to 2,072.50. [C12.]    SHORTCHANGING PUBLIC PENSIONS -- A number of states, counties and municipalities have engaged in maneuvers similar to the city worker pension fund in San Diego, which, after being underfunded, set off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments. [A1.]    TRADING IN CADAVERS -- ''Body Worlds,'' a show displaying preserved, skinless human corpses, has attracted 20 million people worldwide over the past decade and taken in over $200 million. But now with millions of people flocking to see that exhibition and others like it, a ghastly new underground cadaver industry has emerged in China. [A1.]    CELLPHONE BOOM IN IRAQ -- The State Department said there are 7.1 million cellphone subscribers in Iraq, up from 1.4 million two years ago. [A1.]    MARTHA STEWART SETTLEMENT -- Martha Stewart, the celebrated domestic tastemaker, reached a settlement with securities regulators over insider-trading accusations, agreeing to pay $195,000 to conclude a five-year legal battle that once put a dent in her brand name. [C1.]    GOOGLE IN DEAL WITH MYSPACE -- Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com, the social networking phenomenon, as well as other Web sites owned by the News Corporation. [C1.]    I.B.M. CLEARED IN RETIREMENT CASE -- A three-judge appellate panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age-discrimination suits. [C1.]    FORBES FAMILY SAGA -- The sale of 40 percent of the company that publishes Forbes magazine may resolve some growing tensions among Forbes family members, some of whom have been unhappy about the sale of nonpublishing family assets in the last six years. [C1.]    THE MAN BEHIND THE FORBES DEAL -- Wall Street bankers are abuzz about Roger McNamee, a force in Silicon Valley venture capital circles who founded Elevation Partners, a private equity firm that has invested an estimated $250 million in the Forbes publishing business. [C1.]    APPLE COMPLETES TRANSITION -- Apple Computer said it had completed its transition to computers based entirely on Intel processors. [C4.]    WAL-MART TO RAISE SALARIES -- Wal-Mart Stores said it would raise starting salaries at a third of its United States stores by about 6 percent after a company survey found that it needed to improve hourly pay to remain competitive. [C4.]    AOL REMOVES SEARCH DATA -- AOL removed a list of the Web search queries of 658,000 unnamed users from a public Web site over the weekend, after bloggers complained that the information was so detailed and personal that it could compromise the users' privacy. [C4.]    NEW TACTICS FOR MAGAZINES -- Condé Nast's Fashion Rocks extravaganza demonstrates what it takes for a publisher to stay relevant lately: staging outsize, razzle-dazzle productions that incorporate television, the Web and wireless communications, but have relatively little to do with a print product. Advertising. [C4.]    OUTREACH TO INDIA -- The Bush administration is organizing a business delegation to India this fall, potentially the largest such mission ever to a single country and one that underscores the economic potential of a nation of 1.1 billion. [C7.]    COLA CAMPAIGN IN INDIA -- PepsiCo and Coca-Cola intensified a long-running campaign in India to prove that their products are safe, as local governments imposed a partial ban on their soft drinks. [C7.]    ONLINE    MORTGAGES -- Bob Tedeschi's weekly column on mortgages and finances can be found at nytimes.com/realestate.    ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    ONE FOR BABY -- For years baby food changed little. Now there has been a growth spurt of alternatives, from single-ingredient purées to complete toddler meals in designer packages. A report is at nytimes.com/style.    TWO NEW G.M. PICKUPS -- Chevrolet and GMC introduce the 2007 Silverado and Sierra pickups -- delivering what G.M. says is the best power and fuel economy in the segment. A report is at nytimes.com/automobiles.

headline: Israel to Occupy Area of Lebanon as Security Zone
abstract: Almost two weeks into its military assault on Hezbollah, Israel said Tuesday that it would occupy a strip inside southern Lebanon with ground troops until an international force could take its place.     The announcement raised the prospect of a more protracted Israeli involvement in Lebanon than the political and military leadership previously signaled or publicly sought. Officials have talked about limited raids into Lebanon, but now they seem ready to commit ground forces for at least weeks, if not months.

headline: Settlement by Medtronic Is Challenged in U.S. Court
abstract: Andrew Carr Jr, lawyer for whistle-blower Jacqueline Kay Poteet, who accused Medtronic's spinal implant division of paying doctors illegal kickbacks, files objection; says case has not been adequately investigated and describes Justice Department's $40 million settlement as 'woefully inadequate'; company, which denied wrongdoing, and government made settlement contingent on dismissal of both whistle-blower's lawsuits (M)

headline: Housing Slows, Taking Big Toll on the Economy
abstract: Housing industry has lost its vigor in recent months and has begun to bog down broader economy, which slowed to modest 2.5 percent growth rate this spring; that was sharp comedown from 5.6 percent growth rate of first quarter, caused in part by third consecutive quarterly decline in spending on houses and apartment buildings, after several years of rapid growth; housing slowdown is perhaps clearest effect of Federal Reserve's two-year campaign of raising interest rates in bid to tap brakes on economy and reduce inflation; graphs; photo (M)

headline: New Service From Amazon Offers Downloadable Films
abstract: Amazon.com begins selling films and television programs through its AmazonUnbox service, which can be downloaded and watched on computer or portable video player; will compete with Apple's iTunes Music Store and growing market, which includes Google, AOL, Movielink and CinemaNow; movies will sell for $7.99 to $14.99 or $3.99 for rentals; most television shows will be available for $1.99 per episode; photo (M)

headline: In Diversification Move, Times Company Buys a Subscription Entertainment Database
abstract: The New York Times Company announced yesterday the acquisition of Baseline StudioSystems, a leading online supplier of data and information about the movie and television industries.     The $35 million purchase extends the Times Company's reach into the entertainment world and adds a source of subscription income to the company's Internet operations. Subscriptions account for three-quarters of the $6 million in revenue that the Times Company expects Baseline to receive this year.

headline: New Kid on the Rack
abstract: Article on Christopher LaPolice and Rea Laccone, business partners whose hot contemporary apparel label Vince is sold at upscale retailers; two comment on working for larger labels and decision to strike out on their own; photos (special section, Small Business) (L)

headline: Suspects Are Arrested in India Commuter Rail Bombings
abstract: Abdul Karim Tunda, one of India's most wanted men, is arrested in Kenya and three people appear in Indian court in connection with train bombings in Mumbai that killed over 200 people and wounded at least 800; suspects in Mumbai are Khaleel Aziz Sheikh, Kamal Ahmed Ansari and Mumtaz Ahmed Chowdhury; photo (M)

headline: Comverse Cuts Ties With Former Officials
abstract: Comverse Technology severs all employment agreements with former chairman and chief executive Jacob Alexander, former chief financial officer David Kreinberg and former director and general counsel William Sorin after they are charged in government crackdown on stock option manipulation (S)

headline: A Conscience of Corporations
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Sister Patricia Wolf, executive director of Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility; Wolf comments efforts to prod corporations on social issues; drawing (M)

headline: Tide of Arab Opinion Turns to Support for Hezbollah
abstract: At the onset of the Lebanese crisis, Arab governments, starting with Saudi Arabia, slammed Hezbollah for recklessly provoking a war, providing what the United States and Israel took as a wink and a nod to continue the fight.      Now, with hundreds of Lebanese dead and Hezbollah holding out against the vaunted Israeli military for more than two weeks, the tide of public opinion across the Arab world is surging behind the organization, transforming the Shiite group's leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, into a folk hero and forcing a change in official statements.

headline: Time Shares Are Shedding the Faint Odor of Disrepute
abstract: Alina Tugend column takes second look at vacation time shares, noting they are slowly shedding negative reputation from 30 years ago; explains options available under terms time share and fractional ownership; notes they now include hotel rooms, yachts and castles, but resort condominiums still dominate and Florida has almost 28 percent of entire US inventory; photos (M)

headline: Hotel Revenue Climbs, but So Do Expenses
abstract: Hotel market, anticipating record-breaking revenue for 2006, is experiencing hikes in expenses for labor, insurance, real estate, taxes and fuel; hotel operators in New York City, for example, say property taxes have risen by about 50 percent in last five years while fuel costs have grown 22.8 percent in last year alone; average daily room rate in New York is now $211.80, compared with $98.35 nationwide; photos (M)

headline: Opera Canceled Over a Depiction of Muhammad
abstract: A leading German opera house has canceled performances of a Mozart opera because of security fears stirred by a scene that depicts the severed head of the Prophet Muhammad, prompting a storm of protest here about what many see as the surrender of artistic freedom.     The Deutsche Oper Berlin said Tuesday that it had pulled ''Idomeneo'' from its fall schedule after the police warned of an ''incalculable risk'' to the performers and the audience.

headline: For 4th Time, Pope Clarifies Islam Remark
abstract: Muslims angry about Pope Benedict XVI's remarks on Islam are not the only ones talking about an apology.      ''What should he apologize for?'' asked Daniele Corbetta, 43, a psychologist in Rome. ''There is freedom of speech, and what he said is objectively true.''

headline: At AOL, a Plan for a Clean Break
abstract: Should AOL sacrifice its cash cow in hopes of finding a prosperous future?     In two weeks, the board of Time Warner Inc., which owns AOL, will hear a proposal from Jonathan Miller, AOL's chief executive, calling for a near halt in marketing for AOL's 17-year-old Internet access service, price cuts for existing customers and thousands of layoffs. His goal is to devote all of AOL's energy into building its free Web-based services.

headline: A Flight Attendant’s Revenge
abstract: Former flight attendant Ellen Simonetti Frequent Flier column on decline in airline passenger behavior; describes how one colleague exacted revenge against unruly passenger; photo (M)

headline: In Connecticut, an Office Hub Resurges
abstract: Vigorous office market is signaling Stamford, Conn, resurgence as major center for financial services; expanding companies are filling towers as new buildings are erected; photos (M)

headline: Battle for Baghdad Boils Down to Neighborhoods
abstract: The Bush administration's announcement on Tuesday that it will shift more forces to Baghdad is much more than a numbers game. It reflects a new strategy to reclaim control of the Iraqi capital and a new approach for deploying the troops.     The plan is to concentrate on specific neighborhoods rather than distribute the forces throughout the city, control movement in and out of sectors of the capital and try to sweep them of insurgents and violent militias.

headline: Lebanon’s Three-Sided Postwar Game: Who Gets Shabaa Farms?
abstract: Israel and United Nations say 10-square-mile area of hilly land known as Shabaa Farms is part of Golan Heights, which has been occupied by Israel since 1967 war; Lebanese insist farms are theirs and Syria agrees; Hezbollah says it will not lay down its arms until Israel gives area back; Lebanese opposition says removal of issue would give it leverage against Hezbollah, but Israel says it will only discuss Shabaa Farms if Lebanon fulfills UN obligations that ended fighting, including disarming of Hezbollah; photo; map (M)

headline: Wake of War Idles Lebanon’s Fleet, and Its Fishermen
abstract: Sidon Journal on ancient Lebanese port town where fishermen have been unable to put boats out since Israel imposed blockade in conflict with Hezbollah; photo; map; Israel says blockade cannot be lifted until peacekeeping troops ensure that weapons are not being imported (M)

headline: Hezbollahs Prominence Has Many Sunnis Worried
abstract: To one Damascus University professor, the faint echo of Israeli bombs exploding in the lower Bekaa Valley brings two fears. He recoils at the destruction he imagines across the border, less than 10 miles from his village home, but deeper down he worries that any Hezbollah triumph will come at the expense of his own Sunni branch of Islam.      ''Since the Americans invaded Iraq we have all become aware of the danger from the Shiites,'' said the professor, who asked not to be identified by name because discussing sectarian rivalry is taboo in Syria, an authoritarian state run by a religious minority. ''Ordinary people only think of Hezbollah as fighting against Israeli aggression. But the educated classes think that if Hezbollah controls the region, then the Sunnis will be abused.''

headline: Why the Tide Hasn’t Turned Toward Growth Stocks
abstract: Paul J Lim Fundamentally column on why tide has not turned toward growth stocks; says while growth stocks have been in slump for more than six years, some investors say these stocks may need several more months to regain lead; graph (M)

headline: Dynegy in Deal to Raise Generating Capacity by 69%
abstract: Dynegy agrees to buy LS Power Group's electricity plants for $2.3 billion; move will extend Dynegy's reach to 15 states from nine and expand its generating capacity by 69 percent, to 20,000 megawatts (M)

headline: Studios Shift to Digital Movies, but Not Without Resistance
abstract: Every weekend through the summer, big-budget movies compete for dominance at the box office. On movie sets, a quieter sort of contest is taking place as a handful of companies are angling to have their digital movie cameras used to capture the action, supplanting the traditional 35-millimeter film camera.      Many of this summer's most prominent releases have relied on digital movie cameras, including ''Superman Returns'' from Warner Brothers, ''Click'' from Sony Pictures and ''Miami Vice,'' a Universal Pictures offering that opens Friday.

headline: Deaths of Aid Workers in Darfur on Rise, U.N. Says
abstract: More aid workers in Darfur, the troubled Sudanese region, have been killed in the past month than in the previous three years of conflict there, the United Nations said Tuesday.      Eight aid workers, all of them Sudanese, were killed in July in attacks across Darfur, the United Nations said, compared with only six from 2003, when the conflict began, through June.

headline: India: Refining Business Lifts Energy Company
abstract: Reliance Industries of India reports profit rose 10.7 percent in quarter ended in June, to 25.47 billion rupees ($544 million), from 23.1 billion rupees year earlier; says sales rose 38 percent, to 245 billion rupees ($5.23 billion) (S)

headline: Marketers Look Past Jelly Stains and See a Mom Who Has Needs
abstract: Claudia Deutsch Advertising column on major marketers that are tailoring their commercials toward mothers and their needs; notes that studies have shown that decisions on family purchases are increasingly made by mothers and if advertising can make them feel empowered they are more likely to form emotional attachment to particular brands; photos (M)

headline: How Does Warren Buffett Get Married? Frugally, It Turns Out
abstract: It did not move markets, and Berkshire Hathaway shares barely budged, but the marriage of Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, to his longtime companion, Astrid Menks, had the financial world all abuzz yesterday.      Mr. Buffett and Ms. Menks formalized a relationship of more than 20 years in a brief civil ceremony at his daughter's house in Omaha Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Diaries Add Hirohito to Debate on Visits to Japan War Shrine
abstract: A bundle of yellowing, two-decade-old diaries made public on Thursday added ammunition to one of the most contentious debates in modern Japanese politics: whether the prime minister should continue to visit a war shrine here.     The diaries, kept by a former leader of the Imperial Household Agency, which manages Japan's imperial family, are said to contain transcripts of private conversations with Emperor Hirohito, the wartime leader who died in 1989. The emperor, whose role in the war is still debated, is recorded as saying that he stopped visiting the memorial, known as the Yasukuni Shrine, after it began honoring convicted war criminals in 1978. In that year, Yasukuni, which honors Japan's modern war dead, added to the honorees 14 World War II leaders convicted of crimes against humanity. Hirohito last visited the shrine in 1975.

headline: A Gazan Rocket Reaches 6 Miles Into Israel
abstract: Palestinian militants in Gaza Strip fire rocket that hits empty high school in Ashkelon, Israeli town six miles from border; Israel responds with airstrike that causes extensive damage to Interior Ministry in Gaza City; photos; map (M)

headline: Rules Ignored, Toxic Sludge Sinks Chinese Village
abstract: Liquid waste from two paper mills overwhelms tiny Chinese village of Sugai, enveloping 57 homes in toxic lake; disaster occurs despite fact that mills were fined and ordered to upgrade their polllution equipment after serious spill into Yellow River in 2004; fact that local officials never carried out cleanup order provides lesson in difficulty of enforcing environmental rules in China, where there is mounting conflict between economic growth and environmental protection; China has begun to take environment seriously, but pollution is actually worsening in some crucial categories, eliciting public protests; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 2 Charged With Racially Motivated Murder In Market Blast
abstract: Oleg Kostyryov and Ilya Tikhomirov are arrested for racially motivated bombing of Moscow market that kills 10 people and wounds more than 40; pair say they carried out attack because 'there were too many Asians' at market; reportedly learned to build bombs through Internet (S)

headline: That Other Guy From Omaha
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on Vinod Gupta, colorful founder and chief executive of InfoUSA, based in Omaha, Neb; says Gupta often prevents large shareholders from asking questions on conference calls, has received unearned compensation and, according to suit filed by its largest outside shareholder Cardinal Value Equity Partners, has been given free reign by board to dispense stock options and to make questionable financial transactions; graph (M)

headline: U.S. General Says Iraq Could Slide Into a Civil War
abstract: The commander of American forces in the Middle East bluntly warned a Senate committee on Thursday that sectarian violence in Iraq, especially in the capital, Baghdad, had grown so severe that the nation could slide toward civil war.     The commander, Gen. John P. Abizaid, also acknowledged that since the security situation remained so unstable, significant reductions in American forces were unlikely before the end of this year.

headline: It’s the Law, but Is the Law Meaningless?
abstract: WHEN corporations do well, the bosses do much, much better than the workers. But what happens if everything goes wrong?     The Dana Corporation, an auto parts maker, is facing lawsuits claiming that it manipulated its books to hide rising costs before it filed for bankruptcy early this year. It is considering reducing or eliminating retiree health benefits. But at the same time, the bosses, including the chief executive, Michael J. Burns, want guaranteed multimillion-dollar payouts.

headline: Chevron Could Avoid Huge Royalties on New Field
abstract: A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which said last week that they had discovered a huge new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for the oil.     The potential bonus to Chevron and its partners stems from a mistake the Interior Department made in signing offshore leases in the late 1990's for drilling in federal waters. The magnitude of the oil discovery -- estimated in a range of 3 billion to 15 billion barrels -- is likely to intensify a battle in Congress over incentives for drilling in publicly owned waters.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Stalemate Enters A New Stage
abstract: The government deadlock continued inconclusively, as President Viktor A. Yushchenko allowed a deadline to pass for selecting a new prime minister without taking action. Mr. Yushchenko has so far refused to accept a parliamentary coalition's nomination of Viktor F. Yanukovich for the post. Mr. Yushchenko acquired the constitutional right yesterday to dissolve Parliament and call for new elections. He was expected to meet leaders of Parliament today.    C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

headline: More Irregularities Are Found at Broadcom
abstract: Broadcom Corp discovers more accounting irregularities that will double its expenses to at least $1.5 billion; earnings for 1998 and 1999 will be restated (S)

headline: Detroit, Far South
abstract: For Mexico, the recent groundbreaking of a new $650 million auto factory was worth celebrating. President Vicente Fox and other dignitaries attended the event. Local executives from General Motors, the investor, flew in to the central state of San Luis Potosí, where the assembly plant now under construction is expected to eventually employ up to 1,800 people and churn out as many as 160,000 compact cars a year.     During the last dozen years, many foreign manufacturers rushed to build factories in states like Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee, inspiring the sobriquet Detroit South. Now Mexico is eyeing that nickname.

headline: 14 Arrested in London Anti-Terror Raids
abstract: British police arrest 14 men throughout London and two men in Manchester in latest display of concern about spread of potential terrorists among British Muslims; none of arrests are linked to huge security alert that began after failed plan to bomb trans-Atlantic airliners, nor is there indication arrests are linked to any specific conspiracy; photo (M)

headline: Canada: Retail Sales Declined Unexpectedly in May
abstract: Canada reports retail sales fell unexpectedly in May by 0.6 percent; sales decreased to 32.6 billion Canadian dollars ($28.6 billion); suggests Bank of Canada's rate increases are slowing consumer borrowing and spending on expensive items; interest rate remains unchanged at 4.25 percent (S)

headline: The Story Behind MySpace
abstract: What's Online column; Valleywag publishes long, critical examination of MySpace and its origins by blogger Trent Lapinski; Cato Institute's annual Economic Freedom of the World report notes that economic freedom remains on rise; YouTube.com publishes set of 1970's toy commercials; drawing (M)

headline: Search Fails to Find U.S. Major in Kyrgyzstan
abstract: Baffling new details surfaced Thursday in the search for a missing Air Force officer in Kyrgyzstan, but the efforts to find the officer continued without a major break in the case, American and Kyrgyz officials said.     The officer, Maj. Jill M. Metzger, the personnel chief of the 376th Air Expeditionary Wing, disappeared Tuesday afternoon while shopping in a department store in Bishkek, the Kyrgyz capital.

headline: The Camera for Your Next Family Reunion
abstract: Fujifilm introduces FinePix S6500fd, 6.3-metgapixel camera with 10x optical zoom with 'face detection' feature; photo (S)

headline: A Fantastic Gadget, Straight From Barcelona
abstract: Ahoy from Mallorca, Spain!     The most amazing thing happened. A reader in Barcelona, having spotted my blog posting last week, e-mailed me. Hed seen that the geek cruise would be docking in Barcelona yesterday, and offered to give my family a personal tour of his hometown!

headline: Merck Wins Vioxx Case in New Jersey
abstract: Jury in Superior Court in Atlantic City, NJ, rules that painkiller Vioxx did not cause heart attack suffered by Elaine Doherty in 2004; rules that Merck warned Doherty's doctor of drug's risk and did not defraud customers; finds that Merck did not warn Doherty herself about drug (M)

headline: A Sweetener With a Bad Rap
abstract: Article explores myths and realities about nutritional value of high-fructose corn syrup, which has, over last 25 years, become hard-to-avoid staple of American diet; many scientists say there is little data to back up its demonization and links with obesity are based upon misperceptions and unproved theories; photos; diagrams (L)

headline: Acquisitions Help Oracle Profit Climb 29%
abstract: The Oracle Corporation announced late yesterday that its quarterly profit rose 29 percent on a sharp rise in sales in its business software unit, beating analysts' forecasts as it experienced strong growth from its recent acquisition spree.      Oracle's profit in the quarter, which ended Aug. 31, rose to $670 million, or 13 cents a share, from $519 million, or 10 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $3.6 billion for the fiscal first quarter, up from $2.77 billion a year ago.

headline: In Canada, the Torch Is Passed on a Quiet but Profitable Legacy
abstract: The Thomson Corporation may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.      Those with long memories may recall it as the owner of The Times of London and a string of newspapers in small-town America. But Thomson, based in Toronto, sold those papers a long time ago and has turned itself into a major purveyor of media of a different sort -- specialized, high-end electronic information sold by subscription to lawyers, financial traders, academics and physicians.

headline: Prestigious Award, ‘Nobel’ of Mathematics, Fails to Lure Reclusive Russian Problem Solver
abstract: Grigory Perelman, reclusive Russian mathematician who solved key piece of century-old Poincare conjecture, declines to accept prestigious Fields Medal and does not attent ceremonies at International Congress of Mathematics in Madrid; other winners are Princeton Prof Andrei Okounkov, UCLA Prof Terence Tao and University of Paris Prof Wendelin Werner; International Mathematics Union president Sir John M Ball, who went to St Petersburg to try to persuade Perelman, says Perelman feels isolated from intenational mathematics community and does not wish to represent it(M)

headline: Flexible Speakers Help Bend Sound
abstract: JLab Audio's 2-watt stereo speakers plug into computer USB ports and are connected to flexible cable allowing user to direct sound; works with most Windows, Macintosh and Linux systems; speakers are available for $40 from company's Web site; photo (M)

headline: Aiming to Be the Truck of Patriots
abstract: General Motors launches advertising campaign for its Silverado which will position vehicle as America's truck; hopes to tap into patriotism in effort to connect more emotionally with consumers; change in strategy is in response to competition from foreign automakers like Toyota, which have made inroads into full-size pickup truck market; photo (M)

headline: A College Savings Plan With One Less Worry
