abstract: Article on investing in 529 college tuition savings plans, whose 2010 sunset provision for tax-free withdrawals has been eliminated; also explores other options parents could use to sock away savings for their child's education; photo (M)

headline: YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED
abstract: Society of Corporate Compliance and Ethics adds session to annual meeting in Chicago in September on stock option backdating (S)

headline: Even Law Firms Have a Yin and a Yang
abstract: Claire Wilson article onnew Manhattan office space of law firm of McDermott Will & Emery; space is designed by Mark Morton of Gensler; photos (M)

headline: A File Sharer Fights Back
abstract: What's Online column; company that owns LimeWire file-sharing service files countersuit against Recording Industry Association of America, accusing members of anticompetitive practices; names 13 record companies that it says prevented its plans to stop copyrighted material from being traded by refusing to license necessary technology; mouseprint.org reports that Scott continues to market its toilet paper as having 1,000 sheets per roll, but with smaller sheets, which reduces each roll by 300 inches; search on YouTube shows how often Steven P Jobs says 'boom' in Apple Computer keynote speeches; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Alone on Israel's Side
abstract: President Bush's qualified support for Israel's strikes on Lebanon put him on a potential collision course with his European allies on the eve of the annual Group of 8 summit meeting.     The European Union criticized what it called a ''disproportionate use of force'' by Israel, and several governments singled out Israel's blockade tactics for condemnation. For its part, the Bush administration tempered its backing by warning that Israel should not destroy governmental resources or cause a refugee crisis.       BY JIM RUTENBERG, PAGE A10

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: FRANCE CAUTIOUS ON G.M. ALLIANCE France is ''extremely cautious'' about the prospect of General Motors forming an alliance with Renault and Nissan, the French industry minister said yesterday. ''This shouldn't be taken as a done deal; it's an idea,'' François Loos, the minister, below, said in an interview with i-Tele television. Mr. Loos was speaking after the boards of Renault and Nissan on Monday authorized Carlos Ghosn, who is chief executive of both carmakers, to begin negotiations with G.M. if its board agrees. The French state holds about 15 percent of Renault. A alliance among Renault, Nissan and G.M. would nevertheless be ''positive'' in principle, Mr. Loos added. (AP)    G.M.'S SALES IN CHINA SOAR General Motors said yesterday that its sales in China jumped 47 percent over a year earlier in the first six months of this year, helped by stronger-than-expected demand. G.M. and its joint ventures sold 453,832 vehicles in China in the January to June period, compared with 308,722 in the same period of 2005, the company said in a statement. G.M. says it had a 12.5 percent share in the China vehicle market, up from 10.8 percent a year earlier, making it the No. 1 foreign automaker in the country. Last year, it surpassed the longtime leader, Volkswagen of Germany. On Monday, G.M. reported a 26 percent decline in its United States sales for June over the previous year. (AP)    MUSIC AND YAHOO CHINA The world's biggest music companies are preparing a lawsuit against Yahoo China for copyright infringement as part of the industry's efforts to crack down on piracy. ''Yahoo China has been blatantly infringing our members' rights. We have started the process and as far as we're concerned we're on the track to litigation,'' said John Kennedy, chairman and chief executive of the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, a music industry trade group based in London. ''If negotiation can prevent that, so be it.'' Yahoo China officials could not immediately be reached for comment. Yahoo China is a partnership between the Internet giant Yahoo Inc., which owns 40 percent of the business, and Alibaba.com of China. (REUTERS)    EMPLOYEES SUE OVER DATA THEFT Concerns about identity theft prompted a group of nine employees to sue the Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest railroad, over the way it uses Social Security numbers to identify employees. The company said in May that a computer with names and Social Security numbers of 30,000 current or retired Union Pacific employees had been stolen from a personnel employee on April 29. The lawsuit was filed Friday in Pottawattamie County, Iowa, by the nine railroad employees on behalf of a class that could include 30,000 members, according to the lawsuit. A Union Pacific spokesman said Monday that company lawyers had not yet seen the lawsuit and had no comment. (AP)    RUSSIA WARNED ON ENERGY The ratings agency Standard & Poor's warned Russia yesterday of the dangers of basing its economy on the energy industry, urging policy makers to avoid ''the pitfalls of hydrocarbon dependence.'' The company said in a report that an influx of foreign currency from the sale of Russian gas and oil could force up the value of the ruble, which could harm other industrial sectors. The report said that receipts from oil and gas provided Russia with about 50 percent of its government revenues, and 65 percent of export earnings. (AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE)    TAXI PROTEST IN ITALY Striking taxi drivers in Rome decided to intensify a major protest that has so far lasted two days and caused disruption at airports, at rail stations and in major cities. Union representatives announced a national strike for July 11 and said they were organizing a march on Rome today for dozens of drivers from all over the country who might continue protesting in the city for two weeks. The drivers called for the withdrawal of a law passed on Friday by the government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi that is aimed at expanding competition in several sectors and that would increase the authorized number of taxi licenses. (AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE)    RETIREMENT HOME DEAL BC Partners Ltd., a London-based buyout firm, said it had agreed to buy Medica SA, a retirement home operator based in France, for 750 million euros ($960 million) less than two weeks after Medica abandoned plans for an initial public offering. BC Partners said it was acquiring Medica with Axa's private equity unit. BC Partners plans to expand Medica by adding new homes and acquiring other operators to cater to the needs of elderly patients requiring medical attention as the proportion of retirees in France's population increases. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    ONLINE    INTERVIEW WITH AN IDENTITY THIEF By the age of 18, Shiva Brent Sharma had joined the underground world of online identity theft. See a video interview at nytimes/com/technology.    VICTIMS OF A COAL BOOM As coal powers China's sizzling economy, thousands of acres of land are literally sinking because of the ravages of underground coal mining.    DEALBOOK A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    YOUR MONEY Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with "Your Money," a free, weekly newsletter from The New York Times. nytimes.com/yourmoney.

headline: Pay Plan at Dana Ruled Illegal
abstract: A plan to pay millions of dollars to the top officials of the Dana Corporation, the auto parts company, violates the new bankruptcy law and cannot go forward, a judge ruled yesterday.     Judge Burton R. Lifland of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan said that the proposal was an illegal plan to retain Dana's chief executive and other top executives. The plan had drawn objections from Dana's creditors, shareholders and unions, as well as the United States trustee, a part of the Justice Department.

headline: HURRY! HURRY!
abstract: American Banker, a trade publication in New York, said it would present a lifetime achievement award to Angelo R. Mozilo, chief executive of the Countrywide Financial Corporation, noting that he had built the company from a start-up to the country's biggest mortgage lender.     Mr. Mozilo, of course, is also a champion of innovations like no-money-down adjustable-rate mortgages, some with low introductory ''teaser'' interest rates. With home prices falling and interest rates rising, many borrowers are finding themselves with higher monthly payments -- some even as their houses are now worth less than what they owe on them.

headline: European Regulators Back Plan for a Fine on Microsoft
abstract: European Union antitrust regulators unanimously support plan by European Commission to again fine Microsoft for failing to comply with 2004 ruling that found company guilty of withholding information about its Windows operating system; Microsoft could be fined up to two million euros (about $2.6 million) a day (M)

headline: SOME WHO DO JUST THAT
abstract: Corporate Library cites ten chief executives who, together, were paid modest $190 million in salary, bonus and stock over last five years while their companies posted total gains of $82.7 billion; list (S)

headline: Think Your Camera Has Enough Megapixels?
abstract: Think your digital camera has enough megapixels?     You dont know jack. Or, rather, you dont know Scott Howard, whos posted a stunning nighttime shot of Sydney Harbor that weighs in at a whopping 720 megapixels. (Thats 40,000 x 18,000 pixels for those scoring at home.)

headline: Young Muslims in Britain Hear Competing Appeals
abstract: Hizb ut-Tahrir Britain, along with successor groups to Al Muhajiroun, London-based group that was ostensibly disbanded in 2004, and Muslim Public Affairs Committee are engaged in aggressive activities to recruit followers; groups engage in social welfare programs to establish legitimate foothold in community, but have as their goal establishment of caliphate, or pan-Islamic government, and dismantling of Israel; photos (M)

headline: Music Player From Microsoft Offers Wireless Song-Sharing
abstract: Microsoft unveils its new Zune player; says device, which it plans to release in time for holidays, will include wireless technology to allow Zune owners to share favorite songs and playlists with one another easily; photo (M)

headline: Germany’s Merck Buying Biotech Concern
abstract: Merck of Germany announced Thursday that it would take control of Serono, a Swiss pharmaceutical maker, for 10.6 billion euros ($13.5 billion) after failing to secure a merger with Schering, its German competitor.     A deal with Schering would have created a German powerhouse focused on traditional pharmaceuticals. But the combination with Serono will put Merck on a different path, creating a strong player in the fast-growing field of biopharmaceuticals -- drugs that use living organisms to treat diseases like cancer.

headline: Fannie Mae Won’t Face U.S. Charges Over Its Books
abstract: Justice Department, concluding two-year accounting probe, will no longer pursue criminal charges against Fannie Mae; move removes significant legal threat against Fannie Mae but it remains unclear what decision means for former chief executive Franklin Raines and former chief financial officer J Timothy Howard (M)

headline: Rank Colleges, but Rank Them Right
abstract: EARLY this morning, U.S. News & World Report will send e-mail messages to hundreds of college administrators, giving them an advance peek at the magazine's annual college ranking. They will find out whether Princeton will be at the top of the list for the seventh straight year, whether Emory can break into the top 15 and where their own university ranks. The administrators must agree to keep the information to themselves until Friday at midnight, when the list goes live on the U.S. News Web site, but the e-mail message gives them a couple of days to prepare a response.     By now, 23 years after U.S. News got into this game, the responses have become pretty predictable. Disappointed college officials dismiss the ranking as being beneath the lofty aims of a university, while administrators pleased with their status order new marketing materials bragging about it -- and then tell anyone who asks that, obviously, they realize the ranking is beneath the lofty aims of a university.

headline: African Union Peacekeepers’ Stay in Darfur Is Extended as Accord on U.N. Force Is Awaited
abstract: The African Union declared Wednesday that it would strengthen and extend the life of its peacekeeping force in Darfur and seek to persuade the Sudanese government to accept United Nations participation in the violence-torn area.     The decision averted the feared possibility that all international forces would depart from Darfur at the end of this month, when the African Union troops were scheduled to leave.

headline: Operations at G.M. Post Profit
abstract: General Motors says its surprising second-quarter operating profit proves that its turnaround is off and running. Analysts counter that it still has not tackled its fundamental problem: sliding market share.     Over all, G.M. reported yesterday that it lost $3.1 billion in the second quarter, including a raft of one-time charges related to the restructuring in North America, where it continued to lose money last quarter. But investors were pleased by G.M.'s adjusted profit of $1.1 billion, or $2.03 a share, in the second quarter, a big swing from an adjusted loss of $235 million, or 41 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.

headline: SMALL IS NOW BIG
abstract: General Motors chief financial officer Frederick A Henderson says small, elite groups of financial staff members are tackling company's largest problems, including settlement with bankrupt Delphi Corporation and United Automobile Workers union, completing sale of General Motors Acceptance Corporation and possible alliance with Renault and Nissan (M)

headline: A Venezuelan Comedian Hopes to Unseat Chávez
abstract: Just when laughter seemed in short supply in the political opposition's dreary struggle to unseat President Hugo Chávez, along came Benjamín Rausseo, Venezuela's best-known stand-up comedian.     Mr. Rausseo, who plays a rube on television with a particularly raunchy sense of humor, also happens to be a self-made millionaire at the helm of a business empire including theme parks, hotels and recording studios. Now he is a contender in presidential elections scheduled for December.

headline: KING TO MARKET LIGAND DRUG
abstract: King Pharmaceuticals said it would pay at least $313 million for rights to market the Avinza painkiller, made by Ligand Pharmaceuticals. King will pay $265 million to sell the drug in the United States and Canada, the company said. King, based in Bristol, Tenn., will also assume a product-related liability payment of $48 million, and will pay Ligand royalties.     Avinza had sales of $179 million last year. King already markets a painkiller known as Skelaxin and plans to seek approval of Remoxy, also a pain drug, as early as next year. King shares rose 33 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $16.26. Shares of Ligand, based in San Diego, rose 8 cents, to $9.95.

headline: In Raid, Greek Police Recover 700-Year-Old Stolen Icon
abstract: Greek police raid on home south of Athens recovers 700-year-old Byzantine icon that was stolen from remote Elona monastery in daring break-in last month; unidentified Romanian man confesses to crime after resisting arrest during raid on his home; police find at least 239 votive offerings that had been left with icon by worshippers (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Making Cookware in China
abstract: Group SEB, French maker of Tefal cookware that is seeking to reduce production costs, reportedly will buy 61 percent stake in Zhejiang Supor Cookware Co of China (S)

headline: Prudential Financial May Settle Mutual-Fund Trading Inquiries
abstract: Prudential Financial reaches agreement, led by Justice Department, that may settle three-year-old probe of improper mutual-fund trading and allow it to avoid criminal prosecution (M)

headline: 2 Are Charged in Criminal Case on Stock Options
abstract: Federal prosecutors on Thursday filed the first criminal charges against executives in a mushrooming investigation into the possible manipulation of stock options.     Gregory L. Reyes, the chief executive of Brocade Communications until January 2005, and Stephanie Jensen, the vice president for human resources until 2004, were each charged in a criminal complaint with one count of securities fraud. Prosecutors said the two doctored the minutes of board meetings, job-offer letters and other documents to make it appear that employees were granted stock options at an earlier date, when the share price of Brocade was lower.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: 1,000 Found In Mass Grave
abstract: Exhumation of more than 1,000 people massacred in Srebrenica, Bosnia, in 1995 is nearly complete; forensic experts say site is largest mass grave in Bosnia (S)

headline: Bush Gives Qualified Support for Israels Strikes
abstract: President Bush gave qualified support on Thursday for Israel's strikes on Lebanon, telling reporters gathered here for his visit with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, ''Israel has a right to defend herself.''     Mr. Bush placed the blame for the tensions squarely on Syria for housing leaders of Hezbollah.

headline: If Not G.M., Says Ghosn, Maybe Ford
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance -- raising the prospect of eventual talks with the Ford Motor Company.     Mr. Ghosn's remarks came hours after he met with G.M.'s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, at Renault's headquarters in the Paris suburb of Boulogne-Billancourt.

headline: A Concern That Consumers Will Stop Spending
abstract: Mark Stein Five Days column; government figures showed that consumers have been buying more, but prices are apparently crimping spending; Federal Reserve policy makers will have particularly difficult decision about whether to raise interest rates further; Detroit automakers fell to record low 52 percent share of domestic market in July; Comcast and Time Warner Cable have agreed to buy rival Adelphia and split its assets and subscribers; AOL has said it will stop competing with cable companies in Web access business by not charging high-speed Internet customers for e-mail and other services and adopting ad-supported model; Northwest Airlines flight attendants overruled union leaders for second time and rejected proposed contract that called for concessions; photo (M)

headline: Amgen Prices Colon Cancer Drug 20% Below ImClone Rival
abstract: Amgen wins approval for colorectal cancer drug Vectibix and sets price 20 percent lower than ImClone Systems's Erbitux; move is competitive strategy and acknowledgement of public concerns about costs of newest cancer drugs; Vectibix will cost $4,000 every two weeks, or more than $100,000 for year's treatment (M)

headline: Profit Margins Are Inducing Fear of Heights
abstract: Conrad de Aenlle column on Morgan Stanley economist Richard Berner's contention that high profit margins, which reached 40-year peak in first quarter, put stock market at risk; Duncan Richardson, chief equity investment officer at Eaton Vance funds, questions Berner's premise and expects productivity gains to persist (M)

headline: Fed Chief Gives Seminar on History of Globalization
abstract: Chairman Ben Bernanke, delivering keynote speech at Federal Reserve's annual retreat in Jackson Hole, Wyo, says pace of globalization is faster and more sweeping than at any time in world history; warns that governments need to help citizens cope with disruptions of new competition and 'ensure that the benefits of global economic integration are sufficiently shared'; photo (M)

headline: Civil Society Forum Heightens Anticipation of G8 Summit
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.    TODAY'S TOP STORIES    NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA  The "Civil G8" forum opened in Moscow Monday ahead of the Group of Eight summit. Nearly 600 non-governmental organizations, half of which are internationally based, are set to discuss questions of global civil society. Ella A. Pamfilova, the presidential civil society and human rights advisor, called the summit unique in that such a forum has "not taken place anywhere before."      The participants will likewise have the opportunity to pass along recommendations to President Vladimir V. Putin when he visits the forum today. Also convening in Moscow next week is an opposition conference led by Gary Kasparov's United Civil Front in cooperation with Andrei N. Illarionov, former presidential advisor and head of a the Institute for Economic Analysis. "A Different Russia" intends to heavily criticize what it contends are the current administration's human rights violations. Sergei A. Markov, member of the Public Chamber, said comparing "Civil G8" to "A Different Russia" is like comparing "a Mercedes and a wooden horse." The Putin Administration has discouraged Group of Eight member states from taking part in the opposition conference.    IZVESTIA  COMRADE, HAVE FAITH!: Monday saw the opening of the Worldwide Summit of Religious Leaders in Moscow. Over 400 delegates from 40 countries met to discuss ways to protect and defend moral and spiritual ideals in the secular world. President Vladimir V. Putin opened the summit with calls not to "drive a wedge" between Christian and Islamic civilization while issuing a warning to extremists who "cynically use believers' feelings" to further their cause. The summit was notable for the absence of both Pope Benedict XVI and the Dalai Lama. The Russian Orthodox Church explained that where a visit by the pope must take place under more notable circumstances, a visit by the Dalai Lama to Russia would "complicate the situation" with China. Izvestia cites likely areas of unity between the leaders to be on questions regarding human rights, the spread of religious knowledge, and denunciation of "perversion, debauchery, and violence" in the media.    VEDOMOSTI  PATRIOTS FOR A THIRD TERM: An obscure group called "Patriots of Petersburg" began collecting signatures for those in favor of a third term for Vladimir V. Putin. This initiative followed an interview of Valentina Matvenko, governor of St. Petersburg, by "Moskovskie Novosti" on Friday where she stated her support for allowing Mr. Putin to run for a third term for the sake of "continued stability." This is not, however, the first of such movements. Earlier third term initiatives were put forth by regional legislatures in the Magadan and Ivanovski regions. Experts attribute the flurry of third term supporters to anxiety on the part of the regional elite. This stems from Vladislav Y. Surkov's recent statement that "when new people come to power, the management of such companies will change." They therefore want Mr. Putin to remain head of Russia's blooming state corporation. Aleksey Makarkin of the Center for Political Technologies, though, does not see these initiatives sanctioned from above; if that were the case, he says, "authorities from culture and the intelligentsia" would head the agitation campaign. Vedomosti was not able to contact the Petersburg patriots for comment.    KOMMERSANT  DEPUTIES SEEK LOOSER SECURITIES LAWS: United Russia deputies seek to make changes to the law governing the Federal Security Service that would allow the president to send FSB special forces abroad to fight terrorism without the permission of Russia's upper house of parliament, the Federal Council. The changes would allow the president to use special forces troops "against terrorists and/or their bases located outside the territory of the Russian Federation for the elimination of threats to national security." The proposed changes are expected to be signed into law and ready for implementation within the next two weeks. While some United Russia deputies want to spell out the criteria for the law's implementation, Kommersant notes that most of the party "will not bother to pay attention to such trivial matters."    VREMYA NOVOSTEI  MILITARY SALES FALL UNDER CIVILIAN CONTROL: The military industrial commission held its meeting Monday announcing plans to create a federal agency responsible for the sale of military technology abroad. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defense Sergei B. Ivanov announced the agency's creation along with a number of other reforms to the military-industrial complex. The civilian agency will represent not only the interests of the Ministry of Defense in foreign sales, but all other state security agencies as well. In addition to the creation of this new agency, the committee discussed new inspection regulations regarding production of military technology and updated the list of sensitive technologies which are deemed essential to national security. These two reforms are being implemented parallel to the state program outlining Russia's military armament plan from 2007-2012.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: WAL-MART TO CUT PACKAGING -- Wal-Mart Stores announced a five-year program with its suppliers to help reduce overall packaging by 5 percent. In the latest step to polish its environmental record, Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, said it would begin the initiative in 2008, and it could help Wal-Mart save $3.4 billion in its own costs. In the five-year plan, Wal-Mart will push its 600,000 global suppliers to find more efficient packaging methods. It estimates total supplier savings of $11 billion.     Wal-Mart said it would start working with suppliers in November to prepare for the changes. Last October, the company's chief executive, H. Lee Scott Jr., above, said Wal-Mart would become a leader in environmental issues with three goals: reducing waste to zero, moving toward using only renewable energy and offering more products made in a way that preserves the environment.

headline: Disney Opts for Marketer in Selection of Film Chief
abstract: Walt Disney Co names marketing chief Oren Aviv president of production at Walt Disney Pictures; move, coming on heels of appointment of Marc Schmuger as studio chairman, indicates that large studios are shifting toward making more movies that appeal to families and that can be marketed around world (M)

headline: McDonald’s Says Investor Plans to Buy Stake for Hedge Funds
abstract: McDonald's Corporation says investor William A Ackman plans to buy more than $793.8 million worth of shares through Pershing Square Capital Management; purchase will give him 1.8 percent of outstanding shares; second-quarter profit rose 57 percent, to $834.1 million; photo (M)

headline: Motorola Buys Symbol Technologies to Widen Reach
abstract: Aiming to expand its position outside the cellphone market, Motorola said yesterday that it would pay $3.9 billion for Symbol Technologies, a maker of scanners and other wireless technology used by manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers.     With growth in the retail cellphone market starting to show signs of slowing, handset makers like Motorola are looking for ways to sell more of their wireless technology to corporate customers and governments.

headline: Indonesian Province Embraces Islamic Law
abstract: Across this most religious of Indonesia's provinces, brown uniformed policemen in black wagons enforce Shariah, or Islamic law. They haul unmarried couples into precincts and arrest people for drinking or gambling. Increasingly, many of the cases are pushed to the ultimate conclusion, public canings at mosques in front of pumped-up crowds.      In mid-July, a 27-year-old man sentenced to 40 lashes fainted on the seventh stroke of a rattan cane from a hooded man in the yard of a mosque here in the provincial capital.

headline: The Good News About Job Cuts (and the Bad)
abstract: Outplacement firm Challenger Gray & Christmas reports planned job cuts for June are 39 percent lower than June last year but 25 percent higher than May this year; graph (S)

headline: A Deal Maker Jerry Garcia Might Have Liked
abstract: What does the lead singer of a rock band want with a financial magazine empire?     That was the question Wall Street bankers were whispering yesterday after the Forbes family said that it had sold a minority interest in its publishing business to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm that counts Bono of U2 as a managing director.

headline: Inflation Jitters Depress Shares for 2nd Day
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 5.74 points, to 1,270.92; Dow Jones industrial average declines 59.95 points, to 11,125.73; Nasdaq composite index drops 29.48 points, to 2,061.99; price and yield for 10-year Treasury note noted; graph (M)

headline: Sun Microsystems Posts a 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Sun Microsystems reports fourth-quarter loss of $301 million, compared to $50 million profit in period year earlier; sales rose 29 percent, to $3.83 billion; chief executive Jonathan I Schwartz comments (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Latvian In Running For Top Post
abstract: Pres Vaira Vike-Freiberga of Latvia is formally proposed as candidate for secretary general of UN by Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania (S)

headline: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale  $3 million    115 East 97th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues)  Manhattan    A developer that owns adjacent sites has bought this 25-foot-wide, 5,532-square-foot four-story building with 3,147 square feet of air rights.    Buyer: Kenbar Group  Seller: Agripina Rios  Broker: Shimon Shkury, Massey Knakel Realty Services    For Sale  $9.1 million    152 East 55th Street (between Third and Lexington Avenues)  Manhattan    A foundation run by the Kabbalah Center is selling this 16,000-square-foot six-story 1985 building, with a rooftop greenhouse and air rights.    Owner: Spirituality for Kids Foundation  Broker: Avi Voda, Prudential Douglas Elliman    Recent Lease  $23.50/sq. ft.  approximate annual rent $274,950    NordenPark  Norwalk, Conn.    A producer of publications, conferences and trade shows is to move into 11,700 square feet on the second floor of this complex off I-95.    Tenant: Red 7 Media  Tenant broker: Jim Randel, Rand Real Estate Services Inc.  Landlord: Norden Center L.L.C., led by JFR Global Investments.  Landlord broker: Trip Hoffman, Cushman & Wakefield

headline: German Police See Possible Lebanon Link to Failed Train Bombs
abstract: German investigators say that bombs found on two trains last month might have been planted by two young men angered by war in Lebanon (M)

headline: Start-Ups Mix Green and Black
abstract: Article on obstacles, constraints and special challenges that small start-up green companies face; while entrepreneurs must find investors, suppliers and customers, they must also adjust to real world as they seek to do well financially and do good environmentally (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Home, Sweet (Second) Home
abstract: What's Offline column; Chris Taylor, in article in Best Life, offers suggestions for saving money to buy second home; articles in Conde Nast Traveler and Weekend offer suggestions on buying your own island on which to build second home; Josh McHugh, in article in Wired, reports on growing trend in tech world--decision to buy new product ideas instead of developing them internally; survey by This Old House finds that readers consider neighbors worst pests they have ever encountered; photo (M)

headline: Apple Updates iMac Desktop Computers
abstract: Apple Computer announces updates to its popular iMac desktop computers; changes include faster Intel chips and introduction of lowest-price model yet; prices range from $999 to $1,999 (M)

headline: To Their Neighbors and Families, Plot Suspects Seemed to Lead Ordinary Lives
abstract: Two weeks ago, Shazad Khuram Ali seemed despondent, so much so that it was almost palpable to one of his neighbors, who was struck by his sudden downcast gaze and strained face.      Wilbur Pires thought that the usually cheerful Mr. Ali might have encountered financial troubles in his used-car business, a small venture he had been running out of his two houses here, despite complaints from other nearby residents.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Sues Boston Scientific, Guidant and Abbott Laboratories Over Deal
abstract: An aftershock from the bitter takeover battle for Guidant early this year occurred yesterday in a federal court in Manhattan.     Johnson & Johnson filed suit against Boston Scientific, Guidant and Abbott Laboratories for $5.5 billion in damages. The suit claims that the three companies illegally shared information on their way to scuttling Guidant's agreement to sell itself to Johnson & Johnson for about $21.5 billion.

headline: Russians and U.S. Push Hard on Trade
abstract: Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization, officials from both countries said on Tuesday.      Russia is by far the world's largest economy still outside the W.T.O., a 149-nation group that sets the ground rules for global trade and investment. The United States has withheld its approval for letting the Russians into the organization, even after other countries signed off on membership.

headline: History and Science: The Video Games
abstract: Article profiles Second Story, fast-growing small business based in Portland, Ore; company, founded by artist Brad Johnson and graphic designer Julie Beeler, is changing art of storytelling through convergence of computing, graphic design, audio, video, text and Internet; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: A Trillion-Dollar Idea
abstract: Still struggling with 1,200 percent annual inflation, Zimbabwe's reserve bank said it would lop three zeros off the nation's paper currency starting today in an attempt to make sales and bookkeeping less onerous. The bank said that Zimbabweans could exchange their existing currency for new bills until Aug. 20, after which the old bills will be worthless. Zimbabweans have become used to carrying satchels of money for even mundane shopping trips, and companies have increasingly groused that their accounting software could not cope with finances measured in the trillions and even quadrillions. Even with the change, Zimbabwe has room for improvement: a loaf of bread, which now costs $1 million, will still sell for $1,000 when the new currency comes out.   MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

headline: China Says Economy Grew 11.3% in Quarter
abstract: Chinese government reports economy grew by 11.3 percent in second quarter, fastest pace in decade, despite goverment efforts to cool down growth; second-quarter figure follows record trade surplus of $14.5 billion in June and could lead to further tightening measures (M)

headline: Bolton in the Senate, Take 2, Picks Up Just Where It Ended
abstract: The second Senate confirmation hearing for John R. Bolton, who became ambassador to the United Nations under a recess appointment, played out Thursday like a summertime movie sequel.     The plot was familiar, although one major character switched sides. There was a little snappy dialogue, a fresh conflict to debate, but not that much action. And it ended, after three and a half hours, without any resolution of the central question: Will Mr. Bolton receive formal confirmation from the Senate this time? So the audience must return yet again to see how it all turns out.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,657 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:    GORDON, David W. 23, Sgt., Army; Williamsfield, Ohio; Fourth Infantry Division.

headline: Israeli Defense Chief Agrees to Independent Inquiry Into Lebanon War
abstract: Defense Min Amir Peretz of Israel bows to rebels in his own Labor Party and calls for independent inquiry into recent war in Lebanon, changing his previous position and putting him publicly at odds with Prime Min Ehud Olmert; photo (M)

headline: The Golden Goodbye
abstract: For most chief executives, stepping down means a hefty cut in pay. But that is not how things went for Clifton H. Morris Jr., when at 71 he gave up the top job at the AmeriCredit Corporation after 14 years as chief executive.      Last year, when AmeriCredit's board approved a salary of $950,000 for Mr. Morris's successor, Daniel E. Berce, 52, it also granted Mr. Morris a $100,000 raise, lifting his salary as chairman to $900,000, according to a document filed last week.

headline: BlackBerry Adds Diversions, Counting on Sales
abstract: Can the BlackBerry, whose service is so irresistible to business people, finally spread the wireless e-mail addiction to consumers?     The question is a significant one for Research in Motion, the company that makes the BlackBerry and is now introducing a new consumer variation, the Pearl. But it is a critical one for cellphone carriers, which have for years been adding features to phones and networks to encourage consumers to run up their bills by using more profitable wireless data services.

headline: A Fed Banker Revives Talk of an 18th Increase in Rates
abstract: Michael H Moskow, president of Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, says Fed might need to resume raising interest rates to reduce inflation and expectations for higher prices (M)

headline: Israel Ends Its Blockade of Lebanon’s Coastline
abstract: Israel lifts its sea blockade of Lebanon, releasing its last major chokehold on country since war broke out in July; turns over responsibility for patrolling Lebanese coast to Italian warships, which will help Lebanese Navy enforce UN-mandated arms embargo against Hezbollah; photo (M)

headline: Rents Are Rising Rapidly After Long Lull
abstract: Government data from June and July show average rents across country were 3.5 percent higher than year earlier, steepest gains in almost four years, and that increase is fueling rise in inflation; rise is tied to soaring home prices and hike in mortgage rates that are preventing many renters from buying homes; only region of country that is resisting trend is Midwest, where industrial job losses and other factors continue to hold rents down; in New York City, where rents never fell as they did in many other cities, rents are advancing at much faster clip; photos; graphs (M)

headline: 2 Rivals Authorize G.M. Talks
abstract: Boards of Nissan and Renault vote to explore historic three-way alliance with General Motors; decision by GM board, slated to meet on July 7, will determine whether talks on alliance move forward; Nissan and Renault action lends new weight to challenge to GM chief executive Rick Wagoner, who has rebuffed earlier challenges to his leadership and taken drastic action to try to turn GM around; photo (M)

headline: Burger King Posts a Loss for the Fourth Quarter
abstract: Holdings, the hamburger chain that went public in May, posted a fourth-quarter loss setting off a 13 percent decline in its share price.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Report Faults Bombing Response
abstract: A report from the Home Office acknowledged shortcomings in the handling of the aftermath of the London bombings 14 months ago that left some survivors and bereaved families ''feeling forgotten and unimportant.'' The 23-page report was the latest in a series of official analyses of the suicide bombing attacks on the London transportation system that killed 52 people. It said that in the aftermath ''those trying to find loved ones found it difficult to get information about which hospitals people were being treated in.'' There were ''concerns about the time it took to identify victims,'' the report said, and ''some families were not kept in touch with the process of identification.'' The authorities, it suggested, were overwhelmed, with the number of people calling about their relatives peaking at about 43,000 calls an hour. In addition, emergency services were communicating over overloaded cellphone systems and creaky radio networks.   ALAN COWELL (NYT)

headline: Group of 8 Talks, Like So Much These Days, Are All About Energy: Russias Gas and Oil
abstract: Deep beneath the thick forests of Siberia, near Lake Baikal, lies a vast deposit of natural gas known as Kovykta, a field so large it could supply all the United States' needs for three years.      But Russia has so far refused to allow the private companies developing the field to build a pipeline to export the gas. Instead, the only customer is a tiny neighboring logging town happy to replace its soot-belching, coal-fired power with gas.

headline: In Reversal, S.E.C. Plans to Question Executive
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission, reversing itself, asks Morgan Stanley chief executive John Mack to testify in insider-trading investigation of prominent hedge fund Pequot Capital Management; Office of Inspector General reopens inquiry into firing of SEC lawyer Gary Aguirre, who said his superiors stopped him from taking Mack's testimony in connection with his investigation of Pequot; photo (M)

headline: New Head of A380 Program at Airbus
abstract: Airbus replaced the head of its troubled A380 program on Monday, a move that largely overshadowed news of the initial passenger flight for the world's largest commercial aircraft.      Charles Champion, a chief operating officer, is the third executive to leave after production problems forced the company to announce a six-month delay in A380 deliveries. The news sparked a management crisis at Airbus and its parent company, European Aeronautic Defense and Space, in July, which resulted in the resignation of the Airbus chief executive, Gustav Humbert, and Noël Forgeard, the French co-chairman of EADS.

headline: Glass Was at Least Half Full at This Conference
abstract: Interactive marketers who focus on consumers online and in digital world meet at conference sponsored by industry group Ad:tech; discuss future of industry and uses that still exist for traditional marketing; argue for more advertising dollars to be shifted online from print and television; hold that today's consumers are more engaged and enjoy advertising (M)

headline: Popping the Cork on a New Headquarters
abstract: Claire Wilson reviews Moet Hennessy USA's new headquarters building, on edge of Manhattan's meatpacking district, designed by TPG Architecture; TPG principal Jim Phillips comments; photo (M)

headline: India Digs Deeper, but Wells Are Drying Up
abstract: Second of three articles examining India's growing water crisis notes that in Rajasthan, heavily agricultural state, up to 80 percent of groundwater areas are in danger of running out; much of India's groundwater is being depleted, problem that has accelerated with proliferation of electric pumps; India is divided into 5,723 geographic blocks; more than 1,000 are considered either overexploited, meaning more water is drawn on average than is replenished by rain, or critical, meaning they are dangerously close to it; Prime Min Manmohan Singh has urged state officials to crack down on pumping, but they have been slow to respond; those who study Indian agriculture are concerned that without careful review of water policy and switch to crops that use less water India stands to imperil its food production; map; photos (M)

headline: This Web TV Is for You, Especially if You’re a Male Aged 21 to 34
abstract: Anheuser-Busch will launch Bud TV online entertainment network is effort to attract males aged 21 to 34 through form of branded entertainment popular with advertisers; joins lengthy list of advertisers becoming content providers as industry shifts and adapts to changing consumer needs; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,538 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    HERNANDEZ, Irving Jr., 28, Sgt., Army; New York City; First Battalion, 17th Infantry, 172nd Stryker Brigade Combat Team.    MONTOYA, Damien M., 21, Specialist, Army; Holbrook, Ariz.; Fourth Infantry Division.

headline: Hussein Is Hospitalized; 57 Are Killed in Bombings in Baghdad and Kirkuk
abstract: Saddam Hussein was hospitalized Sunday morning, and was being fed with a tube and given tests to ensure that he could stand trial later this week despite a hunger strike that began July 7, Iraqi and American officials said.      Widespread sectarian violence returned Sunday after two days of relative calm, with at least 57 people killed in bombings in Baghdad and Kirkuk, shootings all over the country and 11 bodies found in the Tigris River, bound and with gunshot wounds to the head or chest.

headline: Within Its Walls, Club Med Opens a First-Class Preserve
abstract: Club Mediterranee is planning tranformation into upscale resort as it adapts to changing clientelle and tries to overcome problems facing struggling travel industry; is spending 100 million euros ($128 million) annually through 2008 to upgrade villages; makeover is fundamental change in company's culture; photo (M)

headline: Israel Facing a Well-Trained and Supplied Enemy
abstract: With the support of its Syrian and Iranian sponsors, Hezbollah has grown to be less like a militia and more like a disciplined and well-supplied army. Its weapons, training and tactics, including the use of a complex network of tunnels, have surprised the Israeli forces that have confronted them in nearly a month of fighting across the Lebanese border.      The well-organized Hezbollah fighters ''are nothing like Hamas or the Palestinians,'' said an Israeli soldier who just returned from Lebanon. ''They are trained and highly qualified.''   BY STEVEN ERLANGER AND RICHARD A. OPPEL JR., PAGE A8

headline: For Some, a Feature-Filled Phone Uses Its High Speed as a Selling Point
abstract: Cingular introduces LG CU500, first phone to take full advantage of its high-speed network; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Coalition's Bombs Kill 10 Afghan Border Police
abstract: A plane with the United States coalition force in Afghanistan dropped bombs Thursday morning that killed 10 Afghan border police officers and wounded four others while pursuing insurgents who had attacked the coalition forces, an Afghan police official said.      A statement from the coalition forces said the plane had bombed two trucks that had been involved in the attack on the coalition forces and Afghan Army soldiers.

headline: New Name and Strategy for Chip Division at Philips
abstract: Semiconductor unit at Philips Electronics will adopt NXP name as it becomes stand-alone company; will pursue strategy focusing heavily on supplying chips to consumer market for advanced electronics; Frans van Houten will be chief executive; photo (M)

headline: An Inventive Solution to Save Home of Bell Labs
abstract: As soon as word got out in June that the 44-year-old building in Holmdel, N.J., that was home to Bell Labs would be demolished, scientists around the country -- and the world -- set the Internet humming with anguished reaction.     ''Say it isn't so!'' read a typical entry on the technology Web site called Engadget. ''The Holmdel facility is the birthplace of the cellphone. It was home to the work of several Nobel laureates and was the birthplace of the most important communications technologies in history!''

headline: I.B.M. to Buy a Security Software Company for $1.3 Billion
abstract: IBM plans to buy Internet Security Systems for $1.3 billion; will be first large software purchase to be folded into services business, rather than becoming part of software group (M)

headline: Turning 60, and Checking Their Calculators
abstract: Opinion Research study, commissioned by Bell Investment Advisors, concludes that 56 percent of 60-year-olds with at least $1 million in assets surveyed think they have enough to retire comfortably; also finds 37 percent got bulk of their nest egg from real estate and 94 percent plan to help children financially; graph (S)

headline: Pentagon Struggles With Cost Overruns and Delays
abstract: On Sept. 10, 2001, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld stood before hundreds of military officers and civilian employees at the Pentagon and delivered a blistering attack on what he saw as the next national security threat: Pentagon bureaucracy.      He called for quicker decision-making, greater accountability and a streamlined process to get weapons into the hands of soldiers faster. ''We must transform the way the department works and what it works on,'' he said. ''It could be said that it's a matter of life and death -- ultimately, every American's.''

headline: The Search for Life in Yet Another Ghost Brand
abstract: Companies often revive ghost brands, former category-leading products forgotten or neglected by owners, through advertising campaigns designed to raise revenue for developing newer, more advanced brands; changes in marketplace and nostalgia govern decisions on when to reintroduce products; several campaigns and companies producing them are discussed; photo (M)

headline: At A.M.D., a Quiet Doer Gets His Due
abstract: Joe Nocera article on recent run of successes by Advanced Micro Devices, semiconductor company that competes head to head with Intel; compares company's founder W J Sanders 3d with his quieter successor Hector de J Ruiz; Ruiz, in interview, comments on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Text of Fed's Statement on Rates
abstract: Text of Federal Reserve's statement on decision to leave interest rates unchanged (S)

headline: Scandals Emerging in Shanghai as Political Season Nears
abstract: In a reversal of fortunes that may say as much about Chinese power politics as it does about corruption, China's richest commercial city has come under investigation by the central government for a huge pension fraud scheme.     So far, the budding scandal, which has been written about in unusual detail in the country's news media, has ensnared the chief of the city's Labor and Social Security Bureau, or pension fund, along with the chairman of the Shanghai Electric Group, a municipal utility.

headline: Protest Ends in Ethnic Violence
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Monday.    TODAYS TOP STORY: ETHNIC VIOLENCE IN KARELIA  What started as a bar fight in a small town in the northwestern republic of Karelia resulted in what the major newspapers are calling a pogrom against people from the Northern Caucasus this past weekend. While various newspapers provide contradictory details, they agree that last Thursday a group of Russians got into an argument with the bartender at a Chechen-owned restaurant in the town of Kondopoga. The bartender left and returned with a group of his friends, all from the Caucasus, carrying baseball bats, pipes and knives, Kommersant says. The ensuing fight left three Russians dead, according to Nezavisimaya Gazeta and Izvestia, though Kommersant says that two died. Kommersant and Izvestia report that the bartender and his friends were from Chechnya, though Vremya Novostei says they may have been from Azerbaijan.

headline: Drug Makers Take a Fall on Talk of a Generics Release
abstract: Shares of Bristol-Myers Squib and Sanofi-Aventis fall after Medco Health Solutions chief executive David Snow predicts that Canadian drug maker Apotex plans to bring to market version of anticlotting drug Plavix as early as this month, five years before patent is set to expire; validity of US patent is subject of suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan involving three companies (M)

headline: Lockheed Wins Job of Building Next Spaceship
abstract: Lockheed Martin won a multibillion-dollar contract from NASA on Thursday to build the nation's next spaceship for human flight, a craft called Orion that is to replace the space shuttle and eventually carry astronauts to the moon and beyond.     The much-awaited announcement was a major victory for Lockheed and a startling setback for its rival, a joint venture of Boeing and Northrop Grumman.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,580 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this weekend:    LEE, Marc, A., 28, Petty Officer Second Class, Navy; Hood River, Ore.; Seals Team.    STOREY, Clint J., 30, Staff Sgt., Army; Enid, Okla.; First Armored Division.    BESTE, Bradley, H., 22, Sgt., Army; Naperville, Ill.; First Armored Division.

headline: Search for New Oil Sources Leads to Processed Coal
abstract: The coal in the ground in Illinois alone has more energy than all the oil in Saudi Arabia. The technology to turn that coal into fuel for cars, homes and factories is proven. And at current prices, that process could be at the vanguard of a big, new industry.     Such promise has attracted entrepreneurs and government officials, including the Secretary of Energy, who want domestic substitutes for foreign oil.

headline: New at Apple: Smaller iPods, Bigger Ideas
abstract: APPLE, these days, is an innovation factory. The company releases so many products, so often, you get the idea that everyone there just runs around yelling ideas. If this is Thursday, there must be a new iPod.     But this summer, the company was unusually quiet. Apple watchers online concluded that something really, really big must be in the works. A wide-screen iPod! An iPhone! A hovercar!

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: EYES ON THE FED -- The main news of the week will be the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at which the central bankers are widely expected to keep interest rates steady (Wednesday). Last week's news that the Consumer Price Index had risen 0.2 percent in August, down from 0.4 percent in July, looked to some economists like validation that inflation was slowing, a trend that would not tempt the Fed to raise rates. But the Producer Price Index for August also comes out this week, helping to inform any decision (Tuesday). Other reports this week will include the second-quarter current-account deficit (Monday), August housing starts (Tuesday) and leading economic indicators (Thursday).    STORM CLOUD WARNING -- Directors of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will meet in Singapore to discuss, among other things, economic imbalances brought about by the United States' trade deficit with China (through Wednesday). The managing director of the I.M.F., Rodrigo de Rato, said in a speech this month that there were ''more clouds on the horizon than there were a year ago.'' In its semiannual World Economic Outlook last week, the I.M.F. said that the cooling housing market in the United States would probably slow domestic economic growth and suggested that further interest rate increases might be a good idea.    STRONG WORDS FOR CHINA -- Days after delivering a tough warning to China about its economic policies, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the United States Treasury secretary, visits Beijing this week, his first trip there since taking office this summer. Last week Mr. Paulson spoke out against China's policy of keeping its currency, the yuan, at an artificially low value in relation to the dollar, a policy that has led to record trade surpluses for China. He said that China's currency exchange rate was increasingly being viewed by its critics ''as a symbol of unfair competition.''    REPORTING, QUARTERLY -- This week will bring a trickle of big-company earnings reports. They include CKE Restaurants, the Oracle Corporation and Progress Software (Tuesday); Bed Bath & Beyond, CarMax, Circuit City and Morgan Stanley (Wednesday); 3Com, A. G. Edwards, the Carnival Corporation, ConAgra, FedEx, General Mills, Nike, Palm, Rite Aid and Scholastic (Thursday); and KB Home (Friday).

headline: A Bet That Urban and Affordable Can Coexist
abstract: Home building company Kimball Hill Homes forms division to concentrate on central-city development; announces plans for four projects in Chicago and Detroit to address problem of affordable housing; chairman and chief executive David K Hill aims to create housing for 14 million families in United States that cannot afford home without spending 50 percent or more of their income on payments; photos (M)

headline: Homes Post Price Drop for August
abstract: Home prices fell in August compared with a year earlier, the first such decline in more than a decade.     The August price data came with a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Realtors that showed further evidence of deterioration in the housing market.

headline: China Is Called On to Rein In Its Growing Use of Electricity
abstract: International Energy Agency calls for China to revamp its electric power industry, noting that waste and inefficiency contribute to need for country to add enough new, mostly coal-fired, power plants every two years; is especially critical of China's decision to limit increases in electricity prices, saying that this prompts Chinese consumers and industries to use considerably more energy than they need; also urges China to set minimum efficiency standards for coal-fired power plants and to enforce air pollution standards more rigorously for these power plants (M)

headline: Want Even More Resolution? Try This Camera on for Size
abstract: Hewlett-Packard introduces Photosmart R967 point-and-shoot camera with 3x optical zoom and large 3-inch screen; photo (S)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: WIN FOR TOBACCO COMPANIES -- United States tobacco companies won a major legal victory when the Florida Supreme Court upheld a decision to toss out a $145 billion judgment against them. [Page C1.]    MICROSOFT MUSIC PLAYER -- Microsoft's interest in making its own hand-held music and video player indicates that its old way of doing things is not working in its battle against Apple's iPod. [C1.]    PETROBRAS SHIFTS FOCUS -- New offshore drilling techniques and an aggressive plan to diversify have enabled Petrobras of Brazil to shift its focus from production at home toward becoming a player on the global energy market and a major foreign investor. [C1.]    NEW AOL STRATEGY -- AOL, a unit of Time Warner, is putting the final touches on a plan that would stop marketing its subscription service, which for more than a decade has been the most popular way that Americans connect to the Internet, according to an AOL executive. Instead, it will redouble its efforts to build a free, advertising-supported business on the Web, offering members access to the most popular features of its paid service -- including e-mail addresses at AOL.com, free virus protection, and use of AOL's software program. [C3.]    BUDGET DEAL IN NEW JERSEY -- Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the New Jersey Legislature reached agreement on a budget that would bring an end to a six-day government shutdown that left nearly 100,000 workers idled and cost the state millions of dollars in lost revenue. [A1.]    ASSESSING GHOSN'S IMPACT -- What would Carlos Ghosn bring to the table? It is a top-of-mind question for the directors of General Motors, who are scheduled to meet today to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance between G.M. and the two companies that Mr. Ghosn runs, Renault and Nissan. [C1.]    RATE SIGNAL IN EUROPE -- Worried about inflation amid strong economic growth, the European Central Bank signaled that it would raise interest rates in early August, stepping up its pace of tightening credit. [C5.]    DEMAND FOR BANK DISCLOSURE -- The European Parliament demanded that European institutions in Brussels and European governments disclose how much they knew about a American program to tap into international banking data. [A10.]    RETAIL SALES RELEASED -- For the second consecutive month, sales at department stores like Kohl's and J. C. Penney far outstripped those of specialty apparel chains like Gap and the Limited, according to June sales data released by dozens of chains. [C3.]    STOCKS RISE -- The Dow Jones industrial average rose 73.48 points, to finish at 11,225.30. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 3.17 points, to end at 1,274.08. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 1.75 points, to close at 2,155.09. [C7.]    CONCERN ON BOEING SETTLEMENT -- Three prominent Republican senators have written to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to express concern that Boeing may be allowed to take a tax deduction for a $615 million settlement reached last week with the government. [C3.]    HEALTH INSURANCE EXEMPTION -- The Bush administration said that it would exempt millions of the most vulnerable Medicaid recipients from a new law that requires them to prove they are United States citizens by showing birth certificates, passports or other documents. [A15.]    NEW SUIT IN HOLLINGER CASE -- Hollinger Inc. said that it was countersuing the newspaper publisher Hollinger International in Chicago, claiming fraud related to the transfer of two newspapers to the publisher in the late 1990's. Hollinger also sued Ravelston once controlled by Conrad M. Black, left, to seek the equivalent of more than $650 million for damages ranging from breach of contract to unjust enrichment. United States prosecutors have accused Lord Black, the former press baron, and others of looting Hollinger International. [C7.]    MANISCHEWITZ GOES MAINSTREAM -- The leading marketer of kosher foods, Manischewitz, is expanding efforts to reach mainstream shoppers with what the company is calling its first campaign aimed at the general market as well as at consumers who traditionally buy kosher products for religious reasons. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]    SERVICE GROWTH SLOWED -- The United States service sector grew more slowly than expected in June, but the labor market showed strength as jobless claims dipped unexpectedly last week. [C4.]    ONLINE    A SPECIAL REPORT: STOLEN LIVES -- An interview with Shiva Brent Sharma, who was drawn into the world of identity theft as a teenager, can be found at nytimes.com/video.    SCREENS -- In her new blog on Web video, Virginia Heffernan, the TV critic of The Times, discusses a viral video from, of all places, Iran. Her report is at nytimes.com/screens.    ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.

headline: A Shield From Inflation, Though Not From Anxiety
abstract: Investors find that Treasury inflation-protected securities, or TIPS, can be as volatile as other types of bonds; experts suggest investors hold them for at least three to four years, cautioning against use as short-term investment; analyst fund recommendations are given; graph (M)

headline: No Pats on the Back From Frances No. 2
abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy, who is No. 2 in the French government, has become its No. 1 critic in a new best seller in which he promises to break with ''the way we have been doing politics for years.''     The 281-page book ''Testimony,'' with an initial press run of 130,000 copies, has become an instant success, selling out in several stores in France within days of its publication last week. The publisher, XO Editions, has printed 100,000 more volumes, a spokeswoman said.

headline: An S.L.R. Camera With a Built-In Duster
abstract: Canon's EOS Digital Rebel Xti uses high-frequency sound waves to vibrate dirt off sensor; remaining dust is masked electronically by built-in software; costs $900, which is $100 less than earlier models; photo (M)

headline: 'Luxpitality,' It Seems, Is Just Too Expensive
abstract: Complete Retreats, privately held operator of deluxe members-only destination clubs and self-described inventor of 'luxpitality' business, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Immigration Enforcement Benefits Prison Firms
abstract: As the Bush administration gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases its spending on enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons around the country.     By the fall of 2007, the administration expects that about 27,500 immigrants will be in detention each night, an increase of 6,700 over the current number in custody. At the average cost these days of $95 a night, that adds up to an estimated total annual cost of nearly $1 billion.

headline: As Iraqi Lights Flicker, ‘Generator Man’ Feels Heat
abstract: In offices across Iraq, a ritual plays out every morning during the hottest months. Haggard employees drag themselves into the room, mumble a pleasantry or two and slump into their chairs, moaning about what a bad night's sleep they had: the power went out, the backup generator was broken, the heat was unbearable, the baby would not stop crying, mosquitoes were everywhere.      Inevitably, these grievances, like hornets, will gather in a single cloud of fury and swoop down on one target: the generator man, probably the most vilified figure in Iraqi society after Saddam Hussein.

headline: Can Inflation Be Curbed?
abstract: At a Federal Reserve retreat, economists said that global trends make it harder to reduce inflation domestically. Business Day, Page C1.

headline: The Game Is on to Woo the Elusive Female Player
abstract: In one publicity photo, the Frag Dolls loll among soft pink pillows, gripping video game consoles with demure smiles and bright eyes riveted to a computer screen.     This is no slumber party. The stylish, fresh-faced girls are one of the latest weapons in the gaming industry's effort to smash the stereotypical image of the gamer as a geeky teenage boy in a dark basement, battling aliens.

headline: Lebanon’s Future: Bending Toward Hezbollah or Leaning to the West?
abstract: The war with Israel is over and reconstruction has begun, but the battle for Lebanon's political future continues apace. It is a struggle whose outcome could have profound ramifications for the Middle East.     The latest maneuver in that fight is Hezbollah's vociferous call for a national unity government that would threaten the slim majority held by pro-Western parties, known as the March 14 movement after a huge demonstration on that date in 2005. [Hezbollah has scheduled what is expected to be a huge rally on Friday in Beirut.]

headline: With Airports Engulfed, Some Businesses Deftly Adapted
abstract: Word of a plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airliners may not seem like a promising marketing opportunity. But marketers are a relentlessly upbeat bunch, and not long after the terror alert settled in, they were finding some silver linings.     Companies that offer alternatives to commercial aircraft stepped forward to report increases in bookings; they included the Eurostar Group, which runs trains linking London with Paris and Brussels, and some private jet fleets. Samsonite informed journalists about a range of bags that met the new size restrictions for carry-on luggage at British airports.

headline: IPT Huh? It’s Programming for Particular Viewers Like You
abstract: Internet Protocol Television, or IPT, has potential to drastically reduce cost of delivering specialized video programming that can be viewed on PC or televisions with Net-enabled set-top boxes; appeal for first wave of viewers has been access to niche programs that are generally not available on other services; Interactive Television Network, which provides set-top box free to subscribers, has developed narrowcast channels, its main appeal being programming for almost any demographic; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Profit Down at Goldman, but Estimates Are Beaten
abstract: Despite a summer slump in trading up and down Wall Street and expectations of a significant decline in investment banking, Goldman Sachs reported strong third-quarter earnings yesterday.      For Goldman, after stellar performances in recent quarters, the results still represented a substantial comedown.

headline: At a Glance
abstract: Hezbollah guerrilla campaign that ended Israel's 18-year occupation of southern Lebanon in 2000 was in many ways precursor to kind of asymmetrical warfare US troops are facing in Iraq and Israeli troops would face again if they entered Lebanon in large numbers (M)

headline: Housing Numbers Dampen Investors’ Outlook
abstract: Roundup of last week's stock market activity; graph (M)

headline: Demonstrations Become Clashes After Islamists Take Somali City
abstract: Kismayo, one of the largest cities in Somalia, fell to Islamic forces without a shot on Monday -- but then the trouble started.     After the city's warlords fled and hundreds of Islamist fighters poured in, demonstrators took to the streets and hurled stones at the Islamists.

headline: Militia Rebuked by Some Arab Countries
abstract: With the battle between Israel and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah raging, key Arab governments have taken the rare step of blaming Hezbollah, underscoring in part their growing fear of influence by the group's main sponsor, Iran.     Saudi Arabia, with Jordan, Egypt and several Persian Gulf states, chastised Hezbollah for ''unexpected, inappropriate and irresponsible acts'' at an emergency Arab League summit meeting in Cairo on Saturday.

headline: Mexico: Candidates Supporters Paralyze Capital
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators demanding a recount in the presidential election created enormous traffic jams throughout Mexico City, blocking the main avenues in the capital's historic center with protest camps. On Sunday, the leftist presidential candidate, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, a former mayor of Mexico City who election officials say narrowly lost the election last month, called for sit-ins to add pressure for the full recount he wants. As motorists' tempers flared, he apologized for the jams. ''We are not rebels without a cause,'' he told reporters at the biggest camp, in Constitution Plaza. ''It is not that we like being here. We don't like being here. It is out of necessity.''   JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. (NYT)

headline: Dread and Resignation in Israel
abstract: If residents of this kibbutz harbored any doubts about the danger of venturing outside during a rocket-attack warning, they were erased Sunday by the fiery Katyusha packed with ball bearings that killed 12 Israeli reservists.     Ignoring pleas by kibbutz members to seek shelter, the reservists took a direct hit from the rocket, fired by a Hezbollah launcher a few miles away in Lebanon. The charred, dismembered bodies, and blood splattered against a stone wall, turned the stomachs of hardened emergency service workers.

headline: Leaving Behind the Torn-Jeans Look
abstract: Fifteen years ago, as the head of men's and women's fashion at Abercrombie & Fitch, the husband and wife team Michele and Charles Martin decreed a new dress code for American teenagers, filled with baggy cargo pants, weather-beaten rugby jerseys and frayed, athletic T-shirts.      Today, however, the Martins have a very different mission: to wean 30-year-olds off those clothes.

headline: If Boomers Have It All, What’s Left?
abstract: THE baby boom generation may be known to history as the one that took it all, leaving their successors to pay the bills and take on the risks that the boomers did not have to accept for themselves.     A glaring example is in the world of pensions, where corporate executives and directors, many of them baby boomers, are reducing benefits for younger employees.

headline: Adelphia Creditors Ask Bankruptcy Court to Liquidate Company
abstract: A group of creditors of Adelphia Communications asked a judge last week to liquidate the company and its affiliates, and thus speed payments to all creditors.     Banks including Wachovia, PNC and Calyon, a unit of  Crédit Agricole of France, asked Judge Robert E. Gerber of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to convert the bankruptcy cases of Adelphia and some affiliates from a reorganization to a Chapter 7 liquidation.

headline: Even Statelessness Goes Better With Coke. Or Does It?
abstract: When a Coca-Cola bottling plant opened here two years ago, the 400-plus investors invited to finance the project were carefully chosen by clan.     There were Abgal investors and Habar Gedir investors, and representatives of other clans around Somalia as well. All kicked in a minimum of $300 to help start the United Bottling Company, Somalia's only Coca-Cola maker. It was a deliberate effort to create a feeling of communal ownership for the factory in a place where clan-based conflict has long been the rule.

headline: Hello, Boss. I Feel a Headache Coming On.
abstract: Career Couch column offers advice on taking unscheduled days off from work; tips for not alienating boss or using up sick time are given; drawing (M)

headline: Georgia Sends Troops to Subdue Rebel Militia
abstract: Georgia deployed special forces on Tuesday near a remote gorge beside the breakaway region of Abkhazia to arrest a local ruler who had declared autonomy from federal rule and to disperse a militia under his command, Georgian officials said.     As the troops arrived there were reports in the evening of clashes between the sides.

headline: U.S. Warns PC Users of Flaw in Windows
abstract: Homeland Security Department issues unusual security alert, warning users of Windows-based personal computers to patch flaw in Microsoft operating system; Microsoft also warned of 'critical' security flaw; said attacker who exploited vulnerability could take complete control of affected system and make it possible to install malicious programs or change or delete data (M)

headline: Its Air Show Time, but Airbus May Not Want the Spotlight
abstract: Airbus A380 superjumbo jet will be on display at Farnborough International Air Show amid problems facing parent company European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company involving production delays of aircraft and questions about timing of stock sales by co-chief executive Noel Forgeard; problems led to his dismissal; company hopes to emphasize its gains in military contracts as symbol of stronger trans-Atlantic relationships; photos (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: GATEWAY REJECTS HOSTILE OFFER -- The computer maker Gateway said it had rejected an unsolicited $450 million bid for its retail business from Lap Shun Hui, the founder of eMachines, which Gateway bought in 2004. Gateway said the Aug. 23 offer for the retail operations was not in the best interest of its shareholders.     A Gateway spokesman, David Hallisey, would not elaborate on the decision. Mr. Hui, above -- Gateway's second-largest shareholder, after its founder, Ted Waitt -- did not immediately respond to a message seeking comment.

headline: Maker of Baseball Cards Settles a Proxy Dispute
abstract: Topps Company and hedge funds Pembridge Capital Management and Crescendo Partners reach settlement on candidates for board of directors, which will grow from 9 members to 10; ends yearlong battle by Timothy E Brog to force change at company (M)

headline: Fired or Quit, Tom Cruise Parts Ways With Studio
abstract: Citing Tom Cruise's yearlong metamorphosis from pure box-office phenomenon to pop-culture punch line, Viacom's chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, said Tuesday that Paramount Pictures was ending its 14-year relationship with the actor's production company.     Mr. Cruise's representatives insisted that they had not been fired but instead had quit and had already lined up $100 million in financing to produce movies on their own.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two US soldiers killed in Iraq (S)

headline: Plane Crash Adds to Russia’s August Miseries
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.     TOP STORY

headline: Video-on-Demand Viewers Still Buy DVD’s
abstract: Study by Forrester Research suggests that on-demand movies ordered by cable television viewers do not put dent in DVD sales; finds video-on-demand watchers rent about 11 percent fewer DVD movies than before; photo (S)

headline: Suicide Attacks Foiled at 2 Oil Sites, Yemen Says
abstract: Security officials in Yemen say they thwarted two suicide bombings of oil installations in southern and central regions of country (M)

headline: Poles Seeking Jobs Found Forced Labor in Italy
abstract: Italian authorities raid prisonlike agricultural labor camps in Puglia region, where 113 Polish immigrants were kept; international criminal ring lured estimated 1,000 Polish farm workers to Italy promising season jobs picking fruit and vegetables; Poles were forced to work long hours, were paid less than legal rate and were kept under guard in squalid conditions (M)

headline: Take the Liquids, but Leave the Laptops
abstract: Joe Sharkey On The Road column discusses how airline restrictions in wake of foiled terrorist plots by British authorities are affecting travelers; many are taking changes in stride but are starting to change travel schedules and frequency as result; drawing (M)

headline: G.M. Hopes a Line of Pickups Will Lead Back to Prosperity
abstract: General Motors introduces 2007 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra at its testing facilities in Milford, Mich; product development chief Robert Lutz, despite higher fuel costs, is confident that well-designed pickups can lead company back to prosperity; Ford, in response, says it will reduce sticker prices for 2007 F-Series pickups by as much as $1,400, offer two additional body styles and increase towing capacity; photo (M)

headline: Olympics Imperil Historic Beijing Neighborhood
abstract: A short walk from Tiananmen Square and the Great Hall of the People, a historic neighborhood named Qianmen is an eerie picture of destruction. Ancient homes lie in rubble. Scavengers squat in alleyways and wait to ransack vacated buildings.      The reason for the devastation is the 2008 Olympic Games, which have turned much of the city into a noisy, disjointed construction zone. New subway lines and new roads are under construction, even an entire new downtown. On the city's northern rim, at least 25,000 laborers are building the Olympic stadiums and village.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Baidu Profit Increases
abstract: Owner of Baidu.com, China's most-used Internet search engine, reports second-quarter profit rose more than fourfold as online advertising sales surged; net income was 58.5 million yuan ($7.3 million) up from 12.1 million yuan year earlier; photo (S)

headline: New Republic Suspends an Editor for Attacks on Blog
abstract: New Republic editor Lee Siegel is suspended indefinitely and has his blog shut down after revelations that he used Internet alias to anonymously attack readers who criticized his posts (M)

headline: Ukraine Leader Forms Alliance With Rivals
abstract: President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine allied himself on Thursday with a parliamentary coalition led by his critics and rivals after negotiating a nonbinding agreement that he said would preserve his main policy goals, including integrating the country into Europe and NATO.     Mr. Yushchenko described the agreement -- grandiosely called a National Unity Universal -- as an effort to bridge Ukraine's ethnic, social and economic divisions after months of political chaos and stalemate following inconclusive parliamentary elections in March.
