But it also put him in the position of supporting as prime minister a man he once denounced as a bandit, Viktor F. Yanukovich. The reversal prompted new accusations of betrayal on Thursday.

headline: How a Google Search Can Become a Security Threat
abstract: Google hacking refers to use of Internet search sites to uncover useful and compromising information that has been inadvertently left on Web site; examples of material that can be uncovered include passwords and personal data; hackers require no special tools and little skill to locate information they are seeking; security experts say many Web site owners do not understand that their sites are not as secure as they think; drawing (M)

headline: YouTube Ads to Market CD by Paris Hilton
abstract: Paris Hilton will promote her debut CD on YouTube video-sharing service; site plans to officially announce that it will sell space on its main page to run video ads, which viewers will be able to rate and share; will also provide advertisers with designated pages to display videos and other content; co-founder Chad Hurley comments (M)

headline: Wal-Mart to Test Price Cuts on Range of Generic Drugs
abstract: Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, will test a program to sell generic prescription drugs to its workers and customers at sharply reduced prices, according to people briefed on the plans.     The giant discount chain, which has used its size to knock down the costs of toys, clothing and groceries, will sell generic versions of about 300 widely prescribed drugs for as low as $4 for a standard prescription, these people said, speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to disclose details of the new program. On average, generic drugs cost between $10 and $30 for a 30-day prescription.

headline: Gunmen Kill Afghan Official Who Backed Women’s Rights
abstract: A senior Afghan official specializing in women's rights was gunned down here on her way to work on Monday morning by suspected Taliban gunmen. It was the highest-level assassination of a woman in Afghanistan in the five years since the Taliban were ousted from power.     Safia Amajan, 65, had served as chief of the women's affairs department in Kandahar Province for five years, working for women's rights and education and vocational training. A former teacher and high school principal, she was well known and much liked in Kandahar.

headline: Uganda Peace Hinges on Amnesty for Brutality
abstract: In the beginning, it was simply called the Acholi war, and despite its brutality, few people outside Uganda paid attention.     The Lord's Resistance Army, a messianic rebel group, was exploring a new dimension of violence by building an army of abducted children and forcing them to burn down huts, slice off lips and pound newborn babies to death in wooden mortars, as though they were grinding grain.

headline: The Cut-Rate Convention
abstract: Article on impact that increase in convention space across US is having on trade associations and corporate planners, who are being offered range of incentives; Tradeshow Week is forecasting that expositions and trade shows in US and Canada will draw about 65 million attendees and 1.6 million exhibiting companies this year; while organizations are offered free convention space, many offers are accompanied by increased entertainment charges or are made by cities that attendees are not interested in visiting; photo (M)

headline: Performance Reviews: Many Need Improvement
abstract: Kelley Holland column explores whether employee performance reviews, including forced distribution rankings known as rank-and-yank, are effective; combination of complaints and lack of hard support for forced rankings has led many companies to change their systems; drawing (M)

headline: Foreign NGOs Complain Russia Hinders Registration
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Monday.    GAZETA  Only 7 of between 200 and 500 foreign nongovernmental organizations have been able to complete registration procedures to remain active in Russia after Oct. 18 when current registration expires. Organizations must submit all documents by Sept. 18, though many say that the registration process is mired in bureaucratic hassles. Representatives from foreign NGOs complain of having to go to the ends of the earth in search of the correct documents, which the Russian registration bureau accepts only three hours each week. In addition, large or long-standing organizations are having a difficult time securing all the required information, like names and private addresses of founding members with whom the organization may not even be associated any more.    NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA  THE BATTLE FOR BOMBAY: General Jaswant Singh of India arrives in Russia this week to discuss military-technological cooperation. Questions over quality have made India consider other options besides Russias MiG-35 for their upcoming $6.5 billion fighter plane contract. Currently, 80 percent of Indias military hardware is Russian-made. Russias MiG-35 is likely to encounter fiercest competition from American made F-16 and F/A-18 fighter planes. This visit, therefore, is likely to be Russias best opportunity to win back Indias favor.    VEDOMOSTI  MINISTRIES RANKED BY BUDGETARY SHARE: In preparation for the 2007 federal budget, Russias Ministry of Finance has included rankings of federal ministries by their future share of budgetary resources. Releasing such information prior to publication of the official budget is unprecedented. The Ministry of Finance tops the list of budgetary share, followed by the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade. Officials explain the rankings as part of a new result-oriented program evaluating the efficiency of Russias federal ministries.    RUSSIAN OLIGARCH TO ENTER FILM INDUSTRY: Viktor Vekselberg, Russian billionaire industrialist, is planning to finance an historical film called 1612, a period known as the Time of Troubles. His holding company, Renova Media will invest about $4 million in the film. Mr. Vekselberg is the latest Russian oligarch to finance Russias film industry. Where in 2005, 70 percent of the film industry was financed by the state, in 2006 50 to 60 percent is financed by the private business sector.    VREMYA NOVOSTEI  RAMZAN KADYROV PREPARES FOR THE CHECHEN PRESIDENCY: Ramzan A. Kadyrov, prime minister of Chechnya, looks to be in the running for the Chechen presidency. The leader of Chechnyas lower house, Dukvakha Abdurakhmanov, said it is the peoples wish for Mr. Kadyrov to become president. Experts say Mr. Abdurakhmanov often expresses thoughts or ideas that may be too sensitive for higher officials to say publicly. This is therefore seen as a possible prelude to Mr. Kadyrovs run for the Russian republics top post.    KOMMERSANT  ALUMINUM MONOPOLY ON THE HORIZON: The leaders of Russias two major aluminum companies have agreed to consolidate their assets, establishing the largest aluminum company in the world. By merging their companies, Viktor Vekselburg of SUAL and Russian Aluminums Oleg Deripaska will control 100 percent of Russias aluminum market. A clause in Russias antimonopoly law allows for the creation of monopolies that will strengthen Russias position in the global market. The merger, which is planned for mid-October, will create a company worth an estimated $22 billion according to company insiders.    ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA  The leader of Russias main power company, Anatoly Chubais, met with President Vladimir V. Putin in Sochi on Saturday to discuss the energy deficits plaguing dozens of Russias regions. According to Mr. Chubais, solving Russias energy problems will require heavy investment, not just by the government, which does not have the resources to provide the estimated 2.1 trillion rubles needed for the next four years, but by private investors. Mr. Chubais proposed that responsibility for energy production be handed over to private companies, leaving the government with control over distribution and delivery.    IZVESTIA  A funeral will be held today in Omsk for a journalist, his wife and their two young sons who were shot by a 16-year-old local resident on their vacation in Altai on Aug. 8. As explanation for his crime, the teenager, Ruslan Kulish, said he had wanted, if only for one day, to live like a person. After he murdered the family, Kulish stole their 1991 Mitsubishi and about $700. Afterwards he spent the money with his friends, who knew about the crime, but did not inform the authorities.    NOVYE IZVESTIA  In September, the Association of Russian Farmers and Agricultural collectives plans to hold nationwide protests against unrestrained price increases for petroleum. According to organizers, farmers are unable to afford fuel even at current prices, and will not be able to hold out through the harvest season. Government authorities, according to the newspaper, have come up with an innovative way to deal with the problem. They recommend that officials refrain from giving any prognosis on future petroleum prices, so as to avoid public unease.

headline: Raising Issue of Succession at Pfizer
abstract: Directors of Pfizer could decide as early as today on a successor to Hank McKinnell, the chairman and chief executive, possibly ending a fierce competition within the company, a person close to Pfizer said last night.     Directors could also decide to hasten Mr. McKinnell's retirement, which is now scheduled to take place in February 2008, when he will reach Pfizer's mandatory retirement age of 65, this person said.

headline: G.I.s Say Officers Ordered Killing of Young Iraqi Men
abstract: Four American soldiers from an Army combat unit that killed three Iraqis in a raid in May testified Wednesday that they had received orders from superior officers to kill all the military-age men they encountered.      The soldiers gave their accounts at a military hearing here to determine if four colleagues should face courts-martial on charges that they carried out a plan to murder the three Iraqis, whom they had seized after an assault on what they were told was an insurgent stronghold northwest of Baghdad.

headline: Thousands Celebrate the Life of a Famed Crocodile Hunter
abstract: What do you say about a death-defier who dies? You pledge to celebrate his life. You acknowledge that death cannot be defied. And finally you conclude that zest of a certain magnitude -- enthusiasm for mortal danger, say -- offers its own kind of immortality.     Such, at least, were the rhetorical strategies on display at the almost unnervingly sunny memorial tribute for Steve Irwin, 44, the renowned crocodile hunter, who was killed on Sept. 4 when a stingray stabbed him in the chest on the Great Barrier Reef.

headline: A Product Endorsement, Courtesy of the Revolution
abstract: The world already knows that Fidel Castro, the temporarily sidelined president of Cuba, was a pitcher in his younger days -- he even briefly played with a barnstorming team after the revolution -- and remains a huge sports fan. Now it knows something else: like Zinédine Zidane, Tracy McGrady and Reggie Bush, Mr. Castro is an Adidas man.     Not that Adidas, the multinational athletic equipment company based in Germany, is taking out billboards to spread the news. Rather, the world's news media spread the word after the Cuban government released the first photographs of Mr. Castro, 80, recuperating from surgery for intestinal bleeding in Havana. Mr. Castro was shown in a resplendent red, white and blue jacket with an Adidas symbol on the right breast, the kind of unintentional product endorsement that any company trying to sell in the United States might want to avoid.

headline: Annan Says Iran’s President Holds to Nuclear Program
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan meets with Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, who expresses willingness to enter into negotiations on his country's nuclear program but will not agree to suspending uranium enrichment beforehand, as demanded by Security Council; Ahmadinejad makes general commitment to support Security Council resolution ending war in Lebanon, but no specific pledge to back disarming of Hezbollah militia, which Iran helps to finance and arm; will also encourage prisoner exchange between Israel, Lebanon and Hezbollah (M)

headline: Don't Have a Cow. It's Just a Radio Ad.
abstract: Radio ads have decreased in length and number the last few years as broadcasters -- especially Clear Channel Communications -- have tried to keep listeners tuned in and paying attention.     On Sept. 10, that process will reach its natural conclusion. Every half-hour, all 1,100 Clear Channel radio stations will run two-second ads for that night's premiere of the Fox comedy ''The Simpsons.'' Clear Channel calls the format ''blink'' ads.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Message From Castro
abstract: Photos of Fidel Castro appear in Cuba's official newsletter with note from recuperating leader saying 'most critical moment is behind me' (S)

headline: No Victors, Few Spoils in This Proxy Fight
abstract: Joe Nocera column assesses circumstances surrounding downfall of BKF Capital, including involvement of Steel Partners II hedge fund manager Warren Lichtenstein, who resigned from BKF's board last month; describes how former BKF chief executive John Levin also played pivotal role in saga; photos (M)

headline: A Test of Friendship for Indias Leader
abstract: Manmohan Singh, the prime minister of India and an ever-more-important friend of the United States government, is poised to face a storm of criticism this week when Parliament returns for the aptly named monsoon session.     Much of the criticism, it seems, implicates his friendship with the United States.

headline: Wi-Fi for the Building? Depends on the Landlord
abstract: Commercial landlords comment on extent of demand for Wi-Fi Internet access in Manhattan; some landlords have been retrofitting entire buildings at request of tenants and some offer service in lobbies or plazas to attract users to spaces; most, however, say they demand is not strong enough to warrant investing in wireless systems and that most tenants are satisfied with hard-wired broadband access; photos (M)

headline: A Room With a Pedicure
abstract: Hotels are increasingly offering guests full spa services as business travelers find time on trips to relax and pamper themselves; invest millions of dollars in building spas which can generate 10 percent of hotel revenue, second only to room rates; treatments are tailored for busy travelers by offering in-room services and flexible schedules; photos (M)

headline: Hot Market for Second Homes Hits Slump
abstract: The brand new 6,000-square-foot vacation home, backing on a boat dock on Moriches Bay, has been on the market for more than a year. After plenty of showings, but no offers, the investor who built the house recently cut the price twice, by a total of $600,000, to $4 million.     It has still not been sold. To be sure, the price reductions have created more interest, according to the agent representing the owner, and he now hopes that it will be sold right after Labor Day, a prime season for home transactions in the Hamptons.

headline: Japanese Fret That Quality Is in Decline
abstract: Perhaps only in Japan could a television series like ''Project X'' have become one of the most popular TV shows. No, it isn't a science fiction thriller. It's about product quality.     More specifically, it's about a bunch of corporate engineers who invented the hand-held calculators and ink-jet printers that helped turn this nation into an industrial powerhouse.

headline: Business and Islam: Allies Against Anarchy in Somalia
abstract: In this sandy wasteland of palm trees and wrecked seaside villas, there are warlords and then there are moneylords.     Yusuf Muhammad is a moneylord, a shipping magnate who threw his weight -- and men and money -- behind the Islamic militias and helped bring them to power in June.

headline: Indonesia to Send Soldiers for U.N.’s Force in Lebanon
abstract: Indonesia expects to send contingent of 1,000 soldiers to join UN peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, even though Israel said it would oppose participation of soldiers from Muslim countries that did not have diplomatic relations with Israel (M)

headline: Creating a Work Space That Promotes a Brand
abstract: Claire Wilson article on new office space at 375 Hudson Street in Manhattan created by David Howell of David Howell Design for Fahrenheit 212degrees, division of Saatchi & Saatchi advertising conglomerate; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Fourth Suspect In Mumbai Bombings
abstract: The police in Mumbai said they had arrested a fourth man in connection with the July 11 commuter train bombings. They identified him as Tanveer Ahmed Ansari, 33, and described him as a practitioner of traditional medicine and a Mumbai resident who had traveled to Pakistan for guerrilla training. The police said he had links to the banned Students Islamic Movement of India. Three other men, all Indian Muslims, were arrested in India last week in connection with the blasts, which killed almost 200 people.   HARI KUMAR (NYT)

headline: Chairwoman Leaves Hewlett in Spying Furor
abstract: The furor over Hewlett-Packard's spying operation claimed its highest-ranking victim on Friday with the immediate resignation of its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn.      The move was announced by Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive, who will now succeed her. But even as he offered an account of an investigation gone awry, and offered apologies to those whose privacy was invaded, he made it clear that many questions had yet to be answered.

headline: Truckers Testify That Halliburton Put Lives at Risk
abstract: Two truckers who worked in Iraq told a Senate Democratic policy committee on Monday that their employer, a Halliburton subsidiary, knowingly sent a lightly armed convoy of fuel tankers into a combat zone in April 2004, leading to the deaths of seven truckers and at least two soldiers.     The allegations now form the basis of a lawsuit that families of the dead, along with several truckers wounded in the same incident, have brought against the subsidiary, KBR, formerly known as Kellogg Brown & Root.

headline: Pay Rules Adopted by S.E.C.
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday adopted a sweeping set of new rules to make it easier to see how much top executives are paid and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.     With a unanimous vote, the five S.E.C. commissioners set in motion a plan that calls for companies to describe more clearly how their executives are compensated and to provide new information, like the lump-sum cost of retirement benefits and explanations of why specific stock option grants were approved. The rules will go into effect in mid-December, several months ahead of proxy season next year.

headline: A Pen That's More Than Meets the Paper
abstract: Anne Eisenberg column on 102, digital pen from Logitech that allows user to immediately transfer handwritten notes onto computer screen; photos (M)

headline: Pakistan Confirms Many Details About Key Figure Under Arrest
abstract: New details unfolded Wednesday about the main figure arrested in the London bombing plot, Rashid Rauf. They included a confirmation by Pakistani officials that Mr. Rauf had married and settled in Bahawalpur, a southern town that is home to a notorious jihadist group, Jaish-e-Mohammed.      The background included accounts that he used to be at least an active member of the organization, which has been banned.

headline: Trade Focus Now Shifts to Regional Deals
abstract: Two weeks ago, countries in the World Trade Organization agreed on rules that would make it easier to track two-way and regional trade deals. Negotiators were concerned that the proliferation of regional deals would detract from efforts, already faltering, to reach a global trade pact.      On Tuesday, those regional deals moved to the forefront after the collapse for the foreseeable future of global talks that began five years ago in Doha, Qatar.

headline: Sale Shoppers Annoy Grocers as They Save
abstract: Drilling Down column discusses shoppers known as 'cherry-pickers' who visit several grocery stores to shop for only sale items; holds that grocers feel it is violation of trust; photo (S)

headline: 2 Muslims Are Charged in Plot for a Bombing in Denmark
abstract: The case against nine Muslim men arrested in an alleged terrorist bombing plot has generated anger in Denmark's Muslim immigrant community even as police officials admitted Wednesday that they were scrambling to hold the case together.     National police officers charged seven of the nine suspects with plotting to carry out a bomb attack on Danish soil. But at an arraignment hearing that began Tuesday afternoon and lasted into the early hours of Wednesday, only two were formally charged.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Kurdish Rebel's Extradition Blocked
abstract: Highest court in Netherlands blocks extradition to Turkey of Kurdish rebel leader Nuriye Kesbir, saying she ran risk of being tortured if sent home for trial (S)

headline: 3 Rabbis Ordained as Judaism Re-emerges in Germany
abstract: Germany took a richly symbolic step in its long journey of historical reconciliation on Thursday as three men became the first rabbis ordained in this country since the Holocaust.     In a ceremony that blended bright hope for the future with a solemn homage to the past, the three -- a German, a Czech, and a South African -- stood before a senior rabbi in Dresden's starkly modern synagogue, as he told them they had been singled out, just as Moses had chosen Joshua, in Scripture.

headline: Annan Will Travel the Mideast To Bolster Lebanon Peace Plan
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan to start 11-day Mideast tour to gather support for Security Council resolution ending Israeli-Hezbollah fighting and setting path for securing Lebanon's independence (M)

headline: Worry Over Housing Market Offsets Oil Price Cut
abstract: Roundup of last week's stock market activity; graphs (M)

headline: A Drive Big Enough to Hold a Familys Data
abstract: A terabyte of storage may seem like overkill -- after all, that's 1,000 gigabytes, and it was only yesterday that a 4-gigabyte drive was considered gigantic. But Maxtor doesn't seem to agree. Its Shared Storage II, available now, is a network drive that can hold up to 16,600 songs, 72 hours of high-resolution video or 768,000 photos.     If you have yet to accumulate that much media, the drive also offers automated backup of PC's and Mac's, so multiple computers can store mirrors of their data on one centralized device.

headline: Palestinian Reports Unity Deal With Hamas
abstract: The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Monday that he had reached a tentative agreement with Hamas to form a national unity government in an attempt to end the Palestinians' international isolation and the cutoff in Western assistance to their government.     In a speech on Palestinian television, Mr. Abbas said it would take several days to finish the deal, and provided no details of how his Fatah faction and the militant group Hamas, which leads the government, had resolved their considerable differences.

headline: Even at the End, Ken Lay Didn't Get It
abstract: THE tragedy of the former Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay, who died yesterday at the age of 64, is not that his name will always be linked to the seminal business scandal of the era. Nor is it that his fall from grace was so precipitous, as Mr. Lay went from one of the most esteemed businessmen in the country to the disgraced ''Kenny Boy'' in the blink of an eye.     No, the tragedy of Ken Lay is that, right up until the end, he never fully understood what he'd done wrong, or his own considerable culpability in his company's demise. Yes, there were others more directly responsible for Enron's collapse, like its former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, whose devious partnerships allowed Enron to disguise the truth of its financial condition and then sow the seeds of its destruction.

headline: Pushing the Boundaries of Political Satire in Japan
abstract: Comedian Hikari Ota has brought political satire to Japanese television for first time; American television may abound with political parodies, but Japanese television, though rich with social satire, has no history of lampooning country's political leaders; while there is current boom in stand-up comedy in Japan, all but few performers avoid political; Ota photo (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: PUSH FOR BLACKS IN ADVERTISING New York City officials have reached agreements with several of the nation's biggest advertising firms, forcing them to bring more blacks into this crucial sector of the city's economy. [Page A1.]    NEW ROLES FOR FORMER SECRETARY Robert E. Rubin, below, the Treasury secretary under President Clinton, has started a small research group aimed at generating policy ideas and money for Democratic presidential candidates, and from his perch on the board of Citigroup he has become an influential public defender of its chief executive, who is feeling the lash from investors over the stock's stagnant run. [C1.]    REPORTERS WERE MONITORED The California attorney general's investigation into the purloining of private phone records by agents of Hewlett-Packard has revealed that the monitoring effort began earlier than previously indicated and included journalists as targets. [C1.]    WAL-MART'S CONSERVATIVE TIES As Wal-Mart struggles to rebut criticism from unions and Democratic leaders, the company has discovered a reliable ally: prominent conservative research groups. [C1.]    SEEING GROWTH IN BIOFUEL Seed and biotechnology companies see a big opportunity in developing corn and other crops tailored for use in ethanol and other biofuels. [C1.]    BP OFFICIALS UNDER FIRE Top American executives of BP took a bipartisan pummeling from a Congressional subcommittee, over what some members called the systematic neglect that led to the temporary closing at Prudhoe Bay. [A18.]    REAL ESTATE WORRIES Concerns about the state of the housing market deepened as the nation's leading Realtors group issued a more pessimistic outlook for the year, and two major builders shaved hundreds of millions of dollars off their earnings estimates. [C3.]    MICROSOFT BLAMES REGULATORS Microsoft raised the stakes in its European antitrust battle by warning that the introduction of the Windows Vista operating system might be delayed there because of unclear guidance. [C4.]    PACKARD BELL SALE The computer executive Lap Shun Hui is set to complete the purchase of Packard Bell, the European personal computer maker, from NEC of Japan later this month. [C4.]    REVIEW OF VOTING RULES A federal appeals court has at least temporarily cleared the way for shareholders to force companies to hold contested elections for directors, with rival candidates appearing on the ballots distributed by companies. [C5.]    JOBLESS CLAIMS DROP The number of newly laid-off workers filing claims for unemployment benefits dropped more sharply than expected last week, signaling continuing labor market strength despite a general economic slowdown. [C5.]    PRISON DATE FOR EBBERS A federal judge ordered the former chief executive of WorldCom, Bernard J. Ebbers, who was convicted of orchestrating an $11 billion accounting fraud, to report to prison on Sept. 26 to begin his 25-year sentence. [C2.]    SETTLEMENT IN ENRON PENSIONS The estate of Kenneth L. Lay will pay $12 million to settle claims on behalf of participants in Enron's pension plans, the government said. [C7.]    AD CAMPAIGN SECRETS Secrets are at the center of a growing number of national advertising campaigns, with consumers being invited to reveal personal secrets and with marketers sharing with consumers what they describe as corporate secrets. Advertising. Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    STOCKS RETREAT Stocks declined for a second day on mounting evidence that a housing slump is putting the brakes on the economy. [C8.]    STENT MAKERS DECLINE Shareholder qualms about growth prospects for the $5 billion coronary stent business shook the stocks of Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson, the two leading stent makers. [C7.]    SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE MERGER Shareholders approved the $10.7 billion merger of the telecommunications equipment makers Alcatel and Lucent, but only after Alcatel investors voiced doubts about the leadership and financial health of their new American partner. [C3.]    MILLIONS FOR NEW VIACOM CHIEF Viacom said it would pay its new chief executive, Philippe P. Dauman, $2 million in salary and a bonus that could be as high as $14 million. [C8.]    ONLINE    THE NEW RABBIT Volkswagen GTI initiated legions of low-budget enthusiasts into the cult of German performance. The fifth-generation model recaptures the buzz-bomb spirit of the originals. A report is at nytimes.com/autos.    AWAY FROM HOME Exploring the luxury second-home market from Cape Cod to South Florida to the Napa Valley. A report can be found at nytimes.com/travel.    Business Briefing    An article on these developments is at nytimes.com/business.    GATEWAY INC., the maker of personal computers, named J. Edward Coleman as its chief executive, ending a nine-month search to replace Wayne Inouye.     Mr. Coleman, 54, was a senior vice president at Arrow Electronics. Gateway has tallied almost $41 million in losses in the last nine months and is struggling to lift direct sales to counter a rise in less profitable retail orders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Kaplan Thaler Group is awarded Liz Claiborne account; Gotham Inc had account for more than decade (S)

headline: Speaker of Iraqi Parliament May Step Down
abstract: The speaker of Parliament said Monday that he was considering stepping down because of bitter enmity from Kurdish and Shiite political blocs, revealing the first major crack in Iraq's fragile unity government since it was formed nearly three months ago.     The speaker, Mahmoud al-Mashhadani, is the third-ranking official in Iraq and a conservative Sunni Arab. Shiite and Kurdish legislators have banded together to try to push him out, mainly because he is considered too radical.

headline: Accounts
abstract: The Kaplan Thaler Group, part of Publicis, was awarded accounts for the Centrum and Caltrate brands, part of Wyeth. Billings for the accounts are estimated at $45 million.     MMB in Boston remains the agency of record for Jiffy Lube. MMB was challenged by Colby & Partners, part of Dentsu, and Cole & Weber United, part of the WPP Group. Billings are estimated at $25 million.

headline: As Oil Rises, Will Economy Finally Fall?
abstract: WHEN oil almost hit $40 a barrel in 2003, there was talk that the rising cost of gasoline would slow the American economy. The talk returned when oil topped $50 in 2004 and $60 last year. But the economy kept on growing at a good clip.     Now, with oil above $70, some seem to think the logic was simply wrong, and that the new American economy is impervious to oil.

headline: HSBC Agrees to Buy Panamas Biggest Bank for $1.77 Billion
abstract: HSBC Holdings agrees to buy Grupo Banistmo, Panama's largest bank, for $1.77 billion in cash (M)

headline: Japan Finds Still Harsher Words for North Koreas Missile Tests
abstract: Japan ratcheted up the oratory on Monday against North Korea over last week's missile tests when a top government spokesman said Japan should consider whether its Constitution would allow pre-emptive military strikes.      A United States envoy called for countries involved to speak with ''one voice'' in condemning the tests.

headline: Iran Shuts Top Reformist Paper, Citing Cartoon Seen as an Insult
abstract: Iran's conservative press watchdog shuts down four publications, including major reformist daily Shargh; agency statement says Shargh is shut down indefinitely because it refused to replace its director and because it published recent cartoon considered insulting to government (M)

headline: It’s Not How Mozart Started, but It May Amuse the Children
abstract: Electronic piano lessons have not posed much of a threat thus far to your neighborhood piano teacher. I Can Play Piano, an $80 device from Fisher-Price that is intended for children 4 to 8 years old, is no exception, but it could generate some musical fun.     The three-octave plastic keyboard, which plugs into your TV, uses an adaptation of the teaching methodology from an older PC-based piano system called the Piano Wizard.

headline: A Superhero When Magazines Need One
abstract: Julie Bosman Advertising column on Magazine Publishers of America's Captain Read superhero marketing campaign; campaign, aimed at industry insiders, will promote magazines as 'supermedium' able to deliver 'rock-solid' return on investment; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: U.N. Says Israel Blocks Inquiry Of Post Attack
abstract: UN says Israel has refused to give its investigators access to military commanders responsible for directing precision-guided bomb attack on post in southern Lebanon that killed four UN observers (S)

headline: Reporters on Film: Drunks and Tarts
abstract: IN a few scant weeks, students intent on a career in news will arrive at journalism schools across the country, filled with idealism and starry-eyed at the prospect of becoming a part of the noble Fourth Estate.      They must not have gone to the movies lately.

headline: A Closer Look At the Hispanic Population
abstract: United States prepares to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month amid controversy over national immigration policy; Census Bureau estimates Hispanic population, as of July 1, was 42.7 million, nearly twice level in 1990; projects Hispanic population will reach 102.6 million, or 24 percent of country, by 2050; photo; graph (M)

headline: Trade Talks Fail Over an Impasse on Farm Tariffs
abstract: Negotiations aimed at reaching a new global trade agreement collapsed here Monday, touching off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe over farm trade barriers and dealing a blow to the Bush administration's international economic agenda.     After two days of wrangling by negotiators from six leading trade nations and blocs, the director general of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, formally suspended the talks, declaring that he no longer had hope of overcoming resistance in wealthy countries to sharply reducing domestic protection for their politically powerful farm industries.

headline: Times Company Profit Flat; Internet Revenue Increasing
abstract: The New York Times Company reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were essentially flat, in large part because of continued advertising weakness in New England.     The company reported some modest financial gains for the quarter, saying that net income increased slightly, to $61.3 million, from $60.8 million in the period a year ago. Earnings per share were unchanged at 42 cents.

headline: Europes Papers Join the Cry of Read All About It, Free
abstract: Free newspapers have become fixtures of French cities in four years since Metro International moved into country, prompting publishers of paid-for dailies to consider free editions of their own in effort to retain readers; News Corp confirms plans to start free newspaper in Britain in September; Le Monde and Figaro reportedly are working on free newspapers in France; Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck plans to start free business paper as soon as next week in Germany; photo (M)

headline: Burger Lovers Say Cheese
abstract: A clever new interactive campaign by Carls Jr. and Hardees restaurants is tapping into two passions of young men hamburgers and cell phones to stimulate sales and increase customer loyalty.      Created by Spacedog, a Los Angeles-based interactive marketing agency, the campaign involves a Burger Slayer contest, designed for what Carls Jr. and Hardees parent, CKE Restaurants, calls young hungry guys, i.e., men of 18 to 35.

headline: Musical Chairs in the Executive Suites
abstract: Mark A Stein Five Days column; William Clay Ford Jr replaced himself as chief executive of Ford Motor Company with former aerospace executive Alan R Mulally; Sumner M Redstone forced out Viacom chief executive Thomas E Freston; reasserted his control over media giant months after splitting it into two parts; said Phillippe P Dauman would succeed Freston, with Thomas E Dooley becoming senior executive vice president and chief administration officer; recently criticized Freston for being indecisive; California Atty Gen Bill Lockyer said he would review methods Hewlett-Packard's board used to track down internal discussions; Chevron, Devon Energy and Statoil said they found as much as 15 billion barrels of oil in several ultra-deepwater wells in Gulf of Mexico; Labor Department Statistics showed wage pressures from January through June increased faster than first forecast; Justice Department joined with unions and creditors of Dana Corporation in opposing proposed pay system for top executives; photo (M)

headline: In Delaware, Privacy For Big Paychecks
abstract: US Bankruptcy Judge Kevin Carey agrees to seal documents detailing bonuses that will be paid to nine executives at Werner Co, ladder maker that has filed for bankruptcy reorganization; also shuts out public from hearing on pay; University of California law Prof Lynn LoPucki says Werner case may start trend in Delaware bankruptcy courts (S)

headline: U.S. Air Force Major Missing in Kyrgyzstan
abstract: A United States Air Force officer stationed in Kyrgyzstan was reported missing on Wednesday after disappearing during a shopping trip on Tuesday with fellow service members in the capital, Kyrgyz and American officials said.     The officer, Maj. Jill Metzger, has been a personnel officer for several months at the Manas Air Base, which supports military operations in Afghanistan, and was in the final days of her tour of duty.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: 29 Arrested And Accused Of Plotting Coup
abstract: Georgian security officers arrest 29 people, accusing them of plotting coup and planning to assassinate pro-Western government officials; arrests follow lengthy investigation into supporters of Igor Giorgadze, former national security chief (S)

headline: Guidant Settles Device Suit
abstract: Guidant Corp reportedly settles civil fraud suit brought by Beatrice O Hinojosa and Louis E Motal over its recalled heart defibrillators for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Police Cleared In London Raid
abstract: Official inquiry clears British police officers in connection with June shooting of Muhammed Abdul Kahar in counterterrorism raid on East London row house; Kahar was released without charge and Islamist groups accused police of singling out Muslims; Kahar has been rearrested in connection with child pornography images found on computer during raid (S)

headline: Energy Prices and a Hedge Fund Take a Tumble
abstract: Mark Stein Five Days column; declines in crude oil and natural gas prices were prompted by variety of factors; Amaranth Advisors reported more than $3 billion in losses and sold all of its energy contracts to raise cash and avoid liquidation by creditors; Federal Reserve voted to keep interest rates unchanged; Chrysler Group, citing slump in sales of sport utility vehicles, said it would cut production in second half of year by 16 percent; government auditors said Interior Department suppressed their attempts to recover more than $30 million from energy companies they say were cheating goverment out of royalties for oil from publicly owned waters in Gulf of Mexico; Hewlett-Packard's beleaguered chairwoman Patricia Dunn resigned from board but California attorney general decided not to press criminal charges against company, its officers or contractors as spy scandal continued; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Real Estate Concern Acquired
abstract: Grupo Martinsa agrees to buy Fadesa Inmobiliaria for about 4 billion euros ($5.1 billion); will quadruple land holdings (S)

headline: Looking to Take On Apple's iPod, Microsoft Plans Its Own Hand-Held Player
abstract: Microsoft, seeking to compete with Apple Computer's iPod, reportedly plans to have hand-held music and video player, currently under development, in stores in time for holiday season; Microsoft device would be equipped with wireless Internet capability, which would allow users to download music without being connected to PC (M)

headline: Economists Applaud Japan’s Rate Increase
abstract: Japanese economists welcome Bank of Japan's first interest rate increase in six years; target overnight rate edges up to 0.25 percent from effectively zero; global financial markets question timing of rate increase and its effects on international trade; photo (M)

headline: Economy Slowed This Spring
abstract: Commerce Department reports nation's gross domestic product grew 2.5 percent in second quarter, less than half 5.6 percent expansion in first quarter; says consumer spending on durable goods fell by 0.5 percent; residential investment also declined by 6.3 percent, shaving 0.4 percent off output growth; department also reports core price index for personal consumption expenditures surged at annual rate of 2.9 percent in second quarter, up from 2.1 percent in first quarter; Labor Department reports employment cost index--measure of labor costs--increased by 0.9 percent in quarter, up from 0.6 percent increase in first quarter; graph (M)

headline: Shrinking Photos for E-Mail
abstract: Shrinking Photos For E-Mail    Q. When I drag digital pictures into an e-mail message, they come in huge and fill up the screen, making it impossible to see the entire image at once. Can I adjust the size of photos so they fit in the message window?    A. Giant photo syndrome can occur when the resolution of the digital picture exceeds that of the computer monitor. Although the computer's graphics software can sometimes correct the situation and reduce the image's display to fit properly on the screen, this is not always the case.

headline: People
abstract: Bear Stearns has named Bruce Lisman and Steven Meyer co-heads of global equities. The firm has also appointed Wendy de Monchaux to manage a new unit, the principal strategies group.      The board of American International Group has elected Robert B. Willumstad chairman. He will succeed Frank G. Zarb, who has served as interim chairman since April 2005.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY -- Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Bernanke will address the Senate Banking Committee; the next day he will testify to the House Financial Services Committee. With Mr. Bernanke still in his rookie year, many on Wall Street can be expected to be parsing his speech for signs of what kind of player he might turn out to be. (Wednesday and Thursday.)    FANNIE AND FREDDIE -- At the New York Yacht Club, a few people with some strong opinions about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the huge government-sponsored mortgage packagers, will be on hand for a panel discussion about how the two should be regulated -- or perhaps punished. Randal K. Quarles, the Treasury under secretary for domestic finance, and James B. Lockhart III, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, both of whom have been outspoken about the management and accounting scandals at the two companies, will be offering their views. (Wednesday.)    A FLURRY OF REPORTS -- So many economic indicators, so little time. There will be updates on inflation with the Producer Price Index for June (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for June (Wednesday). Other reports: industrial production and capacity utilization for June (Monday); June housing starts (Wednesday); and Federal Reserve minutes for June and the Conference Board's leading economic indicators (Thursday).    EARNINGS DRUMBEAT -- Earnings season gets into full swing this week, starting on Monday with Citigroup. Tuesday's roster will include Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, United Technologies and Yahoo. On Wednesday: AMR, Apple Computer, Bank of America, eBay, General Dynamics, Intel, J. P. Morgan Chase, Motorola, Southwest Airlines and UnitedHealth Group. Thursday: Advanced Micro Devices, Ford Motor, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Nokia, Pfizer, SAP, Wachovia and Wyeth. And on Friday: Caterpillar and Eli Lilly.

headline: How to Avoid Honor Killing in Turkey? Honor Suicide
abstract: Turkey has tightened punishments for attacks on women and girls, so parents who feel their daughters have shamed them are trying to spare their sons from harsh punishment by pressing daughters to take their own lives instead; young women in poor, rural southeastern Turkey, where conservative Islam prevails, are still killed or try to kill themselves for offenses ranging from stealing glance at boy to being raped by either stranger or relative; photo; map (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: H.P. CHIEF AND SPY CRISIS -- Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has had to apologize for his inaction related to the spying scandal there. But he has also won the benefit of the doubt within the company and among investors because he has done so well turning the company around. [Page C1.]    SPOTLIGHT ON CNET -- Dawn Kawamoto, below, a 10-year veteran of News.com, a technology industry news site produced by CNet Networks, is the author of a story that ran in January revealing strategic changes under consideration at Hewlett-Packard. From that point forward, Patricia C. Dunn, who was the company's chairwoman until she resigned last week, embarked on an ambitious quest to learn the source of information leaked to Ms. Kawamoto. The effort has thrown a spotlight on Ms. Kawamoto and on CNet Networks, which has been described as the home page for Silicon Valley. [C4.]    COMPANIES AND SURVEILLANCE -- Hewlett-Packard is far from alone in diving into the world of private investigators and secret surveillance. Despite concerns about the legality of such actions, security experts say there are plenty of reasons that companies need to be involved in the spy game, or at least bolster their intelligence-gathering apparatus. [C1.]    NOT SO FUNNY IN HOLLYWOOD -- For the last few years, a tight network of stars, agents and managers has dominated comedy in Hollywood. But that is changing as relationship are fraying and as studios crack down on the prices they are willing to pay for top performers and reduce the overall number of films they release. [C1.]    PARALLEL MEDIA VENTURES -- The founders of Digg, a Web site where users submit links to news accounts around the Internet, are working on expanding Revision3, an Internet video production firm. Revision3's most successful offering so far is a show called ''Diggnation,'' where two hosts talk about some of the most popular stories on Digg.com that week. [C1.]    COMICS ONLINE -- Platinum Studios, a relative newcomer in the comics industry, plans to begin publishing its books online before they go to press for traditional distribution through stores and newsstands. [C8.]    DONATION DRIVE -- Recognizing that procrastination is an enemy of good intentions, a new public service effort, to be announced today, aims to persuade Americans to actually act upon their altruistic impulses. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]    NEW MTV CHANNEL -- Today, MTV is introducing MTV Tr3s as a replacement for the all-Spanish language ''MTV en Español,'' a 15-year-old video jukebox. The new channel will not shun Spanish, but it will mostly reflect a fusion of American and Latin music, cultures and languages, MTV executives said. [E1.]    HEADBUTT, BY NIKE -- When Zinédine Zidane, the French soccer star, leveled an Italian defender, Marco Materazzi, with a blow to the chest during the World Cup final in July, the incident nearly overshadowed Italy's victory over France. Now, in celebrating their soccer superiority, some Italians, and their sponsor, Nike, are taking a few jabs at the French in a new advertising campaign. [C7.]    FAIR-TRADE CLOTHING VENTURE -- An online store called Fair Indigo will rely mostly on the Web and catalogs to sell what executives say is the first mainstream clothing line made in accordance with fair-trade practices. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C4.]    INTERNET ANTECEDENTS -- As Fred Turner points out in his new book, ''From Counterculture to Cyberculture: Stewart Brand, the Whole Earth Network, and the Rise of Digital Utopianism,'' the romantic, utopian culture of the 1960's, with its deep suspicions about modernity and machinery, is closely linked to the recent Internet revolution. Edward Rothstein: Connections. [E3.]

headline: Phone Card Issuers Must Pay Access Fees
abstract: Federal Communications Commission rules that issuers of prepaid calling cards must pay connection fees and help subsidize phone service in rural areas; AT&T Inc will have to repay $553 million in access fees and Universal Service Fund payments that predecessor AT&T Corp withheld on phone calling cards (S)

headline: HCA Buyout Highlights Era of Going Private
abstract: In April, investment bankers from Merrill Lynch paid one of their regular visits to HCA, the hospital company. Instead of the usual pitch to sell HCA some more hospitals, the bankers had a more audacious proposal: Assemble a group of private investors to acquire the company for more than $30 billion.     Yesterday, HCA agreed to do just that, to sell itself to three private-equity firms and the family of Senator Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader, whose father, the late Dr. Thomas Frist Sr., and his brother, Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr., founded HCA.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Top Of The Scofflaw List
abstract: London Mayor Ken Livingstone says US Embassy owes $1.6 million in unpaid traffic-congestion charges and fines, making it worst offender in city (S)

headline: Preferring the End of a Leash to Being Chained to a Desk
abstract: Pet stores, grooming shops, boarding kennels and dog bakeries are some of the more common pet-related franchises that have sprouted in the last five years. But perhaps the most unusual is Pet Butler, a service that collects dog waste and disposes of it properly for a fee.     The company, based in Dallas, began selling franchises last year, and has 17 nationwide. Matt Boswell, the founder, said there was no shortage of office workers willing to trade briefcases for pooper scoopers. Each month he receives more than 200 applications from people willing to pay the $24,900 franchise fee. New franchise partners can expect to pay a total of about $60,000 in start-up costs.

headline: Atmel’s Mess: You’re Fired. No, You Are.
abstract: ''YOU can't fire me. I'm firing you.''     Many terminated employees may have dreamed of saying that. But of course, such a thing cannot happen.

headline: Russia Returns $15 Million in Phones to Motorola
abstract: Russian authorities return to Motorola 117,519 mobile phones that were seized at Moscow airport in March in case that has become symbol of Russia's capricious and, many believe, corrupt bureaucracy; 49,991 other phones seized the same day were publicly destroyed by Interior Ministry a month later on ground that they violated health standards (M)

headline: Sweden’s Governing Party Voted Out After 12 Years
abstract: Right-of-center coalition led by Fredrik Reinfeldt defeats Sweden's center-left coalition government led by Prime Min Goran Persson, whose Social Democratic Party receives just 35.2 percent of vote, its worst showing since universal suffrage began in Sweden in 1921; Persson says he will step down as party leader in March; Reinfeldt photo (M)

headline: More Financing Is Urged to Fight TB in Africa
abstract: Advocacy group Results International says World Bank is spending far less on proven ways to combat tuberculosis in Africa, where almost 600,000 people die of disease each year, than in India, China and Russia (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Pensions For Foreign Veterans Raised
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac orders significant increase in pensions of veterans who fought for France as foreigners in World War II; decision comes after Chirac views film Indigenes, which describes discrimination against troops from France's African colonies during war (S)

headline: Home Prices Fall in Nearly One-Fourth of Metropolitan Regions
abstract: Government reports that prices of traditional single-family homes fell in 87 or nation's 379 major metropolitan areas from first quarter to second; nationally, prices increased 1.2 percent in quarter (M)

headline: Election Ruling in Mexico Goes to Conservative
abstract: Felipe Calderón, a conservative from President Vicente Fox's party, was declared Mexico's next president on Tuesday by the nation's highest electoral court, officially ending a bitterly contested election that has polarized the country.     Though the decision settled legal challenges to the most contentious election in Mexican history, it did not put an end to the political crisis that has gripped the country since voters went to the polls here on July 2. Mr. Calderón's first challenge as president will be to defuse the anger of leftists who believe the election was fraudulent.

headline: Fleeing Lebanon For a Crowded Island
abstract: Hundreds of Americans fleeing Lebanon arrive in Larnaca, Cyprus, aboard amphibious assault ship Nashville; ship is one of dozens US and other countries have been using to ferry their citizens from conflict; about 3,000 Americans have arrived in Cyprus from Lebanon in last three days (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Advertising Club of New York added three members to its board. They are: Laura Desmond, chief executive at MediaVest USA, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Publicis Groupe; Beth-Ann Eason, vice president for category management at Yahoo; and John Partilla, president at the Time Warner Global Marketing unit of Time Warner.      Hugh Allspaugh joined the Chicago office of RMG Connect, part of the JWT division of the WPP Group, as senior partner and managing director. He succeeds Doug Rozen, who left to join Carlson Marketing, Minneapolis, as vice president for interactive marketing. Mr. Allspaugh had been president of his own marketing consulting company, Marketing Independence, Chicago.

headline: British Soldier Killed by Afghan Insurgents
abstract: A British soldier was killed Sunday during an operation in Helmand Province, bringing to nine the number of NATO soldiers killed in the week since they formally replaced American forces in southern Afghanistan.      The soldier for the International Security Assistance Force, or ISAF, as the NATO force in Afghanistan is called, was killed by a gunfire at the end of an operation in Musa Qala, a mountainous region known for its poppy growing and Taliban sympathies, NATO said. ''The incident occurred when ISAF troops came under small-arms fire, following a successful mission,'' a NATO news release said. ''The operation aims to reduce insurgent presence and to ensure ISAF freedom of maneuver.''

headline: Is It Deal Time Again in the Oil Patch?
abstract: Article offers assessments from analysts and investors on whether Anadarko Petroleum's planned acquisition of Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources signals that other drillers are undervalued and that more deals are in offing; photo; graph (M)

headline: 2 Big New York Deals for Boston Developer
abstract: Boston-based Beacon Capital Partners agrees to buy 1211 Avenue of Americas, between 47th and 48th Street, for more than $1.5 billion from Jamestown, German investment fund; also purchases Westchester One, office building in White Plains, NY, for $181.5 million; building is owned and managed by Bianco & Pepe; photo (M)

headline: Pakistani Official Says a Qaeda Leader Was Plot's Mastermind
abstract: Senior Pakistani intelligence officer says unidentified high-ranking leader of Al Qaeda based in Afghanistan was mastermind of plot in Britain to blow up American airliners; says officials arrested six or seven people linked to plot along with Rashid Rauf, British citizen born in Pakistan who has been described as one of its leaders; says arrest of Rauf was key to foiling plot and that he was link between Al Qaeda and suspects arrested in Britain (M)

headline: A Career Seasoned With Cigar Smoke and Revolution
abstract: José Orlando Padrón, who believes that cigar smoke brings him luck, has puffed his way through some challenging situations over the years.     As a young man he smoked his way from Cuba, where his family grew tobacco in the prime Pinar del Río region, to a life in exile in Miami. Most of the land where his grandfather began growing tobacco in the late 1800's, and where his father continued the tradition, was nationalized by Fidel Castro's government shortly after the revolution that brought it to power in 1959.

headline: Republicans Criticize Lack Of Briefings On Bank Data
abstract: The Republican chairwoman of a House subcommittee said Tuesday that the Bush administration had failed to inform Congress adequately that it was sifting through a vast international banking network in an effort to track terrorists' finances.      The lawmaker, Representative Sue Kelly of New York, chairwoman of the House Financial Services subcommittee on oversight, was joined by members of both parties in accusing the administration of being too secretive and unaccountable to Congress about the program. Its existence was disclosed last month by The New York Times and other newspapers.

headline: Real Money Rides on Bet on Basics of Investing
abstract: Market Place column; debate intensifies about ways investors can efficiently buy large baskets of stocks that mirror significant market segments like Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and Nasdaq composite index; investors agree practice, known as indexing, works but disagree on methods (M)

headline: Guggenheim Foundation and Abu Dhabi Plan Museum There
abstract: The government of Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, announced yesterday that it had signed a memorandum of understanding with the Guggenheim Foundation to build a 300,000-square-foot museum in Abu Dhabi to be designed by Frank Gehry.      The museum, to be called the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, would house Modern and contemporary art and serve as the linchpin of a sprawling development in a new cultural district of Saadiyat (Arabic for ''isle of happiness''), a 10-square-mile natural island just off Abu Dhabi.

headline: A Different Strategy on Pensions
abstract: The winter of 2002 was a scary time for pension funds and the millions of Americans whose retirement they have promised to secure.     Investment losses had wiped away billions of dollars. Required contributions were ballooning. Some companies even started talking about going into bankruptcy, in part because they could no longer afford their pension obligations. Congress and the Bush administration began planning to tighten the law.

headline: In Shiite Areas of Baghdad, 9 Found Dead
abstract: Nine bodies, all with gunshots to the head and torture marks, were recovered in five predominantly Shiite neighborhoods here on Saturday, an official at the Interior Ministry said.      Five of the bodies were found in the eastern Baghdad neighborhood of Baladiyat, which used to have a mixed population of Shiite and Sunni Arabs but has witnessed a steady exodus of Sunnis in the past several months.

headline: A Sluggish 2nd Quarter for Newspaper Industry
abstract: Julie Bosman Advertising column on discouraging second-quarter earnings results for several newspaper industry companies; Tribune Co says second-quarter net earnings slid 62 percent, to $85.7 million, from $231.3 million year ago; reports revenue slid 1.4 percent, to $1.43 billion, from $1.45 billion; McClatchy says earnings slipped to $44.1 million from $44.2 million; Media General says earnings declined 47 percent; New York Times Co says it expects second-quarter diluted earnings to be in range of 41 to 43 cents a share (M)

headline: A Third Capitol Insider Paper to Join the Crowd
abstract: Capitol Leader will be third Washington newspaper to chronicle news on Capitol Hill; will join Roll Call and The Hill when it publishes its first paper on November 21 (M)

headline: How Many Rays Today?
abstract: Oregon Scientific introduces Personal UV Monitor, which keeps track of current UV levels as well as temperature and calculates recommended sun exposure based on skin type and sun protection factor of sunscreen lotion used; photo (S)

headline: Palestinian Cabinet Makes Room For Planned Unity Government
abstract: Members of Hamas-dominated Palestinian cabinet, unable to govern, submit their resignation in Jerusalem to allow for creation of national unity government; it is not clear whether Western countries will restore assistance that was halted when militant Islamic movement Hamas came to power; new unity government is expected to include members of Fatah (S)

headline: Yearning to Put Papers Back in Local Hands
abstract: If the real estate billionaire Eli Broad had his way, The Los Angeles Times would run more photographs of donors at charity events. There would be fewer stories on movies and more about the city's museums and classical arts. And it would champion civic projects, becoming, in his view, the glue to unite a diverse and fractured city.     Newspapers are the soul of a community and they should be locally owned, Mr. Broad said one recent afternoon on the 12th floor of an office tower here overlooking acres of million-dollar homes. And that is why he would like to see The Los Angeles Times, now owned by the Chicago-based Tribune Company, acquired by a group of local organizations, including his own $2 billion foundation.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Recycling Concern Acquired
abstract: Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas SA, Spanish construction company, agrees to buy Waste Recycling Group for 1.4 billion pounds ($2.57 billion) (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Woman Sentenced To Hang In Hotel Attacks
abstract: Jordanian court sentences Sajida Mubarak al-Rishawi, Iraqi woman who confessed to role in 2005 bombings of three hotels in Amman, Jordan, to death by hanging (S)

headline: How 3 Managers Turned Back a Tide
abstract: Federated Market Opportunity fund manager Steven Lehman, CGM Focus fund manager G Kenneth Heebner and Weitz Value fund and Weitz Partners Value fund manager Wally Weitz describe how they managed to make money in second quarter, when other stock mutual funds were declining; graph; photos (M)

headline: New Frank Lowe Agency Lands Second Big Client
abstract: Round-up of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Annan Hopeful on Easing Israeli Blockade of Lebanon
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan said Tuesday that he had put in motion a plan that could lead to a lifting of the Israeli blockade of Lebanon within 48 hours.     In an interview on his flight here from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, Mr. Annan said he was taking action because regional leaders had told him the embargo was the single biggest impediment to beginning the restoration of Lebanon.

headline: Getting Online on the Go
abstract: Getting Online On the Go    Q. Is there a way to get online by connecting a cellphone to a laptop computer?    A. Many mobile phones can serve double duty as laptop modems these days. This can come in handy when you're nowhere near a wireless hotspot, an Ethernet network or even a telephone landline. If both the phone and the laptop can support Bluetooth connections, you can even link them wirelessly.

headline: Somalia: Move to Oust Prime Minister
abstract: More than a dozen politicians in the transitional government resigned to protest, among other issues, the reported presence of Ethiopian troops in the country. The resignations included cabinet members who called for the transitional government's prime minister, Ali Mohamed Gedi, to step down. Many were outraged by recent reports that several hundred soldiers from neighboring Ethiopia, a country with a deeply rooted Christian identity, had poured across the border to defend the transitional government from Islamic rivals. Ethiopia has denied any incursions.   JEFFREY GETTLEMAN (NYT)

headline: BMW’s Custom-Made University
abstract: When Clemson University received $10 million from the German automaker BMW in 2002, the money helped jump-start a $1.5 billion automotive research and educational center. It also led to a partnership that both the automaker and the university acknowledge has grown extraordinarily close.     In return for the largest cash donation ever received by the school, Clemson gave the company some unusual privileges, including a hand in developing a course of study. Clemson's president drives a silver BMW X5 sport utility vehicle, compliments of BMW, whose only North American plant is 50 miles away.

headline: Even for Shoe Bombers, Education and Success Are Linked
abstract: THE fifth anniversary of 9/11 passed with a great deal of hand-wringing over all the people who want to kill Americans. Especially worrisome is the apparent rise of terrorists whose origins seem far from fanatical.     These terrorists are not desperately poor uneducated people from the Middle East. A surprisingly large share of them have college and even graduate degrees. Increasingly, they seem to be from Britain, like the shoe bomber Richard C. Reid and most of the suspects in the London Underground bombings and the liquid explosives plot.

headline: A Class-Action Shuffle
abstract: Indictment of two partners at Milberg Weiss Bershad & Shulman on charges they made more than $11 million in payments to plaintiffs has opened doors for competitors; Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossman is among most prominent firms and expects 'spillover' from Milberg's troubles; Milberg Weiss says it has suffered little attrition of lawyers since indictment; photo (M)

headline: Blackstone Plans to Acquire Cendant Travel Services Unit
abstract: Cendant Corp plans to sell Travelport unit, which owns Orbitz, Cheaptickets and other travel services, to Blackstone Group for $4.3 billion in cash (M)

headline: Senate Limits Financial Sales to Military
abstract: Senate unanimously passes bill that would tighten rules governing marketing of life insurance and high-cost 'contractual plan' mutual funds to American military personnel on military bases; Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, lead sponsor of bill, says stopping abuses will allow people in uniform to 'focus on the hard job' that they do; photo (M)

headline: Putin Favorite Re-emerging in Ukraine
abstract: Viktor F. Yanukovich, the Russia-backed Ukrainian politician vanquished by the Orange Revolution of 2004, was poised Tuesday to make a spectacular comeback as prime minister after the pro-West president, Viktor A. Yushchenko, said his party would not join a broad governing coalition.      With Mr. Yushchenko saying he would take his Our Ukraine party into the parliamentary opposition, Ukraine appeared on course to be led by Mr. Yanukovich. At the same time, a political rival, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, accused Mr. Yanukovich of staging a coup.

headline: Alltel to End Local Service as a Spinoff Is Completed
abstract: Despite all the talk about the convergence of wireless and wired communications services, a growing number of companies are getting out of the traditional phone business.     Alltel plans to announce today that it has joined that list by completing the spinoff of its local phone unit, which has 2.9 million lines and serves mostly rural customers, and merging it with Valor Communications, a smaller business that is publicly traded.

headline: Israel Rejects Lebanon Offer
abstract: Lebanon offered to deploy 15,000 of its troops in the southern part of the country if Israel entirely withdrew its forces. The overture was dismissed by the Israelis. Page A8.

headline: Rice on the Defensive After Rome Summit
abstract: For the past year, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has worked assiduously to resurrect the importance of traditional diplomacy and building consensus among world leaders after America's go-it-alone approach to Iraq.      She has managed to hold together a fragile coalition of countries seeking to curb Iran's nuclear program by offering to end America's three-decade-long refusal to talk to Tehran if it suspends its uranium-enrichment program. And she has a similar coalition holding together on North Korea's nuclear efforts.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: SHOWDOWN OVER STEM CELLS -- The United States Senate defied a veto threat by President Bush and approved legislation that would expand federal support of medical research using embryonic stem cells. White House officials said Mr. Bush planned to veto the measure, ignoring substantial support from Senate Republicans. [Page A1.]    INCHING FORWARD ON RESEARCH -- A bill approved by the Senate to bolster stem cell research is expected to help ease restrictions that have burdened laboratories with red tape, reduced American competitiveness and discouraged young researchers from entering the field. But the legislation by itself would not immediately provide an overall increase in money for the research. [A18.]    YAHOO IN A SLIDE -- Shares of Yahoo fell to their lowest level in nearly two years in after-hours trading as it reported weak revenue from Internet search advertising in the second quarter and a delay in a project meant to match the technology of Google, its chief rival. [C1.]    FRONT-PAGE NEWS, AND ADS -- The Wall Street Journal confirmed long-standing speculation that it would open its front page to advertisers, probably in September, a move that could bring in tens of millions of dollars a year in ad revenue. The ad, informally called a ''jewel box'' and to appear in the bottom right corner, will showcase some of the paper's most valued advertisers. [C1.]    A FOX MORNING TALK SHOW -- Beginning in January, the 35 stations in the Fox group will broadcast a live morning show, to be seen at 9 a.m. in most cities. The show, with Juliet Huddy, left, and Mike Jerrick, currently the hosts of ''DaySide'' on Fox News, will generally forgo hard news for segments on entertainment and lifestyle. [E1.]    BOOM IN PRIVATE PRISONS -- As the country gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons. By late next year, the administration expects that about 27,500 immigrants will be in detention each night. At an average cost of $95 a night, that adds up to nearly $1 billion a year. [C1.]    DISNEY TIGHTENS ITS BELT -- The Walt Disney Company said it would eliminate 650 jobs, change some of its top managers and trim the number of movies it releases to 12 to 13 a year, from about 18. [C1.]    STRONG QUARTER FOR MERRILL -- Quarterly profit at Merrill Lynch climbed 42 percent, aided by a strong performance in stock trading despite a downturn in the markets. Merrill Lynch said it had a profit of $1.58 billion, compared with $1.14 billion in the second quarter of 2005. Revenue increased 29 percent, to $8.2 billion. [C4.]    BATTLE OF THE MICROPROCESSORS -- Advanced Micro Devices, with Phil Hester as its technology officer, has regained some of the market share it had lost to Intel, but the battle for supremacy in producing ever-faster microprocessors has only intensified. Intel has been fighting back with discounts and new designs. [C7.]    THE STAKES GET BIGGER -- The online gambling industry was thrown into turmoil after the federal government arrested a top executive from a London betting company, leaving his competitors wondering whether they could be next. Stock prices of the industry's biggest names, including PartyGaming and SportingBet, plummeted on fears that companies could face charges of criminal racketeering. [C5.]    COMPLETING AN ERRATIC COURSE -- The V-22 Osprey, a helicopter-airplane hybrid made specifically for the United States Marine Corps, made its public debut at an air show in England. At a cost 0f $70 million each, its makers, Bell Helicopter and Boeing, hope it can overcome a troubled 20-year history. [C4.]    AN UNEXPECTED WHOLESALE RISE -- Higher costs of food and energy pushed up wholesale prices in June to an unexpectedly high level, leaving economists to debate whether prices might be rising too quickly. The Labor Department said that the Producer Price Index rose 0.5 percent in June, after a 0.2 percent increase in May. [C6.]    ONLINE    ON A WING AND A PRAYER -- Joe Sharkey, business travel writer for The Times, says airport chapels are good places to find peace and solitude in busy airports. His report is at nytimes.com/business.    AN EXTREME MAKEOVER -- The new wealth in Russia, spurred by oil and gas production, has created a rush for European and American interior designers, homegrown and imported. A report is at nytimes.com/style.    MAP FOR THE ROAD -- Digital mapping companies are rushing to keep up with road construction projects and new subdivisions popping up in what were cornfields only yesterday. A report is at nytimes.com/automobiles.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    THE CHARLES SCHWAB CORPORATION, the biggest United States discount broker, said that second-quarter profit rose 35 percent after price cuts lured new clients. At the TD Ameritrade Holding Corporation, third-quarter net income increased 67 percent. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    WELLS FARGO & COMPANY said that second-quarter profit rose 9 percent to a record on gains in several consumer and business units and more than a tripling in mortgage revenue. (REUTERS)    THE CSX CORPORATION, the rail operation, said that second-quarter earnings more than doubled over the year-earlier quarter on insurance gains and tax benefits. (AP)

headline: Passengers Adjust to New Minimalism in Carry-On Items
abstract: Some airport security lines are long on Aug 11, as workers screen and examine carry-on luggage for liquids and other newly prohibited items; most airports report generally smoother, faster operations than on previous day, when global air travel system was thrown into turmoil by news of foiled plot to bring down airliners flying from Britain to US using explosive liquids; photo (M)

headline: The Rapidly Changing Signs at the Gas Station Show Markets at Work
abstract: Rite Aid agrees to acquire Brooks Pharmacy and Eckerd Pharmacy drug chains for $2.55 billion from Jean Coutu Group; deal continues increasing consolidation of drugstore chain market; photo (M)

headline: Next Season’s Hit Shows? They’re the Talk of the Web
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on report to be released by Consumer Experience Practice, part of Interpublic Group, that will summarize consumer sentiment online about more than two dozen new series for 2006-2007 television season; Consumer Experience president Stacey Lynn Koerner comments on top- and bottom-ranked shows; photo (M)

headline: Rebels Say They Will Retreat From East in Sri Lanka
abstract: Tamil rebels say they have ended their offensive against government forces in eastern Sri Lanka and are retreating to their original positions; there has been no resolution of dispute over irrigation canal that triggered recent clashes that have left scores dead, including civilians (M)

headline: U.S. Won’t Abandon Fight in Anbar, Commander Says
abstract: Lt Gen Peter W Chiarelli says US military in Iraq will not abandon fight against insurgents in Sunni-dominated Anbar Province despite shift of troops toward Baghdad for major operation to stifle sectarian violence in capital (M)

headline: Maturity Is in Demand
abstract: What's Offline column; HR magazine reports companies are searching for more experienced managers who have solid track record and will be able to mentor and develop next generation of leaders; 43 percent of companies have 'no clear process' for succession planning; Business 2.0 reports baby boomers are pursuing dream businesses rather than settling into retirement; AARP says 80 percent of boomers want to work in retirement to build businesses that play to strengths developed during their careers; motivational speaker Zig Zigler says, in interview with Success magazine, that success in business relies on 'passion, peak performance and purpose'; Prevention magazine cites 'better appearance in workplace' as top reason men give for getting cosmetic surgery; photo (M)

headline: Church Excommunicates Zambian Archbishop Who Married
abstract: The singular clerical career of Archbishop Emmanuel Milingo of Zambia -- faith healer and exorcist, who returned to the church after marrying an acupuncturist in 2001 in a group wedding presided over by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon -- appears to be over.      On Tuesday, the Vatican announced that it had excommunicated Archbishop Milingo, 76, for an offense that the Catholic Church, short of priests and under some pressure to loosen celibacy rules, takes seriously: two days earlier, he installed four married men as bishops in Washington, in a breakaway Catholic sect.

headline: Revision Lifts Pace of Growth
abstract: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.     While the revisions were largely in line with expectations, economists said the report was a welcome sign at a time of significant uncertainty about the economy's direction.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Lawmakers Back Federal Overhaul
abstract: Parliament's lower house approves overhaul of Germany's complex federal system (S)

headline: If a Magazines List Doubles in Size, Is That Inflation?
abstract: Magazines used to be satisfied with making lists of 50. People had its top-selling 50 Most Beautiful People issue. Vanity Fair picked 50 power players for its annual New Establishment, a list of people who were rarely new and usually were well established.      Now the paltry list of 50 has given way to 100, the number atop this year's People's Most Beautiful People, Vanity Fair's New Establishment, the annual Time 100, the Maxim Hot 100 and the new Esquire 100. This week's issue of The Los Angeles Times magazine featured its first ''West 100,'' a list of the 100 most powerful people in Southern California.

headline: Musharraf Pledges to Pursue Qaeda and Taliban Insurgents
abstract: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, in a conciliatory speech to Afghan officials and members of Parliament, conceded Thursday that Al Qaeda and Taliban insurgents had been crossing the border into Afghanistan to mount attacks but denied that he or his government were backing them.     In a major policy shift that may cost him support at home, General Musharraf pledged to seek out and destroy the command structure of insurgents apparently linked to Afghanistan's ousted Taliban rulers, who are fighting NATO and Afghan forces in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Options Brought Riches and Now Big Trouble
